XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Alleged Misleading of the House by a Minister
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (9.32 am): Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a matter of privilege. On Thursday, 25 February I answered a question without notice regarding consumer protection. In responding to the question, I drew members’ attention to two congratulatory letter requests that had recently been received by the Department of Premier and Cabinet from constituents via the electorate offices of the member for Kawana and the member for Mudgeeraba. I stated in my response that officers from the Department of Premier and Cabinet had contacted the constituents concerned to check the information provided in the forms.

In a matter of privilege later that day the member for Kawana informed the House that he had spoken to his constituent who advised that the notation on the form, which I referred to, was at his request. As a result of further investigation into the matter by the Department of Premier and Cabinet, I have since been advised that the information provided to me concerning this matter was not correct.

Whilst the constituent of the member for Mudgeeraba had been contacted to clarify the instructions, due to a misunderstanding in the department the constituent of the member for Kawana had not. I am now taking the opportunity to correct the record and apologise for any harm caused in particular to the constituents. To the extent that I suggested that other opposition offices may be involved in amending applications for congratulatory letters, I unreservedly apologise.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.34 am), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. That this House desires to place on record its appreciation of the services rendered to this state by the late Huan Donald John Fraser, a former member of the parliament of Queensland and minister of the Crown.

2. That Mr Speaker be requested to convey to the family of the deceased gentleman the above resolution, together with an expression of the sympathy and sorrow of the members of the parliament of Queensland, in the loss they have sustained.
XML.Hansard-Body: Huan Donald John Fraser was born in Charleville on 16 February 1940 and was educated at Nudgee College. After leaving school, Mr Fraser became a grazier and was later to work as an investment consultant in the banking and finance sector. In 1979, Mr Fraser was elected as a councillor on the Paroo Shire Council, a council on which he was to continue to serve until 1984. Following a move to Brisbane, Mr Fraser was elected as an alderman on the Logan City Council in 1985. Mr Fraser served on the Logan City Council from 1985 to 1988 and held the position of deputy mayor during this time.

In 1986 a redistribution of electoral districts in the Queensland Legislative Assembly established the new seat of Springwood, which covered parts of the Logan city local government area. In a rather unusual circumstance, Mr Fraser was one of two National Party candidates who contested the seat at the state election on 1 November 1986. After a tight electoral contest, Mr Fraser was elected as the inaugural member for the state seat of Springwood.

In August 1989, Mr Fraser was elevated to the ministry by then Premier Mike Ahern. Mr Fraser served from 31 August 1989 to 25 September 1989 as minister for industry, small business, technology and administrative services. Following Russell Cooper’s replacement of Mike Ahern as the Premier of this state on 25 September 1989, Mr Fraser was appointed as minister for industry, small business and technology.

At the state election of 2 December 1989, Mr Fraser was defeated in the seat of Springwood by the ALP’s candidate, Molly Robson. As a man committed to community service, Mr Fraser again sought public office at the 1990 federal election in the seat of Rankin; however, he was unsuccessful at this attempt.

However, Mr Fraser remained active in the political scene. He served as treasurer of the National Party for eight years and as the inaugural treasurer of the LNP. I think that the work of those who serve as party officials is often not seen and not well understood by the public. I believe it is an important part of the democratic process and it is all too often a thankless task. While it may not have been in my political interests for Mr Fraser to have dedicated so much of his life to the conservative parties in this regard, I do take the time to recognise the importance of Huan Fraser’s work in the political party that he served. As well as his many years of service on local councils and in this parliament, Mr Fraser served the community on various government boards and as a member, president or patron of many community and sporting associations, and is well known in that regard.

A service for the late Huan Donald John Fraser was held at the Cathedral of St Stephen in Brisbane on 24 February 2010 and the burial was held at the Charleville cemetery on 27 February 2010. I place on record the government’s thanks for the many years of service that Huan Fraser gave to the institutions of our democracy at different levels of government, the contribution he made to the community that he served and for the part he played in the public life of our state. On behalf of the government, I take this opportunity to extend my sympathy and that of this House to Mr Fraser’s many friends and family.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (9.38 am): I rise to pay tribute to Huan Donald John Fraser, a former member of this House, cabinet minister, LNP treasurer and philanthropist, who died on 18 February aged 70. Huan Fraser represented the state seat of Springwood for the National Party from 1986 until 1989. In his final year in parliament, as the Premier has said, he was minister for industry, small business, technology and administrative services under Premier Mike Ahern and minister for industry, small business and technology under Premier Russell Cooper. Huan Fraser gave long and distinguished service to the people of Queensland, the Nationals and, in more recent times, the LNP.

Born in 1940 into a south western grazing family, Huan Fraser was educated at Nudgee College. After his schooling he returned to the family property Claverton Park at Wyandra. He later married Wendy Biddulph and the couple had three children. Huan Fraser was interested in community affairs and was elected to the Paroo Shire Council in 1979 and served as a councillor until 1984.

Huan Fraser started another chapter in his life when he moved his family to Daisy Hill in Brisbane, and in 1985 he was elected alderman to Logan City Council representing Division 4. Huan chaired Logan City Council’s Finance Committee and was appointed deputy mayor. It was a fast rise, reflecting his people skills and considerable financial skills. Whilst still a serving alderman, Huan won the state seat of Springwood in 1986. As mentioned, he went on to serve as a minister in two cabinets in what were tumultuous years in Queensland politics. After parliament, Huan Fraser entered the finance and banking sector. He was treasurer of the Nationals in Queensland for eight years and, upon the formation of the LNP, was appointed the inaugural treasurer of the LNP. Unfortunately, health issues caused him to hand over this position. His financial acumen helped consolidate the finances of the Nationals to form a strong financial base for the establishment of the LNP.

Huan Fraser was well liked and respected for his openness and his forthright views. He was known for his community spirit, his support for the Logan region and his philanthropy. He was a loyal member of Rotary International. Huan Fraser is survived by his three children. I know that all members of the LNP join me in passing on our deepest sympathies to his wife, Wendy, and children Gina, Jodie and Stuart, their families and to the many friends and associates of Huan Fraser.

Ms STONE (Springwood--ALP) (9.40 am): Huan Donald John Fraser was the inaugural member for Springwood, serving the electorate from 1986 to 1989. However, his political career did not start there. He became interested in local government and was a councillor in the Paroo Shire Council from 1979 to 1984. During this time, he was also a member of the South West Queensland Electricity Board from 1979 to 1984. After settling in Daisy Hill in Logan City, he was elected to represent Division 4 in Logan City Council in 1985. In those days the position of councillor was a part-time job, so he continued to be a councillor while also being elected to the seat of Springwood. He was also a member of the South Coast Fire Brigade Board from 1985 to 1986.

In the years that Logan has been a separate local government, there have been a steady stream of hardworking and dedicated people at the grassroots of the Logan community who should be acknowledged, and Huan Fraser is certainly one of those people. Elected to Logan City Council from 1985 to 1988, during that time he chaired the council’s Finance Committee and was appointed deputy mayor. He was known for his support to the Logan region, both in economic development terms and in community spirit. Huan Fraser served his party in parliament on a number of committees and served in the cabinet for the Russell Cooper and Mike Ahern governments. His portfolios included Minister for Industry, Small Business, Technology and Administrative Services. He also served as the Queensland National Party’s treasurer for eight years.

I noticed in his maiden speech that there could have been a little bit of tension between him and some of his Liberal colleagues when he was first elected. When congratulating the Chairman of Committees on his appointment, he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I was impressed by the fact that the Labor Party did not oppose your nomination. To me that shows the high esteem in which you are held by both sides of this House. Of course, I am discounting the Liberal members’ nomination, because after this 45th Parliament I believe that they will have more or less departed from the political scene in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Some might say that that is an uncanny way in which he predicted the future, but I should also note that he went on to be the inaugural treasurer of the LNP.
XML.Hansard-Body: In his maiden speech he spoke of the vision for Springwood, and that certainly does reflect what the seat is today. He spoke of the many state primary and high schools that are still part of the electorate and which are continuing to provide quality education for the children of the Springwood electorate. He spoke of the development of John Paul College to become one of the largest independent co-educational schools in the state. With an enrolment of over 2,600 students today, it certainly is one of the largest in our state. His maiden speech also reminds us of the huge transformation we have seen with major growth in Logan City and states that this major growth has naturally put a financial burden on council and state governments. Today we still have major growth in Logan City because, as he said, ‘Logan is the gateway to South-East Queensland’.

While in his address-in-reply he was thankful for the new, modern Slacks Creek Police Station, today I am thanking the government for the relocation of the Slacks Creek police to a new temporary police station at Springwood--a new station that will be home to police while the M1 is being upgraded and a decision is made for a police station that will meet the needs of our community today. As I said, he had a flair for predicting the big issues of the future. He believed the National Party government of the day had to look at the very important area of valuations and legislate to stop massive increases.

Huan Fraser was known in the electorate for working with sporting and community organisations and for supporting them as they grew. When I first got elected, I met a number of people in the community who spoke of his tireless work ethic. He was certainly well respected, and I would ask Logan City Council to acknowledge this by considering naming some new infrastructure or perhaps a parkland after him.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Ms STONE: His work in Logan City Council and the parliament is an important part of the history of Logan and, in particular, Springwood. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. I, along with other members, pass on my condolences to them.

Mr JOHNSON (Gregory--LNP) (9.44 am): Today I rise to speak to the condolence motion moved by the Premier and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition. I am reminded of the old poem Send Her Down, Hughie . It has been just a couple of weeks since Huan Donald John Fraser departed this world. He was laid to rest in the Charleville Cemetery in his beloved Western Queensland. Bradley’s Gully has just flooded that cemetery and the Warrego River, which runs past his beloved Claverton Park. I hope, Hughie, that you keep on sending it down, mate, because we’re not going to turn it back.

Huan Donald John Fraser was born on 16 February 1940 in Charleville and passed away to eternal life on 18 February 2010, two days after his 70th birthday. Huan was a born and bred Western Queenslander, residing at the family property at Claverton Park at Wyandra with his family on the banks of the Warrego River--one of the most beautiful grazing properties probably in Western Queensland in what they call the ‘salad bowl’ area of the south-west. Huan was educated at Nudgee College in Brisbane and, on returning to Western Queensland in later life, Huan married Wendy Biddulph. The happy couple were blessed with three children--Gina, Jodie and Stuart.

From a young age Huan was interested in the community around him and was elected to the Paroo Shire Council based on Cunnamulla in 1979 where he served as a councillor until 1984. On leaving Western Queensland following moving his family to Brisbane in 1985, as the member for Springwood just clearly identified and illustrated, he was elected to the Logan council in 1985 where he later chaired the Finance Committee and became deputy mayor. I have spoken with the Speaker of the parliament and other members of councils from Logan and, as the honourable member for Springwood clearly illustrated, Huan was instrumental in setting the good foundations for Logan City with his input in the finance operations. As I said, he was chair of the Finance Committee and deputy mayor of that city. In 1986 Huan contested the state seat of Springwood. As the Leader of the Opposition and the Premier clearly indicated, he served in both the Ahern and Cooper cabinets.

Huan’s forte was always in the world of finance, and he directed his energies into finance after leaving state politics. His financial and business skills set a solid foundation for the finances of the National Party, and he served as state treasurer for the party for eight years and went on to become the inaugural treasurer of the LNP on its formation in 2008. As the Premier said today, many people do not get accolades for the work they do behind the scenes in political parties. I want to put it on the record that the financial situation and the status of the LNP’s business operations are certainly testament to the hard yards and dedication put in by the late Huan Fraser.

I was fortunate to be able to attend his funeral at St Stephen’s Cathedral recently along with my colleagues the member for Callide, the member for Toowoomba South and the member for Beaudesert. The Speaker was there too, as was the former member for Bundamba, the Hon. Bob Gibbs. It was a testament to him, I believe, to see many of his old school colleagues from Nudgee College along with LNP members who formed a guard of honour for Huan Fraser after the funeral. Huan was a man who had presence. He had strong ideals coupled with good Christian values. You always knew where you stood with Huan. He was a no-nonsense bloke, Huan Fraser. There was never any guessing with Huan, I might say. His word was his bond.

The greatest love of Huan’s life was his family. In many ways he was a private man, but he loved his family dearly--as we all love our families. His dedication and commitment to his family was one of the real features of Huan Fraser’s life. Huan is survived by his wife, Wendy, his daughters Gina and Jodie, and son, Stuart, and their respective families. Western Queensland, Queensland as a whole and this parliament is a better place because of the life of Huan Fraser.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.53 am): Over the past week we have seen mother nature at her most ferocious. The enormity of the rain event that we have witnessed over this week has broken all of the known records. Without a doubt it has been both a curse and a blessing: a curse for our fellow Queenslanders in towns such as Roma, Charleville, St George, Dirranbandi, Birdsville, Bollon, Surat, Thallon, Theodore, Thargomindah and for many others on properties in and around these communities, all of whom have taken the full force of the floods. Despite the associated heartbreak of seeing their homes and possessions damaged--and in many cases float away--these people and their communities have faced up to the deluge with an admirable stoicism.

At the same time the rains have been a blessing for the people of the south-east, who have seen their dams approach capacity for the first time in almost a decade. Our regional neighbours are hurting and it is critical that we do all we can to help the townships throughout the south-west through this disaster, which has quickly evolved as one of the most significant flooding events in the state’s history. There was nothing that we could have done to stop the floodwaters, but state and local governments, non-government organisations, the federal government and community volunteers have all sprung into action to help these communities through these difficult times. In the past seven days we have seen evacuation centres established in all of the towns affected by flooding. These have been put in place in most instances by the Red Cross--and I pay tribute to the Red Cross, which has acted so swiftly and so comprehensively. This time last week in Charleville, the Red Cross was setting up an evacuation centre and within hours it was feeding 500 people--no mean feat in a small community affected by one of the worst floods that they have seen.

We have seen communities work together to bring in equipment to build levies and reinforce dams. We have seen communities come together quickly to sandbag and prevent further damage. Notably, we have seen neighbours taking in whole families who have been made homeless by these floods and we have seen everybody throughout these communities come together in an extraordinary clean-up effort. Joint state and federal Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements have been activated for 58 local government areas. Under the NDRA, councils will be able to access funding to cover the cost of restoring essential public assets as well as the cost of counterdisaster operations. Without a doubt, in addition to the personal and family losses that we have seen, there will be significant damage and a very significant bill for state, federal and local governments for the damage to public infrastructure.

Additional funding arrangements will include emergency assistance payments of $170 for each individual and up to $780 for families who have been affected by the floods. This assistance will also include means tested essential household content grants of $1,660 for individuals and $4,980 for couples or families. Also, means tested repairs to dwellings and structural assistance grants are available for those people whose properties were not insured. These grants include $10,250 for individuals and $13,800 for couples or families. Last week, I also launched the Premier’s flood appeal, with a $500,000 donation from the state government. Donations can be made in person at any of the large banks. They can also be made online or by phone at the government call centre. I ask Queenslanders to dig deep. These are our country cousins. Many of them have been doing it tough for a number of years of drought and their ability to cope with these floods is significantly diminished.

In the meantime, we have convened the state government’s floods reconstruction task force. The chair of the Queensland Building Services Authority, John Gaskin, will head the task force, which includes the Building Services Authority, the Housing Industry Association, Master Builders, the Insurance Council of Australia and all of the major insurers and state government agencies. This task force will work with each affected local government. The task force is about getting everybody on the same page to ensure that the rebuilding effort in these communities can take place in the most coordinated, effective and swiftest way possible. I have already spoken about this task force in some detail with the member for Warrego. I have not had a chance to speak with other members whose areas are now being affected, but I certainly encourage them to make sure that they can get regular briefs from the task force about progress on the rebuilding and recovery effort.

As difficult as this situation is for communities throughout the south-west, there is a silver lining for our primary producers. Once we are through the clean-up and the rebuild that many communities will have to endure, an old bush truism will never have been more applicable and will prevail as these communities climb out of drought, and that is that there is more money in mud than there is in dust. I look forward to these rains bringing renewed prosperity to many of these communities that have waited a long time to see it coming.

At the same time that the bush is suffering, in the south-east corner we are faced with an extraordinary situation for a region which, just under three years ago, saw water supplies in the dams plummet to a frightening 16 per cent. For the first time in almost a decade, the combined capacity of our dams has now surged to more than 94 per cent.

This is reason to rejoice. The worst of the drought is now behind us, but it is not a time to forget the lessons of the past. The culture of responsible water usage is now entrenched in the south-east and we will not rush into a decision to alter our regime of water use. Let us not forget how quickly this situation can change, as our very recent history has taught us.

Our thoughts are with those Queenslanders who have lost homes, their treasured possessions and memories and, in some cases, their livelihoods. We are providing prompt and targeted assistance to help local communities recover from Queensland’s biggest flooding event on record. Along with the Minister for Emergency Services, a number of local mayors and local state members I have travelled out to the flood zone a number of times in the past week and have seen firsthand the devastating effects on these communities and many families. This is a sad time for many of these towns but what I also saw was a remarkable display of community strength and resilience in the face of adversity. I am sure others will join with me in congratulating those communities on the extraordinary way in which they dealt with these very difficult circumstances.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: National Service of Thanksgiving and Remembrance, AHS Centaur
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.00 am): It was with both sadness and pride that last Tuesday, 2 March, I attended the national service of thanksgiving and remembrance for the 332 victims and survivors of the sinking of the Australian hospital ship the Centaur in 1943. This national service, which was held at Brisbane’s St John’s Cathedral, was a very moving tribute and it formed a fitting memorial to the victims and survivors of this most terrible of events. The service was attended by the Governor-General of Australia, the Governor of Queensland, the Prime Minister, the chiefs of the Army, Navy and Air Force, representatives of survivors, including one survivor himself, and more than 200 family members of victims and survivors from all across Australia and New Zealand. Without doubt the most moving of all contributions made on the day was from Martin Pash, a survivor of this tragedy. Mr Pash, now in his very late eighties, spoke with great emotion of how he survived as a very young 20-year-old in those terrible, terrible moments after the torpedo hit.

After the event I had an opportunity to talk with a number of the family members. It was brought home to me just how these events reverberate across generations and how a great loss and sadness in war time can go on to have an effect for decades. On the Centaur not only were more than 200 lives lost; there were eight sets of brothers--so families lost more than one loved one--including one set of three brothers. Some 40 or more relatives of the family that lost the three brothers attended the service and many of them spoke to me in very emotional terms, even though they are grandchildren of the men who were lost, of what it meant for their grandmother and for their relatives.

It is hoped that the discovery of the final resting place of the Centaur last year and last week’s national memorial service will offer some peace to those who have been affected by the tragedy. The national memorial service was the first of two commemorations of the victims and survivors, with an at-sea memorial service to be held later this year at the Centaur ’s actual wreckage site. As honourable members are aware, a commemorative plaque was placed on the foredeck of the wreck of the Centaur on 12 January 2010. Crafted by the Centaur Association, the plaque contains the names of everyone who served on the Centaur and personal notes from family members. I take this opportunity to lay upon the table of the House a copy of the program which was circulated at last week’s national memorial service. This program contains the names of all of the men and women who were lost at sea or who survived the sinking of the Centaur . I think it is important that a copy of this program should remain on the official records and archives of the parliament forever. Lest we forget the men and women of the Australian hospital ship the Centaur.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Program of the National Service of Thanksgiving and Remembrance AHS Centaur held on Tuesday, 2 March 2010 at St John’s Cathedral, Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.03 am): Today I wish to advise the House that my government will deliver the most comprehensive reform of Queensland’s statutory valuation in the state’s history. I understand that there is a bill relating to some of these matters before the House. My comments will be suitably cautious in this regard. However, I do think it is important to inform both the House and the public that in recent days a number of discussions with the industry has seen a resolution on these matters reached and we have developed a new way forward.

Firstly, in relation to dealing with the past, valuations that have been issued by the government will be legislatively validated, thereby maintaining the status quo--that is, there will be no new taxes and there will be no refunds by state or local governments. In addition, the government will preserve appeal rights for any appeals already on foot until 1 July 2010. We will endeavour to settle these appeals as soon as practicable and have set aside $30 million in a settlement fund to do so.

In terms of dealing with valuations for the present year, 2010, we will put in place legislation that will allow for the issuing of valuations in line with the scheme originally outlined by the minister with the agreement of the Property Council. The transition system for issuing valuations will remain in place until 1 July 2011 and the minister will bring forward amendments to secure the implementation of that agreement.

In relation to the future--that is, how we will deal with these matters going forward--we will put in place a new regime for land valuation in Queensland. We commit to moving to site valuation, consistent with other jurisdictions and in line with what the property industry and local government have been seeking for some time, for the issuing of 2011 and all future valuations. In addition, we will put in place a new structure to reform State Valuation Services.

Queensland’s valuation legislation has been on a separate track to the rest of Australia since 1944 and it is time to put it back into the mainstream. I confirm today that my government will introduce legislation by September this year, which will be developed with key stakeholders such as the Property Council and the Local Government Association of Queensland. Under the proposed system the site valuation will represent the land’s current market value if it was vacant and will include the value of current site works such as land filling and pipe work. The value will exclude the value of leases, which have been so controversial in recent years in Queensland, because our valuation framework has historically been fundamentally different from other states.

Importantly, the new system will not result in significant changes to rates and property taxes. This is being done to provide greater certainty for our commercial and industrial sectors and residential property investors. It is not a revenue measure. Further, the government will appoint an independent Valuer-General to provide transparency and independence in the assessment and issuing of valuations. This position was abolished almost a decade ago, in 1992. Many other states have retained such a position and the government will re-establish an independent Valuer-General.

These reforms are about recognising the strong case for reform for the future while protecting the integrity of previously issued valuations and ensuring that people pay the tax that they are required to pay. We are preserving appeal rights to ensure fairness. Any settlements of these appeal rights must occur by 30 June this year. We are confirming the past and validating those past decisions, we are providing for valuations to be issued this year on a fair and consistent basis and we are signing up for significant reform for the future.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (10.09 am): Last week Prime Minister Kevin Rudd outlined a bold vision for the reform of Australia’s health and hospitals. The Queensland government has committed to working with the federal government to ensure any national reform delivers the best outcome for Queensland patients. This is not a turf war. I am not interested in a debate about who runs what or who funds what, if that does not deliver for Queenslanders. The Rudd government has committed to a 100 per cent takeover of outpatient services. This is a win for Queenslanders. Currently, Queensland provides more outpatient services than any other state. In 1997 the Howard government locked Queensland into providing $240 million worth of those services in our hospitals, while denying us the right to recover our costs from the MBS as every other state does. We know outpatient and specialist appointment lists are growing and we welcome the Rudd government’s acknowledgement that for too long Queensland has been short changed.

The federal government’s intergenerational report indicates that the proportion of our population over 80 will quadruple in the next 35 years and the proportion aged over 65 will double. More sobering is the fact the proportion of the population supporting that demographic will halve. Australia has the second longest life expectancy in the world. The upshot is that the longer we live the more chronic disease rises and the more demand is placed on our health system. For example, it used to be that most males died from stroke or heart attack before they were ever diagnosed with or, indeed, succumbed to prostate cancer. As technology progresses and stroke and cardiac arrest are no longer a death sentence, men are living longer and are more likely to be diagnosed with prostate cancer. We can treat that too if it is caught early enough. What is more, chronic disease such as heart disease, diabetes and the like can now be managed, depending on the severity of the disease. However, this means more hospital admissions, more outpatients appointments, and more people turning up to our emergency departments.

Under the Howard government, the federal share of health funding fell from 50 per cent to around 38 per cent. The states picked up the shortfall. It is simply inexcusable for Opposition Leader and former Howard health minister Tony ‘Mersey Hospital’ Abbott to justify his government’s lack of funding because the states picked up the tab.
Mr Springborg: What about Paul ‘Hospital Boards’ Lucas?
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Order!

Mr LUCAS: One thing I can guarantee is that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will not ask a question about it. It is also inexcusable for a federal government to ignore the fact that if demand continues to climb and state health funding with it, by 2045 the health minister and Premier will be the only representatives in state government. Queensland is pleased that for the first time in a long time the federal government has recognised this. The Queensland government is committed to getting the details right for Queenslanders and, therefore, committed to ironing out these details over the coming months. So far, the 60/40 funding split means no new money for four years. However, it means the Commonwealth funds 60 per cent of future growth, which is fundamental.
Mr Horan: And why is it better?

Mr LUCAS: We just heard from the hospital tax man. His suggestion was to have a hospital tax and a capital works charge. I thank him for his helpful suggestion. We will take it on notice and I thank him for it. The Kraken awoke; now he can go back to sleep. The Prime Minister has flagged future announcements, but we need to see the detail--
Mr Cripps interjected.

Mr LUCAS: Now we have the mental health volunteer man making his contribution. His contribution to the health debate is to suggest a mental health system run by volunteers. I thank the opposition very much. We have the brains trust over there. The Prime Minister has flagged future announcements, but we need to see the detail on how this translates to more doctors, nurses, allied health professionals and beds and operations. Since 2005 alone, the Bligh government has employed 12,600 extra doctors, nurses and allied health professionals and we do not want to lose that momentum. We want to see strengthened incentives for clinical staff to go west, that is, to western Queensland and other places.

Activity based funding has merit, provided it is flexible for regional hospitals and the unique decentralisation of Queensland. We want to make sure that our small hospitals--most of which operate above efficient cost due to inefficiencies of scale, utilities, wages and the like--are factored into any funding model. For example, we want to make sure the hospital in Charleville is not isolated from other hospitals. Queensland has strong state-wide networks in place such as clinical networks, state-wide surgical networks, telehealth networks and patient transfer networks, and we want to ensure those networks, which foster accountability and excellence, remain in place. As we saw with the 10B psychiatric ward in Townsville, it is when hospitals operate as silos and protectionism sets in that patient safety is compromised.

More importantly, we want to see the Commonwealth step up to its core responsibilities in dental health and aged care. The Rudd government has tried to pass a massive dental package that would deliver more than $52 million to Queensland and more than 180,000 extra dental services. However, the package has been blocked consistently in the Senate by federal Liberal and National senators. What Queensland needs is for the state LNP, the Leader of the Opposition who is a dentist and frankly should know better, and his parliamentary colleagues to stand up to their federal colleagues and unblock the vital first step in reform. It is Queenslanders and their right to free health care that this side of the House puts first. I ask: who does the other side of the House put first?

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (10.15 am): As I foreshadowed at the last sitting, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has been undertaking a review of its methodology for distributing the GST revenue amongst the states and territories. On 26 February, the federal government took receipt of the Commonwealth Grants Commission’s 2010 review. Throughout the review process, Queensland and Western Australia fought hard for a new methodology that would take into account the true cost of funding new infrastructure for states such as ours with rapidly growing populations. As we now know, we were successful in urging the independent Grants Commission to recognise those challenges, with a major policy victory putting in place the framework for a fairer distribution of GST into the future. However, as those of us familiar with the process know, generally what the Grants Commission gives with one hand it takes with the other. Other adjustments, including the equalising of mining income through royalties and changing the averaging process from five to three years, mean Queensland will roughly break even. There is potential upside from the Commonwealth’s determination of the overall pool in its budget due in May, but that matter will be determined then.

We have also seen promoted by the federal government significant changes to other aspects of the GST. I echo the Deputy Premier’s comments in supporting the federal government’s efforts to fundamentally change the way we fund health services in this country. We are unambiguously pro-reform. There is no doubt that plenty of questions need to be asked and answered, and there is plenty of detail to work through, but one thing we all know is that for too long the states have done the heavy lifting on health funding. In our government’s view, a proposal that sees the Commonwealth take up 60 per cent of the funding is one worth progressing.

Finally, last week saw the release of the national accounts data for the December quarter. Within that data, state final demand figures for Queensland showed growth of 0.5 per cent in trend terms. In comparison to many other economies around the world, a positive result is very welcome. Of course, we all acknowledge that a quarterly result of 0.5 per cent, along with an economic growth projection on annual terms of one per cent, remains below the trend growth the state has averaged of around five per cent for the last decade. Anyone who thinks the global financial crisis was merely a ripple should look no further than this indicator to understand the depth of the challenges this state and the nation still face. As we frame the 2010-11 budget, we will remain steadfast in our determination to meet these challenges. As promised, we will focus on Queensland’s priorities: the schools, the hospitals and the roads we need. By undertaking reform of the state’s balance sheet and abiding by our fiscal principles, we are committed to building stronger Queensland finances and a stronger Queensland economy.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Before calling the Minister for Public Works, I acknowledge in the public gallery the former member for Mulgrave, Mr Warren Pitt. Welcome back, Warren.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (10.18 am): And he looks a picture of good health, Mr Acting Speaker. It is good to see you, old mate.

Pursuant to what the Premier has just said, I acknowledge the efforts of John Gaskin and the BSA for the leadership they are showing in the latest disaster. It seems that, unfortunately, they have had a lot of practice in that regard in recent years.
Mr Mulherin interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the member for Mackay for his positive interjection. He is aware of the role they have played in Mackay. I also place on record my thanks for the Q-Build day labour workers who have been putting their shoulders to the wheel, as they always do in these disasters.

I am pleased to inform the House that the construction of the RSPCA’s new headquarters at Wacol is now another step closer. The long-awaited development approval from the Brisbane City Council for the former John Oxley detention centre site has now been received allowing the expansion to move forward. I acknowledge the efforts of the Leader of the House in advocating the site for that purpose. The development approval paves the way for major construction to get underway by mid-2010. This government is providing $12 million towards the expansion, as well as donating the site which is valued at around $7 million. Early site works have already taken place. The buildings have been stripped, most of the fencing has been removed and the demountable buildings have been relocated.

I am sure members of the House will agree that the RSPCA provides an invaluable service for the community every year by caring for thousands of neglected domestic and wild animals. More than 700 animals will find a home in the new headquarters when it opens, making it one of the best such facilities in Australia. Across the state, the RSPCA cares for more than 40,000 animals every year. At their new campus at Wacol they will care for between 15,000 and 20,000 animals each year. I wish it were none.

The Wacol site is almost double the size of the current overcrowded facilities at Fairfield and will be a more amenable and people-friendly facility. The extra land means that stables and a large, modern barnyard can be constructed, allowing the RSPCA to better look after livestock as well as domestic pets like cats and dogs.

The new headquarters will be an opportunity to improve the reach of RSPCA’s service to the community and is a major step forward for animal welfare in Australia. Queensland will now be seen as a benchmark for other states. The Department of Public Works is continuing to assist the RSPCA to relocate to the Wacol site and is providing ongoing support to ensure a successful project outcome.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.21 am): The Bligh government is committed to finding ways to see more Queenslanders convert to affordable clean energy solutions for their homes. That is why we launched our Solar Hot Water Program--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Order!
Mr ROBERTSON: That is why we launched our Solar Hot Water Program--to help make converting to solar hot water affordable for more Queenslanders.

As we have stated from the outset, our Solar Hot Water Program relied on the continuation of the federal government’s solar hot-water scheme. I note the member for Clayfield’s recent comments in this regard on ABC Radio. I table the documents that clearly show this, and I look forward to him correcting the record lest he leave himself open to allegations of dishonesty. I table the original media release from the Premier during last year’s election campaign.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Press release, dated 15 March 2009, from Anna Bligh headed ‘Solar program to slash power bills’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table a number of--
Mr Nicholls: What did you say?
Mr ROBERTSON: The member for Clayfield asks me what it says.
Mr Nicholls: At the launch--what did you say at the launch when you stood up?
Mr ROBERTSON: It says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘We will be able to offer the systems at cheaper than market price by using our bulk purchasing power and using the Rudd government’s solar hot-water rebate of $1,600 and renewable energy certificate of $1,200 schemes,’ Ms Bligh said.
XML.Hansard-Body: I then table copies of media releases from me as responsible minister, including the first on 15 April, where I said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To qualify for the program Queenslanders must be eligible for Federal assistance totalling around $2800 and must have an electric hot water system. A full list of criteria will be released shortly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: A number of associated press releases follow on from that.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Press releases, dated 15 April, 1 July and 8 October 2009, from the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade regarding solar hot water schemes.
XML.Hansard-Body: I also table the record of Hansard of 17 September when, in response to a question from the Leader of the Opposition, the Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is a program that was always going to be done in partnership with the federal government, because it is the conjunction between the federal government’s rebate and the bulk purchasing power of the state that will deliver these units at a cost-effective price, as we committed to.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Extracts, dated 17 September and 8 October 2009, from the Record of Proceedings regarding solar hot water schemes.
XML.Hansard-Body: I refer to the last sitting week. In answer to a question from my shadow minister, the the Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: As we have outlined in the last couple of days and as the minister advised the House this morning, this program was always, in its current form, attached to the federal rebate system.
XML.Hansard-Body: We have always been clear on this issue. I look forward to the member for Clayfield’s apology, but I will not be holding my breath.

While our goals have not changed, the federal government has drastically changed its solar hot water program, which has left us with no alternative but to close our scheme and consider new options. The decision by the federal government to reduce its solar hot-water rebate from $1,600 to $1,000 and further reduce the heat pump rebate from $1,000 to $600 means that the Queensland government would have to find well over $100 million to bridge this gap if we were to meet our target of installing 200,000 solar hot-water systems during the term of this government. As a result, it is with deep regret that we have been left with no other choice but to close our solar hot-water scheme while we continue the work to find alternatives to maintain our commitment to see more Queenslanders access affordable solar hot water.

There are approximately 700 customers who have a contract with one of the two suppliers signed on or before 19 February 2010. These contracts will be honoured in line with the old scheme guidelines. And we will continue to send receipts to customers who have had an installation completed under our program so that they can meet the federal government’s 19 March deadline. I have also written to the former minister responsible for the federal scheme, Peter Garrett, and the current minister responsible, Greg Combet, seeking an extension of the federal government’s 19 March deadline. As a result of a combination of persistent wet weather and the temporary suspension of our major contractor due to licensing issues, there has been a delayed rollout of our scheme over the past few weeks. It would be helpful if those Queenslanders who had signed a contract and were awaiting an installation date could receive special consideration by the Commonwealth.

It is unfortunate that not all of those who expressed interest in the Queensland Solar Hot Water Program will be able to be assisted at this point in time. However, we are not walking away from our commitment to support solar technology. As the Premier said in this House just last sitting week, ‘Our determination to deliver affordable solar hot water to Queensland homes is as strong as it has ever been.’ That is why the government is looking at alternative ways to support solar for Queensland households into the future. But before we can proceed down that track it is necessary to review the old scheme in the context of wider changes brought about by the federal government’s recent decisions.

In the meantime, over the next few days all Queenslanders who have expressed an interest in participating in our scheme will be contacted with further information and an invitation to transition to a new program once details have been finalised. In the meantime, customers with installation inquiries can contact the Solar Hot Water Program hotline on 132523.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.27 am): Queensland is awash with floodwaters. Many communities have or are experiencing flooding at record levels--in some places new records are being set breaching previous flood levels set 25, 50 and over 100 years ago. Major areas of impact over the past week include Roma, Charleville, St George and Dirranbandi in the south-west, and the small township of Theodore in Central Queensland.

Smaller neighbouring communities have also experienced peak flood levels. Bollon is completely surrounded and inundated by water. Thallon, Nindigully, Cunnamulla, Hungerford, Quilpie, Thargomindah, Meandarra, Moura and Baralaba are also dealing with floodwaters and inundation.

Of great significance is the impact on rural and remote properties, with houses and sheds inundated, stock losses and damage to crops and infrastructure. Many other small communities across Queensland are also impacted by floodwaters, and local and district disaster management groups and the SES are working to provide support to those communities.

Over the past week, the Premier and I have visited the communities of Roma, Charleville, St George, Bollon and Dirranbandi, and yesterday I visited Biloela and Theodore. While the focus of attention has been in the southern parts of the state, in Far North and Western Queensland many communities are still dealing with the impacts of floodwaters. They include Normanton, Karumba, Birdsville, Bedourie, Quilpie, Hungerford and many others.

Across Queensland hundreds of properties, homes and businesses have been inundated with water. Roads, bridges, railway lines and other public infrastructure have been damaged. The repair bill will rise to the hundreds of millions of dollars.

The joint state and Commonwealth Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements have been activated in 59 local government authorities, covering around 80 per cent of the state. The clean-up and recovery effort is well underway in townships such as Roma and Charleville, and over the coming weeks and months many other communities will commence the long road to recovery.

Queenslanders can be proud of the response of our emergency service workers and agencies. The commitment, professionalism and dedication of our State Emergency Service, Queensland Fire and Rescue Service, Emergency Management Queensland, Rural Fire Service volunteers, Queensland Ambulance Service, police and local council officers have shone through once again. Working in partnership with local disaster management groups and councils, they have helped communities prepare for flooding and manage the inundation and isolation.

I would also like to acknowledge the efforts of all government departments, particularly those on the front line--the Department of Communities, primary industries and QBuild for their logistics and community support--and non-government organisations such as the Red Cross, Salvation Army, Lifeline and many other local community groups which do a fantastic job in supporting communities in need. They have worked tirelessly supporting the evacuation centres in Charleville, Roma, St George and Theodore, where hundreds of residents have slept or been fed.

One of the more notable experiences of both the Premier and I--and, indeed, other members on both sides of the House who have supported their local communities--was to witness how communities across the state are helping each other: neighbour helping neighbour, and volunteers from all over the state responding and relocating to flooded communities to help those in need. On behalf of all Queenslanders, we thank those people for their spirit of generosity.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.31 am): Main Roads crews are out in force out west, inspecting flood damaged roads and assessing damage. As the Premier and the police minister said earlier, the region has been hit with the worst floods in more than a century. The road network has copped a real hammering. So far around 1,300 kilometres of the state’s road network have been damaged by floodwaters. Only when the waters recede will we know the full extent of the damage.

I am heading out to Roma today to see the damage firsthand and to talk to the mayor, the local community and Main Roads staff in the region. Together we will prioritise the repair work--fix the worst affected and most dangerous sections--to make them safer for motorists. We have road crews ready to swing into action as soon as the water recedes. They have already been out on the Gore Highway, between Millmerran and Goondiwindi, carrying out emergency repairs. In the south-west, we have around 20 road crews inspecting and assessing roads, and carrying out emergency repairs. I take my hat off to them. They are out there hard at work in difficult and trying conditions. Main Roads workers in Roma also pitched in to help the local community mop up the mess. Many of them would have been personally affected with their own homes under water, yet they have put the community’s needs ahead of their own. That is what I call real community spirit.

As well as RoadTek staff, maintenance contractors from the Maranoa regional council are also hard at work, repairing the roads where the waters have receded. Major highways most affected by the flooding are the Warrego, Mitchell, Carnarvon, Landsborough, Dawson, Leichhardt, Barwon and the Bruce. It will take a mighty effort to repair the vast road network we have in Queensland. We know how important a reliable and secure transport network is to the communities they serve, and that is why we will soon move heaven and earth to get them fixed as quickly as we can. In the meantime I urge motorists and road users in flood affected parts of the state to take the utmost care on our roads.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.33 am): Later today DEEDI officers will fly over the Charleville and St George area by helicopter to conduct an aerial survey of the flood situation facing primary producers. Yesterday they flew from Charleville to Cunnamulla to assess the damage in that area. A lot of machinery sheds have been flooded and expensive equipment destroyed. They observed small mobs--100 to 200--of stranded cattle and sheep. The positive news is that, after the excellent seasonal conditions prior to the flooding, the stock they saw appeared in good condition. They have largely been strong enough to withstand the flooding. There have been confirmed losses of mobs of up to 300. While our officers did see some dead animals, they did not see that sort of destruction yesterday. The stranded livestock will be monitored to ensure they are able to walk to open country as floodwaters recede.

Producers should be congratulated because they have been very active so far in removing at-risk stock. They have been flying people to shallow water to walk stranded sheep to safer country. We will continue to work with industry, AgForce and QFF to assist where required. Our mobile office will travel to St George as soon as it can get there to establish a state government one-stop shop. There are also one-stop shops in Charleville and Roma. However, producers not able to get to these locations can register for outreach assistance. We have two four-wheel drive vehicles that will have an experienced DEEDI officer and Communities officer travelling to outlying areas and providing the services of a one-stop shop.

Concessional loans are available for up to $250,000 at four per cent, and freight subsidies of up to $5,000 for eligible producers. Last week I established a flood control group consisting of senior DEEDI staff, AgForce, QFF, and QRAA to coordinate our flood response around issues affecting primary producers, and I will take part in another telephone hook-up today. These rains could inject more than a billion dollars into regional economies in the coming years, but in the meantime we will continue to work in cooperation with industry to assist in the recovery.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.35 am): Last Friday I opened the Mental Health Association Queensland’s new premises in Annerley. The Mental Health Association Queensland has been delivering quality early intervention mental health services to Queenslanders since 1961. Since last year the Mental Health Association became a registered trainee organisation and began providing training for the mental health workforce. To date it has provided training to more than 210 people. The Bligh government values the work of the Mental Health Association of Queensland and is pleased to contribute over $750,000 annually.

We are also pleased to be providing $6.4 million for the time-out housing initiative announced in the 2009-10 state budget. Over the next three years this initiative will benefit over 250 Queenslanders aged between 18 and 25 who are experiencing early signs and symptoms of mental health problems. Today I can inform the House that Cairns and Logan will be the first two pilot locations for this early initiative for mental health. Pilot programs will soon be up and running in both places, run by Aftercare in Cairns and the Youth and Family Service in Logan City.

I would like to thank the Treasurer for his strong support of this important initiative. It will help prevent hospital admissions and relieve pressure on acute mental health services while ensuring young Queenslanders can access clinical support, counselling and specialist public mental health services where appropriate. What we want to do is prevent these young people from ending up in our hospitals by providing them with the support they need at this early stage of diagnosis. Both services will be staffed 24 hours a day, seven days a week by two support workers. Each service will also have outreach workers to support people for up to three months after they leave the program.

This initiative tackles mental illness early on, with the aim of minimising its detrimental effects. Early intervention can help to deliver better mental health outcomes and is an important part of our vision to support one in five Queenslanders who will experience a mental health problem during their lifetime. We are getting on with the job of building stronger community mental health services, and we are continuing to invest. The Bligh government is contributing $55 million this financial year to make sure that we provide the very best community mental health support services throughout Queensland.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.38 am): Yesterday was International Women’s Day, making this an excellent time to update the House on the 1 Million Women campaign. The Queensland government is encouraging all Queensland women to sign up to this national campaign to reduce their carbon footprint. Later this month we will be announcing a major partnership involving a well-known celebrity that will see even more women take up this challenge. The 1 Million Women campaign is all about the simple lifestyle choices that women--who make the majority of decisions in a home regarding purchasing--can do to reduce our carbon emissions.
An opposition member interjected.

Ms JONES: No, it is the data. The data shows that women make the majority of those decisions. That is why we are encouraging women to make choices which are low-carbon emissions. That is also the theme of this year’s Earth Hour, which the Bligh government is once again proud to support. We are investing $25,000 to support this international event, and I urge all Queenslanders--men and women--to register their participation on the Earth Hour website before switching off their lights and appliances from 8.30 pm to 9.30 pm on Saturday, 27 March.

There will be a number of reminders in the run-up to Earth Hour, including a series of advertisements in the media. On Friday, I will join with celebrity chef Ben O’Donoghue who will be cooking up a sustainable brunch to launch this year’s events. Organisers, the World Wildlife Fund, are asking each of us this year to not only switch off our lights for this hour but to make a personal commitment to reduce our carbon footprint.

There are a number of government programs to help Queenslanders do just this. For example, by signing up for the ClimateSmart Home Service people can not only reduce their footprint but also save themselves up to $325 on their power and water bills every year. When shopping for more cost and ecoefficient appliances people can go to a ClimateSmart retail store. These are just some of the examples of how the Bligh government is implementing its policy to encourage all Queenslanders to reduce their carbon footprint in their homes.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Urban Land Development Authority, Development Guidelines
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.40 am): A new approach to suburban development that could be the future of Queensland housing has been released by the Urban Land Development Authority. The Urban Land Development Authority recently released Residential 30: guidelines to deliver diversity in new neighbourhood development and the first suite of practice notes to provide simple guidance on how residential developments can diversify to meet the changing needs of Queensland communities. These guidelines and notes respond to the need for more affordable housing and the need to promote excellence in sustainable planning and design in the face of climate change and growth.

It is no secret that Queensland is feeling the pressure of population growth. The state is growing by around 115,000 people each and every year--that is a city the size of Darwin. At the same time, the average size of households is getting smaller so there is a real need for a greater diversity of housing. These Urban Land Development Authority guidelines and notes provide not just planning guidelines but examples of design elements related to neighbourhoods, streets, buildings, blocks, lots and parks as well as case studies for achieving innovation and diversity in a range of different densities.

The practice notes cover a wide variety of topics, incorporating practical tips on successful small lot development, improving commercial return from higher smaller lots, engineering techniques for higher density development, affordable sustainability innovations and tree retention within suburban projects. Both documents can be found at www.ulda.qld.gov.au. I encourage practitioners, both in industry and from councils across the state, to access these important resources.

The Urban Land Development Authority is already demonstrating this diversity in the affordable Fitzgibbon Chase development in Brisbane’s north. It is also working with a number of community organisations to manage a range of innovative social programs in conjunction with this project. One of these is the Fitzgibbon Industry Relevant Schools Training, FIRST, program, developed by the Urban Land Development Authority to provide students with on-the-job training at the Fitzgibbon Chase development as part of their school curriculum. This valuable program increases student awareness of potential future career paths in the building trade and provides skills which can be used in a range of industries across Queensland.

The Bligh government is proud to be associated with projects like FIRST because they provide skills and ongoing opportunities for local students as well as Queensland industry. While I am speaking about that project, I want to thank the member for Sandgate for her commitment to ongoing support for opportunities in her area--opportunities for local students and opportunities for Queenslanders seeking an affordable home.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport)
(10.43 am): The Premier’s Bike Week Challenge, an online competition running in conjunction with Bike Week, started last Monday as part of Bike Week 2010 celebrations. The challenges sees the Bligh government awarding 89 new bikes to the value of $300 each to primary school children in grades 5 to 7 across Queensland through an online competition. That means one bike for each state electorate, ensuring the bicycle safety message is communicated across the entire state. The challenge runs until 19 March--that is, for two more weeks--and can be accessed via the TravelSmart website. I encourage all children in grades 5 to 7 across Queensland to enter.

The challenge will raise awareness of cycling and bike safety, while encouraging children to ride a bike. Obviously, Queensland children are already interested in active transport from the large response we are seeing. The Premier and I have written to all principals across Queensland and encouraged them to get involved with this initiative. I also invite all members of this House to encourage students in their electorates to enter.

The Queensland government is proud to be the principal sponsor of Bike Week, an annual event coordinated by Bicycle Queensland, running from 13 to 21 March. It aims to increase awareness and promote bike riding around the state. The Bligh government, through its TravelSmart program, is working with communities, schools, workplaces, local governments and destinations across Queensland to reduce the reliance on cars, encourage people to use healthier, more environmentally friendly forms of travel such as public transport, walking, cycling and car pooling.

The Premier’s Bike Week Challenge 2010 is on now. I can report that 240 entries have already been received. I encourage all kids in grades 5 to 7 across the state to enter and to be in the running to win one of 89 brand new bikes.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.45 am): The government is determined to reduce alcohol fuelled violence and create and support safe communities. There has been growing concern about the incidents of glassing in our pubs and clubs. The fact is that glassing is an horrific act of violence which causes permanent injury and scarring; put simply, it destroys lives.

While there is no doubt that individuals must take responsibility for their actions, licensed establishments also must realise their responsibilities to patron safety and harm minimisation. Last year the government promised it would respond swiftly to address this problem. I am pleased to report today that we are making good on that commitment. Since this government introduced legislation last October, the Office of Liquor and Gaming Regulation has identified and investigated 77 venues involving glassing or violent incidents over the past 12 months.

Those venues are currently being notified by OLGR of any changes they will need to make. Eight venues have been classified as high risk, which means they will need to remove regular glass completely and replace it with alternatives like tempered or toughened glassware. The remainder will either have restrictions on glass products--for example, only having glass in their restaurants--or have to submit a risk management plan detailing the steps they will take to minimise risk to patrons.

This is about cracking down on unacceptable violence with good, common-sense policy. OLGR compliance officers will incorporate checks on glass use as part of their normal compliance activities. I understand the majority of establishments have already voluntarily made the transition from regular glass, and I congratulate them for doing so.

The issue of alcohol related violence within our community affects many--from patrons on a night out to our emergency services and health workers. That is why the Law, Justice and Safety Committee will next week table its report following an investigation into public safety and alcohol related violence. This government is determined to end this culture of excessive consumption of alcohol which quite often has violent and sometimes tragic consequences.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.47 am): As we are all very aware, the recent spate of severe weather has caused widespread damage and inconvenience right across the state. Communities have been seriously impacted by heavy monsoonal rain, associated flooding and damaging winds. Relief and recovery arrangements are now activated in 58 local government areas. However, it is not just homes, businesses and infrastructure such as roads, bridges and power networks that have been affected. Flooding in the south-west of the state has had a huge impact on sport and recreation clubs, damaging playing fields, clubhouses, equipment and other property. In Charleville, the bowls club has sustained damage to its clubhouse, the green and futsal court and the netball courts are cracked and have to be repaired. The full extent of the damage will not be known until the water recedes.

These clubs are the lifeblood of regional and remote communities so it is important that we get their facilities and services up and running again as soon as possible to minimise disruption to the community. Today I can announce that the Queensland government has committed $1 million to the Disaster Recovery Program to ensure clubs can quickly get repairs underway and replace or repair equipment and infrastructure. The Bligh government will contribute up to $5,000 to replace damaged equipment and up to $20,000 to repair infrastructure. We understand that our clubs will suffer damage to practical, everyday items, and many can simply not afford to repair and recover on their own. From replacing lighting and fencing to operational items such as sport and recreation equipment, white goods and canteen items, this funding will help clubs get back on their feet as quickly as possible. The Bligh government recognises that access to quality, safe sport and recreation facilities and services is essential if Queenslanders are to lead active, healthy lifestyles.

While repairs will take time, when it is possible we want to see people back out playing sport and getting active as quickly as possible. Officers from the Department of Communities’s Sports and Recreation Services will be on the ground to assist clubs with their applications. The funding guidelines will be available from the Sports and Recreation website as well as regional offices. I encourage sporting and recreational organisations affected by flooding across the state to apply for this valuable assistance.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.49 am): I wish to advise the House that the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade will be absent from the House on Wednesday and Thursday this week. Minister Robertson will be attending the New Zealand-Australia Investment Forum in Auckland.
Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (10.49 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 3 of 2010 .

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (10.50 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. The Premier has already indicated that she will not be able to lead the Labour Day march this year because she will--coincidentally--be overseas at the time. But the Premier is in luck, because the Queensland workers are marching outside here today, and I ask: will the Premier undertake to go outside and listen to the workers whose jobs and livelihoods Labor is putting at risk?

Ms BLIGH: As the member indicated, I will not be available to attend the annual May Day march this year because I will be leading a delegation--one of the largest ever--on a trade mission to the annual BIO conference, a very important part of Queensland’s growing and diversified economy. I am not sure if the Leader of the Opposition knows, but the opposition believes it is so important that it has applied for the member for Clayfield to attend with me and for the Queensland taxpayers to assist him financially in that regard. So we will not see ‘Big Red’ Tim at Labour Day, either--‘Big Red’ Tim who we know has only lately joined the antiprivatisation brigade.

Let me say this about today’s rally: the representatives of trade unions who are affected by the government’s decision have every right to voice their views on this as part of the democratic process. What we will be doing for the members of these unions is ensuring that the interests and conditions of their members are protected as we transition into a public float. We will be making sure that Queensland Rail has access to a private injection of funds so that it will grow and we will see more jobs in a bigger, better Queensland company.

What we will not be doing today is sending the Queensland Police Service down with batons to hit them over the head. What we will not be doing is using the Queensland Police Service as a semimilitary organisation as those opposite did. What we will not be doing is taking the officials of any of these unions to court to take their family home off them as those opposite did, and what we will not be doing is taking the superannuation of the workers involved in these protests.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Stop the clock. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. So when we hear the Liberal National Party speak about its support for protests, we should remember that it only supports protests that are against anyone other than itself. When it had the opportunity, it stripped away the democratic rights of these workers, it stripped their superannuation and it stopped them from even complaining about it. Under Labor, what we will see is the protection of workers and the growing of jobs.

Mr LANGBROEK: I note that the Premier will obviously not be going to meet with her own people today. My second question without notice is also to the Premier. I refer to the Prime Minister’s vows of support for the Premier’s economic strategy during the election campaign. If Mr Rudd agreed with the strategy of protecting state government jobs, why is he closing small hospitals and axing jobs in state hospitals for which the Premier bears responsibility? Was the Premier conned or complicit?
A government member: It’s going to be a long week!

Ms BLIGH: It is going to be a very long week. I am unaware of a single Queensland hospital that the Prime Minister of Australia is seeking to close. What I am aware of is that we have a Prime Minister who, for the first time in decades, has said that the level of government that raises the most revenue--the Commonwealth--should take the lion’s share of funding for one of the most critical public services in the country--health. Doesn’t that stand in stark contrast to what we have seen from the previous federal government? What did it do? Instead of funding our hospitals fifty-fifty, at the end of the Howard years what had it got down to? Thirty-five per cent! You ought to be ashamed of yourself!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Order!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: The Premier has the call.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. And where was the member for Surfers Paradise--a health professional--when John Howard was ripping money out of the health system? He was hiding under a dental chair somewhere, just like he was when Joh Bjelke-Petersen took away people’s right to march. On any big issue you will find him wanting. You will find him lacking in courage, lacking in fortitude, wanting. Because when it comes to substance, when it comes to standing up for something, when it comes to courage, what they have is a frontbench that is feeble. This is the most feeble frontbench you will find in any parliament of Australia.

What do we have? We have a federal government that wants to put more money into Queensland hospitals. Well, we will stand up with the federal government and we will work to improve health services for every Australian and every Queenslander. Will we ask questions? Of course we will. Will we work to get it right? Of course we will. But we will not get any help from those opposite or from their comrade-in-arms Tony Abbott, because we know what Tony Abbott stands for in health. We can judge him on his record: he stands for cuts in the health system. The only side of politics cutting funds in health contains the former minister for health, the member for Toowoomba South, and the leader of the federal opposition, Tony Abbott. What you see here in Queensland is a government that has almost doubled its funding in health in five years. What has it meant?
Mr Cripps interjected.
Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection. This is from a member who has got a brand-new hospital out of this government that would never have been built by his side of politics.
Ms O’NEILL: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier update the House on the progress of the new $1.28 billion Queensland Children’s Hospital project?

Ms BLIGH: I am very pleased to advise the House where I will be at lunchtime today. Along with the health minister, I will be turning the sod on the brand-new Queensland Children’s Hospital. This is a government that is determined to get on with building what Queenslanders need and our new Children’s Hospital will be a $1.28 billion investment in the children of this state. It will be Queensland’s first single tertiary children’s hospital and it will combine the expertise and services of the Royal Children’s Hospital, the Mater Children’s Hospital and the Prince Charles Hospital paediatric areas into one facility by 2014. This will mark a new era in children’s health in Queensland. It will be an 11-level facility with about 71,000 square metres of floor space. There will be 359 beds, which is 71 more than the combined total now at the Royal and the Children’s Hospital.

This new hospital will provide new services that currently do not exist. There will be a new obesity clinic, a new pain and allergy clinic and a new renal treatment centre for children. It will also have a new research facility that will bring together all of the paediatric research into one facility. The early works that the Deputy Premier and I will see start today will begin the construction of a four-level basement car park to provide for families and patients with 660 parking spaces.

In the next four years we will also be working to expand children’s health facilities at the Ipswich, Logan, Caboolture, Redland, Redcliffe and Prince Charles hospitals. That is what a government investing in health does.
