By 2012, we will see a new children’s emergency department at the Prince Charles Hospital, which will have 12 emergency treatment spaces, 20 beds for short stays and additional children’s outpatient services.

How can we as a state government afford that kind of investment? Why can we stand here with confidence and start work on a $1.2 billion hospital for children? Because we have the internal fortitude that is needed to make the right budget decisions that will deliver the infrastructure that Queensland needs. Today we will hear a lot about asset sales from those opposite and from some outside. We will not hear a credible alternative that will deliver the Children’s Hospital, deliver the Cairns Hospital, deliver the Townsville Hospital, deliver the Mackay Hospital, deliver the Rockhampton Hospital, deliver the Sunshine Coast Hospital and deliver the Gold Coast Hospital. That is what this government stands for.

Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Before calling the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I acknowledge in the public gallery students and staff from Runcorn State School in the electorate of Sunnybank represented in this parliament by the Hon. Judy Spence.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question is to the Premier. Given that the Premier’s 100,000 new jobs promise lies in tatters, her no-fuel-tax promise lies in tatters, her no-privatisation promise lies in tatters and now her 200,000 solar hot-water systems for Queensland homes promise lies in tatters, does the Premier now understand why her credibility now lies in tatters?

Ms BLIGH: There is nothing that gives me more pleasure than talking about implementing election commitments. Let me talk about the 100,000 jobs that we provided. When did we say we would deliver these? We said we would deliver them by the end of this term. Are we on the right track? You bet we are. We now see unemployment in Queensland falling. We have had jobs growth for six consecutive months. What does that mean? Our economic strategy is working. What is our economic strategy? What did we say we would deliver? We said we would deliver an LNG industry and it is on track. We said we would deliver a Green Army and people are employed in it. We said we would deliver new skills places and they are in place. We said we would deliver our infrastructure plan and that is what we are doing.

What we said we would not do is we would not cut 12,000 jobs every year. If the LNP had come into government, we would be about 14,000 jobs down. It promised to sack 1,000 people a month. That was its economic response to the global financial crisis. We are on track to deliver on our 100,000 jobs promise and jobs continue to drive our government’s agenda.

Let me talk about jobs in QR. I am very happy to talk about jobs in QR, because the QR coal and commercial venture is a growing organisation. Currently, we are in the market looking to fill 600 new jobs. What sort of jobs? We are looking for freight train drivers, for trainee network controllers, for graduates, for maintenance workers for Rockhampton, Mackay, Townsville--right across the state. Guess what? That number comes on top of 200 people joining QR since December 2009. So that is almost 1,000 new jobs by the middle of the year.

When it comes to the Solar Homes Program, we are very proud to be a government that supports solar power. Queensland, the Sunshine State, should be the solar state of Australia and that is what we are determined to deliver. We will redesign this program and we will deliver solar hot water that will reduce people’s power bills and contribute to cleaner, greener energy. We made a promise in this area because we believe in it and we are going to deliver it.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Premier. I am sure all members are aware that yesterday was International Women’s Day. Could the Premier advise the House of the Bligh government’s commitment to improving opportunities for Queensland’s women?

Ms BLIGH: I am very pleased to take the question from the member. I know her commitment to improving the status of women. Mr Acting Speaker, I also know what a great supporter of International Women’s Day you are and how pleased I am to see you with a purple ribbon today, matching a purple tie.

Yesterday was International Women’s Day, but there are now so many events to commemorate this day that one day is not enough. The events often go over a number of days. Tonight I will be very pleased to host a reception here at Parliament House for a number of women from different sectors of the community to celebrate. Last Thursday I was very pleased to join more than 1,400 women, and quite a few men, at the 21st United Nations Development Fund for Women--UNIFEM--International Women’s Day breakfast. It was terrific to see the Girl Guides represented there.

The year 2010 is the centenary of Girl Guides internationally. This women’s organisation has for 100 years given girls and young women an opportunity to build leadership and confidence in their lives. I take a moment today to congratulate Girl Guides. I particularly congratulate young guide Marnie O’Dea, who spoke to an audience of 1,400 people. She is a great credit to the organisation. She spoke with a great deal of passion and inspiration about the millennium development goals for women in Third World countries. This year the Queensland government’s theme for IWD is ‘Women leading the way’ and it relates to our government’s goal of increasing the participation of women in all parts of our community--in our homes, our workplaces and boardrooms--in leadership, decision making and community building.

Nationally, 2010 is also the Year of Women in Local Government. Currently in Queensland, one-third--or 183 women--are councillors in local governments. We have 10 mayors who are women and 16 deputy mayors. Some of the biggest local government areas in Queensland are now run by women. Pam Parker oversees the fifth largest council by population in Queensland and in Cairns women hold the top three positions, with Mayor Val Schier, Deputy Mayor Margaret Cochrane and the new CEO, Lyn Russell. I also pay tribute to those mayors who are serving in some of the western parts of our state, such as Donna Stewart, who has five towns in her shire--St George, Dirranbandi, Bollon, Thallon, and Mungindi--all affected by floods and she has been terrific throughout. In the Paroo shire in the south-west, Jo Sheppard has also been dealing with some of these floods. These women have been proving themselves to be more than up to the task in very trying circumstances. Our government supports a greater role for women in decision making at all levels in both public and private sectors and we will continue to work to achieve that.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy. I refer to the statement that the minister made earlier today regarding the abandoned solar hot water election promise, and I ask: what are the licensing issues the minister referred to that are preventing the installation of solar hot-water systems that Queenslanders have already paid for? Can the minister advise why the government contractor Conergy has for a week now not been answering phone calls from out-of-pocket Queenslanders?

Mr ROBERTSON: One of the things that I find most galling about the constant criticism from day one from the opposition about our solar hot-water scheme is that they would criticise a government that is trying to make fundamental change to the way that we embrace clean energy. What did those opposite take to the last election in terms of a solar hot water policy? Absolutely nothing. Not one word was spoken during the whole election campaign by the opposition in terms of an alternative energy strategy. That is why it is so galling to hear any criticism about our desire to make a fundamental change and get more solar hot-water units on people’s roofs in the most affordable way.

I do not think that is a valid criticism. We are a government that is committed to making solar hot water affordable for the majority of Queenslanders. That is what being in government is all about. The whole point of our scheme was to bring down the price of solar hot-water units to make them affordable for the vast majority of Queenslanders. We targeted price points at $500 and $100 for pensioners. No other government has tried to make such a bold scheme work. Once again we see an opposition that is all criticism and no substance.

With respect to the licensing issues, despite Conergy giving commitments at the time the scheme was launched in October last year that all necessary licences were in place and signing off on that, we subsequently found in February that not all appropriate licences were in place. Upon discovering that, Conergy was immediately suspended.

It needs to be understood that Conergy are not the installers. Therefore, they are not the company that is actually installing the solar hot-water units on people’s roofs. Nevertheless, the BSA still requires them to hold an appropriate licence. This is not an issue about safety or an issue about quality of installation; it is an issue about whether, as the principal company involved in our standing arrangement, they had all necessary licences as required by the BSA. As a result of discovering that they did not, we immediately suspended them and we continued to work through the issues with the BSA to return them to a fully functioning company.
Ms van LITSENBURG: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the minister update the House on the different proposals for health reform?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I acknowledge her interest in the subject matter of health. For years politicians at all levels and on both sides of politics have called for genuine policy reform when it comes to health. Demographics and rising expectations present the greatest challenges to the health system. As we know, by 2050 the number of Australians over 80 will quadruple, the number of those over 65 will double and the number of people of working age to pay for them will almost halve. That is an incontrovertible fact that we have to deal with when it comes to health policy.

On top of that is the rising expectations of people in terms of what they want out of the health system. Once upon a time, certain procedures were not performed on people once they were past a certain age. Now we proudly do that--and so we should. But forever and ever there will be an increasing expectation to perform those procedures. Australia has the second longest life expectancy on earth. That indicates on an overall basis how we as a system have performed.

We are now about to debate fundamental change at a national level with Kevin Rudd. What have we seen in the past from the opposition? We know the policy stance of Tony Abbott, who is a previous health minister. What was his great policy contribution to health? He had two. The first one was the worst public policy health decision in Australia’s political history--the Mersey Hospital. I invite members opposite to tell me what policy justification there was for taking over one hospital in one federal marginal Liberal seat in Tasmania? He gave Treasury a fit, he gave Costello a fit and he gave the AMA a fit. I table what the AMA said at the time. It said that ‘the intervention will be dangerous and not sustainable’.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: ABC News article posted 11 August 2007 headed ‘AMA, doctors slam Govt over Mersey takeover’.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what Tony Abbott gave people during his time as health minister.

Earlier I referred to demographics. They do not change; they continue to present as a problem. Tony Abbott failed to increase federal health funding in line with the increased demands on states. We went from receiving 50 per cent of the funding to receiving 35 per cent of the funding from the Commonwealth. If there is one thing, more than anything else, that has put the system under pressure it is his failure to deliver on that. Everybody knows that at a state level taxes increasingly are going to the Commonwealth government to collect but states are still expected to deliver those services.

Finally we have an opportunity for a debate at a national level about future funding for health. If we do not address this in the future, in 20 or 30 years time there will be two ministers here--a Premier and a health minister--because there will be no money at a state level for anything else. That is not sustainable. The body that has the most taxation power is the body that should have the most skin in the game. We welcome the opportunity to negotiate. What did the Leader of the Opposition say on it? Nothing.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is for the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. I refer the minister to what his department calls ‘Project Tarzan’: the privatisation of Forestry Plantations Queensland. An internal memo asks managers, ‘If you have concerns regarding Forestry Plantation staff being spoken to by the bidder’s agents it is appropriate for you to ensure staff are not working in the areas nominated by the bidder’. I table a copy of that email.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email, dated 2 March, regarding Project Tarzan: ‘Forest Access Deed + bidder expert team access’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Will the minister say why this gag is being put on ordinary workers? What does the government have to hide and why are workers being told not to speak with the potential buyers of Forestry Plantations Queensland?

Mr MULHERIN: I accept the question from the honourable member. Those opposite never cease to amaze me. I understand that the member’s previous incarnation, prior to his time on Brisbane City Council, was as a qualified lawyer. I would have thought that as a lawyer he would know the issues around probity which relate to any sale, be it in the public or the private sector. We have set up a process of ensuring that probity is carried out through this whole process. The sale of FPQ is on track and it should be concluded by June.
Mr CHOI: My question without notice is for the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of ownership eligibility for the QRNational float?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Capalaba for his question. I can advise the public and the House of the eligibility requirements for people who want to bid for QRNational. That is, it is open to the public. It is open to all Queenslanders. For those coal companies that yesterday sought to form a consortium under the leadership of Nick Greiner, the message to them is clear as well. They will be invited to bid for the asset, but they will be invited, along with every other person in Queensland and around the world, to bid on market, to bid transparently and to bid in accordance with the process that the government has undertaken.

We are undertaking a transparent process with competitive tension and with probity oversight. That requires that in relation to FPQ, the timber business that is for sale, there is a probity adviser, which requires that contact about the sale is conducted and oversighted by the probity adviser and that all the information is provided in a secure data room subject to the normal commercial arrangements. This is what occurs in every single transaction, public or private.
Ms Bligh: Public or private.

Mr FRASER: Public or private. For the alternative Treasurer in this state to put forward a view that those people who are swinging an axe at FPQ should be in charge of conducting this transaction shows how fundamentally he misunderstands the responsibilities and the task at hand. The reality is that probity oversight is fundamental to ensuring the integrity of the outcome and getting the best results for taxpayers. That is a supremely embarrassing question and allegation. It shines a light on the shadow Treasurer’s new-found quest to be the Barnaby Joyce of Queensland politics. His efforts last week, when he ran around Western Queensland with Barnaby, are matched only by the fundamental misunderstanding that he shows by asking that question.

It is with little wonder that we learn of the revelation that another former Liberal leader is beating a path to Queensland. Not only do they have Nick Greiner; the state LNP has invited yesterday’s man, former Liberal Prime Minister John Howard, to come up and give its members a few tips. One can only imagine what is going to go on as he gives them a few tips. Lets us look at what Mr Howard has said in the past. In 2006 he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And there’s one thing I will fight for to my last political breath, is to preserve the nationwide unity of the Liberal Party of Australia.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Obviously he is coming up here not only to read the last rites but also to kneel at the graveyard of the Liberal Party in Queensland, to make sure that he pays his respects to the death of liberalism. What do members think Mr Howard will say about their fake opposition to privatisation when he is the one who sold Telstra? What do members think he will say about the sort of Barnaby Joyce economics being promoted by the shadow Treasurer? We can say a lot of things about the mean-spirited policies that John Howard pursued, but at least we knew what he stood for. I hope he is here to tell these jokers that they need to stand for something and that they need to put forward a policy. What we want to see from this state opposition is that they stand for something and that they can put forward an alternative, rather than just whinge and criticise.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Fraser: You’re about to be shadow Treasurer, Ray.

Mr HOPPER: You poor little man. My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries. In the last session of state parliament, the Minister for Transport was asked if she could give a guarantee that no Queensland Rail worker seeking to keep a job would be forced to relocate from their community. Can the Minister for Primary Industries give the same undertaking, that no Forestry Plantations worker seeking to retain their job will be forced to relocate?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. Most of the forestry operations are in the south-east corner. Currently FPQ employs about 400 people. We have given a guarantee to those people that no-one will be sacked and no-one will be forced into redundancy. We will guarantee their working conditions for two years past the sale of FPQ. Discussions around the industrial instruments that they operate under currently and into the future are part of the negotiations that the sales team is having with the unions representing the interests of those workers.

Ms NELSON-CARR: My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Could the minister update the House on the rollout of the national broadband network in Queensland and the state government’s involvement with NBN?

Mr SCHWARTEN: As the honourable member well knows, she will soon represent the most connected people in Australia as, last week, the federal government announced that the rollout would begin in her electorate in Aitkenvale, where 3,000 houses will be connected.
Mr Wallace: Hear, hear!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I note a ‘hear, hear!’ coming from the member for Thuringowa. I am sure that everybody on this side of the parliament is very envious, as we understand how significant this is. I see the member for Ipswich West nodding. What is happening in Aitkenvale is effectively akin to the opening of the Ipswich to Grandchester line 130 years ago. Last week I was in Germany where we talked about 50 megabytes. This is 100 megabytes, which will enable the connected citizens to download movies, health outcomes and the like, which will bring the entire world into their living rooms and onto their doorsteps.

I note that before Christmas the Leader of the Opposition offered his support for this project. I thank him for his support for NBN. In my view, it is a bipartisan issue. He needs to talk to the member for Currumbin. I am surprised to see her here. I thought she would be at the Oscars. The reality is that she might as well be at the Oscars, because she is well and truly out of touch in terms of what she has to say about broadband in this state. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition is on the right track here and I suggest that the shadow minister develop a little bit of high speed--
Mr Messenger: There are some good unionists chanting outside, Robbie.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I have a stye in my eye at the moment and I cannot quite see the gentleman over there. If I have it right, I might be misusing the term ‘gentleman’. Given his manners this morning, I think that the occupant of this very large stye may well be sitting over there. They are reminiscent of a razorback pig, with the table manners to boot. The fact of the matter is that this is good news for 3,000 citizens of Mundingburra. At the last election the federal government promised--
An opposition member interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I notice the squawking of irrelevancy coming from someone who, like John Howard, thinks that wireless is something you cock your ear at to listen to Blue Hills .

Mrs STUCKEY: It was interesting to note that the awards were taken out by women. My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the Minister inform the House if Australasian Technical Services Pty Ltd, a Melbourne based company whose asbestos removal licensee, Frank Gatto, was suspended by the ACT Planning and Land Authority in October 2009, was allowed to conduct asbestos removal in Queensland schools during the summer holidays?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I am not aware of that. If that is the case, I will have it investigated immediately and I will get back to the honourable member. I will say this about asbestos, and I have said it time and time again: I have handled asbestos myself and I would venture to suggest that I am one of the few members in this House who has. My own father died from an asbestos related illness. Certainly I would never condone someone who is a shyster getting into the industry. I know first-hand about the dangers of the illness that can result from exposure to this product. As a result of that, no stone will be unturned to get to the bottom of the issue. I thank the honourable member for the question. I take it that it is sincerely asked.

Mrs KEECH:
My question is to the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, and I ask: can the minister outline to the House what action has been taken to ensure the safety of householders and workers in relation to insulation?

Mr DICK: I thank the member for her question, for her interest in electrical and community safety and also for her support of a family tragically affected by an electrocution incident last year. I commend her for that. Members will recall that I have previously provided information to the House on electrical safety and ceiling insulation, most recently on 25 February. Since then I have received further advice about issues and concerns relating to the electrical safety of Queenslanders and their property, particularly in relation to foil insulation. As a result, today I will issue a new ministerial notice under the Electrical Safety Act 2002 for electrically conductive foil ceiling insulation. This notice will add to the regulatory measures relating to insulation safety that were implemented in November 2009. It will apply in Queensland, irrespective of any requirements or conditions imposed under the Australian government’s household renewable energy bonus scheme, which is yet to commence.

This latest ministerial notice, which I will sign today and which will be effective from the time of its gazettal this afternoon, requires electrically conducted foil insulation installers to arrange a preinstallation electrical inspection by a licensed electrical contractor and to install safety switches on all circuits in the ceiling space. Further, the notice requires installers to mark and separate foil insulation from any wiring that cannot be protected by a safety switch.

The Electrical Safety Office is aware that there is currently a large stockpile of foil insulation products in Queensland, and this surplus stock may be sold and installed at discounted prices outside any new federal scheme. The Queensland government is concerned that these products could be rushed into the marketplace and exacerbate electrical safety risks. Last month, federal minister Peter Garrett made reference to the introduction of a strengthened compliance regime in concert with state and territory occupational health and safety and fair trading authorities. This latest ministerial notice will complement any new compliance regime and provides the clear regulatory framework necessary to properly address this important issue.

I have written to Greg Combet, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Climate Change and Energy Efficiency, outlining the ongoing concerns of Queensland’s Electrical Safety Office in relation to foil insulation. I have urged him to consider these concerns with respect to any future federal action on both existing insulation under the former program as well as the new scheme. The Electrical Safety Office will also be undertaking advertising and communication activities to inform electrical contractors and householders about these new requirements. This is a great and important Labor initiative. Householders and electrical contractors wanting more information about the notice can phone the Electrical Safety Office on 1300650662 or visit electricalsafety.qld.gov.au.

Mr JOHNSON: My question is directed to the honourable Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. I refer to the former police minister, who proclaimed in 2007 that with the introduction of electronic monitoring the government was ‘implementing Australia’s toughest regime against dangerous sexual offenders’ and that this ‘is the best option available to monitor sex offenders’. Given that of the 54 offenders subjected to this regime, 17--or one in three--breached provisions of their sentence while under this surveillance, I ask: will the minister now admit that the best option would be to implement LNP policy that dangerous sex offenders remain behind bars until they are able to prove their readiness for release?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for the question. Six years ago dangerous sex offenders were released into the community without any supervision. It was a Labor government which introduced legislation to provide an option for the courts to either keep them in prison or release them into the community under Corrective Services supervision with very stringent conditions. So, in terms of the National Party seeking to gain credibility on this issue, it was a Labor government in Queensland which introduced what is the toughest legislation in the country.

Prisoners who have committed sex offences against adults and children in particular are assessed prior to their release as to whether they are going to be sought to be classified as a dangerous sex offender. If that is the case, they are brought before the courts and the Supreme Court makes a determination as to whether that offender will be kept in custody--which is the preferred position of the Labor government. But, if the court determines that they can be released into the community, they are released under very stringent conditions.

Currently there are around 54 people on supervision orders in the community. Some of those people have 40 and 50 conditions attached to their particular release into the community--conditions such as where they can live, where they can work, who they can associate with, the times at which they are required to be within their premises. On all of these conditions they are monitored proactively by the Queensland Corrective Services Commission. If the offenders breach those conditions they are brought back before the courts and in many cases returned to custody or indeed additional supervision orders are put on them.

Our preferred position would be to keep all of these offenders in jail. The dangerous sex offenders legislation is at the limits of constitutionality. Our law says that when you serve your time you get out of prison. With these offenders we have extended and given the courts the right to keep them in prison. We introduced that legislation. If the court determines that they can be released, it applies the conditions. Queensland Corrective Services gives these people no quarter. If they breach conditions, they are brought back before the courts and extra conditions are placed on them or they are put back into prison.

I am happy to talk about law and order issues in this parliament. Let me get back to some of the things I was talking about last week. Under the National Party--those opposite talk about how tough they are about law and order issues--as I said, it is a case of throw away the keys and bring back the gallows. But let us look at the facts. Under Labor, crime rates have reduced by 21.5 per cent; property offences, 42.5 per cent; offences against the person, 18.7 per cent. They are all talk and no action when it comes to law and order issues.

Mr PITT: My question to the Minister for Main Roads is about planning for growth not just in South-East Queensland but across the state. Bearing in mind the Premier’s Growth Summit to be held later this month, can the minister please advise the outcomes of the Roads Summit held with North Queensland mayors in Townsville last Friday?

Mr WALLACE: That is a good question. I congratulate the member for Mulgrave. I was in Innisfail last week for community cabinet. He is very well received in his local electorate. He is working very hard for the people of Far North Queensland, especially on the issue of roads. I have some good news for the member for Mulgrave. The Roads Summit was a great success in Townsville last week and it links in very well with the Premier’s Growth Summit--to get Queenslanders involved in shaping our state’s future.

As a result of our Roads Summit in Townsville, I will be leading the charge to Canberra with a wish list of priority roadworks for the Bruce Highway in North Queensland. With over 2,000 people a week heading to Queensland, it is more important than ever that we plan for our future growth. We want to build stronger regional communities to cater for that growth and we want to generate jobs into the bargain.

I met with mayors from St Lawrence to Cairns on Friday. We all agreed on some urgent priorities for this vital 1,000-kilometre section of the Bruce Highway. Some of the works which we concluded needed to be done were: the northern approach to Mackay; Sandy Gully, north of Bowen; Yellow Gin Creek, south of Home Hill; the ring-road stage 4 at Townsville; the Ingham to Cardwell Range realignment; the Eubenangee Swamp realignment; Wrights Creek Bridge widening, south of Cairns; and overtaking lanes right across our region.

As a community we have worked shoulder to shoulder with the Rudd government to deliver some real achievements in roads in North Queensland. As a result of an earlier summit that I hosted in 2007, the Rudd government committed more than $1 billion to the Bruce Highway north of Sarina--$1 billion for that section of highway. We want to maintain that momentum. The best way to keep the ball rolling is to involve all three tiers of government--even more so after 11 years of neglect by the Howard government. The Bruce Highway in North Queensland, as the member for Mulgrave will know, was an absolute disgrace thanks to the lack of funding by the Howard government. The Rudd government has put in $1 billion.

The Bligh government’s focus is firmly fixed on regional Queensland. Better roads and a better lifestyle will attract more people to settle in the regions and encourage regional growth. We are building more roads in regional Queensland. We are building a better, brighter future. Work will start this year on the $90 million Cardwell Range realignment and the $110 million jointly funded Douglas Arterial duplication in Townsville. Projects to ease congestion in Mackay and Sarina are on the drawing board and planning work is well underway for the $150 million upgrade of the Bruce Highway south of Cairns.

The Bligh government and Rudd government are rising to the challenge of our fast-growing state when it comes to roads, with sensible, working solutions. I thank those mayors from St Lawrence north who joined with me. We will take the fight up for further funding for our Bruce Highway.

Mr WELLINGTON: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. With respect to the incident of a person dying as a result of Queensland Health staff refusing to admit the person to a mental health unit for observation, notwithstanding the pleading of family members and carers for the person to be admitted, I ask: will the minister today speak with his director-general and ensure a direction is immediately issued to all Queensland Health staff that they must give due weight and act on the pleadings of family members and carers?

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member has asked me to speak with the Director-General of Queensland Health concerning the issues raised by him. Of course I am happy to convey the issues raised by him with the director-general in accordance with his request. If there is a specific incident that the member appears to be indicating, I am more than happy, if he wants to provide details, to ask the director-general--
Mr WELLINGTON: With respect, Mr Acting Speaker, the minister’s office is fully aware of the incident I am referring to.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Order! Member for Nicklin, there is no point of order. You have asked your question; you will get your answer. The minister has the call.

Mr LUCAS: I am making the point that, if there is a specific incident that the member wishes me to raise with the director-general, I will also do that. The issue of mental health is a significant and serious issue for Australia--and, indeed, for the West and the world--and is one which the government recognises needs absolute attention.

In terms of the best way to interact with families and to deal with families’ concerns, I have made it clear in the past, for example--and we have seen some of this debate nationally on privacy issues--that sometimes when it comes to communicating with others health systems become very focused on privacy issues with respect to a patient. Ultimately it is to the detriment of that patient because they do not raise them with either their general practitioners or members of the family. I do not know whether or not that specifically relates to this issue, but I think that is an issue that is very important. We have significantly increased our funding for mental health, but mental health is an issue that is of growing concern. I am not commenting specifically on this issue, but certainly drug induced mental health is a major issue, too. I am not saying that it relates to this issue because I do not have that information in front of me.

Clinical decisions about how best to respond to particular matters are best left in the hands of those people who are clinically qualified to do that. I, as a legal practitioner, have never sought, for example, to tell people in other professions how they might best deal with issues under their concern any more than I would expect that a doctor would tell me how to deal with legal matters. I am a great believer in having appropriate qualifications to deal with these matters. If, however, there is an issue about how families are being dealt with and there is an issue of general concern about that, I am more than happy to do that because I see families, particularly in respect of mental health issues, as critical stakeholders--as partners with Queensland Health in dealing with those things.

There is one thing I want to add, though. As with all health matters, including mental health matters, it is very difficult to draw particular conclusions as a result of what has happened before. Tragically, a whole lot of factors are often involved in deaths, and it is wrong to draw particular conclusions as a result of things that may or may not happen. That is a practice that I have observed in my dealings in government or with oppositions or oppositions federally. I am happy to have it further examined.

Ms GRACE: My question is to the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. The energy efficiency of new buildings is a real concern in the face of climate change. Could the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning inform the House what is being done to reduce the carbon footprint of the state’s new homes?

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I thank the member for Brisbane Central for her question. I know that the member is particularly committed to ensuring that a large number of new home units being built in her electorate have a lesser impact on the environment than such development has had in the past. The Queensland government is delivering on its commitment to protect the Queensland lifestyle by combating the effects of climate change.

As I mentioned earlier, Queensland is growing by around 115,000 people every year. That is equivalent to a city the size of Darwin. Not only do we need to meet the infrastructure requirements of that growth; we also need to use this infrastructure more wisely while protecting our unique environment. The introduction of a five-star standard for new and renovated units is an important part of the Cleaner Greener Buildings election commitment and will help achieve the Toward Q2: Tomorrow’s Queensland target of slashing Queensland household greenhouse gas emissions by one-third.

From 1 March 2010 all new units built in Queensland are required to achieve a minimum five-star energy equivalence rating. This includes a four-star minimum rating for individual units and a five-star average rating across all units in a building. Green designed features that count towards this rating and recognised under the initiative include ceiling fans in living and bedroom areas; shading with wide eaves and awnings; natural ventilation through windows and doorways; and, very significantly, one-star recognition of units with covered outdoor living areas. Features like these are the ones that the community wants. The units that have these sorts of features are ones that win design awards.

The five-star standard for units was first canvassed as part of the government’s ‘Improving sustainable housing in Queensland’ discussion paper in 2008. During a three-month industry and community consultation period it received over 90 per cent support. Ongoing feedback from industry has also been positive. This is because unit buyers are snapping up products that capture the things that we love about the traditional Queensland lifestyle. It is clear that outdoor living areas are key in both units and other homes.

The Bligh government’s green housing initiatives also include five-star energy rating efficiencies for houses; the phase-out of electric hot-water systems in gas reticulated areas; and the prevention of sale and installation of energy inefficient air conditioners. These measures demonstrate the Bligh government’s commitment to a proactive and long-term approach to protect the future of Queensland and to support Queensland lifestyles.

What does the opposition say? Nothing. We hear nothing about these issues. What sorts of policies does the opposition have to make Queensland houses more affordable? Get rid of one form. The members opposite are a policy-free zone on sustainable housing--an issue of very great substance in the face of global climate change.

Mrs MENKENS: My question is to the Minister for Community Services and Housing. I refer to the procurement by the department of housing of a Palm Cove block of land on the corner of Oliva and Harpa streets for the reported sum of $1.3 million. The block of land has approval for 18 two-bedroom units. The prime tourism niche of Palm Cove has none of the associated infrastructure or facilities required for public housing tenants. There are limited employment opportunities in the area. A similar size block of land at other sites with the required facilities for these tenants could be acquired for under $200,000.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Order! Member for Burdekin, ask your question, please.
Mrs MENKENS: Why is the department wasting significant government money on land that is totally inappropriate for the tenants’ needs?

Ms STRUTHERS: I am wondering whether the member wants signs put up around the state, on the Captain Cook Highway: ‘No public housing tenants welcome’. I wonder whether she wants them at Caloundra: ‘No public housing tenants welcome’ as you come over Caloundra Road; or at Surfers Paradise, as you come down the highway: ‘No public housing tenants welcome here’. Is that what the member wants me to do? That is what it sounds like from her question.

The member is making outrageous claims about where people ought to be located. Everyone in this state--every senior, every person housed in public housing or on our register wanting to be housed in public housing--has a right to be housed in their own community. Every person in this state in public housing, every person in this state who is on the register for public housing, every person we know--and many in our own families or in our own communities at some point in their life may need the support of public housing--deserves to live in their own community. If they grow up on the northern beaches of Cairns--if they are seniors and they retire or their life circumstances change--and they need public housing, where should they live? Ipswich? Logan? The back of Bourke? Is that where the member wants them to live?

Every person in this state who needs public housing or at some point in their life will come to need public housing deserves to live in their own communities, and that is what our policies are all about. Gone are the old days when people were put on the fringes of communities. But, clearly, the opposition is stuck in the old days. The member for Surfers Paradise, the Leader of the Opposition, is setting the trend here. ‘Not in my backyard,’ he said. What did he say about Skiff Street, Surfers Paradise? ‘Not these people in this community.’

Let us put a sign up on the highway. Let us put a sign up on Smith Street and on the Gold Coast Highway that says ‘No public housing tenants welcome in Surfers Paradise’. Do you want me to put one up in Cairns, on the Captain Cook Highway: ‘No public housing tenants welcome on the northern beaches’? That is clearly what underpins the message.

The future is that public housing is in the communities where people need and want to live. Everyone has the right to live in their own community, whether they need public housing or not. That is the message from this Labor government. That is the future of public housing. We do not want signs up in communities saying ‘Public housing free zone’ or ‘Public housing tenants not welcome here’. Let me remind members how many new social housing units are being developed under our stimulus package. How many, members? Did I hear 4,030?
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: The time for question time is over.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Building Services Authority, Comments by Member
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (11.50 am), by leave: The BSA is an administrative agency responsible for regulation of the building industry. It is not a judicial body. It cannot decide contractual disputes or award damages. It must work according to the legislation under which it was established. I make this point as to the role of the BSA as the member for Burnett recently took up the cause of a local--
Mr Messenger interjected.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER: Member for Burnett!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I make this point as to the role of the BSA as the member for Burnett recently took up the cause of a local constituent and relied on her version of events concerning the role of the BSA and the commercial and consumer tribunal which is now known as the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal.
Mr Messenger interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I intend to table the entire documentation about this case and I will invite the honourable member to apologise to the parliament and to the BSA for his untoward remarks.
Mr Messenger: You should apologise to homeowners.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I certainly will not be doing that.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Member for Burnett!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I would like to inform the honourable member that the BSA and QCAT are two distinct bodies. I would like to inform the member that he does not have the facts and the evidence given by his constituent was found to be less than reliable, as I will explain later.
Mr Messenger interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Burnett!

Mr SCHWARTEN: The local newspaper, the Bundaberg News Mail , also took up the cause on behalf of Mr Messenger’s constituent. However, they also have a responsibility to report the facts of the matter. They unfortunately relied on Mr Messenger’s view of the matter who, in turn, relied on the information, we suppose--
Mr Messenger interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: The member for Burnett!

Mr SCHWARTEN: He is again making a goat of himself in here. In fact, a goat would make more sense. I will start again. They unfortunately relied on Mr Messenger’s view of the matter who, in turn, relied on the information passed on to him--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, could I ask you to refer to the member by his title.
Mr SCHWARTEN: The member for Burnett.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The minister is making a statement, thank you.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The local newspaper unfortunately relied on the honourable member for Burnett’s view of the matter who, in turn, relied on the information passed to him by his constituent or perhaps the member for Burnett invented it. Fortunately, the BSA, QCAT and the courts are required to--
Mr MESSENGER: I rise to a point of order. I find those words offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Well, whatever he finds offensive, Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, if you withdraw, you must withdraw unreservedly.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I did so. I am just going on with the statement. Fortunately, the BSA, QCAT and the courts are required to take a fairer view. Building contractors have the same rights as consumers. The builder in this case was found by QCAT to be hardworking and experienced. For the honourable member to claim, as he did, that the BSA did nothing is an untruth. I have the time line of events here, which I now table--
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Time line of Events (owner)--(contractor) outlining a 2007 complaint regarding water penetration and a 2009 complaint regarding rusty nails staining weatherboards.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Messenger: Your own department found two category 1 defects.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I will go back and do it again. We will stay here all day, if we have to. For the honourable member to claim, as he did, that the BSA did nothing is an untruth. I have the time line of events, which I have now tabled, along with the two judgements made by the tribunal, which I now table.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Queensland Commercial and Consumer Tribunal--Fergus v Halkett [2009] QCCTB 167 (31 July 2009).
Tabled paper: Queensland Commercial and Consumer Tribunal--Fergus v Halkett [2009] QCCTB 132 (5 June 2009).
XML.Hansard-Body: There is no doubt that this is a complicated matter. However, it is before the tribunal and not in the hands of the BSA. I repeat: it is out of the hands of the BSA.
Mr Messenger: You can put in a recommendation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Burnett, you have been asked on a number of occasions to not interject. Would you please refrain from comments, thank you.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Which brings me to the one-sided and ill-informed attack upon the local builder last week. I quote from the QCAT decision made by member Sheaffe. It stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The applicant and the respondent gave oral evidence and were cross examined in detail. The applicant was a builder of considerable experience ... he came across to me as a hard working, no nonsense builder and I have no hesitation in accepting his evidence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the man that the honourable member defamed. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: On the other hand, I have concerns about the respondent’s evidence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the person for whom the honourable member is taking up the case. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: These concerns were raised by her exaggerated demeanour in the witness box and by the evidence that she gave ...
Further, the reasons why she made the speculative claim of $10,000.00 at the trial were difficult to explain.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Remember that this is an independent person making this statement. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In her original defence the claim for $10,000.00 was not made and it was first made on the day of the trial and significantly there was no evidence tendered to support it. This claim was no more than a spurious claim for damages and I am satisfied that the making of this claim, at the door of the Court, reflects poorly on her credit.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the person that this honourable member is standing up for. It continues further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The applicant is a small builder, he does not have financial reserves or financial means, he is financially not in a strong position and he incurred the costs of materials and wages for these variations.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the man that the honourable member attacked. It continues further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The respondent requested the variations, the applicant provided quotations that were accepted and he carried out the work ... I am satisfied that the applicant is entitled to an order approving the recovery of the sum of $9,490 for the variations.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is a small businessperson. It continues further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: After taking into account all these matters and the general demeanour of the respondent I find that I am not prepared to accept her evidence unless it is corroborated by others. Where the evidence of the applicant and the respondent are in conflict, I will accept the evidence of the applicant.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a pretty straightforward statement. The applicant is the builder. This is the man who was attacked by the member for Burnett. These are just some of the facts available to the member and can be publicly accessed if he takes the time to look. Also, for Mr Messenger’s information, the statutory scheme which provides the best safety net in the country for homeowners affected by incomplete or defective work is the Queensland Home Warranty Scheme not the home builders warranty insurance scheme, as he claimed it to be. This scheme offers protection for homeowners with legitimate complaints and claims. I have also taken the opportunity to advise the member for Burnett that this matter is listed for compulsory conference at Hervey Bay on 19 March and is listed for review by QCAT, an independent tribunal, on 25 March.
Mr MESSENGER: I rise on a matter suddenly arising.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: The member for Burnett.

Mr MESSENGER: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wish to correct the facts. I have never attacked any builder or named any builder as the minister suggested. The only person and authority that I have attacked is the minister and the BSA.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I rise to a point of order, if that is a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: I have a ruling on the previous point of order. That is not a point of order, member for Burnett.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I rise on a matter suddenly arising from what the honourable member said. It is clear to me that the attack that was made on the BSA was an attack on the builder. It supported somebody who has been declared an unfit witness before an independent tribunal. That is your standard.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: That is not a point of order, Minister. If there is a matter of privilege I would ask that the member write to the Speaker and set out the matter of privilege claim.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Further Answer to Question; Forestry Plantations Queensland
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (11.59 am), by leave: During question time in a response to a question from the member for Condamine I said that post sale of FPQ workers would be guaranteed employment for two years when I should have said three years.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: International Women’s Day; Bligh Labor Government
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.59 am): It is my pleasure to rise today especially given the acknowledgement by the Premier yesterday of International Women’s Day. It is not hard to see where women across Queensland who hold positions of leadership have taken their inspiration from. We honour the first woman to lead a political party in Queensland, the LNP’s Joan Sheldon--the first woman to exercise the powers and responsibilities of Premier when she became Acting Premier at various periods between 1996 and 1998. We honour the first woman to hold a cabinet position in Queensland--the LNP’s Yvonne Chapman, breaking the glass ceiling. We honour the first and only female Lord Mayor of Brisbane--the LNP’s Sallyanne Atkinson. We honour Dame Annabelle Rankin, who in 1946 for the Liberal Party became the first Queensland woman to sit in the federal parliament when she took her seat in the Senate. And who can forget Irene Longman from the Country and Progressive National Party--the first woman elected to this place in 1929. We also remember fondly today that 14 years ago the coalition became the first government in Queensland to introduce paid maternity leave for the Public Service--not Labor. It was the LNP that introduced paid maternity leave to recognise working women in the public sector.

This government goes from joke to farce. This morning in question time we saw that the Premier’s own union, the ASU--also the union of the Deputy Premier, the Minister for Climate Change, the Minister for Primary Industries and the Minister for Transport--has put out press releases saying that the ASU continues not to support the position of the state government on the privatisation of assets matter and that ‘members are encouraged to attend rallies against the sale of assets in their local communities’. But of course with ASU members rallying outside today, did we see the Premier or those ministers or any of these Labor ministers having the intestinal fortitude to go out and face them? No, we did not! They would not face their own members!

Of course in the last week we have had the spectacle of this Labor Premier admitting that after 12 years of the Beattie and Bligh governments--after 12 years of telling the people of Queensland that they will fix it, that Queenslanders can count on Labor--they have finally given in to what has been obvious to Queenslanders for some time: Labor cannot run hospitals or health. Last week Kevin Rudd delivered a massive vote in Premier Anna Bligh and state Labor. On Tuesday last week we saw the start of the final act of a desperate Premier and a desperate health minister who, having admitted their own failure in running Queensland Health, have taken the first step towards handing over the running of Queensland hospitals to Kevin Rudd and Nicola Roxon.

In the last 12 years let us look at what this tired Labor government has given us. It has given us four health ministers, with one of those ministers in jail for taking secret commissions. It has given us an explosion in waiting lists. It has given us an explosion in waiting lists to get on the waiting lists. It has given us a cut in the available number of hospital beds. It has been slammed by the Auditor-General for a total failure of planning for Queensland’s future health needs. It has given us queues of ambulances parked outside public hospitals trying to get patients in but being told there is no bed available. It has overseen a system that has hundreds of children each month failing to be treated within reasonable times in Queensland’s emergency departments.

So bad is the government at running Queensland’s hospitals that the Premier thinks that the federal government--the same government that cannot even safely install roof insulation--is better placed to manage Queensland hospitals than a state Labor health minister. This is a minister who is strangely quiet about matters of health but who carries on like Foghorn Leghorn about everything he thinks he can score political points on in this House every morning in question time. What an amazing admission! Kevin Rudd cannot fix a roof, but he is still better than state Labor at organising brain surgery, or so the Premier would have us believe. So there you have it: Kevin Rudd’s ministers and thousands of health bureaucrats in Canberra directing which regional health authorities get money for a brain surgery here, a heart transplant there. I can see it now: every muck-up by a Rudd-run hospital, every botched operation and every decision of a nameless, faceless bureaucrat in Canberra being appealed to the Commonwealth health minister will result in them then saying, ‘It’s not my problem! It’s not my decision! Don’t blame us! We just take the GST money and burn it up on Commonwealth bureaucracy.’

In the last week the people of Queensland have seen a Premier whose government has gone from bad to worse. This Premier and her Treasurer continue to thumb their noses at their own supporters. She continues to drive her ham-fisted campaign to sell off the state’s assets in a fire sale. She is on the verge of destroying the state’s finances for generations to come by taking steps down the road to handing to the Commonwealth 30 per cent of Queensland’s GST revenue. I know, she knows and every member of this House knows that if Kevin Rudd is allowed to unpick the GST deal and steal Queensland’s money the whole fabric of Commonwealth-state financial relations starts to fall to pieces, and the people of Queensland will be the big losers in the long run. If we hand over the lion’s share of Queensland’s GST money for hospitals, what next? The money for schools, for roads perhaps? At what point will the state government ever be responsible for running services ever again?

Not only would our hospitals, schools and roads infrastructure be horribly messed up for future generations to fix, but everyone in Queensland knows that state taxes will have to rise to pay for all of the new bureaucracy and so-called reform. I challenge the Premier and her government to give an ironclad guarantee that state taxes, charges, fees and levies will not rise to make up the GST shortfall. We all know that she cannot guarantee it and will not guarantee it, because she cannot. The state will have to go scrambling for more revenue and greater taxes like a whale that cannot get enough plankton, and the Bligh government will have to suck in more and more taxes to make up for the money she has gifted to Kevin Rudd.

Does anyone actually think that the amount Queensland Health spends will go down by the same amount that we pass over to the Commonwealth? Of course it will not! When we hand over our public hospitals, the cost of running health in Queensland will remain almost the same and the state will no longer have the rivers of gold that it used to have to fund Queensland Health. Queensland gets $7.839 billion of the $42.3 billion GST pool. That is about 18 per cent of the GST pool. If respected economist Henry Ergas is correct and the states in total stand to lose $140 billion over 10 years, the people of Queensland will lose $25.94 billion over 10 years--an enormous amount of money for the state to give up. To make matters worse, the Premier has not rebuffed the Treasurer for saying that he was happy to hand over Queensland’s mineral royalty scheme for a federal resource rent tax to be shared among the other five states, two territories and the Commonwealth government. This Premier and Treasurer simply will not stand up for Queensland. They are happy to do Kevin Rudd’s dirty work and in doing so are putting our state back decades.

Let us be very clear: I will stand up for Queensland against Canberra and Kevin Rudd. Our nation is supposed to work on the principle of cooperative federalism. This announcement by Kevin Rudd and the Premier’s likely capitulation means that cooperative federalism is dead. State governments are to become nothing more than branch offices of Labor Inc. The stench of arrogance and incompetence from this Premier, her Treasurer and her health minister continues to get stronger and stronger by the day. The Treasurer as recently as last Friday said that the Solar Hot Water Program would continue to be rolled out. Today it is cancelled. This Labor state government delivers another broken promise!

In a desperate bid to cling to anything, change the news story and divert attention from the ever-dysfunctional government that she leads, the Premier and the Treasurer this morning have resorted to throwing mud. Last week they decided to attack me for doing my job in readying the LNP for the next election and presenting to the people of Queensland the change and new direction that the people of Queensland so desperately need. When I announced that former Prime Minister John Howard was going to come and speak to the LNP party room, the Premier attacked me. She had the temerity to say that we were desperate. John Howard showed what good governments can and should do: good governments pay off Labor debt. I have invited him to come and speak to my troops because if we are elected we will be facing the same problem that John Howard and Peter Costello had when they were elected in 1996. I make no apologies for ensuring that my team is prepared for government and that we have learnt from those who have gone before us, because we know that we will be left with almost $85 billion in state government debt racked up by this Premier and her Treasurer.

John Howard and his government got the nation’s books in order. We on this side of the House are proud of the legacy left by titans such as John Howard and Peter Costello. Paul Keating was an abject financial failure, Gough Whitlam nearly destroyed the nation’s economy and Bob Hawke will help out only if you pay him a fee. As I said, I make no apologies for inviting John Howard. The Bligh government is in terminal decline and reeks of hubris. As one Labor Premier so eloquently put it many years ago, the people of Queensland are waiting on their porches with baseball bats. This time, the baseball bats are directed at this arrogant Premier. The government is utterly tired and worn out. It is time for another mutiny on the bounty and this ‘Captain’ Bligh is destined to be thrown overboard too.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (12.10 pm): The Bligh government is planning for the future growth of Queensland’s state schools in the Toowoomba region. Last Thursday, I had the pleasure to represent the Hon. Geoff Wilson in announcing that the Department of Education and Training has now finalised the purchase of a block of land at Highfields. The 10.15 hectares on O’Brien Road, bounded by Polzin and Kleinton roads, was purchased as a school site for the future. The move is part of the state government’s forward planning to cater for population growth throughout the state. We are delivering on yet another election commitment with the purchase of this land. Queensland’s population continues to grow and this land will be set aside to ensure that we can meet the future education infrastructure needs of the region. When the time arises, the community will be fully consulted about any potential projects on the land. We are, of course, always keen to gain community feedback on education needs and requirements.

It was an election commitment by the Bligh government for the purchase of the land at Highfields for a future secondary school. The Treasurer promised to commit $2.5 million for this purpose. I understand, however, that the final cost was more than that, but the actual figure is commercial-in-confidence. I am particularly pleased that, after a very long effort on behalf of the local community, this land, which is a most ideal location, has been secured. Soon after being elected as the member for Toowoomba North, the need to secure this particular site was made very clear to me. In 2001 or 2002--I forget now which year--I had the pleasure of accompanying the then minister for education, the Hon. Anna Bligh, around Highfields indicating the need to secure this site. Over the years many Highfields residents have worked extremely hard with me to achieve this goal. Of special note are the members of the Highfields State School community, led by Bronwyn Cairns and Councillor Bill Cahill, who, along with other Crows Nest councillors and the then mayor, Geoff Patch, were long-time advocates. Last Thursday was a truly historic day for Highfields, as it ensured that future generations of Highfields residents would have their own secondary school facilities within the centre of Highfields itself. The location of this site is particularly handy to existing sport and cultural facilities, such as the Highfields Cultural Centre, the swimming pool, the indoor sports centre, and it is opposite a large expanse of land that is designated for future sporting or open community use space.

Education advancement for the Highfields area has always been of the highest priority for the Beattie and Bligh governments. How has that priority been demonstrated? Firstly, by their support for the Mary MacKillop Catholic School on Highfields Road through the three stages of its development. This school has received the lion’s share of its funding for its construction from the state government. It now has a student population of around 400. Likewise, Highfields State School, which has a population of over 800 students, is a great state school and has received attention when it has been needed from time to time. For example, the latest major infrastructure project--that is the building of a $3 million state-of-the art auditorium--is a splendid project involving a partnership with the local school community through the P&C, the federal government via the Building the Education Revolution, and the state government. The state government’s contribution is substantial indeed. In round figures, it is about $1 million, half of which is coming from the education department and the other half from Sport and Recreation.

Conscious as I am of the privilege to be the member for Toowoomba North, which includes the splendid locality of Highfields, I must say that when I was first elected in 2001 the area lacked greatly in terms of public infrastructure. I am very pleased now to advise the House that, since that time, government infrastructure is now in place in addition to the educational assets to which I have referred. For example, there is the four-laning, with three sets of traffic lights, of the New England Highway through Highfields, the new electricity substation at Meringandan Road and the further $12 million substation--

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (12.15 pm): Today, I want to inform the House of the great work being done by our SES volunteers during the current flood situation, which has devastated much of inland Queensland. Last Friday morning, I had the very great pleasure of representing Neil Roberts, the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services, at the Ipswich SES depot. I was there at about 6 am to share a breakfast and to congratulate and encourage 75 volunteers from around South-East Queensland, dressed in orange overalls, who were about to head out the gate on the long road to Charleville and places beyond. Of the total of 75 people deployed to Charleville last Friday, 73 were SES volunteers and two were Emergency Management Queensland staff liaison officers. Of the 73 SES volunteers, 66 were general members and six were welfare officers. That deployment of volunteers towed with them a mobile kitchen and refrigeration unit as well as a couple of flood boats. That was done deliberately to allow the volunteers to be as self-sufficient as possible. That was necessary because the volunteers did not want to impact or impose on the local food supplies or, for that matter, any other resources. In fact, originally the volunteers were going to take tents for accommodation. However, after a few calls it was considered that the town hall would offer drier and eminently more suitable accommodation.

I should also point out that I believe that for the first time one of the SES volunteers was also a full-time QSA paramedic. I spoke to this volunteer over breakfast and I can report that he was very keen to assist with the deployment as it was his job to provide paramedic support as required to the members of the deployment. I am told that, as of yesterday afternoon, that paramedic had, in fact, treated nine SES volunteers for minor injuries. Again, this action was taken to avoid the volunteers having to draw on any of the medical facilities that were on the ground, which were stretched to the limit.

As members can imagine, the deployment travelled by road in convoy--in buses, four-wheel drives and utes. I am told that the journey took about 12 hours with, thankfully, only one tyre puncture en route. To be honest, though, when I saw the back of the LandCruiser troop carrier loaded with volunteers, in some ways I felt that it was going to be a long journey for all involved.

Once on the scene the group was split into task forces Alpha and Alpha 1, which included the Brisbane region’s 33 SES volunteers, and Task Force Bravo, which contained the south-eastern region’s 40 volunteers. Task Force Bravo’s 40 volunteers included eight from Ipswich, 18 from Lowood and Somerset, nine from Logan and five from the Gold Coast. I had the pleasure of chatting with some of those volunteers and I can say that I have seldom seen people so focused on their objectives. As members could imagine, many of those volunteers were tradespeople, some were retired and some were simply there to do what they could.

I am advised that the deployment’s tasks were many and varied, but I can report that they were able to complete 98 tasks in their first two days and it was expected that they would assist in completing an additional 52 outstanding jobs yesterday. The volunteers were also doorknocking to check on the welfare of the residents. In fact, I am advised that they found one confused and elderly lady in her 90s to whom they were able to offer help. I am now advised that, currently, most of their work involves the cleaning of flood affected properties, such as the town library and the community centre, as well as some commercial properties. I understand that much of this cleaning was going on while the volunteers were working in unison with Ergon Energy, which was responsible for checking electrical safety at residential properties and, of course, as the minister pointed out before, the ever reliable QBuild, which is checking the structural integrity of buildings. As members could imagine, these services are extremely important as only once this was done was it possible for the SES volunteers to move into some of the residential properties.

I am advised that, from a residential perspective, the volunteers’ tasks included cleaning out houses, clearing out damaged fridges and removing damaged whitegoods, ripping up carpets, cleaning walls and floors and basically anything to help the residents. As well, it was also important for the volunteers to move damaged items to the footpath so that the council could collect them for removal.

Further to this, I can report today that an additional deployment--that is, Task Force Echo--has already departed Brisbane Airport by chartered flight to provide an additional 20 SES volunteers and one EMQ staff member to Charleville. They left at approximately 6 o’clock this morning and I understand that everything is going well. This means that 20 SES volunteers from the current deployment will be able to fly back to home on the return journey. I am also advised that these new volunteers will also sensibly use the existing SES vehicles that were driven out last Friday with a view to bringing them back on Saturday.

The current advice is that the floodwaters have reached a peak and it is expected they will recede slowly. This does not mean that the work is over. Far from it, in fact. Rest assured that this government will continue to do whatever it can to ensure that our country cousins are assisted in any way possible during this unfortunate event.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP)
(12.20 pm): With the recent good rains Wivenhoe Dam is filling rapidly. Today it is approximately 92 per cent full. Wivenhoe Dam was built in the late 1970s. In response to the floods that devastated Brisbane in 1974 it was constructed to have not just a large water supply capacity that has become the basis of our water supply today but also a considerable amount of extra storage volume to act as a flood buffer to help to manage future flooding in Brisbane. As Wivenhoe Dam today approaches full storage level, it is important to note that the full storage level is under half the possible storage level available in the dam. The full storage level is 1.15 million megalitres while the actual total storage available in Wivenhoe Dam is 2.6 million megalitres. In effect there is another Wivenhoe Dam over and above the one that was originally designed for water storage. This ‘extra’ Wivenhoe Dam was designed and built in the late 1970s as a flood buffer for Brisbane.

I believe that it is time to review the comparative uses of the total storage available in Wivenhoe Dam. I believe that more of the total available storage space should be used for water storage so that there is less chance of a water crisis developing in the future. Obviously the dam needs to continue to be operated to maintain a flood buffer for Brisbane and any decision about storing extra water will have an impact on the effectiveness of that dam’s flood buffer role, but this is a question of finding the right balance between the two roles that Wivenhoe Dam performs today. It is a question of reviewing the situation to determine whether the balance between those two roles that was struck in the early 1980s when the dam was completed is appropriate for the situation that exists today.

It is clear that much has changed since 1980. Brisbane and Queensland generally have experienced long periods of low rainfall resulting in a critical water crisis which saw the real possibility of the city running out of water entirely. Since that original decision was made in 1980, technology available to the dam managers has also advanced considerably. We are now able to forecast and predict the occurrence of rainfall events with much more accuracy and much more reliability than was ever thought possible 30 years ago. In addition, the automatic stream flow monitors and computer flow models allow for much better informed decision making in regard to managing any potential flood events. These advances alone make it possible to attain the same level of flood protection for Brisbane while using less of the available storage area in Wivenhoe Dam as a flood buffer. That frees up the additional volume for extra water storage that should be used to complement the available water for South-East Queensland and guard against another water crisis developing in the future.

A discussion paper prepared by Seqwater in 2005 found that an extra seven metres of water could be stored in the dam before there were any concerns about the long-term safety of the dam wall. A table in that report shows that just an extra two metres of storage in the dam--two metres out of the possible seven--would store an extra 228,000 megalitres of water and provide an extra no-fail yield of 31,000 megalitres per year to the water supply of South-East Queensland. That is roughly equivalent to what could reasonably be expected to be the annual total yield from the Tugun desalination plant. This proposal has the potential to significantly add to water supply reliability in South-East Queensland just by using an extra two metres of the seven metres that is available in Wivenhoe Dam for additional storage.

I believe it would be absurd to release water from Wivenhoe Dam at the current time. It would be absurd to allow any releases until this option is thoroughly investigated. I call on the minister today to ensure that no water is released from Wivenhoe Dam and that serious commitments are made to developing this proposal to increase the storage levels in Wivenhoe Dam. The water that is running into the dam at the moment may well be sorely needed in the future to avert another water crisis.

A quick look at the dam record shows that, under the current rules of operation, an amount of water equal to 30 per cent of the dam’s capacity was released in 1999 and then further smaller amounts were released in 2001 and 2002. Even if some of that water had been retained it would have made a huge difference in 2005 and 2006, when the people of Brisbane were facing the worst of the water crisis.

It is time the minister got serious about this issue. The Labor government has seriously mismanaged the water issue for many years. It has brought the city of Brisbane to the brink of running out of water. It then spent billions of dollars in panic on projects that are hideously expensive and grossly inefficient to run. It now thankfully has the opportunity to start to get it right. We need to make the best of our existing infrastructure--infrastructure that was provided by previous conservative governments and that has been poorly managed by the current Labor government.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of the school captains and teachers from Coombabah High School in the electorate of the member for Broadwater, whom I now call.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP)
(12.25 pm): I congratulate those students from Coombabah High School on their recent appointments as school captains and welcome them to the House today.

Heavy rain has brought much flooding across many parts of the state. Hardest hit has been the south-west including Townsville, Charleville, Roma and St George. There have been 63 SES volunteers from Brisbane and south-east regions activated in support of the south-west flood event. They arrived in Charleville and Roma on 5 March. An additional 20 SES volunteers were deployed to St George. SES members have also been activated to a number of other locations across the state.

Just yesterday some 23 SES volunteers were tarping roofs on the Sunshine Coast, undertaking storm damage operations in Brisbane and sandbagging and doing temporary roof repairs in the south-east. The deployment of SES volunteers demonstrates just how ready our SES volunteers are to swing into action in times of emergency and disaster.
