Their vital work will go some way to helping residents of Charleville, Roma and many other towns and suburbs get back on their feet.

There are over 6,800 active SES volunteers in Queensland but we always need more. The basic concept of the SES is one of self-help and mutual assistance within each community. This concept involves the community in all aspects of disaster and emergency activity including prevention, preparation, response and recovery measures that will help protect the community when disaster strikes.

Each year the SES receives thousands of calls for assistance via the SES hotline--132500--launched by this government. In the last six months alone there have been over 7,000 calls made to the SES hotline. During the same six-month period of 1 July 2009 to 31 January 2010 there were approximately 1,792 SES activations resulting in 31,839 operational hours being performed by SES members. This financial year the state will contribute a total of $14.068 million in direct funding to the SES.

As part of the government’s 2009 election commitment we will provide 20 SES vehicles, four SES flood boats and two SES rescue trailers this financial year. The state and local governments maintain an important partnership in assisting SES volunteers to provide a valuable volunteer emergency service to their local communities.

I pay tribute to our partners, BCF and NRMA, who supported our SES in 2009--BCF, through their 26 stores state-wide, asked customers to round up to the nearest dollar. These funds were totalled at $90,000 recorded and distributed to SES groups in each region equally to purchase additional ladders, portable lighting, hand-held navigation devices, computers and noticeboards. The NRMA have also provided significant funding to the SES to provide vital storm preparation messages to the public through TV, radio and print advertisements. I know that the Department of Community Safety looks forward to continuing its partnership with BCF and NRMA in 2010.

This month we have been reminded of the devastating impact of Mother Nature, but more importantly how vital our SES is. This government is committed to recruiting more emergency service volunteers. Last year I launched a new volunteer management strategy to help deliver on this government’s Q2 target of increasing the proportion of Queenslanders who volunteer in the community by 50 per cent. That is an ambitious target but one that we can certainly go a long way towards meeting. The volunteer management strategy will help to strengthen our volunteer management in terms of the recruitment, retention, support, recognition and management of volunteers. Assessing the number of Queensland volunteers who are trained and active provides a definite indicator of our state’s ability to respond to emergencies and disasters.

2010 has proved to be another busy year for emergency volunteers. On behalf of all Queenslanders, I thank our volunteers for their marvellous efforts. I urge anyone looking for an interesting and rewarding challenge in 2010 to consider joining their ranks. For more information on becoming a volunteer, people can visit the website www.emergency.qld.gov.au/volunteers.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (12.30 pm): Last week the Prime Minister outlined his proposal for the National Health and Hospitals Network, which is comprised of four principal points: firstly, corralling one-third of Queensland’s GST revenue to assist with funding public hospitals; secondly, the Commonwealth government becoming the major funder, providing 60 per cent of the efficient price of running the public hospital system, while the states provide the balance; thirdly, the way public hospitals are run will be moved from central authorities to what are termed local hospital networks or, as we in the LNP call them, local hospital boards; and fourthly, over time the Commonwealth will fund 100 per cent of the efficient price of primary healthcare equivalent outpatient services provided to public hospital patients. Within a matter of hours, the Queensland government and, in particular, the health minister had basically rolled over and accepted the federal government’s determination, despite significant and critical questions remaining to be answered.

No-one doubts the necessity for a change in the way the Queensland public hospital system is run. What is ironic is that it was Kevin Rudd, under Wayne Goss, who abolished Queensland’s regional hospital boards and put in place the current structure, which has strangled the delivery of health services in this state. It is equally ironic that, as Prime Minister, Mr Rudd has advocated local hospital networks, a body he took the axe to a number of years ago. Successive Queensland Labor governments under former Premier Beattie and the current Premier have continued to deliver the most appalling health outcomes for Queenslanders. Despite all the rhetoric, pamphlets and brochures, Queensland’s public health system continues to deteriorate, with quarterly performance reports showing greater and greater waiting lists, more ramping, increased access block and, generally, the withering of our once proud health system.

The proposal by the Prime Minister takes from Queensland’s budget one-third of the GST revenue. It is important to note that Nicola Roxon did not rule out an increase in taxes to pay for the new system. Despite the Prime Minister’s claim, there will be incredible pressure to increase the GST, and what guarantee does Queensland have that the third grab will not increase? The Queensland government appears not to be able to understand or comprehend the implications of what is proposed and the risks of a dual funding and reporting system. The policy announced by the Prime Minister gives no detail as to how it will be measured or what will be measured to determine the effectiveness of this change. There has been no rationale given as to what changes will occur in an operational sense to improve services, efficiency or the effectiveness of the system. It has purely been a statement about a shift in funding without any detail as to how this will actually improve the state of the healthcare system and address the many issues that confront us in health today.

For example, what measures will be put in place to determine if the funding is allowing for good patient care and patient outcomes? It would appear the focus is purely on numbers in terms of funding by numbers of patients treated without any consideration given to the effectiveness of the treatment. There is mention of a set of national standards but we have already a system of national standards through the Australian Council on Healthcare Standards, which was not referred to by the Prime Minister. There is no focus on the core business of health care, that is, how will this policy impact upon clinical outcomes, access and equity or workforce issues? The issue of waste has been mentioned in interviews, but no strategy to eliminate waste has been outlined. How will this shift in the funding mechanism relieve the pressures at the ward level or in the emergency department? These are just a few of the many questions that need to be considered in relation to this policy, as opposed to simply rolling over and accepting it.

The Queensland health minister has been loud and consistent in decrying the return to a local hospital board structure, saying that we would be going back to the days of a bygone era and that they were failures. It is clear that he was not listening to local clinicians, that he was not listening to local nurses and that he was not listening to local people in the various regions across the state including Cairns, Townsville, Mount Isa, Rockhampton, Ingham, Brisbane and the Gold Coast. It is clear also that Kevin Rudd did not bother to listen to him. At least on one issue, that of local hospital boards, Kevin Rudd and the LNP are in agreement. The LNP will not be supporting this proposal, but will continue to work with all clinicians on a local level to empower local hospital boards to deliver better and more efficient outcomes.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (12.35 pm): One of the most exciting areas of reform for the Beattie and Bligh governments has been in education. We have reintroduced the prep year, ensured all young people are learning or earning until they are 17, rebuilt many schools, put an increased emphasis on literacy and numeracy, and reduced class sizes in the middle years. More recently, we have started building or expanding 240 kindergartens and have increased funding to long-day-care centres so they may provide a kindergarten service. This will give all young children the flying start to education that they need. However, our plans do not end there. The Bligh Labor government believes that a good education is the best start that any government can give a child. That is why the Premier recently released some proposals for further improvement to our education system.

Last Monday night I was very pleased to host a forum at Albany Hills State School to discuss the new education proposals. At this point, I would like to thank the principal and staff of Albany Hills State School, who hosted the forum with me. Despite it being a very rainy night, 65 parents, teachers and principals attended, which reflects the level of interest in these ideas. It was a very fruitful night with lots of discussion about the pros and cons of the government’s proposals. On balance, the proposals were positively received. Parents welcome the government’s support for reading, both at home and at school. They support the government’s proposal to further lift school standards through the creation of a new, independent standards authority.

Not surprisingly, most debate surrounded the government’s proposal to shift year 7 to secondary school. A number of the forum attendees acknowledged the inevitability of this move, given schools across Australia are moving to a national curriculum. In most other states, year 7 is in secondary school and those students have access to specialist teachers in science, maths and other subjects. With Queensland adopting the national curriculum, Queensland students also deserve access to teachers with specialist content knowledge. Indeed, one parent at the forum, who is also a secondary teacher, mentioned that the rigour of the national curriculum will mean that teachers of year 7 subjects will increasingly require specialist knowledge in order to teach that curriculum. While some parents present at the forum accepted this move, others were concerned by this prospect, and I understand that concern.

The concern of a number of parents centred on the risk to their children, when they reach year 7, in mixing with students in higher year levels. Those parents said that they would feel more comfortable with moving year 7 to secondary school if secondary schools established a middle school for years 7, 8 and 9. Middle schools exist in many Queensland schools at the moment and they have proven to work well. I think this suggestion from parents has a lot of merit and I have asked the Minister for Education to consider adopting it, should the government decide to move year 7 to secondary school.

The other major concern raised at the forum involved how schools would be resourced if this proposal goes ahead. This was a particular concern for the school staff who attended the forum. Currently, schools receive resources such as deputy principals, physical education teachers and instrumental music teachers based on their enrolment numbers. School staff are concerned that, if year 7 is moved, they will receive fewer resources. Again, I have discussed this with the Minister for Education. He has assured me that the connection between enrolment numbers and school resources will be considered in the implementation of this proposal and it will not automatically result in a loss of resources for primary schools.

It is true that this government has been in power for a significant period of time. However, these proposals show that we have not run out of ideas on how to improve Queensland. Our previous reforms have already boosted education and training in Queensland. Our literacy and numeracy performance has improved, our teachers are better paid, and we have more Queenslanders graduating with post-school qualifications than ever before. Education is critical to a person’s life chances. The more we can do to give all young Queenslanders a quality education, the more chances they have to succeed in life. These proposals represent the next great wave of reform for Queensland schools. I will continue to advocate for these reforms, but also for the government to take on board the feedback received at the forum held in the Everton electorate last week. I would like to thank all who attended the forum last week. I appreciate them all taking time out of their busy lives to help us make Queensland’s education system even better.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (12.39 pm): In June last year I informed the House of mistakes made by the Minister for Public Work’s department regarding asbestos removal at Caningeraba State School. Despite initial denials that these were mere allegations and the minister’s verbal abuse of a concerned parent, the minister finally admitted that there were errors that ‘warranted my close attention’. This close attention resulted in an internal QBuild investigation and an external investigation by Workplace Health and Safety Queensland. The damning report found that QBuild had failed to comply with its own policies and procedures regarding asbestos handling. Failures included documents requiring updating, inconsistencies with legislative requirements, terms of notification, access to the school’s asbestos register, access permits generally and work method statements.

Finally revealing these findings to the House some three months after the incident, the minister not only claimed that QBuild would implement all recommendations from the said report but insisted that ‘this must never happen again’. The minister cannot claim that this was a one-off incident. Such behaviour has happened before and has happened again--this time at Mackay West State School in December 2009. Once again this minister has shown that the only thing he takes seriously is avoiding responsibility. He ignores reports that he himself ordered. The minister claims that QBuild employs a suitably qualified contractor in all instances where such a licence is required. Evidence from Mackay West State School shows that this has not happened. It is alleged that QBuild went to Programmed Maintenance Services, who were contracted to clean this site, and directed them to backdate a workplace statement to December 2009 stating that workers were trained in asbestos handling when they were not. I table photos of workers cleaning up the site.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Photographs of asbestos removal.
XML.Hansard-Body: One of them, Mr Farnham, has been sacked for speaking out. Like a broken record we heard how seriously the minister takes asbestos, how much it has personally affected him. Yet, despite these protests of feigned outrage, despite these reports which point out where training and procedures are inadequate, despite his word that ‘this must never happen again’, it has. The Bligh government’s attitude of silencing decent accredited workers and telling others to turn a blind eye is why so many people label the way the government handles asbestos removals as ‘dangerous cowboy operations’.

A recent accusation that QBuild representative Bill Paton has destroyed a Mackay asbestos removalist’s business and along with it 28 jobs since the December incident deserves close attention. The aggrieved contractor, Jayson Maskell-Drew of Asbestos Removal Technology, believes Mr Paton should be called to account for his actions and claims that Mr Paton took it upon himself to inform the contractor’s client Townsend Building Services Mackay that he will preclude them from tendering on any jobs if they intend to use him or his company as the asbestos removalist. I note that my colleague the member for Moggill has seen fit to write to the CMC, asking it to investigate official misconduct, and I fully support this move.

If this is how QBuild and the Queensland government treat companies who comply with the code and do not take short cuts, then it gives you a pretty good idea of how lightly they take asbestos removal and mock their own code of practice. Now the minister has been forced to order another investigation--this time supposedly an independent one, with firm Ashdown Integrity Services, but he has enrolled staff from Project Services to provide technical support. Where is the independence in that? Queenslanders could be forgiven for thinking we have our own Peter Garrett here in the form of the Minister for Public Works. The issue that is of greatest concern is ensuring that all government employees whose jobs give them a reasonable prospect of encountering hazardous substances such as asbestos are given the proper training to prepare them to deal with this substance.

QBuild had 944 field staff as at 4 August 2009. Of those 944 staff, not one of them holds an ‘A’ class asbestos removal licence. Furthermore, only 66 per cent of QBuild staff have completed asbestos specific training and hold a ‘B’ class asbestos removal licence. Why has the minister not ensured that all QBuild field staff have received this training? The evidence is clear that the current training system is not working to protect QBuild employees or the general public. How many people have been contaminated by this government’s sloppiness?

In government, the LNP will not simply pay lip-service to the safe removal of asbestos. We will ensure that there is adequate training for QBuild staff who handle it. Breaching of procedures will not be tolerated or swept under the carpet so to speak. Companies without appropriate training, such as Programmed Maintenance Services, will not be employed to handle asbestos without trained employees. Independent audits will be just that, not the same company conducting both, as happens now. And we will implement a regulatory body with teeth. Allegations that companies have committed serious breaches and bringing in workers from interstate to work in our schools is a slap in the face for Queenslanders and exposes the Bligh government’s jobs, jobs, jobs mantra as a complete farce.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (12.44 pm): I rise to speak about the recent decision to provide community space at Wacol, in the neighbouring electorate of Inala, following my representations on behalf of my local community over many years. Before my election to the electorate of Mount Ommaney in 1998, the then Leader of the Opposition, Peter Beattie, committed future Labor governments to ensuring that there will be no future prisons built at Wacol after I campaigned with members of the local group called CRAMP, the Concerned Residents Against More Prisons group.

The Premier, Anna Bligh, has reaffirmed that position and confirmed that the government has purchased land at Gatton to provide land for future prisons in South-East Queensland without the need for an additional prison at Wacol. In 2006, I successfully pursued the Beattie cabinet on behalf of the community to quash the Westgate proposal for housing development on the Wacol site. The then Premier, Peter Beattie, on 2 August 2006 promised to make available Corrective Services land at Wacol for public recreation and open space. Our Premier, Anna Bligh, has now asked Queensland Corrective Services to ensure that land is made available for appropriate public access in suitable areas of the site.

The Premier outlined in a meeting with the Centenary and District Environment Action group at the western suburbs community cabinet late last year that her aim was to ensure that there is appropriate public access to that vast tract of Corrective Services land at Wacol. This is consistent with previous undertakings of the government which ensures that community safety is maintained. Any decision regarding access will be based on issues relating to community safety and the effective management of correctional facilities. The community appreciates that safe and secure prison operations require reasonable buffer zones between prison infrastructure and residential and community areas. These buffer zones protect the community by minimising public contact with offenders and reduce the likelihood of security incidents.

Given Queensland Corrective Services is not equipped to manage public reserves, it has liaised with the Brisbane City Council on managing land for public access at Wacol--that is, QCS will transfer land not required for a buffer to Brisbane City Council for community space. QCS has indicated that there is approximately 60 to 70 hectares of land that it can transfer to the Brisbane City Council to manage for community space. This 60 to 70 hectares is in addition to the 17 hectares of playing field already ceded to the Brisbane City Council and leased to the Centenary junior rugby league club, the 40 hectares of land north of Wolston Creek ceded to the Brisbane City Council as public recreation and the 40 hectares south of Wolston Creek that Brisbane City Council will replant and manage on behalf of QCS. The land remaining with QCS will be about one-third of the size of the original holding. The remaining approximately 70 hectares of land is required for correctional use and will be used as a buffer zone. While this land will not have public access, in line with the Premier’s commitment, it will not be used to build a new prison and will be open space.

Generally in town planning the term ‘open space and recreation’ refers to public and private land that contributes to the recreation, conservation, biodiversity or landscape and amenity of an area. It may include land which does not allow public access, and there are a number of local government planning schemes that use this definition. Accordingly, the essential buffer zone required to ensure community safety will be retained as open space. It is the government’s intention to selectively replant this land to ensure a clear demarcation of non-public access areas and deliver an ecological benefit for the area that can provide a habitat for wildlife without being disturbed by further encroachment.

The Wacol Land Use Working Party, which I initialised in March last year, will work with the proposed allocation of land and its future uses according to the needs of the community and the local member of Inala, who has jurisdiction over that part of her electorate. The Premier, Anna Bligh, acknowledges the strong representations that I have made to the former Premier in relation to quashing the proposed Westgate development and his subsequent decision to use this space for the community. The community appreciates that I have lobbied hard on this issue for many years to all Corrective Services ministers and instigated the formation of the current working group. I acknowledge the important role of the Centenary and District Environment Action group and the part they have played in supporting my representations to government.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (12.49 pm): On Friday and Saturday in Rockhampton and Gladstone respectively groups of angry and frustrated people met and marched to again highlight the concerns of QR workers, their families and supporters, as well as union members across many unions at this government’s proposal to sell assets. In Rockhampton I am advised that approximately 300 people marched. In Gladstone, 75 to 100 people marched or met at the park to hear speakers expressing concerns in relation to this government’s asset sale proposal.

At both events participants were invited to sign a retirement card addressed to the Premier and the Treasurer, as participants remain of the opinion that, if the Premier and Treasurer continue in their plan to sell the assets as proposed, they or their party will be unsuccessful at the next election. So great is the feeling that comments on the card include: ‘After 22 years of voting Labor, next election will see me change that’. This family signed their names clearly and without equivocation, such is the feeling of many long-term Labor voters.

Additionally, Craig Giddins from the ETU, on behalf of those in attendance at the meeting, requested that I pass on to the Premier and Treasurer along with the retirement card this game of Monopoly. It is not any game of Monopoly but the Australian version as modified by Craig and others. The front reads: ‘Monopoly--The Australian Here and Now--Sold Tomorrow Edition’. The board has been overlaid with pertinent new properties--our ports, our forests and our railways. It was stated at the meeting that perhaps a few games of Monopoly would bring home to the Premier and the Treasurer that one of the fundamentals of the game is not to sell your utilities. Properties may come and go. However, the utilities are proven money earners. In the real world it must also be acknowledged that affordable services such as power, water, transport, health, education and the like undergird the health, confidence and prosperity of a community. These strategic assets are most wisely operated by the people through their elected government.

I am on the record here and elsewhere opposing the sale of strategic assets. The people I speak to daily express concern that the government is selling those assets which are actually earning this state an income. For one single injection of funds, the government is intending to dispense with, in the case of QR coal freight, not only an asset which earns a significant return to state coffers but also an income stream which shows exponential growth.

While this government offers job security for two or three years after the sale of rail, ports and forestries, the reality is that, once sold, the government loses control and influence in these areas. The Premier has stated in this chamber that the sale of QR coal freight will create additional jobs. That has not been the case in the sale of Telstra, which is the closest sale size wise to QR. Workers there have been sacked in their thousands, and QR employees feel betrayed and isolated. People are angry that this government is not listening to their concerns.

I would place on the record thanks to Phil Golby and Craig Giddins, who have been organising these events, for allowing people in the community to express their dissatisfaction and frustration. Thanks also to the hundreds who turn out to these peaceful demonstrations. The demonstration outside this building today further reinforces the strength of feeling about this government’s proposed asset sales. Across the state there is significant opposition. We should not be following the ‘privatise, profits; socialise, losses’ mantra.

I seek leave to table the card and Monopoly set for those concerned residents of Rockhampton and Gladstone, and again ask this government to reconsider its proposal to sell assets in direct conflict with the wishes of the majority of Queenslanders.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Could the member for Gladstone please indicate what the game attempted to be tabled represents?

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: It is a game of Monopoly. As I said in my speech, the people who offered this as a gift to the Premier and to the Treasurer believe that, in playing it, they would get a better understanding of the financial management of public utilities.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: In terms of the card, it is capable of storage. In terms of the game, it would appear that it is not a suitable item to be tabled, unless it can be tabled in a paper form which is capable of storage.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Retirement card to the Premier and Treasurer regarding the sale of assets.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (12.54 pm): The Bligh government is fully committed to supporting growth in the drive tourism market. That is why we committed $37.8 million last March to support tourism in the state through our three-year Tourism Action Plan to 2012, which included $1.8 million for the development of minor infrastructure on Queensland’s strategic drive tourism routes. An important part of this plan is building the lucrative drive tourism market throughout regional Queensland.

Drive tourism is all about holiday-makers and overseas travellers who get in their cars, campervans and motorhomes to experience Queensland regions, and in turn boost the economies of our towns and communities. It is a huge money-spinner, with drive tourism worth more than $4 billion and accounting for around 70 per cent of the overnight leisure market. To meet the expectations of our tourists and encourage more to come, we know that we have to improve our facilities and infrastructure such as toilets, roadside picnic areas, rubbish bins, walkways, and signage and information sites.

The government’s Minor Tourism Infrastructure Grants Scheme is working to attract and encourage tourists to stay longer in our regions by offering grants of up to $50,000 to communities for local infrastructure projects. Last year the scheme provided more than $580,000 for 15 projects in regional Queensland. These projects included the installation of a viewing platform and stairs for tourists to visit the dinosaur footprints at the Mount Morgan mine site on the Matilda Highway; the construction of shade, shelter and picnic settings at the front of the Queensland Heritage Park complex in Biloela; and the construction and installation of an ecofriendly toilet on the Bedourie-Windorah road at the truck stop, and placement of refuse points at tourist stops in that shire.

The visitor experience in the Burke and Doomadgee shires will be improved by the development and installation of 20 directional signs and interpretive signage. Existing facilities and infrastructure on our strategic drive tourism routes can often be many kilometres apart--something that can be frustrating for both motorists and tour operators alike. That is why this program targets regions that are popular for driving holidays and special interest experiences.

Last week in Cairns we announced the opening of round 2 of this program, which closes on 30 April. Up to $600,000 in grants will be available this year to local government authorities and regional tourism, development and community organisations to improve facilities in their regions. The program will further enhance Queensland’s reputation with travellers and support more jobs throughout the state. I know there is significant interest in upgrading and building new roadside infrastructure right across the targeted routes, so I urge as many organisations as possible to apply for the grants.

These sorts of improvements not only make a very positive impact on the drive tourism market and further enhance Queensland’s reputation with travellers but also lead to more jobs in regional towns. In tropical North Queensland the Great Tropical Drive between Cooktown and Townsville is an identified route, and we know that previous marketing of this route has been a great success. Other routes include The Adventure Way between St George and the South Australian border; the Great Inland Way between Charters Towers and Dirranbandi; the Capricorn Highway between Rockhampton and Barcaldine; the Leichhardt Highway between Theodore and Goondiwindi; and the Warrego Highway between Dalby and Charleville.

As well as trying to improve the drive tourism market, the Bligh government is also committed to luring the international market back, particularly to the tropical north. Aviation will be the key to this recovery in 2010. Over the past few weeks the region has welcomed an increased number of Chinese visitors as a result of additional China Southern Airlines charter flights over the Chinese new year period. In the year ahead the local tourism industry can also look forward to the introduction of a new Virgin Blue group international service between Auckland and Cairns. The Pacific Blue flights will operate twice-weekly services, representing a 79 per cent increase in available seats on the route. In addition, Continental Airlines will operate a daily service from Guam to Cairns from 17 March to 6 April to meet an increased demand from Japan and Guam. In April the tropical north will see the arrival of 17 new flights per week from Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide and Perth, adding just over 3,000 weekly seats. April arrivals will also include resumed direct flights between Osaka, Japan and Cairns. The four-weekly Jetstar flights will add up to 1,200 seats for the region per week, which equates to approximately 63,000 seats per year. The Bligh government along with Tourism Queensland will continue to work together to ensure the future of Queensland’s tourism industry grows strongly.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The time for matters of public interest has expired.
Sitting suspended from 12.59 pm to 2.30 pm.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (2.30 pm), by leave: The issue of probity on one of the five businesses the state is putting to the market was raised in the House this morning. This is an issue of the utmost importance to this government. It goes to the heart of the sale process and indeed to the integrity of those parties involved.

Through all of the sales processes independent probity advisers have been involved, providing independent oversight of the transactions. After the somewhat bizarre question asked by the member for Clayfield this morning, I can advise the House that I have received correspondence from the probity adviser confirming that the sale of FPQ is being conducted under appropriate probity protocols. I table a signed letter from the probity adviser for the benefit of the House, but in particular for the benefit of the member for Clayfield.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 9 March 2010, from Rory O’Connor, Managing Director, O’Connor Marsden & Associates to Mr Graeme Garrett, Commercial Transaction Team--Treasury, regarding probity protocols.
XML.Hansard-Body: I can also confirm that specific protocols have been distributed to FPQ which set out rules for the management of inquiries from the public in relation to the sale process and the interaction with customers and potential bidders for the FPQ business and assets. This is standard practice in both the public and private sector.

To question this reflects very poorly on the shadow Treasurer. No-one is under any illusion about the importance of maintaining the integrity of the sale process. Again, this is standard practice in a sale process of this nature. The suggestion from the shadow Treasurer that such probity protocols should be set aside is at best ill-informed and ultimately frighteningly irresponsible.
Mr NICHOLLS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I made no such suggestion. I find his comments offensive and ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): The member has asked for those comments to be withdrawn.
Mr FRASER: I withdraw. At this point I merely ask members to reflect upon the record of the House. As I said, the suggestion is at best ill-informed and ultimately frightening irresponsible.
Mr NICHOLLS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is exactly the point I raised before.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Clayfield, hold on. Minister take your seat. There is a point of order. I call the member for Clayfield.
Mr NICHOLLS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is exactly the same point I made a moment ago. I made no such suggestion and I find the words offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr FRASER: I withdraw and I note that he did not suggest that they were untrue. Our commitment to integrity and probity--
Mr NICHOLLS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, take your seat! The member for Clayfield.

Mr NICHOLLS: If the Treasurer is going to play semantics, he ought to withdraw and withdraw without qualification. He has just made a qualification about the truth or otherwise of the statements made. I find them offensive.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Clayfield, I understood that and I was going to get to that as well. Treasurer, I seek your withdraw without qualification.

Mr FRASER: I withdraw without qualification. Members of the House should understand that our commitment to integrity and probity is about acting in the interests of taxpayers and the suggestion from the shadow Treasurer this morning is one which reflects very poorly upon him and--
Mr NICHOLLS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Treasurer, please take your seat. Member for Clayfield.
Mr NICHOLLS: This is now the third time that the Treasurer has said that I made a suggestion. I made no such suggestion. I find the comments that I did offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr Fraser: I didn’t reflect upon him then.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Treasurer, I would ask that you withdraw those comments unreservedly.

Mr FRASER: I withdraw. Our commitment to integrity and probity is about acting in the interests of taxpayers. Any suggestion to the contrary provides a window on the way in which such matters would be dealt with under the alternative government in this state and therefore reflects very poorly on the opposition in this state given that it is providing a suggestion that the probity protocols, appropriate in these circumstances, would be set aside in such a transaction. This is standard practice. I refer all members, especially the member for Clayfield, to the advice provided by the probity advisers to this transaction.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (2.34 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Community Ambulance Cover Act 2003, the Duties Act 2001, the First Home Owner Grant Act 2000, the GST and Related Matters Act 2000, the Infrastructure Investment (Asset Restructuring and Disposal) Act 2009, the Land Tax Act 1915, the Pay-roll Tax Act 1971, the State Financial Institutions and Metway Merger Facilitation Act 1996, the Superannuation (State Public Sector) Act 1990, the Taxation Administration Act 2001 and the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition (Queensland) Act 2003 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
Tabled paper: Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (2.35 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 amends the state’s revenue legislation to maintain its currency and ensure it operates as intended. Many amendments are beneficial in that they provide new or extended exemptions and concessions or clarify the operation of the legislation, which will assist both taxpayers and the Office of State Revenue. A number of these beneficial amendments will have retrospective effect reflecting the fact that some exemptions and concessions have been operating on an administrative basis. Some other relatively minor amendments are also being made. The remaining amendments are necessary to protect the integrity of the state’s revenue laws.

A number of beneficial changes to the Duties Act 2001 are included in the bill including ‘top hatting’ relief for the property industry. New exemptions from duty for certain restructuring of stapled entities which meet the requirements for the Commonwealth’s capital gains tax rollover relief and other conditions. The exemptions will facilitate the adoption of more efficient operating structures.

Other changes include: reassessment and refund provision for cancelled transfers; extending access to the home concession provisions for home buyers who acquire a lease of a home rather than the freehold title; extending the exemption for transfer of an interest in a home from one spouse or de facto partner by way of gift to situations where an existing mortgage is involved; providing an exemption for transfers resulting from the incorporation under the Commonwealth’s Corporations Act 2001 of an incorporated association which satisfies certain conditions; and providing a discretion to extend the start date for use of a property for a qualifying exempt purpose by a charitable institution. Some beneficial changes are also being made to the Community Ambulance Cover Act 2003.

The bill also contains important measures to ensure that the integrity of revenue laws is protected and that the revenue legislation operates as intended. On 14 January 2010, I announced changes to the insurance duty provisions in relation to life insurance riders and certain insurers to be effective from that date. The bill gives effect to the announced changes. To ensure the integrity of the self-assessment regime for duties, effective management of self-assessor noncompliance is critical. The bill extends the Commissioner of State Revenue’s powers to suspend a self-assessor’s registration by providing for immediate suspension where there is an immediate unacceptable risk of noncompliance with the self-assessor’s statutory obligations. This amendment is a necessary protective measure to ensure the public interest is preserved and consumers can be protected from potential loss.

The Pay-roll Tax Act 1971 will be amended, with effect from 1 July 2009, to change the territorial nexus for wages paid to employees who provide services in more than one jurisdiction. These national changes, announced on 29 June 2009, are necessary following a decision by all jurisdictions to change the nexus rules from 1 July 2009. All registered payroll tax clients were notified of the change and given the option of either switching to the new nexus arrangements from 1 July 2009 or continuing with the current arrangements until the law is amended and making necessary adjustments for their 2009-10 annual return. The amendments provide clarity around which jurisdiction levies payroll tax and avoids the risk of double taxation.

Other measures in the bill include: clarification of the conditions of entitlement to the transfer duty exemption for conversions of ownership from joint tenancy to tenancy in common and vice versa; extension of the operation of the contracted property provisions to include trust interests; for the corporate reconstruction exemption ensuring that the condition that the property be group property applies as intended where property is subdivided; and providing that charges over land registered by the Commissioner of State Revenue for land rich duty and first home owner grant rank as first charges to align with land tax charges and with revenue laws in a number of other jurisdictions. This change is prospective.

A reduction of the cap on the value of homes which qualify for the first home owner grant from $1 million to $750,000 from 31 March 2010 to align with the caps in other jurisdictions and to allow the sharing of first home owner grant information with the Commissioner of Taxation under reciprocal arrangements are also included.

The bill will also amend the State Financial Institutions and Metway Merger Facilitation Act 1996 to remove the current requirements that a minimum number of directors of each Suncorp group company be residents of Queensland. The requirement that the managing director be a resident of Queensland will continue and is being progressed after consideration and endorsement by Suncorp’s AGM. This amendment is necessary as Suncorp continues to compete as a publicly listed company in the competitive finance industry.

The bill will also clarify the extent and the operation of the existing state guarantee for Suncorp Insurance and Finance for insurance and indemnity policies that existed prior to the merger with Metway Bank in 1996. Earlier, Queensland law operated to provide a state guarantee for these insurance and indemnity policies on the basis that Suncorp Insurance and Finance was state owned. Suncorp, in its current form, was created on 1 December 1996 as a result of the merger of the Queensland government owned Suncorp Building Society, Suncorp Finance Ltd, Suncorp Insurance and Finance, QIDC and Metway Bank. The merger was aimed at enhancing the availability of banking, finance and insurance services throughout the state by creating a financial institution that was able to use its well-known brands to offer a wide range of banking, finance and insurance products in an increasingly competitive market. Prior to the merger, the entities all had strengths in different areas of the banking, finance and insurance industry. The merger brought these strengths together that provided a mix of banking, finance and insurance services to the whole of the state.

Suncorp’s annual general meeting was held on 28 October 2009 and at that meeting shareholders passed a vote to amend the company’s constitution to change the residency requirements that apply to Suncorp’s directors. The resolution passed by shareholders requires that only the managing director of Suncorp be ordinarily a resident of Queensland. For this resolution to be implemented, the act must be amended to remove the current mandatory residency requirements. The requirement that the managing director be ordinarily a resident of Queensland will be retained, as will the requirement for principal operational offices of stated company personnel and company services being located in Queensland.

The bill will also amend part 7 of the act to clarify the provisions relating to the state’s guarantee of all insurance and indemnity obligations by Suncorp prior to its merger with Metway in 1996. To be specific, the guarantee will only apply to policies or contracts of insurance and indemnity that were in existence on 30 November 1996 and to the maximum liability under the policy or contract of insurance or indemnity, whether actual or contingent, that existed on 30 November 1996.

The bill also amends the Infrastructure Investment (Asset Restructuring and Disposal) Act 1990 to facilitate the commercial restructure of the declared projects. In particular, on 8 December 2009 the government announced that the Port of Brisbane, Abbot Point Coal Terminal and QR Ltd’s below-rail coal network would be divested by way of 99-year leases. This bill inserts new provisions to facilitate the lease of these projects and provides appropriate commercial certainty for the state and the ongoing businesses.

Further, the bill amends the Superannuation (State Public Sector) Act 1990 for the purposes of simplifying the current process for the continuation of eligibility for membership with QSuper for employees who are no longer employed by a state public sector unit as a result of a restructure of a government business. For prior transactions, the main process has involved the employee and new employer each giving a written notice to QSuper that the parties agree to the employee’s continued membership with QSuper. The amendments introduce a new process which permits the minister to give notice, by gazette, to QSuper declaring that employees keep all of an employee’s existing and accruing rights relating to superannuation. The effect is that the new employer will be bound by the QSuper scheme. The proposed amendments are intended to maintain the status quo and ensure that there is a simple streamlined process for QSuper, the new employer and the affected employees. These amendments will apply generally.

The bill also contains amendments to the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition (Queensland) Act 2003 to remove the requirement for an act of parliament for Queensland to endorse Commonwealth regulation amending the goods and occupations that are exempt from the operation of the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Act 1997 at the Commonwealth level. This will bring Queensland in line with other jurisdictions. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Nicholls, adjourned.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (2.43 pm), by leave: Today the Department of Environment and Resource Management has released an important and timely report which injects a much needed dose of reality into the public debate about statutory land valuations in Queensland. I table for the information of the House a copy of the Department of Environment and Resource Management’s Property market movement for the 2010 valuation .
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Department of Environment and Resource Management, Report titled ‘Property market movement for the 2010 valuation--Snapshot 2010’.
XML.Hansard-Body: This report does not purport to be, and should not be interpreted as, comprehensively or definitively representing any revaluation undertaken by the chief executive of the department under the Valuation of Land Act 1944. However, this report does provide a useful forecast of what we could expect when they are issued by 31 March of this year.

Anyone following and believing some of the wild public claims in the recent debate may be surprised to see that this report does not show evidence of massive valuation increases or the ‘biggest ever change to land taxation’. In fact, what this sober report shows is land valuations reflecting the market movements since the property was last valued. With some exceptions, those valuations undertaken in 2007 should show substantial declines in commercial and industrial property sectors. Those local government areas not undertaken since 2005 should generally show net increases over the period due to the boom of 2005 to 2008, offsetting the declines or flattening of market values since 2008.

What do we see when we look at those sectors that have been the centre of claims about massive increases predicted in 2010? Since the 2008 valuation, commercial property on the Gold Coast and Brisbane fell by 16 per cent and seven per cent respectively and industrial property fell by 24 per cent and three per cent respectively. Indeed, land values for the top 10 most valuable properties in Brisbane’s central business district appear to have actually dropped by 16 per cent in value, reducing their collective value by some $193 million. The report forecasts a 15 per cent to 23 per cent decrease in the value of theme parks, consistent with the overall commercial trend on the Gold Coast. Those shopping centres already on the prescribed formula will have increases of about two per cent since the 2008 valuation.

The report indicates that residential land values in Brisbane show an overall increase on average of 11 per cent since 2007, which is modest compared with average annual increases between 2005 and 2008. Gold Coast residential land decreased on average in value by five per cent over the same period. Not every local government area being revalued would see a fall in its property values. The report highlights the increase in sales volume and prices over the period from 2005 to 2008 in all market sectors. This boom period will be reflected in some local government area revaluations which have not been revalued since 2004. In the more regularly valued areas--mostly Brisbane and the Gold Coast--reductions in value are common due to the economic downturn. This report provides some much needed factual information and should calm the nerves of many industry sectors and property owners who have been spooked by recent campaigns. The report is available on my department’s website.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 11 February (see p. 242), on motion of Mr Robertson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (2.47 pm): I rise to oppose the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 as it was introduced into this House, and we will oppose it in the strongest possible terms. Today we debate a bill that has provided confirmation, if confirmation was needed, of the extent to which the Queensland government under Premier Bligh has descended into an administrative farce.

The bill before the House is the result of the government losing its particular case in the court over a period of time. This particular piece of legislation deals with an issue that is very complicated, and the government has sought to use the complicated nature of the issue to hide its true intentions and to hide the facts behind the legislation that has been introduced. In effect, the bill before this House this afternoon is a blatant, cynical attempt to increase the amount of land tax that the government takes from Queensland property owners. In simple terms, the government’s intent for the last 10 years has been all about increasing the base on which land tax is applied at every opportunity, and increasing that land tax base to the maximum level possible to line the government’s coffers.

This is a government that went broke in the biggest economic boom in Queensland’s history and to compensate for its shocking lack of financial management it has sought to increase its land tax take at every possible opportunity. The figures bear that out. If we look at the total gross returns for land tax, we see that they have trebled in a 10-year period. They have trebled in a 10-year period because of a constant campaign to increase the base upon which that land tax is levied.

The base on which that land tax is levied is the unimproved value of land. Land tax has been paid on the unimproved value of land since that model was introduced into Queensland in 1944. Currently, land tax is paid by landholders who hold land with an unimproved value over and above $600,000. But it is the calculation of that unimproved value that has been the genesis of this legislation. Not only has the government taken the opportunity to increase the quantum of that unimproved value at every opportunity; it has sought to misuse the mechanism by which that valuation is calculated, and it has done that since 2002. Since 2002 there has been a campaign, particularly in relation to commercial shopping centre sites, but commercial sites generally, to tinker with the mechanism, the equation and the concepts that are used to calculate that unimproved value.

Once again, this argument gets very complicated. As I said, the government is seeking to use the complicated nature of the argument to somehow hide its true intentions. But in simple terms the unimproved value is calculated by taking the market value of a property and subtracting the improvements. The improvements have always been considered to fall into a number of categories, some of which are easy to identify and easy to value and others which are more difficult. Obviously, the first category of improvements that are easy to value are the physical improvements--the bricks and mortar. That is easily understood. But even in this particular bill before the House the government seeks to try to change that mechanism--and I will go into the detail about how it changes that mechanism later on.

The second category of improvements that has always been part of that calculation is what is known in the industry as invisible improvements. They are improvements that have essentially become part of the land, such as clearing, filling, levelling and stabilisation that, once again, have long been recognised as improvements that need to be deducted from the market value to get to that unimproved value of land.

But the third category of improvements is the one that has been the instigator of the legislation before the House and it has been the issue that the government has sought to use to its own advantage since 2002, and that is the category of intangible improvements. Intangible improvements encompass things such as leases, business goodwill, development applications--a whole range of things that add value to a site but which are really intangible. Obviously, that is why they are called intangible improvements. Since 2002 the government has sought to have the value of those intangible improvements reside in the land for the calculation of the unimproved value on which it levied its land tax. As I said, the government has done that to try to maximise the value of the land tax base, to gouge land tax from a group of people who it philosophically sees as being able, in its words, to pay a higher level of tax.
Mr Stevens: Mum and dad’s superannuation.

Mr SEENEY: But the government, in its philosophical blindness, fails to understand that most of the people who are impacted by those decisions are, as the member for Mermaid Beach indicates, mum-and-dad superannuation investors. Shopping centres are a great example of those investments. In the main, they are owned by property trusts whose main investors are either unit holders or superannuation funds which hold units on behalf of their investors. So the government, in its philosophical blindness, seeks to gouge additional land tax from those people without understanding or acknowledging that it is everyday mum-and-dad Queenslanders who are worse off because of its decision. As I said, it is that question of intangible improvements that has been at the heart of the dispute that has been running since 2002. It has been at the heart of the attempts by the government to increase that unimproved value of commercial property since 2002.

We considered legislation in this parliament in 2008 after the government lost one litigation case. Obviously, the legislation that was introduced in 2008 did not achieve all of the government’s objectives because, late last year, it was back in court again and it lost again. So we are back in this parliament today because the government cannot get its own way in the court. The court has found consistently that the government’s interpretation of the legislation is wrong. The court has found consistently that the government’s attempts to gouge extra land tax from the property owners of Queensland are illegal. The government’s attempts are not supported by the law. So the government has come into this parliament to seek to change the law.

This is a pattern that we have seen from this government for 10 years across a range of departments, but more particularly in the department of natural resources. Time and time again the department of natural resources has sent its hapless minister into this parliament to change the law to ensure that the department gets its way when it cannot get its way in the court. When the court rules that the actions of the department of natural resources are illegal in case after case after case, the minister gets sent in here with legislation to change the law. It is almost as though the department of natural resources considers this parliament to be the final court of appeal, where it knows that it is going to get the result that it wants. The department knows that it can use the numbers in the Labor government to get the result that it cannot get in the litigation that it initiates.

It is important to understand that the litigation in this case was initiated by the department; it was initiated by the government. It has never been a case of property owners trying to tinker with the system to minimise their land tax obligations. This court action has been instigated by the department in trying to tinker with the system to maximise its land tax take. It has been at the department’s initiative that the whole concept of unimproved value has been challenged, has been stretched and taken into areas that it was never considered to be. In fact, the legislation before the House reaches absurd levels when it talks about the meaning of unimproved value. It says something along the lines--and I will get to it in detail when we go into consideration in detail--that unimproved value has a special meaning in this bill that is not related to the dictionary meaning of the words. In this bill, ‘unimproved value’ has a special meaning that the government wants it to have simply so that it can increase land tax and so that it can gouge money from Queenslanders who own property either directly or, more commonly--and certainly in greater numbers--through their superannuation funds.

I think the consideration of this bill that we are going to undertake this afternoon is something of a first in another way in that the government has indicated that it is going to introduce extensive amendments. In fact, the amendments that the government has indicated that it is going to introduce effectively all but gut the bill. They take out all of the features of the bill that have caused so much debate. The amendments introduce a sunset clause to the bill that effectively means that it will have a life of less than one year and one valuation cycle.

But we have to consider the bill as it has been introduced and as it is tabled and we will consider the government’s amendments when they are introduced during the consideration in detail. Effectively, in the tabling of those amendments, the government has admitted that this bill would destroy Queensland’s economy and it has admitted that the bill was a huge mistake from the beginning. It is a bill that was introduced without consultation with the industry. It is a bill that was introduced almost in a fit of pique by the minister after the department lost yet another case in that long-running series of litigation to which I referred earlier. As I said at the very beginning of my consideration, it is an indication of the extent to which the administrative capacity and capability of the Bligh Labor government has all but dissipated completely.

The Premier also said this morning when she made a ministerial statement about the bill that the government would be moving towards site valuations. That is something that I believe is long overdue. It is something that I have called for. We have advocated for some time that there be a total revamp.
Mr Robertson: There is no record of it. It was done in silence because we can’t find any record of you actually doing it. ‘Seeney’ and ‘site valuation’ does not appear in the one sentence.
Mr SEENEY: We have often called for a total revamp of the valuation system.
Mr Robertson: Never. Don’t try to get tricky.

Mr SEENEY: Absolutely. It is what the minister should have done when he introduced the bill. When he introduced the bill I said that he should have gone to a full revamp of the system. We will watch and wait for the government’s legislation, which will supposedly be introduced in September, to see just how genuine the government is about achieving a proper revamp of the whole valuation system.

When the bill was first introduced into the House the LNP said that it had the potential to send land tax bills soaring. We said that it should be scrapped. We said that it should be thrown out and that the government should start again. We said that the government needed to go back to the drawing board. We said that Queensland needed a valuation system that was fair and equitable, that has been modernised. We said that business and investors in Queensland needed certainty and this bill did not deliver on any of these aspects. We have seen over the last decade the Labor government plumb the depths to find any blatant tax grab or revenue snatch to empty Queenslanders’ pockets. We said that this bill was a continuation of that agenda. We said that the changes proposed in this bill to the Valuation of Land Act would destroy more jobs in Queensland than the global financial crisis and the impact would be further reaching and longer lasting. We were treated with contempt by the minister and the government.

It has eventuated since that the majority of property owners and interest groups across Queensland have agreed with us that this bill will destroy investor confidence in Queensland. Some of the biggest investors in property in Queensland have publicly expressed that view. They have agreed with us that this bill will massively increase the cost of doing business in the state. They have agreed with us that this bill will inflate rents across all sectors of society and they have agreed with us that this bill will put house prices, particularly in new property developments and greenfield sites, way out of the reach of any first home buyer. Every other stakeholder has agreed with us that this bill will devastate the superannuation nest eggs of Queenslanders. They have agreed with us that it will demolish Queensland’s tourism industry, it will kill small business in Queensland and it will flatten the construction industry in our state. The major retail companies themselves have agreed with us that it will ruin retail business futures throughout the state.

In short, if this bill were to be passed in the form that it was introduced into the parliament Queensland jobs and livelihoods would be devastated and decimated. The government has done this by trying to sneak through a change to one of the most important tenets underpinning the land taxation system--that is, the unimproved valuation of land. It tried to sneak through the change without consultation and against the results of two court cases. It tried to do that by using the complicated nature of the issue to hide the real effect of the bill before the House.
The positions that we took were supported by a range of interest groups. Some of their comments need to be put on the record. There were comments such as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘A radical change to Queensland’s rating and land tax system.’
‘In one blow Queensland has undermined all the efforts in attracting foreign investment in Australia.’
‘The new bill fundamentally alters the definition of unimproved value.’

‘The proposed amendments are aimed at protecting the State budget’s bottom line in the short-term. Their legacy, in terms of the inevitable disincentive to investment in Queensland, will be with us for years to come.’
XML.Hansard-Body: All this under a Labor government that was desperate to gouge money because it went bust in a boom! The only people who did not see the absurdity of the bill were those with vested interests--those who were part of the Bligh government struggling against the results of its own financial mismanagement. When the minister announced the bill he stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The government introduced legislation to prevent a recent Court of Appeal decision overturning decades of past practice in the valuation of commercial property.
If we don’t correct the Appeal Court’s interpretation of the law, then we would be accepting commercial property calculations on a fundamentally different basis to other property valuations.
XML.Hansard-Body: Both of those statements have been demonstrably shown to be untrue. While I will not use a term that is unparliamentary to describe the minister’s comments, I will refer the minister to the fact that every professional body concerned with this matter has disagreed with his statement and has pointed out the untruthfulness of those statements. They include private valuers in Queensland, the Property Council of Australia, the Urban Development Institute of Australia, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland, the Shopping Centre Council of Australia, the Queensland Bar Association, the Queensland Law Society, a range of major superannuation funds, a range of major construction bodies, agricultural bodies and the mining industry. All have said that the minister’s statements in this House when he introduced this bill are untrue and false.

We saw the Premier come into this place this morning and admit that they had got it wrong. It is in direct contrast to the position that the government tried unsuccessfully to maintain through things such as placing a full-page ad in the Courier-Mail that tried to maintain the unsustainable position that this bill meant no change for Queenslanders. The fact of the matter is that the government was caught out and, against the weight of evidence, had to concede that this was a blatant tax grab. The truth of the matter is that the government had been trying to change the valuation of land by stealth for 10 years and it has been caught out.

As I indicated earlier, the figures do not lie. Land tax receipts since 2001-02 have increased by over $800 million, or 355 per cent. Land tax as a proportion of state revenue has increased from 4.8 per cent to 11.1 per cent. Yet another example of Queensland’s long-cherished low-tax status has been thrown away by the Labor government in its bid to deal with the consequences of its own horrific financial management. In the biggest economic boom in Queensland’s history, when the government had rivers of gold in terms of its income stream flowing from the mining industry, the property turnover tax and the GST, it still went out of its way to concoct this complicated approach to ensure that land tax rose by 355 per cent, so desperate was it to gouge money from the property sector in Queensland. Where have all these funds gone?
Mr Shine: Schools, hospitals, police, roads. Think about it.
Mr SEENEY: Every time we consider the government’s economic management it is appropriate to ask where these funds have gone. Where has the money gone?
Mr Shine: Skilled Park.
Mr SEENEY: It is as well that the former Attorney-General seeks to interject, because he is a man who has sat in cabinet and he could tell us where all the money went.
Mr Shine: I just did--schools, hospitals, police, roads.

Mr SEENEY: Even before the global financial crisis, Labor had racked up more than $64 billion in debt. That is the legacy of the member for Toowoomba North and his colleagues who sat around the cabinet table when the government was in that fortunate position of receiving those cash inflows from the economic boom. In that period it racked up a debt that represented $16,000 for every man, woman and child in our state.

Today, every Queenslander owes over $19,000, so every time we stand in this parliament and consider legislation such as the bill before the House, which seeks to adjust the tax system, it is fair to ask: where did all that money go? It did not get spent on our roads, it did not get spent on our hospitals, it did not get spent on our schools. Unfortunately, the money disappeared into a black hole--the black hole of Labor Party mismanagement. Queenslanders have nothing to show for the biggest tax grab that our state has ever experienced. Those who are struggling to understand this debate and have seen the advertising war in the Courier-Mail need to know that the debate comes down--
Government members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Pitt): Order! Members to my right, I have given you some latitude. Let the member be heard in silence.

Mr SEENEY: Those people need to know that the debate comes down to a fundamental issue. It comes down to an attempt by the government to implement a fundamental change to one of the most basic definitions underpinning a taxation regime in our state, which is the definition of ‘unimproved value’. It has long been the principle that land should be valued on its unimproved value for its highest and best use. However, the Valuation of Land Act 1944 requires that a valuer treat any improvements as if they did not exist in assessing the unimproved value of land for the purpose of levying land tax and rates. The government has increasingly ignored those principles, especially in regard to highly improved commercial properties. It has effectively stated an amount for intangible improvements such as goodwill and the existence of leases in its valuations. It has tried to include the value of those intangible improvements in the value of the land. This approach has been twice struck down by the courts. In the most recent case, the Pacific Fair centre was found to have an unimproved value of $47.5 million, but under its system the government submitted the value should be as high as $255 million. When there are such markedly different valuations, it is clear that it is not just a question of interpretation; it is a question of the government trying to fundamentally change the calculation. It is a fundamental change to the calculation that would achieve a difference between $47.5 million and $255 million as the base for the land tax that is going to be levied on that particular property.

The Land Appeal Court stated that the government’s valuation amounted to ‘a radical change to the state’s rating and land tax system’. The government has consistently denied that. As late as today, the government is still trying to maintain that the bill before the House does not do anything to fundamentally change the land tax system or the land valuation system in Queensland. But the government’s solution to the problem was to seek to retrospectively change the existing law to invalidate any outstanding appeal and to come in here with the bill that we are considering now that throws out the definition of ‘unimproved value’.

Under this bill ‘unimproved value’ would now mean market value minus the depreciated cost of any buildings. An unimproved valuation will now include profit and risk; it will include the value of leases, the value of goodwill and the value of infrastructure charges. Those are the intangible interests that have previously been specifically excluded under Queensland’s valuation of land system. Effectively, this bill introduces a tax on a person’s business ability. Even the government admitted that. In the court case that led to this bill--and I will quote from the transcript from the case--Mr Jones said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It seems to me that a fundamental consequence of your submission is that at the end of day it does result in a tax on entrepreneurial effort and skill and from my reading of a number of cases that has been contrary to the traditional approach of the Courts in assessing what unimproved is about.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: On behalf of the government, Mr Fraser said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In terms of entrepreneurial effort it will involve considerations of, for example, prudent entrepreneurs. I mean, the unsuccessful one won’t be taxed.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is a fundamental shift in the land valuation system in Queensland. It puts our state further out of step with the rest of the nation.
XML.Hansard-Body: The government is sitting on a major review of Queensland’s valuation system by Professors Boyd and Heffernan. That review was instigated by the previous minister for natural resources and it has been long awaited by the industry. Today I call on the government to release this study in the lead-up to the introduction into this House in September of the bill that it has indicated it will introduce. The release of the review will ensure that the debate is fully informed and is not sprung on stakeholders when the bill is introduced into parliament, which is what occurred with the deficient legislation that is before the House this afternoon and is the subject of this debate.

As part of the public debate that has ensued since the introduction of this bill we have heard the government vilify those who oppose the bill as just shopping centre owners trying to protect their massive profits. There is no doubt that this industry is one of the many that will be negatively impacted by changes included in the bill, but let us be reminded of some real facts as we consider the legislation here in the parliament. In Queensland the retail industry is a massive employer. It does pay its way and it pays many individual Queenslanders. Already before this bill comes into effect, this industry is paying more land tax in Queensland than any other state.

A prominent proprietor of shopping centres has advised me that in a comparable interstate centre they are paying between $10 and $16 in land tax per square metre. Under the current regime, the Queensland Treasury is extracting $21 per square metre in land tax for similar shopping centre space. By how much do members anticipate this will rise under the new legislation? It will not be not double or triple; they predict that the land tax regime that this bill will introduce will result in a sevenfold rise. This land tax will increase the charge to around $150 per square metre. Queensland would be charging more than 10 times the land tax paid in other east coast states, yet the minister and the government still claim that the Queensland has the lowest land tax rate in Australia. Queensland may have the lowest land tax rate in the dollar, but it is the unimproved value in Queensland that makes the difference. The government’s focus since 2002 has been on increasing the level of unimproved values so that it maximises its land tax take. What the minister neglected to state is that while the land tax is low, the valuations underpinning it are extraordinarily high compared to other states. Under this bill, they will only increase. In fact, the very purpose of this bill is to justify and invalidate the government’s attempt to increase the land tax base.

In other cases the increase is likely to be less, but I have talked to a number of property owners who anticipate a substantial 20 to 40 per cent increase in their land tax, yet the Premier and the government continue to deny the implications of this decision. On the weekend the Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is not an issue that affects mum and dad investors--the only people affected by this are the very big end of town.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: How wrong and misleading that is. The fact is that many Queenslanders, both directly and through superannuation funds, will have their investments slashed as a result of this decision. For example, most members in this parliament would have been contacted by a fund manager which stated that 50 per cent of its funds are invested in Queensland, largely in commercial property, and its investors are wholesale superannuation funds. In other words, the mums and dads the Premier claims will not be impacted are the very ones who will lose. They will lose because their superannuation funds will lose. This particular fund manager said that the bill will drop the value of the assets it holds in Queensland by a further nine per cent. It is not a big company, it is not a super rich family, it is not some overseas investor. The assets that the fund holds are held on behalf of everyday working Queenslanders. It holds their superannuation funds and it invests those funds in Queensland properties. The fund manager also stated that the change will delay or cancel further investment in the state. That is something that has been repeated across a range of correspondence that has flooded into electorate offices in response to this very poorly thought out legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: The fact of the matter is that the bill will devastate business investment in Queensland and it will devastate Queenslanders who have invested for their retirement.
