The bill will cost jobs across the state and it will destroy business certainty in Queensland. Not only is the government seeking to change the definition of the valuation of land for valuations in the future but it is also seeking to correct its intentional tax gouging in previous years by retrospectively changing the definition of ‘unimproved land’ back to 2002.

This breaches the core and fundamental legislative principle that under a fair legal system the law on any given day should govern the actions of its citizens. No less than the Bar Association of Queensland has seen fit to write to the Premier and to all members to remind us of this principle and that ‘citizens are entitled to organise their affairs (domestic and commercial) on the statute law as enacted from time to time’. It is the Bar Association’s opinion that nothing in the bill or in the explanatory memorandum or in the government’s public justifications would excuse a departure from this expected norm. It has long been the principle that retrospective legislation should be used only in extraordinary circumstances. We see too much retrospective legislation introduced into this House by a government which seeks to use that retrospectivity to either justify its previous actions or to correct its former mistakes.

I note that the government has claimed in the media that some $600 million of rates and $300 million of land tax would need to be repaid if this bill were not made retrospective. That is simply rubbish. This has been disputed widely with legal advice that if a valuation was not challenged and subject to appeal then that valuation would stand. As a result, we believe that the likely impact would be much less--certainly less than the government’s figure and probably in the order of $20 million to $30 million. The LNP understands the importance of ensuring the revenue base of Queensland’s economy is protected. But this is an underhanded and blatant tax grab and it is clearly unacceptable.

To make it worse, the bill before the House effectively removes appeal and objection rights that have traditionally been available to landholders. It sets up a case where Caesar judges Caesar. Objections to valuations must be received within 45 days under the provisions that the bill seeks to introduce. The onus is on an owner to provide a high level of detail to support their objection. This would include details on improvements on the land, valuation reports, depreciation schedules and insurance assessments. But under the provisions of the bill the government does not have to inform the objector on what grounds it made the valuation. Only the government can make a determination that an appeal is properly made. If it decides it is not, there are no appeal rights available to the property owner. The government can require more information under the provisions of the bill, but if that information is unable to be provided the government may determine the objection may lapse, and there are no appeal rights to that decision that the government may make.

In addition, under the provisions of this bill, despite not knowing on what grounds the valuation was determined when making the original objection, the objector can only appeal on grounds included within the original objection. This is counter to the principle of natural justice and basic and reasonable fairness. The LNP again puts its position on the record. No-one should be in any doubt that we will always oppose the removal of objection and appeal rights for Queenslanders. Everybody has a right to appeal. Everybody has a right to have their objection heard. That is basic fairness. It is a reasonable situation that every Queenslander should have a right to expect when dealing with the Queensland government.

The bill before the House sets up a valuation schedule for Queensland local government areas over 10 years. Depending on growth, historical market movements and the numbers of valuations, each local government area will be revalued between three and five years. In the years when a valuation is not issued, an adjustment factor will be provided to the relevant local government by the Office of State Revenue. This will be determined and set by the department’s chief executive. I understand that a property owner will have no right of objection or appeal against the valuation that has increased as a result of this adjustment factor. Once again, the right of appeal, the right to have their case heard, will be denied to ordinary Queenslanders. In an environment where land valuations regularly increase by more than 10 per cent a year, the impact of this change will be substantial and should not be abided by any of us. This will impact on both metropolitan and regional areas and yet again removes those basic rights that people have to a fair go, a basic right to fairness. The LNP will strongly oppose such changes wherever they appear in legislation.

As I noted earlier, the Premier this morning announced that the government would be introducing major amendments to the bill. In essence, they are a face-saving exercise for the government admitting that it got it wrong. However, some fundamental issues remain even after the consideration of the amendments. Even following the government’s amendments, the fundamental change to the definition of ‘unimproved land’ will stand in the bill. That sets a very dangerous precedent that I believe has the potential at least to be misused in the future. Other fundamental issues will remain after the passage of the government’s amendments. The effective removal of objection and appeal rights remain in the bill and will become legislation if the bill is passed, and the future of the land valuation system is still in doubt even with the passage of the government’s amendments.

Let me conclude by saying that the valuation of land bill currently being debated by this House is, as I said at the beginning of my contribution, a blatant tax grab by a government that went bust in a boom, a government that set out to treble the land tax take at a time when every other one of its income streams was running at a record level. There is no doubt that this bill before the House would cost Queenslanders jobs--many jobs. There is no doubt that the bill before the House will hit businesses, particularly small businesses, due to the resulting increase in land taxes that they will pay, and that in itself will destroy Queenslanders’ jobs.

There is no doubt that the bill before the House will be devastating to business certainty in Queensland and will reduce our state’s attractiveness as an investment destination. There is no doubt that that too would destroy Queenslanders’ jobs. There is no doubt that the bill before the House would affect housing affordability for every Queenslander. It will be hit yet again, as the cost to homebuyers will rise to reflect the increase in land tax, particularly in new developments and greenfield sites. That will result in houses becoming even more out of reach of Queensland first home buyers. There is no doubt that the bill before the House will mean that average Queenslanders will be hit through the impact on their superannuation funds, most of which include some form of property investment. There is no doubt that as a result of this bill Queenslanders’ retirement funds will dissipate and disappear.

The Bligh government has been caught out trying to misinterpret the law twice. It has been caught out acting illegally twice. It is retrospectively seeking to change the law to validate that illegal action. In addition, the Bligh government is effectively removing most Queenslanders’ rights to object and appeal against decisions made by their government in regard to the valuation of their land which forms the basis of the land tax system. The Liberal National Party will oppose those changes wherever they appear in legislation.

We will await the debate on the amendments that the government has sought to introduce. We will consider those amendments on their merits. We will consider the sunset clause that the government seeks to insert into the bill. We will discuss the impacts of that sunset clause when it is introduced as an amendment to the bill in consideration in detail. As the bill stands before the House, as we must consider it as it was introduced into the House, it is a bill that should be voted against by every member of this House. It has been opposed by every stakeholder in Queensland’s property industry who understands how important the unimproved valuations are to the land tax system. It has been opposed by everyone who understands the impact that higher land taxes will have on property investment.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Pitt): Order! Members, I remind you that cross-chamber activity is not on.
Ms Jones interjected.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability, I am speaking. Please take your conversations outside. If you wish to have debates away from the chamber, please do so. Apart from that, the member for Callide has the call.

Mr SEENEY: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I was saying, this bill has been opposed by every interest group that has an understanding of the land tax system in Queensland. It has been opposed by every major investor who seeks to invest in Queensland’s future, and it should be opposed by every member of this House. It is a blatant attempt by a government that went broke in a boom to gouge further land tax from a sector of the Queensland economy that it wrongfully believes has some capacity to pay. I look forward to this bill being defeated in its consideration before the House this afternoon.

Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (3.30 pm): Make no mistake about it: this bill, as originally presented, is purely and simply a sneaky new tax grab by a sneaky government that has sent Queensland’s finances deep into the red. It is a government, as the member for Callide, the shadow minister, has said, that has sent Queensland bust in a boom. We can imagine what was going through the minds of government ministers when this bill was being debated. The minister responsible for land valuations would have gone to the Treasurer and said, ‘Treasurer, have I got a plan for you. You know how we are running out of money? You know how we are spending it like drunken sailors? You know how we are not getting any value for it? I can fix that problem for you, because we have all this land here. We have a property boom that is about to happen. What we will do is create a new way of valuing land in Queensland. It will be a different way of going about it. What we will do is introduce a sneaky new method of valuing unimproved land, and that is we will value it as improved land. Instead of it being unimproved land, we will call it improved land. But we will say, “When you read the word ‘unimproved’ it actually means ‘improved”.” You can bank on that. You can put that in your future years’ income and in your outlays. You can bank on the revenue that you will get from that particular sleight of hand. We will say that this is justified by valuation practice, or this is the way we have always done things, and we will start doing it.’

I guess the Treasurer said, ‘We are always looking for a new way to take more money out of the pockets of hardworking Queenslanders. We are always looking for a way to penalise businesses, investors and people who make sacrifices, do the hard work, make the hard yards, incur the risk, put their families’ wellbeing on the line and put their assets on the line. We will take that money and we will run with it.’ In 2002 the dearly departed Treasurer at that time, Mr Mackenroth, said, ‘You beauty. We’ll take that money.’ All of a sudden, property valuations started issuing. The year before they had been $40 million for the unimproved value, and the following year they came out at $155 million. How do you explain the valuations going from $40 million to $155 million in one year? The minister gets up in this House and has the presumption to say that there was no radical change in valuation methods. One year it was $40 million and the next it was $155 million, with no radical change in valuation method. It just does not wash.

This scheme--this sneaky new tax grab--comes from the same gang that brought Queenslanders 30-plus per cent increases in electricity charges after promising that no Queenslanders would pay any more. This is the same gang that promised not to scrap the fuel subsidy. What did the Treasurer say before the last election? He said, ‘Make no mistake about it: we’ll be delivering a fuel subsidy. It will stay in place.’ In reality, what happened? As soon as the Labor gang got re-elected it promptly scrapped the fuel subsidy--in effect, introducing a new fuel tax. Queenslanders now have the highest average price of unleaded petrol in mainland Australia on a regular basis.
Ms Grace: Rubbish.

Mr NICHOLLS: I hear the member for Brisbane Central--that sympathetic voice to business and entrepreneurial effort who has spent her entire life in the unions--say ‘rubbish’. She is now so ensconced in the fantasy land of Labor Party politics that she does not even believe that Queenslanders are paying more for petrol after her government introduced a tax of 8.2c per litre. This is the same member who, when her office was approached by someone complaining about this particular legislation we are dealing with and the changes it will bring, said, ‘I don’t think we’ll worry about responding because the person complaining doesn’t live in Queensland.’ She could not even be bothered sending a response back saying--
Ms GRACE: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I find the words uttered offensive and ask that they be withdrawn as they are not true.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! The member has asked for the comments to be withdrawn.
Mr NICHOLLS: I am happy to withdraw, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will speak to the member later and have a discussion with her about that.

This is the same Labor gang that imposed car registration increases of 17 per cent to 22 per cent last year. It is the same gang that promised to install 200,000 hot-water systems for $500 each, or $100 for pensioners, with one-third of them to be done that way, and has so far delivered less than one per cent of that total and has now scrapped the scheme. It is the same gang that, in addition to causing heartache to hundreds in the Mary Valley, lost $265 million by its own admission in going ahead with that fateful plan. It is the same gang that this year will oversee a $2.35 billion loss in Queensland’s operating statement. This is the same gang that for the first time in Queensland’s history lost our AAA credit rating. It is the same gang that has presided over the highest unemployment rate in Australia recently. It is the same gang that deceived the electorate by promising not to sell assets and is now shamelessly doing so.
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr NICHOLLS: The member for Everton pipes up now and says ‘100,000 new jobs’--100,000 jobs for 100,000 breadwinners. The January ABS statistics--
Mr Watt: They’re on the way.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The member for Clayfield has the call.

Mr NICHOLLS: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. The member for Everton refers to job creation. The member for Everton should check the ABS statistics for January which show that there are 22,000 fewer full-time jobs in Queensland now than there were when that promise was made 12 months ago--22,000 fewer breadwinning jobs for breadwinners, and he is satisfied with that outcome. Not only is his government charging people more for the basics; it is also ensuring people have less capacity to pay for them by making sure they do not have a job.

When we hear the protestations of the minister, the Treasurer and the Premier that these proposed changes to the Valuation of Land Act are not about higher taxes, we know that in fact that is exactly what they are about. They have form. Their record speaks for itself. When the Bligh Labor government’s form is analysed, when its actions are measured against its words, the people of Queensland can only reasonably come to one conclusion: this is a government built on the foundations of falsehood and deceit. This is a government that says one thing and does the diametric opposite.

This can even be seen in the minister’s second reading speech. In his second reading speech the minister refers to a Court of Appeal decision. Obviously the government is unhappy with that. That is unusual, bearing in mind that the decision is the decision of the highest court in Queensland, one of whose members--the Hon. Justice Keane--has just been appointed by the federal government to be the Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia. He is obviously someone whom the minister will take issue with and prepare to cross swords with in terms of his understanding of the law. In his second reading speech the minister stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If the court’s interpretation of the act in this case were to apply in future--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: as it has in the past, for the last 60 years--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: it would result in fundamentally different valuation principles being applied to commercial land, as opposed to other land types like residential land.
XML.Hansard-Body: A bald statement is made without any justification or facts to back it up, and it is in complete contradiction to all the best advice from both lawyers and valuers. It is the case that the Court of Appeal’s decision reaffirms the decision of the Land Appeal Court, which is a reaffirmation in itself of 60 years of valuation practice and which is clearly settled in law and in valuation practice in Queensland. In fact, if we look at the reasons for judgement of the Land Appeal Court, reasons which were explicitly confirmed by the Court of Appeal--and it is a good read, Minister; I suggest you go through it and have a good look at it, and once you have read that you can then read the Court of Appeal judgement and understand it--we can see that what this government is proposing is a substantial change from previous history. Paragraph 90 of the Land Appeal Court decision contains this statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Had parliament intended such a radical change to the state’s rating and land tax system, it would have said so in clear and express terms as for example, the manner in which it included the increase in value associated with planning instruments and development approvals under section 3(2B).
XML.Hansard-Body: If the government had intended such a radical change, it would have said so. These are not the comments of the Property Council of Australia. These are not the comments of the shopping centre council. These are not the comments of the small investors out there. These are the comments of the specialist court formulated to determine appeals about property valuations. It is clear that what the minister and this government is proposing is indeed a radical change to land valuation practice.

This decision of the Land Appeal Court was expressly approved by the Court of Appeal. So in a contest between three judges of the Land Appeal Court, three judges of the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of Queensland, including the now Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Appeal, we have a clear statement about the state’s proposal being a radical change to the state’s rating and land tax system.

In contrast, we have the intellectual horsepower of the minister who comes in here and says that it is not a radical change, the courts have not decided it correctly and they do not understand what the prior 60 years of valuation practice in Queensland are all about. Bear in mind that this is the minister who introduced changes to overhaul the valuation system in 2003 which were considered so unpopular, so ineffective, that his successor, the member for Thuringowa, had to come back in here in 2008 and not simply introduce legislation repealing those changes that the current minister introduced in 2003 but introduce legislation to say that they had never been made in the first place. They had to try to rewrite history because those changes were so bad.

The minister said in his second reading speech that Queensland already has the lowest land tax rates in Australia. While Queensland may have some of the lowest tax rates for land tax in Australia, it has amongst the highest valuations. The government’s argument about land tax rates is puerile and facile. As everyone knows, you cannot eat or bank percentages. It is the actual dollars that have to be paid by the owners of property that have to be counted.

Some figures provided by property owners show that land tax levied by other states is between $10 and $16 per square metre of retail space. In Queensland today it is already $21 per square metre, that is, it is 50 per cent higher in Queensland. Estimates show that if the legislation was enacted in the form it has been introduced into this House it could triple those payments. There is only one way that a sneaky tax grab will be paid--a tax grab like this--and that will be through tenants having to pay more, whether they are industrial tenants or commercial tenants, or by passing higher prices on to customers.

Then we have the minister’s further line that the government’s policy has always been to value land as developed. He says that the government’s policy has always been to value land as developed. Why then since 1944 has the Valuation of Land Act referred to unimproved value? When one looks at the Valuation of Land Bill second reading speech from 1944 one can see reference to the term ‘unimproved value’. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The term ‘unimproved’ is used in part 5 of the bill. That is entirely in accord with the definition used in the Land Tax Act for the purpose of interpreting the terms ‘unimproved value’ but the value of improvements is also defined. All these definitions are based on decisions of the High Court of Australia.

The valuation made by the Valuer-General is to be the unimproved value for land tax purposes, the rateable value for local government rating purposes, and the unimproved value for the city of Brisbane rating purpose. That is the object of the bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those were the words of the Hon. HA Bruce, the then secretary for public works, when the Valuation of Land Bill was first introduced. Unimproved value was clearly understood at the time and had a clear meaning.

When one looks at the government’s own website one sees the concept of unimproved value under the Valuation of Land Act. It has been explained. It is on the web. It says that it requires the land to be viewed in its unimproved state, exclusive of any improvements but possessing all existing infrastructure and the environment external to the land. It goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The unimproved value should be determined on the basis that the land in question was without buildings but was situated in a community with the amenities and facilities which had grown up around it.
XML.Hansard-Body: There is a long history of case law which clearly points out the true meaning of unimproved value, not the radical change sought by the minister in the legislation he has introduced.

Putting aside the minister’s obvious inability to reconcile the facts and truth with this government’s agenda to introduce a sneaky new tax, we can now turn to the impact of the proposed legislation. Over and above the inherent fundamental deceptions which I have exposed, the proposed legislation fails on three principle grounds. Firstly, it is retrospective. Secondly, it changes the whole understanding of the valuation of unimproved value and makes a mockery of the term ‘unimproved value’. It seeks to directly overturn the law of the land as determined not once, not twice but three times--twice by the specialist Land Appeal Court comprising three members and once by the Court of Appeal in Queensland. Thirdly, its process for providing for objections is so stringent and so tightly controlled that it makes the process of appealing against government heavy-handedness almost impossible and financially out of reach for small landowners.

I turn to the first of these. The government’s proposal, as advanced in court hearings and in this legislation, will see a radical change in the way properties are valued. No longer will land be valued for land tax and rating purposes based on unimproved value. This is a method that in Australia has been used and accepted in a variety of jurisdictions as a valid and a certain method of going about taxing interest in land. Applied properly--calculated on unimproved value--this is a fair and proper tax.

When it was first introduced in the 1870s it was considered almost a perfect tax because it sought to break up large landholdings, it sought to recover a value for the community but it did not tax the individual’s business effort and enterprise. As the land value increased, as a result of community input around it--as roads were built, as sewerage was put in, as parks were provided, as communities grew--the value of the land increased. The increment--the actual increase in the value of the land--was taxed because the owner was getting the benefit of the increase in value, not from things he had done but from things outside his control. So it made sense to tax the increase in the increment of those things. But it was never a tax that was imposed on the work that the owner did in improving his own land because the owner already pays tax on that. He pays income tax. They pay corporate tax.
Ms Struthers: What about her land?
Mr NICHOLLS: It does not matter. In 1877 it is a historical fact, I am sorry, that women could not own land. Gladly that has changed and Queensland was one of the first to do it.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! Members should direct their comments through the chair.

Mr NICHOLLS: Sorry, Madam Deputy Speaker, I was correcting the historical record there. In effect there were two taxes. There was the land tax for which the unearned increment was taxed in the hands of the owner of the land. Then there was the personal tax, the income tax, that was paid by people who carried on business on the land and presumably earned a profit. We have not yet got to the stage in Queensland of charging a tax on people who make a loss--although, under this government, anything is possible.

That is the basis on which land tax on unimproved value has been assessed since the introduction of land taxes in Australia. There have been variations developed over the years. In New South Wales they have site improved value and in Victoria they have site improved value. There are different aspects of land value across-the-board. But unimproved value as a concept has been clearly understood for a long time. It is the way the courts have interpreted the law. It is the way valuation professionals have interpreted the law. It is the way past valuers-general have interpreted the law. It is the way in which honest governments have interpreted the law. It is obviously not the way this government interprets the law.

To seek to introduce limitations and to change definitions, as this legislation does, and to insert provisions to require the benefit of leases, agreements for lease or any other agreements included in the unimproved value is to make a mockery of both the English language and the courts’ decisions. In fact, the Land Appeal Court was quite clear about what the government intended to do and what the impact would be, an impact now brought about by these amendments. It says at paragraph 45 of the decision--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It seems clear from these submissions--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: these are the government barristers’ own submissions, Mr Fraser QC--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: that the respondent’s position ... is that the assessment of unimproved value is now to include material elements of what would ordinarily be part of the goodwill of the business being conducted on the land.
XML.Hansard-Body: In other words, the government was contending in the Court of Appeal and the Land Appeal Court that it wanted to tax as a land tax the value of the business conducted on the land--a sneaky new tax grab by a sneaky old government. Mr Fraser says as part of that case--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Well if one has regard to the trading history that is a reflection of the entrepreneurial skill because the trading history is what those who have developed the site have been able to achieve.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The instance that your Honour gave about looking at the trading history and seeing it has failed, well, that person won’t be asked to pay any more in consequence.
XML.Hansard-Body: So fail and one pays less tax on the land and succeed and one pays more tax. It is obviously a tax on entrepreneurial effort. It leads to bizarre results. It would impose a tax on the end product of value generated by the individual entrepreneurial skill and the efforts of taxpayers. The consequences would be at odds with what has been the recognised broad policy which has underpinned taxation on the unimproved value of land in Australia for many decades.

There are many other unintended consequences that flow from this. It would lead to discrepancies in unimproved values of similar parcels of land. All manner of commercial properties could be affected, ranging from shopping centres of varying sizes to CBD properties and various tourist attractions. It is interesting that I have a letter here from the Ipswich Visitors and Tourism Association which shows that proposals under this legislation were introduced. It stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Combined with coming off the worst conditions since the 1930s we believe that any increase in land tax should be thoroughly debated and economic modelling undertaken to identify the impact of such a bill on small, medium enterprises.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is one example of the impact this legislation will have on the investment that is to be made in Queensland and in Ipswich, and I am sure members opposite would be pleased to say to the people of Ipswich that they are not taking any account of what happens in that part of the world! There are many other problems with this legislation, but time runs against me. There are problems with the retrospective nature of it. There are problems in terms of the appeal process. This government needs to amend this bill before it is finally passed. It needs to take into account the changes that it has been forced to make kicking and screaming. It needs to make sure that past valuations for properties are properly preserved and that a process is put in place for the future that equates to fairness, constancy and provides a reasonable return to Queensland taxpayers to meet the needs of our growing state. Under this bill, as introduced by this government, it does none of those. It is a mean, nasty, sneaky tax grab on individual effort, enterprise and business acumen.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (3.50 pm): I rise to speak on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, and I do so with a very heavy heart. This is probably amongst the worst pieces of legislation to come before this House. It is an ad hoc, knee-jerk reaction by a government that is out of money and looking for every opportunity to raise funds from any sector it can to try to make up for the shortfalls in its fiscal management. Those members on the other side who hold their electorates by less than five per cent--I think there are about 18 of them at last count--should be very angry at their leadership team for putting them into this financial situation and the fact that we have to have this ridiculous legislation taking up the time of this House. It was uncertain even as late as yesterday as to the outcome, and there is uncertainty in terms of community support for this legislation. As the shadow minister said earlier, this legislation is an absolute gouging and he expressed very clearly where the impetus for this legislation has come from. Quite clearly, the House is the poorer for this legislation coming into it.

This legislation brings uncertainty into the business planning of these groups that are affected by this bill. They have been going along running a business making returns for mums and dads through superannuation funds and, all of a sudden, a very clever, a very sneaky and a very out-of-pocket Labor government decides to change the rules that they need to play by so that it can get more funding in for this bankrupt government. It is a government that has had its credit rating downgraded from AAA to AA--the only one of the mainland states. We are even worse than New South Wales! For all of those backbenchers opposite who can stand up and say, ‘This is great legislation. We think it should go ahead because we have to make up the money,’ it will be very interesting to hear what they have to say about their leadership team that has put them in this situation after the next election.

How much has it cost, Minister? I ask the minister to itemise to the House in his summing-up speech how many millions of dollars have been spent on these court cases, and I will refer to my speech in March 2008 later on because exactly what has happened today is what I pre-empted back in March 2008. I ask him to identify how many millions of dollars this has cost in legal fees for the taxpayers of Queensland and also the department’s time and energy that has been wound up in trying to defend the undefendable or attack a situation and gouge this extra tax from the people of Queensland.

The government should be ashamed of itself for imposing increased taxes on a minority section of the community because it thinks it can get away with attacking the big end of town. It is not attacking the big end of town; it is attacking all parts of the community. This morning on Sunrise the CommSec report was that those in the business community are very worried about the certainty of the economic climate in which they have to do business and that is restraining those people from employing more people, and that would satisfy the member for Everton. That is the problem when we have legislation coming through like this--completely unexpectedly--which impacts on business, and members have seen the reaction. There was no consultation at all with the property industry. There was just a sneaky grab in trying to play catch-up football since the first time it tried this sneaky trick in 2002 with Pacific Fair.

The result of this legislation will flow through to the end user, just as PIP charges do not stop with the developer. PIP charges are passed on to the first home buyer. What those on the other side do not understand is that the charges are not on developers; they are on the end user, because developers just pass them on. The same thing will happen with this land tax because, even though those affected by this legislation do not qualify to pass on the land tax through outgoings, when the next lease comes up for a small business--and I have been a small businessperson in Pacific Fair; that is why I know it very well--they will pass on these increases and their rent will double. That is where the end user will pick up the extra increases. They will not be passed directly through but they will be passed on in terms of increased costs and then we will lose more people from the small business sector when businesses cannot carry on and they fold.

There has been very animated opposition to the introduction of the bill. All industry stakeholders cannot be wrong and the government right. Industry stakeholders have been concerned enough to make their issues very public and have gone on a very embarrassing public advertising exercise right across the media, and guess what? It has had some effect, because I understand there are amendments to the legislation. One could really call those the ‘omit amendments’, because everything I have looked at said ‘omit’, ‘omit’, ‘omit’. That becomes a face-saving exercise for a government that has brought in ridiculous legislation. It could not stand the fact that it was going to get turfed out and rejected by the whole of the property industry. New ‘omit amendments’ have been introduced so that it can save face and at least hold its head up for 12 months until this silly piece of legislation reaches its sunset clause and we come back here again for another debate, because I can assure business that this Labor government will be out gouging them again in whatever possible way it can. This is the second attempt--and there will be a third attempt, and it will keep going until business suffers at the hands of this Labor government. The government has supposedly delayed this legislation with these ‘omit amendments’ to address all industry stakeholder concerns, but I think quite clearly it was hoping for the media attention to die down on the matter. That did not happen and, as members know, the Property Council put out very effective ads and quite clearly there has been a backdown by the minister and by the Labor government.

As of yesterday, the negotiations with industry stakeholders and the government had hit a roadblock and yet today we have a situation where amendments will be introduced to get a face-saving movement of this legislation through the House, and that is not what this House is about. This House is about setting legislation for the future direction of Queensland--not stopgap spin for a Labor government out of control. Mr Fraser and Mr Robertson’s skills at negotiating are obviously very limited, or maybe they are saying to the industry, ‘It’s our way or the highway,’ which is probably more the truth of the situation. The objectives of the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 are to amend the Valuation of Land Act 1944 to supposedly clarify the definition of ‘unimproved value’ and terminology. In effect, it is redefining the words ‘unimproved capital value’ as only a Labor Party can do to put a different spin on what ‘unimproved capital value’ has meant for successive governments since 1944 that operated very efficiently and financially effectively within those parameters. Those governments received that budgeted amount of money and spent that budgeted amount of money. This Labor government has spent beyond its wildest dreams and now has to play catch-up football and gouge wherever it can. From a local government perspective, land valuations have been, obviously as we all know, the main source of revenue based on the unimproved capital value, and that has been very effective. As we know, local government--and it has done it for quite a number of years--can set a differential rate, and that has been done for areas like Pacific Fair.

At one time I happened to be the mayor of the Gold Coast City Council. Pacific Fair was one of that council’s very valued ratepayers. We set a premium a little higher than our residential ratepayers were paying, and Pacific Fair accepted that. It was in its business plans. We did not go back and change the rules retrospectively. Pacific Fair knew what rates it had to pay. It had business certainty and the councils--both the former Albert shire council and the then amalgamated Gold Coast City Council--had a wonderful relationship with Pacific Fair.

As we all know, this issue started with Pacific Fair. Certainly it has led to a terrible game of catch-up by legislation. In March 2008, when the government introduced silly legislation to again try to play catch-up and embarrass themselves one more time, I stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: As stated in the minister’s second reading speech, the amendment to this bill only applies to highly developed properties and does not apply to residential or rural properties--but I would add the word ‘yet’ after that sentence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Quite clearly, this bill tries to expand on that legislation that passed through this House in 2008. I also said at the time--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We will see that come in down the track. Commercial properties will be next, as this government becomes more and more desperate to raise funds to meet the interest payment of $10 million every day. That is $70 million in one week. It is enough to buy those seven schools that the government is now looking at the private sector to buy.
XML.Hansard-Body: I said that back in March 2008, and the government has continued with this sneaky manner of doing business with the people of Queensland.

This legislation has been brought in to resolve disputes more efficiently at the objection stage. By ‘resolving disputes more efficiently’, the government means to just make it very difficult and to stamp them out. That is the government’s definition of making the process more efficient. It does not want any appeals. That is how this legislation is drafted. Also, the legislation allows for the use of a general valuation schedule and an adjustment factor in the statutory valuation process. According to the explanatory notes, the amendments to the act are essentially to provide for valuations of land to be carried out equitably, efficiently and fairly. That is not what the court found. The court said, ‘You’ve not done that on two previous occasions.’ This bill is about extracting the government out of a financially embarrassing situation. Quite clearly, the courts have rejected the government’s view, the property industry has rejected it and the LNP rejects it. We are certain that this poor legislation before the House is another nail in the coffin of this Labor government as the community is very concerned about its capacity to govern properly.

Apparently, this legislation is to put beyond doubt what is and what is not included in the land value and to enable the chief executive of the Department of Environment and Resource Management to confidently issue valuations. Owing to ongoing litigation regarding flaws in the dispute resolution process, a less complicated and plain-speech system is needed. Claimants under this legislation must now provide the specifics and supporting documentation and also engage in settlement negotiations before proceeding to court. The amendments will include a lodgement fee--gosh. Guess what? It is a Labor government looking for another fee. That lodgement fee is for objecting to a land valuation in an attempt to recover costs and avid unwarranted objections--in other words, stopping all the objections that the government possibly can. It seems that this bill is attempting to quash the option to object to a valuation of land valuers. It repeats constantly that the chief executive and staff are highly skilled in this area and that their opinion is the only one that will be accepted.

The bill proposes to create a general valuation schedule so that local governments can be sure in what year their land will be valued. Over a number of years I have seen a flip-flop in land valuations for local government. It is just an embarrassment to this government of the past 10 years. When it suits this government it values the land: ‘Look, prices are going up. We’d better have a revaluation and gouge some more land tax out of these poor people.’ When prices go down or stay relatively the same they say, ‘We’ll leave those valuations as they are and we won’t do another valuation.’ I know for a fact that a couple of years ago the Gold Coast City Council was charged an annual fee of $600,000 for valuations, but when the council did not do a valuation the government still charged it $600,000. That is nice work if you can get it--600 grand for doing nothing. So that is what the department regards as an annual valuation fee.

Quite clearly, this bill is all about money. This bill is all about this government rectifying a very poor financial situation that has been brought about by poor planning. This legislation is only going to add to the problems involved for industry in trying to meet proper budgets, in trying to plan for certainty and in trying to conduct a reasonable business.

An adjustment factor will allow for movement in the property market without the local council being undervalued. There will be no objection rights to this adjustment factor. It is not an official valuation and no valuation certificate will be issued. The change in the market must be greater than 10 per cent for an adjustment factor to be provided. That is according to this bill that we are debating without the amendments that will come at a later stage. State Valuation Services values each large local authority every one to three years and smaller ones every three to five years, although I notice that Redlands has not been valued since 2004. Obviously the government has missed gouging some money out of the Redlands community.

The Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Water Act 2009 to recognise environmental risk management plans, which were introduced by the Great Barrier Reef Protection Amendment Act 2009 and which may fulfil land and water management requirements. That will provide flexibility to irrigators so that the chief executive may approve deferrals for extended periods. To ensure that irrigators and applicants do not have to double up on water management plans under the Great Barrier Reef Protection Amendment Act 2009, the management plans used will be sufficient under the Water Act 2009. Providing flexibility to irrigators that have low-risk irrigation plans relieves the burden on both the chief executive and the applicants as the chief executive can approve a deferral on a management plan for up to one year.

Even though the government believes that there will be considerable savings in the costs involved in conducting litigation in the Land Court, there are more cost implications in this bill. There will be increased costs in administrative and valuer resources and major costs involved in changes to the Queensland valuation and sales computer system. When one computer system is changed to another, there are always additional costs involved and, knowing the government’s efficiency, it will probably put out a squillion dollars worth of new letterheads to announce the big change in the computer system.

The bill has inconsistency with basic legislative principles. The principle of retrospectivity is infringed completely. The bill introduces the necessity to confirm the valuations issued previously on or from 30 June 2002, in new section 105. I understand that ‘omit variations’ will change that amendment but, at this point, we are still awaiting those ridiculously late amendments to come into the House. So we are debating the bill that we have before us without those variations, which I am sure the shadow minister will debate very rigorously later on.

The bill allows the chief executive to not provide an adjustment factor in the case of unusual circumstances, in new section 37. In an objection to a land valuation, the chief executive is allowed to ask for the supporting documentation from the claimant. If the claimant refuses, the objection will lapse. If the claimant claims to have no supporting documentation, they must sign a statutory declaration stating so. The claimant cannot make an objection to this requirement but can make a complaint under the Judicial Review Act 1991.

Unless another amount of land value can be approved in the Land Court, the decision of the land valuer’s certificate will stand unless the claimant can give more evidence. There are no objection or appeal rights to the adjustment factor, which is not a valuation. According to the government, community and industry stakeholders were consulted. That is not what we are hearing. All we heard was some minor support from a section of the Local Government Association of Queensland which, obviously, was trying to curry favour with the government on this matter by picking on those big, bad, nasty developers that have been picking on local governments all across Queensland. The Local Government Association of Queensland was supportive. Some of the local councillors were crying all sorts of ridiculous numbers. Quite clearly, that was not the case. The Property Council identified that only those cases that had been appealed would have been affected by this matter. All of those furphy figures that came from the LGAQ were a great disappointment and, unfortunately, have blurred the independence of the LGAQ on this particular matter.

The Bligh Labor government obviously did not consult with major industry stakeholders, judging from the backlash and the reaction that has occurred as a result. The majority of the community have major concerns and are against the introduction of this legislation. The increase in land tax will not be paid by the developer because the developer will end up passing it through to the tenants through lease costs et cetera, and one can guarantee that mums and dads and their superannuation schemes will feel the brunt of this ridiculous legislation. I support our opposition to this bill and the wonderful efforts of the shadow minister. We look forward to this bill being voted against by the government and look forward to amendments coming in to make it more appropriate.

Ms MALE (Pine Rivers--ALP) (4.10 pm): In rising to participate in the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 I would like to address the importance of the valuation system to Queensland. Every year State Valuation Services in the Department of Environment and Resource Management provides valuations to property owners across Queensland. These valuations are critical to local and state governments as the basis for determining rates, land tax and state land rental. How valuations are undertaken and their validity impacts every Queenslander in one way or another. This bill introduces amendments to give certainty to the way in which valuations have been prepared so that Queenslanders can have confidence that their valuations are assessed on a consistent and legislatively sound basis and so ensure equity for all landowners. Opposition members have spent the last hour trotting out every bit of scare tactic they could. Once again they have shown no concern for the running of the state of Queensland in a sensible and sound manner to ensure certainty in the valuation system.

Under the Valuation of Land Act 1944, State Valuation Services makes valuations of up to 1.6 million properties in Queensland. The valuations are undertaken in a professional manner using a longstanding legislative process for the valuation of land in its unimproved state. This process has been used in Queensland for many years. The use of land valuations is considered to be the most effective basis for revenue gathering and occurs throughout Australia and in many other countries. It is used as a basis for the collection of rates by local governments, land tax by Queensland Treasury and state land rental by the Department of Environment and Resource Management. It is critical that landowners have confidence in the system.

The Court of Appeal decision in December 2009 relating to Pacific Fair Shopping Centre in effect will change the way in which State Valuation Services undertakes its valuations. The court’s interpretation of the legislation has, in fact, created two methodologies in how a valuation is determined: one methodology for commercial and industrial properties and one for residential properties. If the court’s decision was to stand, the ramifications of the decision would be to drastically reduce valuations for commercial, industrial and multiunit properties but not for residential properties. It would also require the refund of revenue by local governments and Queensland Treasury. The outcome of this would be that local governments’ ability to undertake necessary public works could have been seriously impacted to the detriment of local landowners. This uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue. The procedures set out in this bill restore surety to the revenue base.

I received in my office yesterday a letter from the Office of the Mayor, Councillor Allan Sutherland, for the Moreton Bay Regional Council. It is dated 5 March and he wrote it to the Premier. Throughout it he says things such as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This Bill responds to a ruling in the Court of Appeal and is designed to protect ‘mum and dad’ ratepayers, and in turn their councils, from having to meet any large shortfalls in revenue caused by the retrospective re-evaluation of commercial properties and shopping centres.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mr Sutherland goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Should last year’s court decision stand, Moreton Bay Regional Council’s revenue loss could be in the vicinity of $26 million, or an additional cost of $6.75 for every ratepayer per million dollars lost. Effectively this means Moreton Bay’s 120,000 residential ratepayers will end up subsidising the rating obligations of the commercial and property sector.
XML.Hansard-Body: He goes on to talk about the fact that the Moreton Bay Regional Council is committed to keeping residential rate rises to a minimum as part of the amalgamation process and he has told me that last year that council delivered one of the lowest rate increases in South-East Queensland. They have been able to achieve this by reducing triplication across the three former councils to deliver $9.1 million in savings last financial year and an anticipated $10 million this year. He further states in his letter--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To now face a $26 million shortfall would send our council and the community backwards--and significantly derail our efforts to make amalgamation work for our community.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He finishes up by saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Once again, I appreciate and value the Bligh government’s actions to date and your intention to support, assist and protect councils across Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: It would appear that Councillor Allan Sutherland and the Moreton Bay Regional Council get it, it seems that all the members on this side of the House get it, but once again the LNP members have shown that they fundamentally cannot understand good legislative process and protecting our community and making sure there is fairness across the system.

Without the amendments in this bill the decision of the Court of Appeal would have a major impact on local government’s provision of essential services to all Queenslanders, services such as road maintenance, public parks and recreation reserves, libraries and so many more things. The amendments in this bill will ensure that residential ratepayers will not be adversely impacted and local governments can continue to provide these valuable services.

How do the amendments do that? The amendments make sure that the way in which statutory valuations have always been undertaken does not change. The amendments confirm that the valuations that have been issued have been issued correctly and that the valuations that have been issued in the past in local government areas across Queensland will not change. That means that the proportion of rates or land tax that residential landholders pay will not have to change.

Despite claims that have been made by peak property industry bodies, the amendments are not a new tax on Queenslanders. What this bill provides for is clarification of the valuation system in Queensland to ensure equity and fairness to all property owners in Queensland. The government is committed to ensuring that all properties in Queensland are valued using the same process. The amendments ensure that big business does not gain a windfall at the expense of ordinary landowners. The government has moved quickly to protect the revenue base of local governments and to ensure that landowners are not deprived of those essential services that are expected to be provided by this level of government. It has also moved to protect the state government’s revenue base to allow it to meet its commitment to provide services to the people of Queensland. I congratulate the minister, his staff and his department on drafting this sensible and very important legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP)
(4.16 pm): In rising to participate in this debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 I would like to address in particular the streamlined objection and appeal process changes contained within it. All landowners who believe that their land valuation is incorrect have the right to object to the valuation, which results in a review of the original valuation of the property and other nearby properties. This bill introduces a more transparent and efficient process for Queensland landowners to object to their valuation. I would like to place on the record that a number of constituents have brought this particular part of the valuation process to my attention and I have relayed to them that there are changes in this bill that will address their concerns.

The new objection process will ensure that landowners know what information they have to provide so that the department has better information to decide land valuation objections and can do this in a more timely manner. Currently the legislation does not require landowners to provide any supporting evidence when lodging an objection. This means that the department had to review objections without a reasonable level of information to support that objection. As a result of this, departmental staff had to repeatedly go back to some objectors requesting information and the basis of these objections. These often lengthy exchanges resulted in significant delays in deciding all of the objections before them. Frequently the information was not forthcoming.

As insufficient information was available when making a decision this often resulted in an objection being disallowed and the landowner consequently appealing the decision to the Land Court. This has resulted in significant legal costs to both the objector and the department in defending valuation decisions in the Land Court. Consequently the objection and appeal process has not been transparent or efficient for landowners or, indeed, the department. This bill sets out a better process for the landowner to object to a new land valuation making it more transparent and efficient.

As was the case previously, landowners will still have 45 days after the date of issue of a notice of valuation in which to lodge an objection in the approved form. In addition, if the form is not correctly completed landowners will be advised by the department and will have a further 14 days to resubmit the correctly filled out form. Only if the objection meets the standard format and the information requirements--that is, the objection is properly made--will the department progress the objection to the review and the decision stage. This will ensure that valuers from the department have a reasonable amount of information to consider an objection and will streamline the decision-making stage, thereby reducing the time taken to decide objections.

To help landowners lodge an objection, a simple step-by-step guide will be available in March when the 2010 land valuations are issued. This guide will ensure that all landowners with a legitimate concern about their land valuation can have their case considered by the department. Landowners will be able to access a copy from the department’s website or call centre, which will be operating during the objection period.

Another change to be introduced is that if an agent submits an objection on behalf of a landowner the objection form must be accompanied by the landowner’s written consent. That will ensure that all objections are made with the full knowledge and authority of the landowner. Once an objection has been properly made, a valuer will assess the objection and the amendments in this bill will enable the valuer to request additional information from the landowner at that stage. In most cases, this will be done by the department making a written request to the landowner to provide specific information.

In cases of highly valued property, valued at $2 million or more, the owner may be required to provide specific information that is necessary for the valuer to determine the property’s value. These measures apply where the valuer requires specific information that was not provided in the original objection but that is required for them to fully consider the objection before them. When the owner can show that they do not have the information at hand, they can do so. Through this process, landowners will have an opportunity to add information that may not have been available at the time of lodging the objection form or modify the grounds of the objection. It also clarifies factors that are not valid grounds for an objection, such as a personal circumstance, council rating or land tax levels. Previously, a landowner could appeal to the Land Court on different grounds from those considered and decided in the original objection. Therefore, the circumstances considered by the objection decision maker would be different from those considered by the Land Court.

It is important to remember that the new objection process does not commence until the new valuations are issued in late March 2010. The existing objection form 58 is current until the 2010 valuation issues and should be used for any interim objections. The new forms will be gazetted prior to the issue date and the Law Society will be advised when the form is available and will be provided with a link to the guide and form on the department’s website. This means that solicitors who use the form will be aware that the objection process and the form have changed. It is important to note that generally more than 98 per cent of landowners believe that their valuation is correct and do not lodge an objection.

The revised guide and the notice of objection form will be available from the Department of Environment and Resource Management website, by contacting the department business centre or by phoning a number on the valuation notice in March when the annual land valuations are issued. This new process encourages landowners to declare relevant information upfront, thereby allowing the department to assess their objection in a timely manner. By ensuring that the same grounds for objection carry through to the subsequent appeal, the department’s resources can be directed to efficiently resolving objections and issuing appropriate valuations. I commend the minister and I commend the bill to the House.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (4.23 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, which is obviously a blatant tax grab by Anna Bligh and her Labor government. Under their stewardship, Queensland went bust in a boom and this move will only cost Queenslanders jobs. Along with my colleagues, I call on the government to throw out this ill-thought-out, muddled legislation. We will continue the immense pressure brought to bear by the Liberal National Party and groups such as the Property Council of Queensland to ensure that this legislation is not supported. Nothing short of major amendments will suffice and one would hope that, with enough pressure, this legislation will not be successful and will lead to yet another monumental backflip by the government, which is obviously cobbling together policy on the run with little regard for the fact that it will put even further pressure on the long-suffering residents of Queensland who are already coping with a downgrade in our credit rating.

This morning we heard the Premier talking about the introduction of further legislation in September to tidy up the mess the government has made of this bill. On behalf of the constituents of Mudgeeraba, I reiterate that this is a blatant tax grab by Anna Bligh and her Labor government because Queensland went bust in a boom. This move will cost Queenslanders jobs and it will hit business, particularly small business, due to the resulting increase in land tax. This will result in Queenslanders’ jobs being destroyed. It will be devastating to business certainty in Queensland and will reduce our state’s attractiveness as an investment destination. This too will result in Queenslanders’ jobs being destroyed. Yet again housing affordability will be hit as the costs for homebuyers will rise to reflect the increase in land tax, particularly in greenfield sites. This will result in houses becoming even more out of reach for Queensland first home buyers. In addition, average Queenslanders will be hit through the impact on their superannuation funds, most of which include some form of land investments. This will result in Queenslanders’ retirement funds disappearing.

The Bligh government has been caught out breaking the law twice and it is retrospectively changing the law to make legal this radical change to land tax. In addition, the Bligh government is effectively removing most of Queenslanders’ right to object and appeal decisions made regarding the value of their land. The LNP will be opposing this opportunistic cash grab. We will be opposing the bill, but accepting the amendments and not opposing the amended bill. As my colleague the shadow minister for natural resources, mines and energy, Jeff Seeney, stated in his speech earlier today, the amendments mean the changes will only apply for the next year and, if a new bill is not introduced, foreshadowed for September 2011, valuations will be assessed on the legislation that is in effect now, that is, before the commencement of the amended bill before the House.

In essence, the amendments change the retrospectivity of the bill to validate previous valuations, with the exception of outstanding appeals that must be resolved by 30 June 2010. The bill applies the government’s definition of ‘unimproved value’ with minor changes subject to it being replaced with site value in the bill to be introduced in September. That will allow the 2010 valuations to be released at the end of March, that is, this month. The bill has a sunset clause by the end of the next financial year after which, if a new bill has not passed, the current regime will be reactivated.

Appeals and objections continue to be massively restricted. There have been some other announcements, including the reinstatement of an independent Valuer-General, a move to site value by September 2010 and, in essence, the following fundamental issues remain: the government’s attempt to fundamentally change the definition of ‘unimproved land’ in Queensland, the effective removal of objections and appeal rights, and the future of the land valuation system. In essence, the changes allow the government to save face regarding the poor bill that it introduced and to return to the consultation process to find a workable long-term solution to land valuations in Queensland.

This is an obvious tax on entrepreneurial efforts and nothing more than a great big new tax for Queenslanders. In an advertisement in the Courier-Mail on 18 February 2010, the Property Council of Australia stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A ‘GREAT BIG NEW TAX’ IS ALREADY HERE IN QUEENSLAND
There’s a sneaky new business tax being rushed through by the Bligh government.
The biggest ever change to land taxation--and you probably don’t even know it’s happening.
But if you own commercial, industrial, retail, rural or residential investment property--this affects you.
You’ll not only be taxed on the value of your land--but also on any extra value created by your hard work.
It’s called the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. And it’s retrospective!
Not much of an incentive for your hard work--is it?
It will affect every Queenslander.

Increasing land taxes and council rates. Putting pressure on mortgages and rents. Crippling small businesses, the rural sector and tourism owners and operators. Torpedoing job-creating projects. Shrinking the value of your superannuation. Increasing prices of goods you buy.
We already have very high rateable land values in Queensland, meaning we already pay much more land tax than most other States.
Now the more you improve your property, the more tax you will pay. The more successful you are, the more you will be penalised.
If we do nothing this new tax will rob Queenslanders and their properties of hundreds of millions of dollars.
Investors will take their money, and the jobs they create, to other States.
XML.Hansard-Body: Further in a letter to my office dated 22 February 2010, the Property Council of Australia brought the following to my attention, which would horrify all the mum-and-dad investors in the electorate of Mudgeeraba, and I quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is not just a ‘big business issue’, this will also have an impact on small business owners, who will be taxed for their efforts, and the harder they work the more land tax they will pay with increases in land tax expected of 20 to 40%. It will also hit residential investors including ‘mum and dad’ investors who have been diligently investing for their retirement. Those renting will also not be immune, with landowners passing on the increased cost of owning land through rental increases.
XML.Hansard-Body: Over the past few weeks many residents and business owners in Mudgeeraba have contacted me on this issue. One constituent stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Obviously we would not be happy with the proposed land tax calculation. Land tax already has gone up $8500 (from $16,000 to $23,500) for Mudgeeraba property last year, the money grab is out of control.
XML.Hansard-Body: Another constituent stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am appalled that yet another piece of oppressive, retrospective ill-considered legislation is being contemplated. I own a property within the electorate of Mudgeeraba and have already been adversely affected by the Bligh Government’s amendments to the Land Tax Act passed in 2009.

The proposed new legislation is arrogant and offensive--having lost its appeal in the Courts, the Bligh Government now proposes a bizarre solution which is doubly offensive through incorporating a retrospective change in the law.

This proposed new law will adversely affect a vast number of landholders in Queensland and will tell the rest of Australia that Queensland is a bizarre place where the Bligh Government has no respect for normal commercial and legal principles, and no understanding for the usual processes of accounting and property valuation. This inevitably worsens business uncertainty and is more akin to rule by decree and the ‘heads I win, tails you lose’ principle.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Yet another constituent states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am writing to express my absolute dismay that such a proposal could even be considered never mind implemented. This is not only about Land Tax; this is about our whole economy and its destruction. The Government is actually proposing a brand new tax on a mammoth scale, which the property industry cannot absorb and so it must be passed on. Rents and prices must go up so the economy is on a new scale of costs at a critical point in recovery. The outcome is not hard to predict. This is a recipe for disaster and must be resisted at our peril.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Finally, a resident in Bonogin writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Until the GFC, we had a marginal but manageable financial position but over the last two years or so it has turned heavily against us and any negative impact--large increases in health insurance, car registration, council rates and electricity--will severely exacerbate our already tenuous finances.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would not be representing the mum-and-dad investors in my electorate if I put my support behind this current ill-conceived, ill-thought-out, cobbled together, lacklustre legislation, put together by a minister who obviously does not get it and who will not even be present to see the passage of his own bill through the House. I cannot support this legislation. I call on this Labor government to radically amend this legislation on behalf of my constituents in the electorate of Mudgeeraba.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (4.32 pm): The Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, as it is currently before the House, is merely a tax grab by the Bligh government. It is driven by the state of the Queensland budget. Under this government and Queensland’s worst ever Treasurer, the budget this year--
Government members interjected.

Mr EMERSON: They interject on ‘the worst ever Treasurer’. I have seen a few Treasurers here. Let us have a look at his report card: state debt--F; deficit--F; AAA credit rating--F; unemployment--F. He is the worst Treasurer this state has ever seen. Under this government and Queensland’s worst ever Treasurer--and, unfortunately, many government members are likely to lose their seats because of this worst ever Treasurer. However, I did note from the Courier-Mail the other day that the Treasurer himself will hold on to his seat, according to the polling. Unfortunately, many of his colleagues will not.
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr EMERSON: It is good to hear the member for Everton standing up for the Treasurer.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! There is too much noise.
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr EMERSON: It is good to hear the rather feeble efforts of the member for Everton trying to defend his good friend--

Mr ROBERTSON: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. The member has now spoken for nigh on two minutes without referring at all to the bill that is currently being debated. I would ask you to instruct him to refer his comments, and make them relevant, to the bill before the House.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! There is no point of order. Will the member be certain to stay on the bill.
Mr EMERSON: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I do appreciate the opportunity to speak on the bill. As I began, before a few interjections from my opponents across from me--
Mr Watt interjected.

Mr EMERSON: The member for Everton again wants to have his piece and talk about the poor state of his side of parliament. The Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, currently before the House, is merely a tax grab by the Bligh Labor government--along with its tax grabs from everywhere else. It is being driven by the state of the Queensland budget. Under this government and--I say it again--Queensland’s worst ever Treasurer, the budget this year has a $2.3 billion deficit and the peak debt is currently budgeted to be $85 billion. The LNP will be opposing this opportunistic cash grab, as presented in this bill.

For the current year, land tax will net the Bligh government just over $1 billion--a 30 per cent rise on the previous year. The Bligh government now appears determined to create the most punitive valuation and land tax regime in the country. The minister says that he wants to ‘correct the appeal court’s interpretation of the law’. The appeal court has said, ‘This is what the law is,’ and the minister does not agree. So he wants to correct the court. This is a radically different approach to any other land-rating system in Australia. This proposal is retrospective, applying to valuations since 2002. It overturns historic valuation principle and practice in Australia. Effectively, the more an owner improves their property, the more they will be taxed.

The bill redefines ‘unimproved value’, taking into account intangibles such as leases, goodwill and profits. Queensland has always used unimproved value as the basis for setting valuations--that is, the value of the land without improvements. This bill proposes to include such elements as leases and business goodwill, which have nothing to do with the land; they relate to the business on the land. To quote the Queensland Law Society president, the bill is ‘ill-conceived’ and takes the nonsensical decision to turn the term ‘unimproved value’ on its head to mean ‘improved value’.

This bill will cost Queenslanders jobs. It will hit business, particularly small business, due to the resulting increase in land tax and this will result in Queenslanders’ jobs being destroyed. Housing affordability will also be hit, as the cost for homebuyers will rise to reflect the increase in land tax. This will result in houses becoming even more out of reach for Queensland’s first home owners.
Government members interjected.

Mr EMERSON: It is sad to see how unconcerned my opposition is here to the issue of housing affordability. We want Queenslanders to be able to afford homes; they obviously do not care about that at all. In addition, average Queenslanders will be hit through the impact on their superannuation funds, most of which include some form of land investment. This will result in Queenslanders’ retirement funds disappearing.

The legislation will not affect just the big end of town. The principles outlined in this legislation do not apply just to the big end of town. In fact, the legislation does not make reference to big business, shopping centres or large commercial or industrial properties. The bill will apply to a unit, a small business or a house. These principles are required to be applied to all classes of land. They will hit residential investors, including mum-and-dad investors who have been diligently investing for their retirement. Those renting will not be immune, with landowners passing on the increased cost of owning land through rent increases. While your home remains exempt from land tax, your investment property may not. The benefit you receive from rental income from an investment property will now be included in calculating the unimproved value of your land which then determines your land tax bill.

These effects are not restricted to property owners, with increased costs able to be passed on to tenants. One in three homes in my electorate are rented--about 50 per cent more than the Queensland average. Most of those renting are students attending the University of Queensland. They continually struggle to afford to pay their rent. They have already seen public transport fees go up under this government. They have already seen the price of fuel go up under this government. What they do not need to see is their rents rise because of another tax grab by the Bligh government. I have been contacted by many constituents about this bill.
Government members: How many?

Mr EMERSON: Let me read it out for the interest of honourable members. Obviously they are concerned about this now. It was interesting to hear that they were not concerned before about those renting properties. They must not have anyone in their electorates who rents. As one of my constituents who wrote to me said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: As a retired person who relies on a self-funded pension and investment property, I am appalled at the prospect of additional costs associated with owning property ...
There is only one alternative and that is to automatically increase rent.
Then there is a flow-on effect to renters and increases to the cost of living.
It doesn’t make sense and is counter-productive.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am aware of the amendments flagged by the government which clearly recognise the public’s concerns with this legislation.
