As I have said, the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is merely a tax grab by the Bligh government. In its current form, the LNP will be opposing this opportunistic cash grab.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (4.40 pm): This piece of legislation we are debating today shows that this government is prepared do anything to get more money out of Queensland taxpayers. What is worse, it is trying to con people into believing that this bill is business as usual. Land tax is one of the biggest contributors to the Queensland Treasury coffers. It will generate $1 billion in tax revenue this year--up from less than $400 million over the past five years. In the past 10 years it has gone up by well over 300 per cent. Over 70 per cent of that increase has occurred in the last couple of years. The economic slowdown has led to inequities between land tax value and the current market value of property. Land tax is being paid on the basis of valuations conducted when the impact of the slowdown is still happening.

Investors are faced with land tax bills that reflect the value of their property that would not be realised if they tried to sell it. This inflated value is made worse by three-year averaging systems. The government has also deferred revaluations of land in a number of regions last year, ensuring that land tax rates continue to be inflated. Property owners in this state are already struggling to pay these excessive land tax bills. These new laws could well be the final straw for many of those landowners.

Land tax is not just paid by the big end of town. It affects small investors--the mums and dads who have put some money away in property to help fund their retirement. It affects all businesses whether they own the land they operate on or are tenants. Land tax increases will inevitably have to be passed on to the end user in one form or another. Increased costs to business directly impact on employment and investment, not just investment by companies already in Queensland but potential new businesses. We need new investment, but we will not get it by making our taxes even higher. Investors will turn to other states with lower tax regimes. Existing jobs will be lost in Queensland and new ones will not be created.

The message this government is sending to the business and investment community is: be successful in Queensland and we will slug you with higher taxes. What a great incentive that is to keep people away from the state. This legislation changes the rules on the definition of unimproved land so that it can include goodwill, the value of leases, development profits and infrastructure charges. All of these are, in fact, improvements. Improvements under these changes will mean that landowners pay more tax. The added costs are likely to flow on to council rates as well.

The government would have us believe that these charges will only affect large landholders--big commercial enterprises like shopping centres--but the legislation applies across-the-board. It will be imposed on all land that is subject to land tax. That includes residential land and residential property owned by investors. What a joke from a government that pretends to have a commitment to affordable housing. This is not going to help their cause by any means. It will drive up the cost of housing. I think they know that.

The negative impact on the value of assets like office buildings and shopping centres will flow through to those who invest in commercial property, many of whom are retirees or people who have contributed to superannuation funds. Worse still, this bill is retrospective. It applies to all valuations from June 2002. It begs the question: how many more laws will this government seek to bring into retrospectivity when it does not like a decision handed down by the court? Who knows what it is going to do next?

So desperate is this government to find excuses for this bill that it even claims the additional cost to the government in its implementation will be offset by savings for landowners and the department in taking cases to the Land Court. There is no mention of the substantial additional cost of increased land taxes. This will have to be met by all landowners. Has the government considered the real cost of undertaking the individual valuations required when additional factors like leases and goodwill have to be taken into account? This will mean an enormous amount of additional work compared to the traditional approach of a mass appraisal. How will the government guarantee these valuations will be applied consistently and fairly?

If landowners want to object to the valuation, this bill will make this process more difficult. Objections will need to be supported by significantly more supporting documentation. Appeals will be limited to matters raised by the property owner in their original objection. Owners may also face revised higher valuations on the basis of the financial information they are required to provide. Let us make no mistake: it is ordinary people across this state who will be unfairly targeted by another tax grab.

I would like to refer to just a couple of examples of my own constituents who have expressed their concerns to me. One is a retired couple who have a small commercial investment property. They have been trying to minimise rent and other increases to tenants who are small businesses and retailers who have been doing it tough over the last couple of years. This couple have invested in improvements to their property to improve the amenity of the area. Their reward for that effort and expenditure will be increased land tax which will, in some form, have to be passed on to the tenants. This concerns my constituents who are well aware that extra costs may force some people out of business. As small investors without the resources of a big company, the new objection process will also be more difficult for them to access.

Another constituent has several investment properties, all of which are mortgaged. With the economic downturn, his income from those properties is around $35,000 a year, but his land tax bill is currently $100,000. His bank valuations have decreased but his land tax will continue to increase. In order to meet his land tax bill, he has already laid off staff and will impose pay cuts on others. He is now seriously considering cutting his losses and taking his investment money out of Queensland because he cannot afford to invest here anymore.

This government keeps telling us that it is about job creation. Property investment creates jobs. As my constituent said to me, ‘Where is the incentive now to invest in property?’ He is just one person for whom yet another massive hike in land tax is one too many. Make no mistake: this bill is not about business as usual. It is not just another huge tax increase by a government desperate to reduce the massive debt that it has inflicted upon the state. It also changes the whole principle of unimproved land value to include improvements to the land that will increase its value. This is bad law not just for property owners but also for all Queenslanders.

This government has imposed on the people of Queensland a fuel tax, rate rises, amalgamation, the sale of assets, the debacle of the Traveston Dam and still the controversy relating to water. Where is this government heading? I think it needs to learn from the mistakes of the past because it continues to repeat them. Forcing businesses out of Queensland is not going to create jobs. That is what this land tax is doing. This bill is going to transfer increased land tax costs onto people who rent properties, who work on those properties and who are employed by people who own the properties. The government is going to be forcing people out of work.

If the government is serious about trying to reach its target of 100,000 jobs created in Queensland, this is the perfect way not to do it. What it is doing is going against its own principles that it committed to the people of Queensland at the last election. The government promised it would create 100,000 jobs. This is the right ingredient to cancel jobs in Queensland. Tomorrow, after this bill is passed, I would like to hear the Premier come in here and say, ‘We have just destroyed so many jobs in Queensland.’ I hope the government has factored it into the documentation in this new land tax grab, because that is what it is going to do. It is going to destroy jobs. It is going to make people and businesses move out of Queensland and invest elsewhere because this is a greedy state government which has not been able to manage the economic climate in this state over the past 20-odd years, except for the two years when we were in government. Those opposite are bad managers of money, and they need to realise it. They need to get good advice from good businesspeople in our community, because they are not listening to them. They are about to destroy their livelihoods and drive them out of the state.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP)
(4.49 pm): I rise to join the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill which was introduced into the House on 11 February by the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. This bill seeks to amend the Valuation of Land Act 1944 by altering the definition of unimproved value of land, reforming the process for objection and appeals to a valuation and devising a schedule of valuations to replace annual valuations.

As honourable members have heard from the honourable member for Callide and LNP shadow minister and other opposition members, we on this side of the House feel that this legislation is repugnant. The LNP vehemently opposes sections of this bill that relate to land valuations as it currently stands before the House.

Rarely have we witnessed such an uproar from industry stakeholders who fear for the welfare of every Queenslander. This sort of advertising blitz is usually a union funded campaign. We saw and heard outside the parliament this morning the wrath of angry unionists who are ropable that this government is selling off their assets. For Hansard I note that the Premier, the Treasurer and the member for Brisbane Central abandoned them. They did not have the courage to go out and meet with these people whom they purport to represent.

Only yesterday evening this government moved this bill from No. 6 on the Notice Paper up to No. 1. Then this morning those opposite hastily gobbled together amendments as a direct result of the massive backlash from industry bodies. In doing so, the government has admitted that it got it wrong and that, if the legislation as it was introduced were passed, Queensland industries and the Queensland economy would be far worse off. As honourable members have heard, the LNP are prepared to consider the proposed amendments that were described by the Premier this morning based on their merit. Following a decision of the Court of Appeal in December 2009 that rejected the government’s appeal of the valuation of Pacific Fair on the Gold Coast, this government has attempted to overturn decades of industry practice to save itself from its imminent demise.

The bill before us will have a dramatic impact on the way land is valued in Queensland and subsequently on the amount of land tax and rates that owners must pay. The implications of these changes are enormous and not only threaten to affect owners of commercial land but tenants, mum-and-dad investors, small business owners, superannuation fund holders--the list, unfortunately, is endless here. This bill is little more than a sneaky attempt to hike up the government’s land tax base and boost its income stream to the detriment of industry, businesses and the economy in the long term.

The provisions in the bill before us represent a substantial shift in the legislation relating to land valuation which should be given the respect of honest and thorough consultation from industry representatives. Prior to introducing the legislation, consultation only occurred with the Local Government Association of Queensland and probably some government departments which stand to gain considerably from these amendments. Key industry bodies have led the fight against this government’s outrageous attempt to overthrow decades of industry practice. These include the Property Council of Australia, the Shopping Centre Council of Australia, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland, the Queensland Law Society, the Urban Development Institute of Australia and the Real Estate Institute of Queensland, among others. The Queensland division of the Property Council of Australia in particular has expressed its deep concern with this legislation, as many members would be aware. Its interpretation of the changes is that the proposed definition of unimproved value will now extend to entrepreneurial effort. The more an owner improves their property the greater likelihood their taxes will increase based on this new definition.

Typical of this government, the harder someone works the harder the government will punish them for their effort. Small businesses, the retail sector and the tourism industry are still struggling to recover from the huge losses as a result of the global financial crisis. Passage of this bill would be a huge blow to industry throughout Queensland and the long-term effects would see our economy going backwards.

LandMark White, a leading valuation company, says these changes represent a sizeable shift that will affect everyone in Queensland at some level. The greatest concerns of LandMark White and others within the Property Council of Australia committee are the radical amendments to long-established valuation practice, the unworkable objection and appeal process that has been proposed and the retrospectivity which will remove the rights of some 300 appellants currently appealing their valuations before the land courts. The government’s assertion that the changes proposed in this bill reflect procedures that have been practised for decades is highly disputed by these industry professionals.

As it is defined in the bill before the House, the term ‘unimproved value’ has been completely warped by this government. What the government is calling a clarification of the definition of unimproved value is about as far from the definition of the word as the term itself is proposed to become. Unimproved capital value, as it is understood by the industry, and has been for many years, is the value of the land in its raw state. Regardless of what has happened to the land at the owner’s discretion, unimproved value is assessed without improvements.

If this bill is passed in its current form, unimproved capital value will be assessed essentially as improved value, taking into consideration a number of intangible measures that have the potential to greatly increase land values and subsequently land tax and rates for business and property owners. Unimproved value will include: the development premium or profit and risk associated with the historical development of the land; leases, including arrangement for leases; a component for goodwill as a measure of the business or purpose the land is being used for; and infrastructure charges--a far cry from the clarity offered by this government.

A submission by the Queensland Law Society to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee warned that the ambiguous drafting of the word to the opposite of its ordinary meaning is inappropriate and misleading. The definition as proposed in the current bill has absolutely no correlation to the industry accepted use of the term. But those on the other side of the House are happy enough to change the entire backbone of the industry without a shred of consultation.

If the government thinks that the litigation sparked from the definition of unimproved value was too much to handle in the past, the inclusion of these highly subjective terms will undoubtedly drastically increase people flocking to object to the valuations. By proposing an onerous and virtually impossible procedure for lodging an objection, however, this government is ensuring that its decisions will remain unopposed.

Instead of propping up the resources available to land courts, the government’s proposed amendments will directly shift the onus to civil property owners who are unlikely to have the capable industry knowledge to complete the requirements. If this bill is passed an objection will need to include particulars of the facts and circumstances relied upon for the grounds of objection. One industry leader has suggested that professional assistance will be needed to lodge an objection because of the standard of proof that will be required.

Stakeholders believe requests are more likely to be disallowed by a public servant because of a non-complying objection rather than anything to do with the merit of the claim. The President of the Queensland Law Society, Peter Eardley, has concerns that the 14-day period for modifying an unsatisfactory objection will be ‘woefully inadequate in most circumstances’ and the proposed appeal process is ‘virtually unworkable’.

This bill seeks to apply alterations to the ‘unimproved value’ definition retrospectively to valuations in effect in or after 30 June 2002. The Property Council of Australia asserts that Queensland currently has the highest unimproved values of land in the country, with business and property owners already having to fork out exorbitant amounts in land tax for commercial, retail and industrial properties. In making this legislation retrospective the government is trying to weasel its way out of paying back property owners money that has been taxed and spent outside of its legislative purpose.

It could not be more obvious from the nature of the legislation before us that the government’s reaction to the Pacific Fair decision is just another excuse for a big tax grab. While Queensland’s land tax rate is calculated at a low two per cent, the Property Council of Australia asserts that Queenslanders face relatively high rateable land values. In other words, the tax might be low but the inflated values of Queensland properties see Queenslanders coughing up more to the government.

Indeed, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland reports that government land tax receipts have increased by over $817 million or 355 per cent since 2000-01. A whopping 72 per cent increase has been seen in the last two years alone. It does make one ask where all this money is going. And this from a government whose ill-fated election promise was to protect Queenslanders from more taxes! Those on the other side of the House can cry all they want that these changes will only affect the big end of town, not residential property owners, not local shopping centres. Unfortunately, the stories of those in my electorate of Currumbin reflect the real situation.

One residential landowner in my electorate detailed the increase in land tax from $4,300 in 1996 to $42,000 in 2009. Likewise, his council rates soared at an equivalent pace. Increasing the tax burden on owners will see tenants bearing the brunt of the financial hardship. It is logical for landowners to pass increasing maintenance costs on to tenants, and these proposed amendments will mark a point of no return for housing affordability in Queensland.

The retail sector, still trying to recover after the enormous economic downturn that gripped the world about a year ago, will undoubtedly suffer due to the changes proposed in this bill. One of the largest shopping centres in my electorate, The Pines, revealed that the unimproved value of its land has increased from $14 million to $31 million in just three years, with no work or material changes made to the centre itself. This centre has over 50 per cent of its tenants being small and independent businesses or franchises. The ongoing effects of this increase will hurt small business in a big way and may send many to the wall. If this bill is passed, it is scary to think what the land tax for this shopping centre might become.

The lack of foresight of those opposite in the House is outstanding. This short-sighted, sneaky approach to improve the state budget’s bottom line and forgo any consideration of what these proposed amendments will do to the Queensland economy in the long term is negligent. The unnecessary stress and angst that it is causing people around this great state is totally unacceptable. Businesses, jobs and investment are all under threat by this government’s hasty decision to bring this bill in. One Queensland law firm has described the impact of the inevitable disincentive to invest in Queensland as the legacy to be left by this incompetent government.

Members have been inundated with correspondence from investment industry professionals along with mum-and-dad investors and everyday citizens over the last couple of weeks detailing the loss of investment in Queensland that will be the direct result of passing this bill into law. Investment, whether interstate, national or international, is crucial to the future economic prosperity of our state. This bill as introduced by the government shows total disregard for attracting investment in the Queensland business and property sectors and makes a complete mockery of the Bligh government’s ‘jobs, jobs, jobs’ mantra.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (5.01 pm): I rise to support the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I want to start by thanking all of my constituents and business representatives who have either spoken to me directly or contacted my office regarding this legislation. Obviously they were stirred into action by what I believe was somewhat misleading information regarding the true objects of this bill, and I am looking forward to confirming the information I have forwarded to these people who contacted my office.

I know that land tax can be a very controversial issue. Nobody likes paying land tax and, with valuations increasing in recent times, it is not surprising that recent misleading media statements brought to the surface for many residents concerns regarding how they may be impacted and gave them the opportunity to highlight what they think about land tax in general. I have listened to what they have said and read all of the emails and correspondence and can assure my constituents that I have passed on their concerns, and I am pleased that the government listened to those concerns and we have the bill that we are debating this afternoon.

However, it is pleasing today to outline exactly what this bill aims to achieve and to get the record straight with regard to these amendments--clearly, amendments that have not been understood by those opposite when we take into account the recent contribution by the member for Currumbin. Firstly, as advised to those who contacted my office, this bill does not change the way land is valued in Queensland. In fact, it aims to achieve the status quo and to validate valuations which would have been impacted upon due to the recent Court of Appeal decision that threatened to turn past processes upside down. Also, this decision would have had drastic consequences for local governments, where it has been estimated that up to $600 million in rate repayments to commercial and industrial property owners would have to be made if the bill were not enacted.

This bill will ensure that, with the way homes are valued, property owners will see no change to the manner in which their valuations are prepared. This provides certainty and delivers an outcome which means no new taxes for property owners--I repeat: no new taxes for property owners--and no big refunds from state or local governments. Validating valuations already issued is the most sensible course of action to take, and I support this bill in doing so. I just do not understand why one would be opposing this bill as amended. In addition, this bill will ensure that the method for valuing property is crystal clear now and into the future by completing the 2010 valuation with certainty.

I also note that, as a preliminary report tabled by the minister today demonstrates, obviously due to the global financial crisis valuations have generally decreased--a situation that even the Property Council of Australia Queensland branch agrees with, as it has stated that it expects that 2010 valuations will generally be lower because of the GFC.

I also welcome recent statements made by the Premier and the minister, who have committed to going further and introducing a simpler method of valuation--site value--for non-rural lands from 2011. Site value methodology will bring Queensland into line with other Australian states from 2011 valuations for all property owners except those in rural areas. I also welcome the commitment to introduce an independent statutory position of Valuer-General to lead Queensland’s State Valuation Services. I note that the member for Currumbin described this bill as ‘repugnant’. She clearly has not kept up to date, because I note that the Property Council of Australia Queensland branch has stated that it is pleased that this bill being debated today will address many of the concerns raised by industry. In fact, I have in my hands its press release, issued today, which says ‘Queensland property owners breathe sigh of relief’--
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Member for Lockyer!

Ms GRACE: It goes on to say how pleased it is with what the bill we are debating today contains. Just keep up, those opposite; just keep up. It is not that hard. It states--and I agree--that this bill will ensure that the rights of those appellants with objections or appeals before the courts are protected and that settlement negotiations will continue under the current act until 30 June 2010. It is also pleased with--not averse to--the government’s commitment to a full review of the state’s valuation system for the 2011 round of valuations, with a focus on site valuations.
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Lockyer, that is your final warning.

Ms GRACE: I know that it is looking forward to being consulted over the coming months in relation to this review, and I support full and proper engagement with industry as outlined by executive director Steve Greenwood--an ex-constituent of mine, I might add--in his media statement of today.

To set the record straight, I believe it is important to outline that Queensland has the highest threshold and lowest maximum rate of any state for individual taxpayers with regard to land tax. Queensland’s land tax effort as measured by the Commonwealth Grants Commission was 30 per cent below the national average in 2008-09, and this is the latest independent comparative data. So all of those statements made by those opposite are misleading and untrue. This bill as amended addresses many of the concerns raised with government. As the Property Council of Australia’s media release states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I would like to acknowledge the strong leadership shown by the Premier in our final negotiations which ensured that a satisfactory resolution could be reached.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Seeney: You don’t believe that!
Ms GRACE: That is what it has said.
Mr Seeney: You don’t believe that!

Ms GRACE: I do not have to believe it; I am merely stating what the Property Council of Australia Queensland branch has said. So we have industry pleased in coming on board by welcoming the amendments but, as usual, all we get from the other side is carping and nonsupport for a bill that addresses industry concerns, protects ordinary ratepayers as outlined by the LGAQ and commits to surety for current appeals or objections currently before the court.
Yet again, from those opposite there is no policy alternative. Nothing has been put. There is no alternative plan and no idea. Member for Callide, you did not offer one--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! I would ask the member for Brisbane Central to direct her comments through the chair.

Ms GRACE: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I apologise. The member for Callide gave no idea whatsoever in his speech in regard to this bill. This bill indeed provides for what the government has set out to do. Those members opposite have come into this House and made misleading and untruthful statements and, unfortunately, the member for Clayfield likes to play the person and not the ball. This bill provides exactly what the government intends to do. It protects the ordinary mum-and-dad ratepayers who would have been severely impacted by the recent Court of Appeal decision, as confirmed by the LGAQ. This bill maintains the status quo by validating valuations that have already been issued, ensuring no new taxes and no unsustainable impacts on local governments. I say that for the benefit of the member for Indooroopilly, who seems to think that all the taxes in the world are going to rise and that the whole world is going to fall in. As for the member for Buderim, my goodness! All businesses are going to leave Queensland and go somewhere else. Unfortunately, land taxes there are higher than they are in Queensland.

We also have people who are concerned about rent increases. Those opposite have talked about rent increases, yet not one of them has made any statement in here on behalf of unit owners or unit renters who have experienced rate increases beyond their unbelievable imagination. Of course, in regard to that issue there has been no comment from those opposite on the impact of those increases.

This bill also protects appellants’ rights currently before the court to be settled under the current act until 30 June. This bill is essential for all the reasons that I have outlined. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr ELMES (Noosa--LNP) (5.11 pm): I rise to make my contribution to this critically important debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I welcome this opportunity, as I do every time I am given the opportunity to spend some time on my feet in this place to represent my electorate of Noosa. This is particularly the case today as the bill before the House seeks to savage my constituents of Noosa and those of my nearest colleagues in communities such as Cooroy and Eumundi by affecting employment. This bill will cost jobs in my seat--jobs that are very hard to replace when at the same time major employers are laying off a number of staff.

The first casualty of war is truth. If members read the Courier-Mail yesterday, they would have seen an advertisement--paid for with borrowed money to be repaid, principal and interest, by the long-suffering taxpayer of Queensland--which purported to tell those same taxpayers the truth. My office has been inundated by outraged constituents telling me that it is not so. They are telling me that that ad was the mother of all whoppers. But with the capitulation that we have witnessed today by the minister--a double backflip with pike that even the former Premier of Queensland, Peter Beattie, would have been proud--I ask: what has changed so dramatically in the past 24 hours to make Monday’s truth so different from today’s truth? Is it fluid truth or dynamic truth that we are hearing? It certainly is not the absolute truth.

I have prefaced my contribution with these remarks just to set in context that this Labor government is reminiscent to so many people who have migrated here from the southern states, particularly Victoria. I have heard painful stories about the dying days of the Cain-Kirner governments in Victoria when the poor unfortunate Joan Kirner was Premier. Of course, she inherited the consequences of the dreadful incompetence of her predecessor, John Cain, and his Treasurer. I am told that those were the days when you could see the weight of the state that was rapidly going broke etched in the faces of the populace as they shuffled along the streets of Melbourne like derelicts--shoulders stooped and spirits broken. Those were the days when the Labor government in its death throes tried to sell a hospital to a university and lease it back simply to get cash to meet its recurrent expenditure. Given the absolute panic that we have seen today by this Labor government and this minister, I wonder how far off such a repeat will be in Queensland following the desperate measures that we are seeing here today.

So why do these images keep recurring in my mind’s eye? Why do I lie awake at night in a cold sweat thinking about the possibility? It is because the evidence of a repeat of the Victorian experience is growing day by day? Here in Queensland, everywhere we look now the Labor government is failing and the financial chickens of that comprehensive failure are coming home to roost. One of the candidates for the job of Premier is enhancing his credentials for the leadership by sending WorkCover broke. If the Attorney-General does not act quickly, then WorkCover’s net debt will amount to about 20 per cent of the entire Queensland state budget.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! I remind the member for Noosa that this bill is not about WorkCover; it relates to land tax and I would ask you to come back to the bill.

Mr ELMES: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is because of the monumental failure by this Labor government to make our workplaces safe. This Labor government is now ratting around hither and yon looking for yet another hollow log from which to extract some revenue. It seeks it here, it seeks it there; it seeks it everywhere. It seeks a magic pot of gold at the end of the rainbow which is called the magic pudding. I will bet pounds to peanuts that the government has a very secret task force somewhere dreaming up new taxes and charges with its members to be paid on commission.

The Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is just the latest in another Labor government attempt to screw even more money out of our long-suffering community. It is gouging. It is using this bill to fix a mistake made in its rushed legislation only of last year to ensure that it can continue to mine $1 billion from land tax payers--a tax take that increased to $620 million from the $380 million of the very recent 2004-05 tax year. This hike is grossly unfair as the current property values are higher than market prices because the latest valuation was made before the impact of the current economic slowdown was felt. This effect is particularly disadvantageous for commercial property. The negative effect is made even worse by the three-year averaging, which keeps the valuations above the appropriate market price.

Has anyone done a cost-benefit analysis of this legislation? Unless the minister has been on another planet, he would know that investment advisers regard this bill as a very serious attack on property investment. Unless the Treasurer has been with him, he would know that stamp duty receipts would be under direct attack as investors flee the state on the advice of financial advisers and property consultants. It does not matter how much you bluff and bluster and how many times you put misleading ads in the major dailies, the perception is that the government intends to change the rules fundamentally and, as a result, investors will go elsewhere. There will be a capital strike as the government has now compounded the problem by creating uncertainty and exhibiting panic through introducing what really is a half-pregnant bill.

What will be the effect on the building industry? One message that I have received argues compellingly that industrial land will become worthless and that there will be no point in developing it as there is no return for the owner and no tenant could afford to rent it. Another point has been made that four years ago outgoings averaged $10 per square metre. Today, it is $30 per metre, and most of that is rates and land tax. Although I am sure that this blatant tax grab can be dressed up by just some or more of the Labor government’s 640 spin doctors to make it look equitable and to be the panacea for anything and everything, the very harsh reality is that it is a tax on jobs. It may now be a tax on 2010 jobs only, but it is still a tax on jobs.

Working families, which trusted Labor in 2007 at the federal level and in 2009 at the state level, are about to lose their jobs because of conscious decisions taken by this Labor government. Small business--the major provider of employment in this state--will be hit hard by this land tax. Our competitiveness as an investment destination will also be adversely impacted. The superannuation nest egg of all of those who were encouraged to migrate to Queensland will be adversely affected. Prudent investment of a superannuation portfolio requires a spread of investments and the property sector is part of a prudent, balanced superannuation fund investment. Retirement funds already brutalised by the effects of the global financial crisis are about to be hit by a double whammy by this Labor government through the effects of this tax on their investments. This attack on superannuants and self-funded retirees mirrors the assaults on those mum-and-dad investors who loathe Stephen Conroy with a passion for his attack on their Telstra investments.

Is Labor consciously attacking the financially self-dependent deliberately? Does it want every retiree to be totally dependent on the largesse of an Australian government of some kind? Does it propose to make the resourceful, who have scrimped to secure a loan for a single investment property to make themselves a little more comfortable and self-sustaining in retirement, stand helpless as legislation executes their initiative? It would certainly seem so.

The real trouble with this Labor government is that it has become so used to spin as a way of presenting information that it no longer recognises truth when the genuine people tell it the truth. It judges everyone by it is own appalling standards. When genuinely concerned constituents tell me that this legislation will cause mum-and-dad investors to suffer, that owners will breach financial covenants as property values fall, as loan defaults increase, as receiverships rise, as economic growth in the property sector stalls and as my constituents lose their jobs, I listen carefully and act accordingly.

Then we have the effect on housing affordability. Housing affordability is much touted, much spun and much talked about by this Labor government as if it were the sole champion of housing affordability, but what do we have here in this legislation? We have the true colours of this Labor government being nailed to the mast and it is the mast of lip-service. This tax hike will inevitably be reflected in the cost of land and house-and-land packages, particularly in greenfield sites. It will be the straw that breaks the camel’s back for at least some. How many potential homeowners will never be proud homeowners because of this tax hike?

This bill was introduced into the House on 11 February 2010. During the last sitting week, which commenced on 23 February, the minister made a number of public statements indicating deferment of the bill to allow proper consultation with the Property Council of Australia. Fast-forward to today and we have the bill back as the first item on the Notice Paper . A week sure is a long time in politics. Why am I concerned? Because the rush to get this bill through the House mirrors the haste that got us into this mess in the first place. The rush to get the previous amendments in place appears to have created this uncertainty and it appears that this Labor government was about to compound that mistake. Now with the capitulation, we are certain that was the case.

The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee has grave concerns about this legislation, concerns which I and every fair minded Queenslander share. The committee pays particular attention to reviewing legislation according to the Legislative Standards Act, one of the inbuilt checks and balances of legislative excess. One of the pillars for review is whether proposed legislation has sufficient regard to the rights and liberties of individuals. The committee has in this regard drawn attention to clauses 26, 27, 32, 33, 37, 39, 51 and 54, which either alter or limit review of administrative power conferred by the Valuation of Land Act 1944. The committee was particularly concerned with clause 33, which may be inconsistent with the principles of natural justice. Concern was also expressed in regard to clause 52 regarding ‘unimproved value’ to operate retrospectively and in regard to clause 5, which would amend the definition of ‘unimproved value’ in the Valuation of Land Act and which may not be drafted in a clear and precise way.

The committee has also expressed two other significant concerns. The first was that clause 21 allows a decision of the chief executive to amend both the act and subordinate legislation. Accordingly, the bill does not have sufficient regard to the institution of parliament. The second grave concern was that clause 54 fetters the discretion of the Land Court.

The explanatory notes trumpet that one of the three objectives of this bill is to clarify the definition of ‘unimproved value’ and the associated terminology. The Legislative Standards Act requires legislation to be unambiguous and be drafted in a sufficiently clear and precise way to protect the rights and liberties of individuals. The Queensland Law Society does not believe that this is the case here. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is the submission of the QLS that use of the term ‘unimproved value’ is not sufficiently defined, is ambiguous and not drafted in a sufficiently clear way to give a lay reader of the Bill a fair understanding of the Government’s policy intent. It is inappropriate and misleading for a term in legislation to be substantially redefined to mean the opposite of its ordinary meaning.
XML.Hansard-Body: I ask members to just pause and listen to that again, because it is a very critical point. It is not me but the Queensland Law Society that says that it is inappropriate and misleading for a term in legislation to be substantially redefined to mean the opposite of its ordinary meaning. The prime motivation alleged by the minister for this legislation to clarify the definition of ‘unimproved value’ and the associated terminology will not be achieved, in the opinion of the Queensland Law Society, because there is a term in the legislation which has been so substantially redefined as to mean the opposite of its ordinary meaning.

Another grave concern about this legislation which I share with the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee is in regard to clause 33. The committee is restrained in its report when it says clause 33 may be inconsistent with principles of natural justice. I will just lay out the facts, which seem to me to speak loudly for themselves. The legislation confers administrative power on the chief executive to publish an adjustment factor. However, landowners would not receive a valuation notice reflecting the adjustment, nor would there be an opportunity to object. The chief executive, in one fell swoop, becomes the prosecutor, judge, jury and appeals court all in one. That does not seem fair and equitable to me.

In terms of efficiency, the Pacific Fair LAC decision will have a significant impact on the chief executive and departmental valuers engaged in valuations who will be required, if the amendments are not retrospective, to proceed on the basis of what had previously been accepted as an appropriate process that should be discarded and a new process engaged in. That leads to a great deal of inefficiency. It will also result in inequitable valuations. Without retrospective changes to the act in that respect, the Pacific Fair LAC conclusions regarding the determination of unimproved value would have to be applied to other commercial, industrial and multiunit properties, exposing the state and local governments to significant repayment of land tax or rates charged on the basis of established valuation approaches.

However, in its submission the Property Council draws attention to the fact that the substantive amendments will retrospectively apply to valuations in effect on and from 30 June 2002, including those presently the subject of unresolved objections or appeals. This will give rise to inequities between the rights of landowners who have settled objections and appeals proceedings and the rights of those landowners whose objections and appeals remain pending. Clearly the retrospective legislation is a bad idea, and here is a first-class example of why. While intending to provide equity and fairness, it has exactly the opposite effect. I am enormously relieved that the minister has come to his senses and thrown out retrospectivity, at least for now.

What troubles me most about this legislation is the Labor government’s arrogance. This legislation shows a complete contempt for the courts and the judicial process in this state. This legislation flies in the face of decades of valuation practice in this state. Rather than create certainty for both businesses and private landowners as well, the Labor government has created immense uncertainty by the approach it has adopted. Rather than argue its case before the High Court, the proper and time honoured process for review of a Court of Appeal decision with which the government disagrees, it has resorted to retrospective legislation. In one fell swoop the Labor government has announced to everyone that if it gets court decisions it does not like it will legislate retrospectively to overturn them.

Where does that leave the community now, particularly the investment community? How can business plan and invest for the future on the foundations of a shaky past or in the knowledge that this Labor government will move the goalposts during the course of the game on a whim? Now it has compounded that problem by vacillation. Its credibility is shot. What will any future investor in this state be able to rely upon if this Labor government is in power?

This is taxation by stealth. It shows just how very desperate this Labor government is. That it would seek to gouge the principal donors of the Labor Party--that industry which donates more to the Labor Party coffers than does its trade union base--with this grubby piece of legislation sends shivers down my spine. How close are we really to the Victorian experience of moral, intellectual and financial bankruptcy to which I referred earlier? I am afraid we are very close.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP) (5.29 pm): I rise to say a few words on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I would like to congratulate the shadow minister, the Hon. Mr Seeney, who has done a wonderful job highlighting the flaws--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! The member should refer to members by their correct title.
Mr RICKUSS: The member for Callide has done a wonderful job showing the flaws in this legislation. He actually highlighted the issues weeks ago and now the minister has come around to see real sense.

I have heard from people from every part of my electorate complaining about the issues raised by this legislation. I will read out a couple comments. This letter is from Don and Pam up at Withcott on the western edge of my electorate. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We don’t believe the government’s full page advertisement in today’s Courier-Mail that attempts to allay our fears. The article by a member of the Property Council seems nearer to the facts of the matter.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those comments are from Don and Pam, who are small investors in my electorate. Kathleen from the southern end of my electorate down near Logan in the Jimboomba-Greenbank area rang me on Friday very concerned about what was going on. I have had a lot of complaints from people living right across my electorate.

It must be disappointing for the minister to have to bring this poorly drafted legislation into the House. This seems to be a regular occurrence with the department of natural resources. I do not understand what is going on there. For some reason that department seems to be letting down the minister when drafting legislation. The scrutiny in the department itself seems to be rather poor.

The worst ever Treasurer, who has actually dug this enormous hole and now has to dig himself out of it, is also putting exceptional pressure on the minister. The rest of the ministry is now struggling to find ways to make a few bob for this worst ever Treasurer to fill up these enormous holes that have been dug. Unfortunately they are digging the hole with a backhoe and trying to fill it in with a spade.

It is disappointing that such poorly drafted legislation keeps coming into the House. It is really disappointing that our parliamentary time is being wasted and that money is also wasted through the running of full-page advertisements in the Courier-Mail because process is not being followed. It is a total disappointment. The changes to unimproved values and the ambiguous wording of some parts of this legislation are really disappointing the parliament. I think the government is almost treating the parliament with contempt in trying to ram through this poorly drafted legislation. I acknowledge that we are not going to support this legislation. There is no reason to support such poorly drafted legislation.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (5.33 pm): There is a wonderful saying that we need to cut our cloth according to our means. It is a truism of life. The changes to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill proposed by the Labor state government demonstrate everything that is wrong in a legislative step. The truism applies because the motive for change is driven by a desperate need not to secure a revenue base but a rush for the cash. In doing so, the ripple effect has led to an enormous coalition of businesses, companies and individual Queenslanders all opposed to this bill.

When so many people who contribute so greatly to our state’s future feel so strongly that they take the kind of action they have done in response to the government’s action, one has to take notice. I thank all those who have contacted my office, made submissions and personally spoken to me regarding this awful bill, and I acknowledge their great contribution to our great state of Queensland.

It seems to be such a trite statement that the minister and his cronies put out that only two per cent of Queenslanders pay land tax. This is not correct; two per cent pay it directly and 98 per cent of Queenslanders pay it indirectly and will pay this new enterprise tax indirectly as well. Clearly, the tax is passed on to tenants and also to consumers. The new tax--and that is what it is--is an extra burden on Queenslanders already doing it tough. Where does it say in a post-GST environment that the state Labor administration has the right to mandate and implement a new enterprise tax? I accept that the land tax which was previously calculated was an existing tax and, as difficult as it is to pay it, people know that it does apply in certain circumstances with property investment. However, to radically change the rules regarding how it is to be measured, reviewed and collected and then retrospectively apply it eight years back is fundamentally wrong. I realise that the amendment regarding the removal of the retrospective clause is very appropriate, but the mere fact that this was proposed was incredibly wrong and very hurtful.

The five principles of good regulation need to be stated and repeated here. They must be proportionate, accountable, consistent, transparent and targeted. This bill is none of these and those opposing it have every right to feel that this ‘jackboots and dictatorship approach has no role in modern democracy. To ignore the stakeholders is to risk all and is reflective of a government and its ministers and advisers who not only do not have experience in business but who are also incapable of understanding the mechanics of business.

We will not be supporting the bill as presented. I would like to briefly emphasise this as a small business owner of 25 years experience in the area of medical care in the general community. Even in these businesses, if you do not make a profit you will go broke. Every government tax has to be paid by consumers. The consumer budget is limited by income and family needs. Every minor rise in fees out of cycle leads to either rationing at the individual level or inability of access. This is the critical point: this new tax will lead to a significant issue--that of access. Access will be denied at every level from the failure of new projects to proceed to individual consumers not being able to afford the increase in charges that will be passed on to them. I ask a very basic question here: if this tax leads to problems of access, why are we doing it?

The Premier was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of Saturday, 6 March of this year as saying that the claims that the changes would hurt mum-and-dad investors were simply untrue. What planet does the Premier live on? The changes will definitely affect all mum-and-dad investors whether they invest directly or indirectly. That is the key factor here. Indirect investment is what superannuation investment is all about. It is very severely affected by this legislative step. The Premier is potentially doing great harm to her own constituency, and everyone else’s too. The evidence is to be found in the UDIA report which significantly addresses the knock-on effect, saying that whilst owner-occupiers who do not pay land tax will not be directly affected, the additional costs that this new valuation scheme will place on developers will see further costs passed on to those buyers. Renters will also be affected as their landlords are required to pay land tax, which will flow through as higher rents.
At the other end of the equation, the Shopping Centre Council of Australia said of this legislation--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bill, if passed, will massively increase the cost of doing business in Queensland. It will increase costs for all businesses, not just for shopping centres or for commercial offices.
XML.Hansard-Body: To specifically address the Premier’s statement, the managing director of Westfield Group, Steven Lowy, said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We see it as a very disturbing issue. It not only affects our centres, it affects every investor in the state.
XML.Hansard-Body: I point out for the Premier--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It has ramifications about how the business community, both domestic and foreign, views the certainty of investment in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: That word ‘certainty’ has been used multiple times today. We should be in the business of reducing the burden on business and the public in general. That burden includes taxation, red tape and incentive. We have no right to implement laws that hurt people and diminish our state’s competitiveness. I put it to members that if this is the Labor government’s belief, it sorely misunderstands the people, it is not representative of the democratic state of Queensland and it does not understand what democratic government is all about.

Whilst these fundamental questions are being considered, we really need to look at land tax in a modern context. While there is great doubt about the claim of $1 billion in lost revenue in the state, equally in a post-GST environment--GST being a 10 per cent progressive consumption tax paid by all and very difficult to avoid--land tax is an input tax that is paid before consumption and, even under the old rules, was a negative tax that Adam Smith’s principles said did not deliver an equal and opposite benefit for the raising of the tax. This afternoon opposition members have covered particularly well the proposals to fundamentally change the definition of unimproved land value and issues involving profit and risk, leases, goodwill and interest income. The courts do not agree with the government’s position and now the government is attempting to rule by decree. In effect, it is subverting the role of courts in our democratic system. It is also intending to introduce a general valuation schedule, although the move to the new system later next year is a good move and has been discussed by the member for Callide.

The alternative to the objection process and, significantly, the scope for the department to reject objections on the grounds that they are not properly made is reprehensible. The alterations to the appeals process limit the grounds included in the original objection. A sunset clause has been proposed in the amendments and that is a good decision, although the government had to be dragged to it kicking and screaming. The retrospective issue has been withdrawn.

Critically, it must be said that this is a new tax. It is not a land tax, but a tax on enterprise and, in all fairness, it should be called that. If it is not called that or a similar name, the Labor government will be implementing laws that mislead the public and potential investors within the state. The proposed amendments will reassure the public, but they have had to be drawn out of the government. The Australian Financial Review correctly stated that the Premier should stow the legislative baseball bat that she has used to resolve what the government believed was a challenge to its revenue base. This Labor government is living in the past and seems to be unable to manage change. We must be in the business of the provision of services, rather than rationing services, and the growth of a progressive revenue base. We must not strangle investment at conception and be unrepresentative of the public. We must not be like the hated adversary that this Premier has become.

This bill is anti employment. Labor has consistently stated that its goal is to create 100,000 new jobs, yet the property industry has calculated that the legislation will result in the direct loss of 50,000 jobs. Who will be affected? It will be average Queenslanders working as grader drivers, drainage labourers, surveyors, surveyors’ assistants, property managers and builders. All those people are well represented in my electorate of Gaven, which is the fastest-growing electorate in the state. At a time when they can least afford it, they will be severely punished by knock-on effects of this bill. In Queensland, the average home mortgage is $450,000 and increasing, and electricity and water costs and interest rates are steeply rising. What do members think will happen? We are going to see foreclosures by the banks and increasing rates.

Members should not be fooled by the Reserve Bank’s statement that interest rates are rising to stem overheating in the economy. Interest rates are rising because the federal government is running an unstable borrowing program. Money is short and money is priced accordingly. In Australia, Joe Average and Mrs Average have no ability to compete fairly in the market with the government. The impact of the new law will not only make their lives harder and more difficult but will also make them unsustainable. Just because the government could not balance its budget and address the issue of the state budget debt of $85 billion, it does not have the right to reach into the pockets of each and every Queenslander and rob them of an extra two cents in every investment dollar.

This is clearly an example of a government increasing its revenue stream through the clandestine manipulation of definitions, rather than by simply and transparently increasing the rate of taxation. The public rightfully expected to see the end of older taxes such as stamp duty and wholesale sales taxes when they supported the federal Howard Liberal National coalition government and delivered them the GST. Has everything changed now that the Rudd federal government is claiming 30 per cent of the GST and, as Health Minister Roxon stated publicly, new taxes may have to be considered to pay for health?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! Member for Gaven, I direct your attention to the purpose of the bill and ask you to come back to it.

Dr DOUGLAS: I support the view of the shadow minister, the member for Callide, regarding the government’s move to a new site improved valuation definition. I would like to see the government clearly respond to stakeholder input into this process. If, as proposed, the Labor government will now move to a new bill later this year incorporating some of the changes and the new valuation of land definition, then we must see compromises at that stage as well. The Boyd and Heffernan review is critical for informing all players and interested parties, and must be released. I call on the minister for its tabling. Every informed commentator in every responsible publication has specifically requested common sense. As the words ‘blatant tax grab’ suggest and the AFR editorial has stated, the minister’s stated defence ‘we need the money’ is an abuse of state power and his reasoning is no different from those excuses heard in criminal pleas made in courts every day of the week. Furthermore, the stated $1 billion loss is really a fraction of the sum; that is a fact. The lameness of the defence is compounded by the fact that the Labor state government has managed the economy about as badly as any state government could and is the creator of its own fiscal predicament.

Like many previous speakers, I find it impossible to accept some of the nonsense that we have heard today from government members about suddenly finding an ability to understand those opposing their view. I say this on the basis of the completely unacceptable second reading speech delivered by the minister, the minister’s questioning of the Court of Appeal judgement and his outrageously inaccurate statements about land tax rates in Queensland as opposed to those in the rest of Australia. The minister has no right to question the judges of the Court of Appeal in the Land Court. His facts are wrong and grossly misleading. Our current tax charges are higher than anywhere else in Australia and the minister’s proposed rates are to be 10 times that of existing rates anywhere else. Our valuations grossly exceed comparable properties in the rest of Australia. The percentages are irrelevant; it is the quantum that has to be stated. The minister is assuming that we are all ignorant, that he can say anything he likes and that we will believe it. No-one believes him. All he has done is harm his reputation, I would think irreparably. For what? A tax grab built on a flawed calculation. I ask: who did the numbers? Who thought this up? Who wrote the second reading speech and why would the minister ever believe it would slip through?
In his second reading speech the minister stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I cannot let that happen. We have to get the balance right between residential rate and taxpayers and commercial and industrial rate and taxpayers.
XML.Hansard-Body: The member for Clayfield has appropriately defined the history of land tax and how it was originally conceived. An owner pays income tax earned on the land and the land tax is paid on improvements that surround the freehold properties, not on the freehold property. I do not believe the minister’s statement reflects an understanding of this issue. This world is facing a double-dip recession. In the US unemployment is at 10 per cent and static, and property values are falling to 1980 levels. In Australia, all the banks are holding huge loans to property speculators, land bankers and developers. Centro is arguably broke but trading, and Australia’s assets are marginal. It is no secret that property values are set to fall, even though statements about land shortages remain. Property after property of undeveloped land is being offered at 50 per cent of its value, not just because of the greater demand for land but because of equity from the banks, yet the property’s value is at least 30 per cent of the earlier valuation. Developers, large and small, are being called on to increase their equity contributions and sell property at fire sales, or are being told to increase their equity position to 40 to 50 per cent, at a 30 per cent below market valuation. What do honourable members think of the implication of this? It is unemployment, decreased GST, decreased stamp duty, decreased personal income tax, foreclosure on personal homes and increased demands for crisis services, including health.

We have had a desperate government propose a totally unreasonable response to its own economic dilemma. I call on government members to not only demand that these amendments that we have driven through are passed but also collectively ask for explanations from those who have misinformed them all. They were misled. No-one in this state believes that we Queenslanders have a greater right to our funds than anyone else, especially other Australians. No-one has the right to tax enterprises, as far as I know. The defence of public revenue base that has been presented here is fundamentally flawed. It is irrational, and the imposition of a fuel tax and this government’s tacit acceptance of a potential new health tax proves this to me. I can say this because the Treasurer is defending his decision to support the transfer of mining royalties to the federal government at a time when government members are all saying that they are attempting to defend the revenue base here today. Either they defend the revenue base or they do not. There is no half measure. Even fence sitting means that the government’s position is hypocritical.

The bill was an attack on business. It was completely undeserved and poorly targeted. It is a proven job destroyer and a destroyer of business confidence and an assault on every Queenslander who is an investor, either directly or indirectly. It makes homes much harder to purchase. It was a breach of trust to every Queenslander wherever they are. To say that it was anything less is completely wrong and to say that it was targeted at the big end of town completely misled people. This argument just does not wash. Has the Labor government learned anything from this shocking and offensive tax grab? If we are to judge from government members’ speeches today, the answer is no. There are some small areas that need correction. The member for Pine Rivers incorrectly stated some facts today which are completely contradicted by the Property Council’s statement and there is also the issue with regard to investment.

For those who believe that the asset sale is going to save them, the CEO of QR, according to the AFR , ‘must be lying awake sweating on the decision of this land tax decision today’. I quote Richard Gilbert, Chief Executive of the Rule of Law Association. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Any decision to continue with the proposed bill will turn off those foreign investors (let alone Australian investors) to whom a stable legal system with an observance of the rule of law is a precondition to any investment.
XML.Hansard-Body: So what does this tax do? It will reduce jobs. It will reduce available, affordable land for development. It will slow growth in state revenue and economic migration from other states. It will cost each and every Queenslander more money in tough economic times. It targets young families, the elderly, the disabled and those who cannot afford it. It will sound the death knell for many small businesses in shopping centres. I put it to this Labor government that it had to learn to live within its means and it could not do so. I thank all of the people who helped me with this speech including my son, Alex.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (5.52 pm): In rising to participate in the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I would like to address the amendments to the land and water management plan framework in the Water Act 2000. The Water Act, among other things, provides a framework for managing the use of water for irrigation through the requirement to have in place a land and water management plan. These plans are prepared by irrigators for their individual properties.

The purpose of land and water management plans is to ensure that irrigation water-use practices are ecologically sustainable both on and off the farm and to manage water use where there is a risk of land and water degradation. Preparing a land and water management plan can be either voluntary or a legislative requirement. The Great Barrier Reef Protection Amendment Act 2009, which received royal assent on 15 October 2009, introduced regulations to improve the quality of water entering the Great Barrier Reef. These new regulations include amendments to the Environmental Protection Act 1994 to require landholders to prepare environmental risk management plans. These plans will help to ensure the adoption of management practices that reduce the levels of farm chemicals, fertiliser nutrients and sediment harming the reef.

Environmental risk management plans may deal with similar land and water degradation issues and land management practices as land and water management plans. In recognising this, the bill amends the Water Act to align the two frameworks. The amendments will allow components of an accredited environmental risk management plan to be submitted and approved as a component of a land and water management plan. The new environmental risk management framework also recognises these linkages and allows land and water management plans and other equivalent documentation to be submitted for environmental risk management plan accreditation. These amendments will ensure irrigators are not required to prepare duplicate plans dealing with risks of land and water degradation.

In addition, the existing land and water management plan framework allows an irrigator to seek a deferral for having an approved plan. The requirement to have an approved plan may be deferred for up to one year. However, under the current framework, after the one-year deferral has passed it is an offence to use water for irrigation without an approved plan. Requiring a plan where the risk of land or water degradation is low creates an unnecessary regulatory burden for irrigators as well as an administrative burden for the Department of Environment and Resource Management to approve and administer low-risk plans.

The amendments proposed by the bill will provide flexibility by allowing deferrals to be granted for up to two years and for subsequent deferrals to be granted where the chief executive considers it appropriate. This effectively creates a rolling two-year deferral process where the department will have the opportunity to review the level of risk every two years. It should be noted that the information provided in each deferral application and the susceptibility of the land and water to degradation from water use is assessed before the chief executive will grant a deferral. These amendments to the Water Act will provide more flexibility to Queensland irrigators in managing the risk of land and water degradation associated with water used for irrigation. In addition, the efficiencies created will allow departmental resources to be better targeted to land management and the practices where the risk of degradation from water use is greater. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (5.56 pm): In rising to participate in the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, at the outset I thank the minister for his leadership in the development of and subsequent amendments to this bill. As the minister’s parliamentary secretary, I know how hard he has worked on this legislation and the conflicting interests from different quarters that he has tried hard to accommodate.

Valuation is a very complex issue and, as the Premier said this morning in her ministerial statement, we as a government have committed to do at least two things: firstly, deal with the court’s decision and ensure that the status quo remains--that is, no new taxes and no refunds to protect the state’s revenue; and, secondly, put in place a new regime to change fundamentally how valuation is done in Queensland--that is, moving from unimproved value to that of site value, which is consistent with a lot of other states. The Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the new system will not result in significant changes to rates and property taxes. This is being done to provide greater certainty for our commercial and industrial sectors and residential property investors. It is not a revenue measure. Further, the government will appoint an independent Valuer-General to provide transparency and independence in the assessment and issuing of valuations.
XML.Hansard-Body: I welcome the announcement and decision by the Premier. I think it is about time, since 1944, that the state of Queensland moved forward--to move from unimproved value to site value.

I will restrict my comments on this bill to the valuation reform program being undertaken by the Department of Environment and Resource Management. For the land valuation system to be effective, it must be transparent, fair and efficient. In Queensland, where the state’s population is growing by about 1,500 people per week, the need for change has been widely recognised by government, business and the community.

This bill provides the first step to give certainty to the way in which valuations are made in Queensland. It also introduces reforms to streamline the valuation objection process to provide a more transparent, consistent and efficient process for all landowners in Queensland. This updated objection process will provide clear processes for lodging an objection and will encourage the inclusion of appropriate information at the beginning of the objection process so that objections can be dealt with by the department in a timely manner. This is better for the landowner and better for the department.

Contrary to the view of the opposition leader in his radio interview with 4BC on 3 March, the amendments do not ‘make it very, very difficult for people to appeal’. In fact, it is quite the opposite. In making valuations, State Valuation Services is not always right, and we are quite prepared to admit that. It does not always have all the information in front of it because it has not been provided by people objecting to valuations.

The right to object to a valuation has always been available and will continue to be available to a landowner. If a landowner disagrees with their new valuation, they have 45 days--which is exactly the same period provided for in the act--after the date of issue of the valuation notice to lodge an objection. The updated objection process now requires all objections to be lodged on the approved ‘Notice of Objection’ form--which is Form 58--stating what the grounds are for their objection to the valuation. I think that is fundamental information that is required to determine whether the objection has any substance.

It will not be sufficient for a landowner to state that the value of their property is simply incorrect or that the valuation is too high. That is not a reason. Information must be provided to substantiate the objection. This is not onerous or difficult. This information is essential to allow a correct and timely decision on the objection. In my view, it is impossible for anyone to make an assessment on an objection without knowing the reason for the objection in the first place. This is a new process, and the Department of Environment and Resource Management has developed extensive supporting information including fact sheets and a guide for landowners on how to complete their objection form. During the objection period there is also a dedicated call centre operating to answer landowners’ questions in relation to how to complete their objection within the required period.

For landholders who in the past have been lodging appropriately prepared objections, this new process should not present any new challenges. In fact, it provides the opportunity for further information to be provided to support the objection if needed by the department to assess the objection. If a landowner is not satisfied with the chief executive’s decision to disallow an objection or adjust a valuation, they can still lodge an appeal with the Land Court. What the amendments make clear is that the grounds used in the objection will be the only grounds that can be used in the appeal. I think it is very fair that anyone objecting to a valuation should state their grounds clearly. The grounds and the information provided in the objection are what is considered by the department when making a decision. Therefore, if the decision is appealed, the appeal must be based on those same grounds. This is common practice in every single level of our courts. This does not preclude the objector from providing further information in the appeal, but it must be relevant to the grounds of the objection.

This new process is fair and is the first step in the reforms proposed to Queensland’s valuation process and State Valuation Services. However, there is more needed to modernise State Valuation Services to accommodate the needs of Queensland’s rapidly expanding population. The government has announced a package of reforms that impact on how statutory valuations will be undertaken in Queensland in the future, and I welcome that announcement. The centrepiece of this reform is a commitment from 2011 to move from unimproved value to site value for non-rural land, consistent with approaches in other Australian states for many years. Site value is more easily understood than unimproved value. It is more reflective of Queensland’s state of development and removes the debate about what land was like in its original state.

Site value does not require the estimation of the value of historical site improvements such as filling, which may have taken place many years ago. It will provide for greater equity in the distribution of rates between filled and unfilled land like canal estates, which previously had a much lower unimproved value. The move to site value will align Queensland’s valuation methodology with that used in other Australian states and ensure that the most commonly used valuation methodology is used for assessment of land tax.

Other reforms, such as setting a rolling schedule of valuations and an adjustment factor, originally contained in the bill, have been removed so that consultation with stakeholders can take place on the overall package of reform including the move to site value over the next two months. The government also proposes to undertake structural and business process reforms to State Valuation Services. These will include establishing an expert peer review process in 2010 for complex valuations; explicit performance standards and benchmarking of the performance of State Valuation Services against national best valuation practice; and the creation of an independent statutory position as the Queensland Valuer-General to provide greater capacity for strategic policy responses and strengthen stakeholder engagement.

The government is committed to introducing the site value methodology for non-rural land in 2011, consistent with the approach to the valuation methodology used in other Australian jurisdictions.
