As a demonstration of our commitment to implement these and other reforms prior to issuing the 2011 valuation, the bill contains a sunset clause provision to expire on 30 June 2011 for all of the amendments, with the exception of the provision to past validation valuations issued before the commencement of the bill. This program of reforms will see State Valuation Services established as a more professional, transparent and autonomous entity, charged with providing an impartial property valuation service that is equitable, efficient and fair, and enjoys the confidence of Queensland’s landowners. I look forward to further consultation with the Property Council. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (6.06 pm): Tonight I speak to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 as introduced by the minister, the Hon. Stephen Robertson, on 11 February 2010. This is a complete farce disguised as legislation, and it is now a poor replica if the proposed amendments eventuate. So many changes and God knows how many amendments are yet to come. The honourable minister cannot win a trick. First, Health unravelled on the minister’s watch. Today we have the cancellation of the problem plagued scheme to deliver 200,000 discounted solar hot-water systems and now this--the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.

This bill is nothing short of despicable as it was introduced and so far has proved to be another example of a government that is incapable of governing Queensland. It is a government that went bust in a boom. This absurd piece of legislation proposes amendments to the Valuation of Land Act 1944 that are likely to affect all future unimproved land valuations and removes the right of appeal for property owners or makes it much more problematic than it ever has been.

The legislation is nothing more than a scramble for cash and an attempt to cover up years of mismanagement, mistakes and incompetence by the Labor government. The only saving grace is that this government has been brought back down to earth with an almighty thud. The amendments flagged and the concessions made in early admissions are significant, and speak volumes about the incompetent Labor government and its shameless grab for cash at any cost, rewriting history and rewriting dictionaries along the way. That is how rife the incompetence and mismanagement of this Bligh Labor government is. It began with Beattie and, believe it or not, it has sunk to new low levels--new ways of undermining Queensland business confidence.

What this bill will most certainly do is cost Queenslanders jobs. It is about jobs lost, jobs lost, jobs lost--not the usual mantra that we hear from those opposite. What this legislation will do in my electorate is see a most significant increase in valuations, not a downward trend as has been hinted at by the government. The Redland City Council area has not been valued for over five years. It would be a brave speculator who would contemplate that the values may go down after five years without land valuations.

Surprisingly or not surprisingly, Redland City Council has, like other councils, been forced to continue to pay the state government up to $320,000 per annum for a service not provided--a service not provided in 2005, a service not provided in 2006, a service not provided in 2007, a service not provided in 2008. Every year ratepayers were shelling out money to the council to pay for a service they were not getting. The figures are about to be released for the valuations made in late 2009. That is, they will be released in 2010.

The impact of that will be that it jeopardises jobs. It will jeopardise jobs in retail. It will jeopardise jobs in property development. It will jeopardise jobs in the building trades. It will jeopardise farming and agriculture. In the Redlands, that is even more critical and has even greater significance when we consider that without consultation the Redlands employment area of Thornlands was taken out of the urban footprint and again thousands of jobs went begging. I am absolutely certain that the other members whose electorates encompass the Redland Council City area--the members for Capalaba and Cleveland--would support me in highlighting the significance that jobs play in our community.

The possible job losses in retail in the Redlands would be a disaster. Retail accounts for 17 per cent of residents’ jobs in the Redlands. That is over 5 thousand jobs just in the retail sector. Those jobs will be jeopardised when the land valuation ramifications are passed on to tenancies, and they will be. Construction accounts for eight per cent of residents’ jobs in the Redlands. That is 2 thousand jobs. Those jobs will be jeopardised because of the poor management of Queensland and the ill-conceived process this legislation has been through to date.

The figures I have quoted are based on the 2006 employment statistics. I fully expect the number of jobs to vary but I expect the percentages to remain unchanged, as they have for a number of years. The figure will be far greater than 5 thousand jobs in retail put at risk. It will be well over 2 thousand jobs in the construction industry that are jeopardised.

This government talks about jobs, jobs, jobs and then fails dismally in the delivery of them. Not only does it fail to deliver; it actually killed off jobs when it removed employment areas from my community that were supported by council, that were supported by the community and that were going to provide jobs.
Mr Moorhead interjected.

Mr DOWLING: Yes, it was the current council--absolutely. It is well and truly minuted that the current council supported the employment area because it does not want the exodus of traffic leaving the Redlands and heading all the way to Brisbane every day on congested and unmade roads and on poor road infrastructure.

There is, however, light at the end of the tunnel if we are to believe Labor. It has backed down and backflipped, as it should. This government is only buying time. It is buying a little breathing space with the amendments that it is talking about. Why is there a suite of changes coming? Because Labor got caught and it got caught big time with its ill-prepared and ill-conceived land tax grab. This is about nothing but cash.

I caution Queenslanders and Queensland that Labor cannot be trusted. It has demonstrated that time and time again. It cannot be trusted when it comes to electricity charges. It cannot be trusted when it comes to water pricing. It cannot be trusted when it comes to registration fees or fuel prices. Again, I remind members about the light at the end of the tunnel. What worries me is that the light at the end of the tunnel may well be an express coal train--a coal train no longer owned by Queensland--or worse still a debt train with Queensland’s worst Treasurer stoking the debt inferno to $85,000 million. That is debt we are looking at. This is the only government to go bust in a boom. It lost our AAA credit rating and it has lost its way.

In the Redlands, primary producers will be driven off the land with these land valuations. They will drive housing affordability well and truly beyond the reach of the average person. Who knows what other damage it will do?

This is an issue that has triggered a huge number of phone calls and emails to my office. Property owners, business owners, real estate valuers, solicitors and other small business providers have not been afforded the right to have their say and be part of a thorough, robust engagement process.

Let us look at a couple of the proposals in the bill through the eyes of an average property owner and see what these changes will mean to them. Firstly, we have the proposed changes to the definition of ‘unimproved value’ which will potentially lead to higher taxes, new or higher levies and surcharges and possible higher council rates as well.
Mr Ryan interjected.

Mr DOWLING: I take the interjection. They could be small business owners that are part of a tenancy that is a large shopping centre. I say to my honourable friend from Morayfield that that large shopping centre will pass on that expense. It will not wear it. The business owners will be affected. ‘Mr and Mrs Average’ and ‘Mr and Mrs Small Business’ will pass on their expenses.

Let us get back to the proposals in this bill. Firstly, we have the proposed changes to the definition of ‘unimproved value’ which will potentially lead to higher taxes, new or higher levies and surcharges and possibly higher rates as well. Effectively, this means that the more a property owner improves their property the more they will be taxed. The greater the risk, the greater the penalty.

We already have very high rateable land values, which means we already pay much more in land tax than other states. The current property valuations are also regarded to be higher than market prices because of the recent economic slowdown that occurred after the latest valuations were carried out. However, that is not true of my electorate nor those of the adjoining state electorates of Cleveland and Capalaba because these valuations have not been done for five years. Their valuations will almost certainly go up.

In addition, Labor last year delayed the revaluation of property for land tax purposes in a number of other regions. That again has resulted in the continued inflation of land valuations and land taxes to state coffers. Land tax is already one of the biggest taxes on Queenslanders each year, with Queenslanders paying out an anticipated $1 billion in land tax in 2010 compared to $380 million in 2004-05. These changes are simply another attempt by Labor to gouge every last cent it can out of Queensland taxpayers to prop up its own failing budget and mismanagement. Let us not forget the $85 billion--the $85,000 million--of Labor debt. Renters will also feel the pinch as property owners pass on increased costs through rent increases. This is in direct conflict with Labor’s commitment to affordable housing.

Then, of course, there is the obvious lack of transparency that is being built into the objection and appeal processes. The average property owner will now have to make their objection blindly, with little more than their belief that the valuation is incorrect. In the previous objections process the property owner at least had the logical process on which to base their appeal. ‘Mr and Mrs Average’ must also state all grounds for objection and support their objection with documentary evidence. The grounds of appeal will be limited to those contained in the objection, even if the value is assessed on an entirely different basis from the previous methods.

Then if State Valuation Services does not believe there is sufficient grounds for objection it may well lapse the objection. How can ‘Mr and Mrs Average’ fully state all the grounds for their objection if there is no prescriptive logic to the valuation process that they can lay their hands on? To add insult to injury, for the first time property owners will have to pay to lodge an objection. This fee has been prescribed under the legislation but we do not how much that fee will be. How easy it is, then, for State Valuation Services to lapse all objections simply because it can, pocketing the lodgement fee and lining the state coffers in the process?

We cannot allow State Valuation Services to have such unfettered power. We cannot afford to give State Valuation Services our money when due process is absent. For Mr and Mrs Average, the amended objection and appeals process is burdensome and is overprescriptive, unfair and inconsistent with the democratic processes at best. This Labor government appears to be imploding and is hell-bent on penalising Queenslanders at any cost and removing the natural process for appeals. This is clearly not acceptable. A letter on this issue received by my office states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The objection process has changed substantially to a far more costly and unworkable exercise. The system is designed to remove all transparency. A bulk valuation process by its very nature will result in errors and the existing system has the transparency for those errors to be rectified. The proposed legislation is designed to ensure that equitable rating and taxation will not eventuate.
XML.Hansard-Body: Then of course there is the retrospective aspect--undemocratic, unfair and just plain wrong. The injustice of this is obvious. To change the rules so long after the valuation date is reprehensible and Labor should be ashamed, and it has been shamed--shamed into acting by industry and by a community who saw Labor for what it is: money-grubbing. The government is introducing this bill--or the amendments--to try to fix the bungled legislation, yet it is still piling error upon error and mistake upon mistake, ending up with a nonsensical and mangled process that will almost certainly disadvantage homeowners and businesses alike.

Let us forget about Mr and Mrs Average for a minute--and, let us face it, Labor forgot them a long time ago--what about the implications for business owners? This will be a new tax on business. It will increase the cost of doing business and will further diminish business confidence in the government. Investors will take their money, their infrastructure and their jobs to other states. There will be a negative impact for retailers, residential investment, child care, hotels, shopping centres and nursing homes. Another constituent wrote to me--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am concerned that if this ill-conceived Bill goes through unchanged, land tax and potentially council rates will increase substantially; which in turn will lead to massive increases in costs and job losses in the business and property sector, and investors looking at interstate alternatives--not a good outlook for doing business in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Another email said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is an issue that will be a vote changer for me.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I am going to operate on the presumption that they may well have been one of the supporters of the other side. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I will be supporting the candidates who commit to lower taxes, smaller government and support for small business rather than this crippling and frankly ludicrous tax grab.
XML.Hansard-Body: The opposition will be opposing the bill but accepting the amendments and not opposing the amended bill. The amendments are significant and changes to the retrospectivity of the bill to validate previous valuations and appeals and objections continue to be a massive issue. There will, I suspect, be other announcements such as the reinstatement of an independent Valuer-General. A move to site valuations in September is something that I think probably has merit, but we have not seen the detail of that. One thing I have learnt in my short time here is that what starts out as potentially a good idea can end in catastrophe and disaster very quickly. However, the fundamental issues remain the same: the government is changing the definition of ‘unimproved land’ in Queensland; there is the effective removal of an objection and appeals process; and the future of the land valuation system. The changes proposed today allow the government to save face regarding the poor bill it introduced and to return to the consultation process that should have been undertaken long before the bill was introduced into the House to find a workable, long-term solution to land valuations in Queensland.

I am sure all members have received correspondence from a number of concerned parties, and I am sure other members received a letter from Steve Greenwood, the executive director of the Queensland Property Council. That letter sets out line by line the Queensland government’s claims and every one of them is false. Claim No. 1 is false. Claim No. 2 is false. Claim No. 3 is false. Claim No. 4 is false. They are all significant, and it goes right through to claim No. 9. The pressure that the Property Council brought to bear, along with that of that LNP, is why we will see such a different bill going forward by the end of the night.

I also spoke to a constituent of mine who has a small business, Warren Pryde of Pryde Fabrication. He wrote a letter to the Premier from which I read an excerpt earlier. When I was talking to him over the weekend he said that he is almost certainly going to have to reconsider his staffing levels based on the legislation if it proceeds as it is. He made an interesting comment--that is, how can anyone now find Queensland an attractive place for investment when the government decides to tax entrepreneurial profit and to make a rating system so unfair, unjust and inequitable? The LNP will not be supporting the bill, but let us not lose sight of the fact that even with the amendments Labor is still going to include land valuations after 30 June to include lease value, goodwill, profit and risk, DAs. It is killing investment. It is killing entrepreneurship. It is not the Smart State. It is certainly not the state one would want to invest in. It is a state that is going backwards. It is a state that is costing jobs, particularly in my electorate.

Employment areas were removed without consultation, without consideration and without forward thought. Those jobs in those key areas in my electorate such as retail involved 5,500 jobs in 2005 and jobs in the construction industry involved over 2,500 according to the employment stats of 2006. There are not just those jobs but the jobs that roll on into other areas in my electorate that feed off those other employment sectors. Redlands is also strong on horticulture. It is an area that I did not mention; I mentioned farming and agriculture. Horticulture is a tremendous opportunity and a tremendous employer in the area. Again, land values will jeopardise that industry’s viability going forward. The land tax issue is nothing short of an incredibly ill-conceived idea driven by Labor and driven without any real focus for jobs in Queensland, without any real consideration and certainly without consultation. That is why we will be spending hours tonight cobbling together something that will be a bandaid for 12 months while we rethink and rewrite the legislation in Queensland so we have a viable strategy going forward.
Mr GIBSON (Gympie--LNP) (6.26 pm): I rise tonight to make a contribution to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
Mr Hoolihan: Another Queensland hater!

Mr GIBSON: I notice that it only takes me to get to my feet and the members of the peanut gallery over there have something to say. If we listened to their contributions through this debate, what we have heard from them is apology after apology--apologists as they have gone forward trying to somehow say that this flawed bill that is before the House now has merit. They are somehow trying to shore up this failed minister in presenting a bill to this parliament that shows his complete and utter incompetence, that shows his inability to present a bill for the state of Queensland that has merit.
Mrs Kiernan: How about a policy from your lot?

Mr GIBSON: Listen to these interjections, Madam Deputy Speaker; listen to them! They are said because they know I speak the truth. They know that this bill should never have been introduced in its current form in the House. We have heard very clearly from the LNP’s shadow minister and the member for Callide and from the LNP’s shadow Treasurer the strong arguments--the very strong arguments--as to the flaws that are contained in this bill and what needs to go forward. But what we have seen from this government is an inability--an inability to say it was wrong, an inability to front the people of Queensland and say, ‘We made a mistake. We’ll withdraw the bill and we’ll do it properly.’ Instead what we have is a bill before the House that we will be required to vote on that is flawed--fundamentally flawed--and then we will face the amendments to that bill to correct those failings. This to me highlights the utter incompetence of this government and the way in which it attempts to bring about changes within this state.

As I looked to the explanatory notes, I wondered how a government could make such mistakes, and it became very clear. When one looks to the explanatory notes of the original bill under the section ‘Consultation’, one finds that the government did not consult with the property industry--this government did not think it was worthwhile to engage with the industry that would be impacted the most. This government did not bother to actually seek industry opinion. It did, however, talk to the Valuer-General of Tasmania. I am sure that the Valuer-General of Tasmania is very concerned about what is happening here in Queensland. But it was the property industry that it should have been talking to. However, we find that as we move to the explanatory notes of the amendments the government has been in ongoing consultation with the Property Council of Australia, the Shopping Centre Council of Australia, AgForce and the Queensland Farmers Federation regarding the effect of the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill following its introduction into the parliament. It is not good enough! These consultations should have occurred before this bill was introduced into the parliament.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 pm to 7.30 pm.

Mr GIBSON: Since this bill was introduced into the House on 11 February, there has indeed been a great deal of concern. I know that within my own electorate my office has taken many calls from constituents concerned about the impacts not on the big end of town but on the mum-and-dad investors who will be impacted by this bill. I could not help thinking that I really have to take some time to look into this bill and the issues that it raises.
Government members interjected.

Mr GIBSON: Again, I note the rumblings of those opposite, who ignore the fact that the bill is flawed. It is only by virtue of the amendments to this bill that have been forced upon this government that we are seeing any semblance of decent legislation. If this bill were allowed to go forward in its current state, it would be an absolute disaster for the state of Queensland.

As I looked into this bill and did some research, I could not help drawing parallels between this bill and the best film nominations at the Oscars. For example, the movie Avatar is all about being focused on unobtainium. Unobtainium is what this government has been focused on in trying to redefine what ‘unimproved value’ is. There was also The Blind Side and An Education --something this minister would do well to look into. There was that great Tarantino movie, the title of which I will not state, that highlights the very approach of this government in dealing with its own constituents. There was also the movie Up , which is exactly where land taxes will be going should this bill in its original form be allowed to pass. Then there was the movie Up in the Air , which is where the property market was as at 11 February because of this bill and the uncertainty that it placed on the market. But of course, like the Oscars, this bill had more in common with The Hurt Locker than it did with any other, because it was a ticking time bomb waiting to go off that needed to be defused.

Thankfully, this government was dragged kicking and screaming to the table to bring about the necessary appropriate amendments. At the end of a campaign by the property industry against this bill, this government, once again arrogant in its approach, was shown to have got it wrong. From this government we got the equivalent of a B-grade movie going straight to DVD. Under Labor, there would be no premiere and no gala night; there would simply be that quiet release and before we knew it the movie would be sold as a DVD because no-one in their right mind would have bothered to view the disaster that was put forward.

Should this bill go forward in its current state, it would be the equivalent of the New South Wales vendor tax. We know what a complete and utter debacle that proposal was by the Labor government of New South Wales. It was so bad that it was required to be withdrawn. The amendments to be proposed for this bill contain a sunset clause that will limit the effect of this bill until such time as we see a new bill--the one that should have been drafted originally. If this government had such serious concerns it should have done its homework originally. As has been stated by many in the industry, this bill is fundamentally flawed and it is only because of the amendments that we see being proposed that it is in any way worthy of consideration. Prior to those amendments, this bill should simply have become confetti. It was worth nothing more than that.

We have here the dynamic duo--the powerhouse, the brains trust of that side--of this parliament’s most unpopular member and the state’s worst Treasurer and a minister who clearly is not across his portfolio. That is saying something, because the government has a broad selection of ministers who are not across their portfolios.

This bill really takes the cake. It is an ill-conceived approach to dealing with a problem. This bill was to legalise the way in which commercial, industrial and residential land was valued for tax purposes after the Land Court had found that this government had falsely inflated unimproved land values since 2002. This bill is trying to make unimproved land values based on intangible concepts, including business risk and business goodwill, rather than just the land alone. This bill is an attempt by this government to legitimise falsely inflated land values to cover its own failings in the way in which it has dealt with ordinary unimproved land valuations. The Land Appeal Court found that the government had more than tripled the value of the land upon which the Pacific Fair Shopping Centre stood, setting the value at $225 million in 2003 when in fact the true value of the land was $47.9 million.
Government members interjected.

Mr GIBSON: I hear the rumblings from those opposite, who clearly were trying to get their hands into the pockets of ordinary Queenslanders. This government, which has gone bankrupt in a boom, which wastes taxpayers’ money time and time again, which has found itself--
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Minister, I would ask you to stop interjecting.

Mr GIBSON: Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for your protection. The rumblings from the brains trust opposite were clearly incoherent. Time and time again we find that. The members opposite have a lot to say but they have no facts. They mumble their way through, throwing out anecdotes, but we really do not find any elements of truth.

Today we have before the House a bill that, in its current form, is one reason among many why Labor does not deserve to govern in the state of Queensland. Even with the resources of the departments behind it, this government cannot present legislation to this House that is worthy of being passed. It is only because of the efforts of stakeholders, our shadow minister and the many other members on this side of the House in highlighting the failures of this bill that we will now see amendments that will rectify the bill’s failings and its totally flawed nature. I say to the people of Queensland: if you want any further example of why Labor is unfit to govern, you simply need to look at this bill.
Debate, on motion of Mr Gibson, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (7.38 pm): I present a message from Her Excellency the Governor.
The Deputy Speaker (Mr Wendt) read the following message--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: MESSAGE
NATURAL RESOURCES AND OTHER LEGISLATION
AMENDMENT BILL 2010
I, PENELOPE ANNE WENSLEY, Governor, recommend to the Legislative Assembly a Bill intituled--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: A Bill for an Act to amend the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003, the Aboriginal Land Act 1991, the Coastal Protection and Management Act 1995, the Dividing Fences Act 1953, the Fire and Rescue Service Act 1990, the Forestry Act 1959, the Forestry Regulation 1998, the Forestry Plantations Queensland Act 2006, the Forestry (State Forests) Regulation 1987, the Land Act 1994, the Land Title Act 1994, the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971, the Survey and Mapping Infrastructure Act 2003, the Surveyors Act 2003, the Torres Strait Islander Cultural Heritage Act 2003, the Torres Strait Islander Land Act 1991, the Vegetation Management Act 1999 and the Water Act 2000 for particular purposes, and to make minor amendments of Acts as stated in the schedule for particular purposes.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: (sgd)
GOVERNOR
Date: 08 MAR 2010
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Message from Her Excellency the Governor, dated 8 March 2010, recommending the Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (7.40 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003, the Aboriginal Land Act 1991, the Coastal Protection and Management Act 1995, the Dividing Fences Act 1953, the Fire and Rescue Service Act 1990, the Forestry Act 1959, the Forestry Regulation 1998, the Forestry Plantations Queensland Act 2006, the Forestry (State Forests) Regulation 1987, the Land Act 1994, the Land Title Act 1994, the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971, the Survey and Mapping Infrastructure Act 2003, the Surveyors Act 2003, the Torres Strait Islander Cultural Heritage Act 2003, the Torres Strait Islander Land Act 1991, the Vegetation Management Act 1999 and the Water Act 2000 for particular purposes, and to make minor amendments of acts as stated in the schedule for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
Tabled paper: Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment BIll, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (7.40 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 provides amendments to a number of acts within my portfolio. Firstly, this bill will amend the Water Act 2000, the Land Act 1994 and the Survey and Mapping Infrastructure Act 2003 to resolve the longstanding uncertainty and confusion about the location of tidal and non-tidal ambulatory boundaries. An ambulatory boundary is defined by reference to a body of water such as a sea or river. The location of an ambulatory boundary may shift over time. This bill will provide criteria for locating an ambulatory boundary; firstly, it will clarify the distinction between the state’s jurisdiction over a watercourse and its ownership of a non-tidal boundary watercourse; secondly, it will clarify the location of each of these boundaries.

Confusion in the location of ambulatory boundaries has been the subject of both lower and higher court decisions. For example, in one case the court determined that the ambulatory boundary set at ‘high-water mark’ was positioned at mean high-water springs. As a consequence some landholders resurveyed their lot to incorporate the land between their original boundary and mean high-water springs. In some cases this increased the size of their lot and incorporated beach land into private ownership.

To protect beaches for the community, in 2005 the government introduced a stay on the registration of these types of survey plans. During the stay, tidal plans of subdivision lodged by surveyors were first subjected to a technical assessment, for example, has the surveyor followed the relevant survey directions including requirements regarding measurements, and then to a public interest test, including issues such as public access and environmental considerations, before being considered by the minister. Under this process, 15 such plans have been approved for registration, six have been rejected for technical reasons and 10 are being assessed.The bill provides that tidal plans of survey approved during the stay will be treated as if they had been surveyed under the new rules. Where tidal plans of survey are not approved before the repeal of the stay, they will be subject to the new rules which, in effect, will be similar to those that applied during the stay. This bill creates a permanent solution to the problem, providing strict criteria to ensure that beach land cannot be taken into private ownership.

It applies similar criteria for non-tidal watercourse boundaries. For land with a non-tidal watercourse boundary, a change to a boundary on resurvey will not diminish a landholder’s riparian rights in any way. Landowners adjoining a watercourse will still be able to take water for stock and domestic purposes, exercise the right of access and bring action against trespassers. This bill will create certainty about ambulatory boundaries for landholders and the state. As a result, it will reduce legal disputes over non-tidal watercourse boundaries.

This bill also provides for the longer term management of the state’s plantation interests by the Department of Environment and Resource Management. This includes provisions for ensuring security of tenure and for public access into the future. Also, this bill will establish a licensing scheme where the state will issue a plantation licence for an area. It will ensure plantation forestry land is used and managed for the purpose of forestry and in a transparent and sustainable manner. This bill also ensures that the rights of others using the state plantation forest, such as apiarists and graziers, are preserved into the future. Importantly, the right of access by the general public is also preserved. Given the need to ensure safety and security of persons during plantation operations, such as harvesting, this bill provides the plantation licensee with certain control powers limited to the licence area.

This bill also amends the Water Act 2000 to provide for the much needed finalisation of the Lower Balonne provisions for the Condamine and Balonne Resource Operations Plan. The Lower Balonne provisions of the draft Condamine and Balonne Resource Operations Plan were deferred in December 2008 due to a judicial review action. This resulted in the resource operations plan only covering the upper and middle Condamine catchments. Although the Supreme Court found in favour of the department and dismissed the judicial review application, it is critical the Lower Balonne provisions for the resource operations plan be finalised without further delay. Water users in the Lower Balonne are the only water users in the Murray-Darling Basin who do not have secure water access entitlements and who cannot participate in the Commonwealth government’s water entitlement buy-back program to achieve improved environmental outcomes for the basin. This finalisation will provide certainty to water users and the environment and deliver the necessary creation of tradable water entitlements in the area to provide the flexibility for entitlement holders to participate in this program.

The conversion of existing entitlements to water allocations and the resource operations plan provisions will commence on the day the resource operations plan is made. This is the day the proposed legislative amendment, if passed, receives the royal assent. The resource operations plan rules will apply to flows from the day of commencement of the finalised resource operations plan. The majority of unsupplemented water entitlements at the commencement of the resource operations plan will be under an instantaneous water-sharing rule. This is a key feature of the finalised Condamine and Balonne Water Resource Plan. As supporting information to the forthcoming debate on this amendment I would like to table the Condamine and Balonne resource operations plan amendment incorporating the Lower Balonne area .
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document titled Condamine and Balonne resource operations plan amendment incorporating the Lower Balonne area dated March 2010 by the Department of Environment and Resource Management.
XML.Hansard-Body: This bill also makes minor amendments to the Forestry Act 1959, the Land Act 1994, the Land Title Act 1994, the Surveyors Act 2003, the Survey and Mapping Infrastructure Act 2003, the Vegetation Management Act 1999, the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003 and the Torres Strait Islander Cultural Heritage Act 2003. These amendments will provide more legal security for landholders entering into agreements with third parties about ownership of the natural resource products on their land; strengthen provisions relating to lease terms under the Delbessie Agreement; ensure the keeping of registers relating to land is as efficient, convenient and accurate as possible; improve regulation of the surveying profession; and rectify a duplication of regulation for vegetation clearing in relation to national parks. The minor amendments will also clarify the definition of the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander native title party for an area to put beyond doubt the identity of the native title party for cultural heritage purposes in the situation where there are two or more previously registered claimants for an area.

In commending the bill to the House I note that in terms of the document I said I would table, I do not have it in my possession at this point in time but I will table it at the earliest possible opportunity.
Debate, on motion of Mr Seeney, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (7.47 pm), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That, notwithstanding anything contained in standing and sessional orders for this day’s sitting, the House can continue to meet past 10 pm to consider government business until the adjournment is moved to be followed by the 30-minute adjournment debate.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 697, on motion of Mr Robertson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (7.48 pm): We heard the Oscar rating given by the member for Gympie of this government’s performance, particularly aligning their acting cred to that of a B-grade movie.
Mr Gibson: Going to DVD.

Ms SIMPSON: Or going to DVD early it is so bad, but I think that there is another analogy and that is of a government that is perhaps deserving of an award in the Razzies. They are certainly the worst economic managers that this state has ever seen. While we can laugh about just how bad they may seem, the sad reality is that it is Queenslanders who actually pay for that failed economic management.

This is the first government that lost its AAA rating. It would have us believe that it was not its fault. In an excuse analogous to the ‘dog ate my homework’, this government lost the AAA rating at a time when other states did not. Now we see this legislation before the House, which is another milestone on its path to economic disaster because it has no connection or understanding of the business and investment world in which we do live. That is not just big business; it is small business and it is private investment. If ever there has been an example of a piece of legislation that has been crafted in such a way as to fail to understand the most basic principles of investment here in Queensland, this is it.

If there is a movie that we can align this government’s performance to it is probably Risky Business . If we look at what industry has been saying about this piece of legislation, they have said this legislation is risky to business. You would think that those who are professional in the area of valuations--professional valuers who are in the business of putting their skills on the line, being willing to go out to the marketplace and make their professional judgements on the valuation of property--may see this legislation as such a great opportunity in that many of them would be called in to undertake revaluations under the government’s proposed legislation. But no, they were critical of this legislation. They were highly critical of this legislation because of the fact that it was risky to business. I will read just one contribution from the valuation industry in this regard which I think is quite important. They said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The deception--the bill--will serve to make Queensland a risky place to invest.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a very strong statement. As I said, this is not just about big business or even small business, which employs the majority of Queenslanders; it is also about private investors--all those mum-and-dad investors and people who have money in superannuation funds. What we have seen with this legislation is a sneaky, sly attempt to justify the government’s desire to grab more land tax by changing the way that valuations are formulated in this state.

I have heard all these excuses from Labor members saying, ‘It’s not really that serious. It was not such a big change.’ When we consider the level of extraordinary outrage from across the community in regard to this bill we realise that this government has no understanding of the field in which it operates. Did it conduct consultation? Looking at the explanatory notes, did it consult with the people it was impacting upon the most? The answer is no. The explanatory notes have a paucity of information about those the government has talked to other than government departments. Also we see that it did talk to government departments interstate. But did it bother to talk to mum-and-dad investors here? Was there any fair dinkum public consultation before this bill came into the House? No. We see it talked to the LGAQ, which is ‘supportive of the amendments in relation to the rolling schedule adjustments factor’. However, I am looking for where the industry stakeholders are listed. I am looking for where the feedback is on the wider public consultation that the government should have conducted about a bill of this nature, and there is none. That is why when this legislation was tabled in the House we saw a rolling groundswell of absolute fury and disbelief that this government, which has taken dishonesty to a new level, would dare to stoop to this.

This legislation shows that this government is desperate for cash. It does not matter how it wants to get it or what means it wants to take; it wants to grab it without understanding the full ramifications upon the purses of ordinary Queenslanders. At the end of the day, to create jobs in Queensland you have to have businesses, big and small, you have to have certainty in the investment arena and you have to have an understanding of how economic development occurs. This Labor government really believes its own mythology that bigger taxes equals better service. It has shown that myth for what it is: there are bigger taxes, but we have not seen better services.

Queensland used to be one of the most competitive regimes in which to operate and it used to be able to deliver hospital services and a range of other services in a much more timely way with infrastructure than what we have seen with this government. Instead what we see now is a government that wilfully wastes money on PR campaigns and on poorly scoped infrastructure programs with significant blow-outs that should make it blush. Yet still it puts its hands out asking for more from the public and hopes that people will allow it to get away with it. The public did not want to allow it to get away with it. The government has had to back down in force as we now await the new legislation, the replacement legislation, which has been announced today and which will allegedly come forward at the end of the year.

Yes, it is an embarrassment to this state that this is the way that this government does business. Ultimately, we in the LNP want to see a business community and an investment climate for small investors that has the certainty to know that governments do what they say they will do and they are not deceitful and operate with a sleight of hand. This legislation as it was presented to the parliament is a sleight of hand. Some of the changes that it proposed were to redefine ‘unimproved capital value’. The government tried to make out it was not really a definition; it already had a certain bundle of other elements within unimproved capital value, which was just fallacious. It has been blown out of the water by those in the valuation industry. The government was attempting in this legislation to tax entrepreneurial profit and to also tax goodwill. It admitted that leases and goodwill were improvements, claiming that these improvements were always deemed to be part of unimproved capital value. As I said, the valuation industry begged to differ.

What was quite significant and took this beyond the realm of just big business is the fact that in Queensland since the amendment to the Land Tax Act in 2009 there is actually a wider base of people who will potentially be affected by land tax. Tenants are now directly liable to pay land tax under those amendments. That is passed on to a whole raft of thousands of Queenslanders. The tax burden might have been widened but it definitely impacts beyond big business; it impacts everybody. Someone who has an investment house, somebody who has a small business or is paying land tax or those at the big end of town--all were affected. Because of the way this government has been pushing up the unimproved capital value with its dodgy self-convenient reinterpretation of unimproved capital value combined with the rate of land tax, Queensland is now one of the most expensive places in Australia.

Queensland deserves better. Queensland deserves a competitive taxation rate and an efficient delivery of services. Queenslanders no longer deserve this myth that has been peddled by this government that bigger taxes equals better government, because what we have seen has proven that to be a complete lie.

We are opposed to the legislation that the government has tabled. We are vehemently opposed to a means which is about taking money off people, not delivering better services, and undermining the certainty which is so necessary not only for business but also for the small investor. Queensland deserves better legislation than this.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (7.57 pm): The bill that we are debating tonight, the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, is a horrendous piece of legislation for Queensland. It will affect landholders and businesspeople as well as ordinary, everyday families trying to get a start. This is legislation that will be devastating to business certainty in Queensland and the Labor government should be condemned for its actions when it comes to the composition of this bill.

What we are seeing is a blatant tax grab. This is about high taxes--nothing else. It is about a broke state government that is on its knees and is ready to rape the Queensland business community to save it from its own financial woes. The Queensland government has definitely gone over the top this time and it is desperately trying to scrape its way back and save face. We have seen thousands of dollars spent on advertising trying to convince Queenslanders, and now the government has had to back down after the huge public outrage was expressed.

As the shadow minister has said, we will not be supporting this bill. I commend the shadow minister, the member for Callide, on his well presented argument and analysis of this legislation. The main thrust of this legislation is that the definition of ‘unimproved value’ for the purpose of rates and land tax has been fundamentally altered by including further components in the unimproved value of land. These include infrastructure charges, leases including agreements for lease and other instruments increasing the value of the land, goodwill of the business conducted on that land and profit and loss generated by the business conducted.

This means that the tax base is no longer on the unimproved value but on a very subjective assessment of the economic value of that land. The original method of valuation of land was based on comparable sales, but more recently this government has moved towards valuing land according to the level of development on that land. Of course, this current legislation has been introduced as a result of the Pacific Fair case, where the court rejected the state’s declaration that the unimproved value of improved land included the added value of leases, goodwill and profit or loss. As the shadow minister has stated, because the department could not get its own way with the court it has now brought this to the parliament to change the face of land valuation across Queensland.

As a result of the huge outrage expressed by the Property Council and so many other organisations and individuals across Queensland, this morning the government brought in a series of amendments to the bill. These include changing the retrospectivity of the bill to validate previous valuations, with the exception of outstanding appeals that must be resolved by 30 June. The bill applies the government definition of ‘unimproved value’ with some minor changes, subject to it being replaced with ‘site value’ in the bill to be introduced in September to allow the 2010 valuations to be released at the end of this month. The amendment introduces a sunset clause to the end of the next financial year after which, if a new bill has not passed, the current regime will be reactivated.

Regardless of the various tweaks of the original bill, the amendments still reflect the government fundamentally changing the definition of unimproved land in Queensland. It still sees the effective removal of objection and appeal rights, and sees the future of the land valuation system in Queensland becoming very concerning. Calculating land valuation is an extremely complicated procedure and it is becoming far more subjective under this legislation.

Like many members of this House, I have been approached by many people who are very concerned about this legislation. In fact, they are very frightened about the effects that the legislation could have on their livelihoods. I quote from a communication that I received from a gentleman who is a respected property analyst and a registered valuer with retail and commercial valuation experience. He states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Valuation of income producing properties is quite technical and requires a high degree of skill. It would appear to me that this Bill has been drafted by parties which do not hold the required experience as the proposals are not only extremely detrimental to the values of income producing properties (of all value ranges) but illogical and unworkable from a practical sense. Contrary to the Government’s claims, these proposed changes represent a fundamental shift away from how valuations have been done in the past. What is even more concerning is the Queensland Government’s denial and rejection of the criticism it has received from most leading industry bodies regarding the issues.
XML.Hansard-Body: I must say that, to a point, we have seen a backdown from the government as a result of the massive criticism it is receiving, but what we debate today is still a fundamental change. It is wrong and it will greatly impact on the business sector of Queensland. There will be a flow-on effect as this will hit business, particularly small business, due to the resulting increase in land tax and very possibly council rates as well. It will result in Queenslanders’ jobs being lost. Housing affordability will be affected. The cost for homebuyers will surely rise to reflect the increase in land tax as a result of valuations.

This will have a very real impact on superannuation. Average Queenslanders who have property shares in their superannuation funds will of course be affected. How can they not be affected? The government is saying that this will only affect the big end of town. That is totally untrue. The flow-on effects of the legislation will affect normal battling families. House costs and land values within superannuation packages will of course be affected. It is so wrong for this government to pat itself on the back and say, so condescendingly, that it will not affect mum-and-dad investors. That is another blatant untruth from the government.

Again we are seeing the socialist system of total control by the government, which is effectively removing most of the Queensland landholder rights to object and appeal decisions that have been made regarding the value of their land. This bill proposes to streamline the objection process, but this streamlining involves a significant increase in the level of detail required in an objection. The objection must now include grounds of objection to the valuation with particulars of the facts and of the circumstances relied on for each of the grounds. This will become a process that will give the department far more scope to reject objections on the grounds that they are not properly made. A process of appeal is a fundamental democratic principle and the erosion of this right is very dangerous for the future of Queensland. I really do fear where this government is taking us.

This is another blatant attempt by the government to get itself out of trouble. It is a deliberate tax grab by the beleaguered Premier and her Treasurer because they have sent this state broke. This is the government that says the global financial crisis caused it to go broke. The Queensland people will not swallow that argument any longer. This government was $65 billion in debt before the GFC and it has effectively racked up another $20 billion since then. In effect, we now see the government saying, ‘Let’s get the big end of town. Let’s push up this wealth tax to get the most we can from them.’ There is no thought for the businesspeople who will suffer, the small businesses that will surely go to the wall and the massive job losses that will result.

Encouraging private enterprise will encourage jobs creation, but this government has no idea. It thinks that all money comes in a pay envelope with a PAYE ticket attached. It has absolutely no idea of wealth creation or the encouragement of wealth creation. Housing affordability will surely suffer further as a result of this land valuation regime. This process will actually place additional costs on developers which of course must be passed on to new homebuyers. However, this comes from a government that has seen fit to waste $1.3 million on land at Palm Cove to build a few units. That money could have been spent much more wisely and much more appropriately to benefit far more Queenslanders and build far more units, which are desperately needed. The government could have built far more, but it does not know the meaning of fiscal restraint. It has no idea and the Queensland people have to bear the brunt of its inadequacy.

Prior to the 2009 election, Treasurer Andrew Fraser said that he would rule out any increase to state taxes. But what is this if not another sneaky way to massively increase land tax? Even though the land tax rate may remain constant, the increased valuation of land will result in a massive increase in taxes, to the detriment of the Queensland business sector. This is pricing Queensland out of the market to investors from right across Australia. I quote another communication that I have received. The person stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I write to you today to advise that every potential buyer of property in the Brisbane CBD from the southern states has now decided it is safer to invest in NSW & Victoria due to the crazy/lunatic antics of the current State Government in relation to changing the way the state values land. This is not just a local issue. How dare the elected government overturn decisions by no less than 4 Judges?
I am dumbfounded that this can happen in an educated society. We are supposed to be the Smart State--we are on a boat with no rudder.
XML.Hansard-Body: How wise that man is! Once again the government has been proven to be wrong and is desperately trying to cover its tracks. At the end of the day, this can only be described as an opportunistic cash grab and the LNP will be opposing it.

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (8.08 pm): I rise to oppose the government’s Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 as it was introduced into this House. I join the many concerned constituents in my electorate and across Queensland who have contacted my office, and I call for major amendments to the bill. I will mainly address the bill in its introduced and supposedly well-considered form.

The government has had plenty of time to get this right. It is an indictment on this Labor government that, despite all the resources at its disposal, it has put forward such a pathetic bill. The government’s incompetence is further demonstrated by the fact that, on the morning of the debate, at the eleventh hour, after suffering from LIP syndrome, or ‘Labor induced panic syndrome’, it suddenly produced amendments. Today members opposite, including the member for Brisbane Central, falsely presented to the parliament the perception that the government planned this approach all along. What a farce! To accept the member for Brisbane Central’s assertion is to ignore all the facts in the lead-up to the debate today.

The government communicated to the public in the light of the Pacific Fair court case that it intended to change the definition of ‘unimproved value’ and to apply it retrospectively. There is no doubt that the Property Council, among other bodies, together with landowners everywhere, interpreted the government’s bill as nothing but a tax grab and a radical change to what the public understands as the definition of ‘unimproved value’. To suggest differently is to fly in the face of the facts--but the member for Brisbane Central rarely lets the facts get in the way of the Labor story.
Ms GRACE: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I find those words offensive. They are misleading and I ask them to be withdrawn.

Dr ROBINSON: I withdraw. The truth that government members are running from and seeking to hide from the public is that the government today performed a gold medal winning backflip. Succumbing to the great pressure applied by the community and the opposition, and with a sudden and rare rush of common sense, the government has decided to scrap several of the discriminatory and unjust aspects of the bill that it fully intended to force upon the public. Except for the high-profile campaign by various property industry groups, the government would have forced its bill through today without amendment. This dramatic backdown by the government on the new land valuation laws while welcome would not have been necessary if the government had consulted with industry and listened to the public and LNP suggestions in the first place. Something has gone very wrong with this government’s public antenna. Labor has lost its ability to listen and respond to the public. When the large majority of Queenslanders do not want Labor’s asset sales or its social experiments, Labor has this ability to ignore the public and push ahead.

This bill needs to be understood in the light of the failure of this government to manage the state’s economy and its need to increase its revenue through increased taxation. Labor’s original laws may have seen land tax increases of between 20 and 40 per cent. Such increases would have threatened the viability of many businesses, cost jobs and hurt mum-and-dad investors. This land tax bill is nothing more than a rip-off tax grab from this high-taxing, high-debt Bligh government. Instead of being more prudent with expenditure, this government looks for every opportunity to feed its tax addiction.

This government loves taxes. Like the mutants in the Will Smith blockbuster movie I Am Legend who thirst for human blood, this government is sucking the life out of Queenslanders--everyday investors and workers. No-one escapes the bared fangs of this tax-thirsty government. It loves new taxes and it loves lifting taxes so that it can spend more. We see the example of Labor’s ETS--a great big new tax--that Labor does not want to talk about since the failure of Copenhagen. We also see Labor’s possible GST increase to 12 per cent rumoured in the hidden Henry review. The tax increase will be needed to pay for the new layer of federal bureaucracy in Rudd’s health plan.

Then there is the Queensland transport minister’s flirtation with a congestion tax. She wants to tax everyone who drives into the city by car. One person who understood the Labor tendency to tax anything and everything said that they were surprised that the Premier had not put a congestion tax on all the voters switching from Labor to the LNP. Based on the latest polls and including union members who were outside the parliament today who are deserting Premier Bligh, we could replace all other taxes in Queensland with a congestion tax on the exodus from Labor.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order!
Would the member return to the topic of the bill, please?

Dr ROBINSON: Taxes? I do not intend to repeat what other opposition members have presented. Let me say that I concur with the excellent speeches provided by the members for Callide and Clayfield, among others, and commend them for their very significant and common-sense contribution to this debate that I have listened to. Further, I condemn the government for its legislative recklessness.

Key problems identified in the bill by opposition members and groups such as the Property Council include: firstly, the cash-grabbing retrospectivity provisions; secondly, the attempt to unjustly redefine unimproved land value in favour of the government and against the public; thirdly, the fact that it supports the status quo in which Queenslanders are already slugged with excessively high land tax bills that under this government will keep climbing--land tax has grown dramatically from $380 million in 2004-05 to a projected figure of $1 billion in 2010; fourthly, the flow-on effect of the tax to everyday consumers as higher rents, rates and prices; fifthly, the loss of jobs when land tax increases cannot be recovered; sixthly, the restrictions regarding appeals; and, seventhly, the ignoring of key stakeholders in the process resulting in unnecessary pain.

I would like to build on the LNP’s opposition to the bill by considering some local stories from my electorate of Cleveland and the wider Redlands community. Since the introduction of this legislation, my office has received many complaints about this bill. These were unsolicited phone calls, emails and faxes. I offer just a few examples to illustrate the problems that Labor’s land tax policy has already inflicted on constituents of Cleveland, the wider Redlands and other parts of Queensland.

One local businessman told me that his land tax bill had gone up dramatically under the Bligh government. His land tax bill has grown as follows: in 1993 it was $1,400 for a number of years up until 2006, when it grew to $3,000. That is a $1,600 increase in around 13 or so years. Then in 2007 it grew to $6,000--from $3,000 to $6,000 in one year. In 2008 it was $10,000. In 2009 it was $14,000. This is a tenfold increase since 1993. Another resident whose land tax bill has soared in recent years to be in excess of $100,000 wrote to me on 8 March. He wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Hello Mark, we are contacting you trusting this will allow us to strongly object to the proposed land tax amendments by the current state Labor Government. Land tax ... can only create increased rents and charges [and] more unemployment. This shallow blind thinking is a cover to recoup wasted millions to boost empty government coffers ... The resultant inflation will immediately erode the spending power of the worker, yes and the investor also--a great result.
XML.Hansard-Body: This individual went on to say that they would normally have to pass on the high level of tax that they pay, particularly any increases, to their clients who would in turn have to pass it on to their customers. However, in this case the leases of their clients were not due to be renewed for another eight years, so he was having to contemplate other remedies. His employees would have to be nervous.

On a slightly divergent but still relevant note, I give another example of the impact of this legislation on local Redlanders. The sports minister, Phil Reeves, today announced in a ministerial statement that the Bligh government will continue its investment in the Australian PGA Championship at Coolum for a further three years from 2010 until 2012. He also claimed that the event generates more than 100 jobs for Queenslanders. I would like the House to consider another golf course that shows the real impact of the government’s tax-hungry policies--the Howeston golf course in the Redlands. Many Cleveland residents use it. I admit to hitting the occasional golf ball into the trees and dams myself. I raise the case before the House to illustrate the fears this insidious high-taxing Labor bill has created in the Redlands community. Recently the owners of the golf course wrote a letter to the Premier and they sent me a copy. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Premier,
We pay $47,178.00 Land Tax now.
We have been in business for 38 years.
Our family business is now in its third generation.

Since we started employing staff in 1984, we have employed 50 different people. Some starting from school days and working here during their university studies. These employees have gone onto professional positions. Six school teachers, events management, environmental officers and so on. Three of our staff have received long service and are still working here.

We have improved our golf course from 9 holes to 27 holes, made by our own hands. This sporting venue has hosted the Queensland PGA Foursomes, the Queensland PGA Championships as well as hosting 38 consecutive annual Pro Am’s. Many of the Professional golfers that have played in these Pro Am’s have gone onto the world stage.

Our sporting venue is an important part of the community attracting players from far and wide. Our low green fees are a big part of the attraction allowing people from many walks of life to play. We neither ask for nor receive any government help. If the government goes ahead with the idea put forward--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: talking about this bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: it would mean the difference of us remaining a going concern. Staff would be out of work. Suppliers affected. Please give this your consideration.

No one would ever improve or invest in their business. This would affect all business and investors. They would leave Queensland en masse. It would be political suicide. Any gain in tax would be chicken feed compared to the loss from business and investors ... Please reply to my concerns. Please consider what you are doing to us and to our State.
Yours faithfully ...
XML.Hansard-Body: The impact of increased land tax on the golf course is clear: higher green fees that some people may not be able to afford, jobs lost, suppliers affected, and potentially bankruptcy. It is clear that the original bill was a disaster, and I note that the government has backed down from some of its most disastrous provisions. While this backdown is welcome, as a member of the opposition in representing the residents of Cleveland, I will be watching for what the government comes up with later in the year to do what I can to ensure it does deliver a fair and proper land valuation system. In summary, I oppose this unfair and unjust bill, and call on the government to implement major amendments.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (8.21 pm): In its original form, this bill could have been called the ‘Robin Hood Bill’ except it did not seek to tax only the rich and it certainly did not seem to have much of an intention of giving back to the poor. The industry has written to each one of us members, and we have all had a flood of emails, faxes and communications from people who were very concerned about the bill in its original form. The Property Council of Australia said that this bill was introduced without prior industry consultation. The government is making much of the fact that it has consulted with the industry, but doing things after the fact is not the ideal way of doing them with credibility.

The Property Council has also said this bill will have far-reaching and significant impacts on all Queenslanders, contrary and far beyond the policy intent expressed by the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy in his second reading speech. The Property Council further urges us to note that if this ill-conceived bill goes through unchanged, land tax and potentially council rates will increase substantially. It is a double whammy, because when that happens asset values will fall which can lead to job losses and massive increases in the cost involved in doing business. At this particular time in the economic cycle, Queensland is in a fairly parlous state financially. We certainly do not want private enterprise to be suffering from those kinds of double whammies. Now that the government has acquiesced and rolled three wheelbarrows full of amendments into this chamber, we now see a new political strategy called ‘WTHCWGAW’, which stands for ‘what the heck can we get away with’. That is the new manifesto and philosophy.

In its original form, this was a pernicious piece of legislation which had a lot of people suitably and, in all fairness, notably worried. Under the bill the unimproved value of land was going to include--among other things--goodwill, the added value of leases and agreements for lease, and the value of infrastructure charges paid. In my previous career in accounting and financial planning, the one thing we would always tell clients who were buying a business was to not pay for goodwill. The government’s original intention to add goodwill into the mix of revenue would be a crazy decision.

I well remember in my financial planning days that people could make things sound good. If ever you saw someone who had a business card that said ‘Offices in London, Brisbane and Hong Kong’, no-one would suspect that you worked at home from your kitchen table. It is not just about looking good; it is about doing good. I want to give credit where credit is due. Now that the government has been to ‘Camp David’ and there is a modicum of peace in the middle east of Queensland finances, let us have a quick look at the amendments. This morning, in her summary of these amendments, the Premier stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The government will preserve appeal rights for any appeals already on foot until 1 July 2010. We will endeavour to settle these appeals as soon as practicable and have set aside $30 million in a settlement fund to do so.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would ask the minister for clarification on what will happen if that $30 million fund is exceeded. In the context of big business, that could be swallowed up very quickly. What will happen after that? Personally I would have liked to have seen that date pushed out until at least the end of the calendar year to give people time to be certain about the cases they were fighting. If there is a conga line of people lining up at the door for negotiation, then these things can take some time to go through. It is already March and July is knocking on our door.

Under the proposed system, the site valuation will represent the land’s current market value if it was vacant and will include the value of current site works such as landfill and pipe work. We could call that colloquially the footprint of the land. I think that is a much fairer system, and I am very supportive of the majority of the amendments that have been foreshadowed to this bill. As I said before, to bring legislation into the parliament and then bring in later 50 or 60 amendments begs the question whether the bill was sound in the first place.

The Premier also stated in her ministerial statement this morning that this was not a revenue measure. If the bill had gone through in its original form, if the government was not dragged kicking and screaming to the negotiating table, it would have been a major revenue grab. The bill in its original intent was tantamount to daylight robbery.

Any settlement of the appeal rights that we talked about occurring by 30 June this year puts far too much pressure on small business. As I said, this is not just a ‘Robin Hood Bill’ of robbing the rich. This is mum-and-dad investors, people with superannuation funds and many other properties that certainly would not be considered to be fabulously wealthy, and it was a big hit either way. Lots of other states have retained the position of an independent valuer-general, and I welcome the government’s decision to do that. I think independence is needed so that in the process there is due transparency. With those few comments, I welcome the amendments that have been foreshadowed in the House. I urge all members to consider them very carefully.
Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP) (8.27 pm): I rise to speak to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
Mr Schwarten: We’ll get some sense now.

Mr KILBURN: I certainly hope so. In rising to participate in this debate, I would like in particular to address the amendments that allow the chief executive of the department to require that further information be provided by property owners in relation to their objection. We have heard quite a lot of talk from the other side tonight about a whole range of things, and a lot of it has been quite deceitful, which is not unusual for them, but what surprises me most is the laziness of their speeches. It appears to me they have made a bunch of speeches they must have written last week and they have not taken into account any of the changes or the amendments that have been made to this bill in the meantime. We have seen deceitful statements made, and I talk particularly about the member for Cleveland’s statement that this was going to apply to farming land and that farmers were going to get hit with a tax on their rural properties. This is either deceitful or the member is incredibly lazy in not taking the time to check his facts, but we have been hearing quite a lot of that tonight.

Under this bill the valuation objection process will be streamlined to ensure that better information is available to decide objections in a timely manner. I would think that that was a good outcome. All objections will now be required to be lodged on the approved notice of objection form which must include information that demonstrates why the objection is being made. It is hardly onerous to ask the landowner why they are lodging an objection and why they believe the valuation is incorrect. It is not sufficient anymore for a landowner to simply state that the value of their property is incorrect. The landowner must now provide the grounds for their objection and information to support this must be provided with the objection form. I think that is pretty much standard when anyone lodges an objection to anything. They have to specify what it is about.

Once this information has been lodged with the department and assessed as being properly made--that means that the form is filled out properly--a departmental valuer will then consider the objection by reviewing the grounds for objection and the supporting evidence. At this point the valuer can invite the owner to provide more information relative to the objection within 14 days of the request. This period can be extended by another 14 days by mutual agreement between the parties. That is a total of 28 days.

I have heard numerous times tonight those on the other side of the House say that we are taking away the right of people to object. That is blatantly untrue. There is still plenty of opportunity for people to lodge an objection. There is also an opportunity for the department to initiate a conference with the objector to discuss the objection. If a conference occurs the objector then has a further 14 days after the conference ends to give the chief executive further written information in support of their objection. Far from taking away the right to object we have streamlined the process and made it more sustainable. We are giving people more of an opportunity to provide information to the chief executive.

Under the Valuation of Land Act 1944 the chief executive has always had the power to require further information be provided in relation to an objection. This request is only made when the chief executive or their delegate considers that the information is in the objector’s possession and is relevant to the decision-making process. In the past, property owners have stated that the information was not in their possession and the objection had to be decided on the information available. If the objection was disallowed, the objector, in some cases, appealed the decision to the Land Court and then produced the evidence that was being requested in the course of the assessment. I think streamlining this process makes sense. It stops time being wasted in the appeal process. It stops people lobbing up at the Land Court with new information that has not been available in the process. I think these are good amendments.

The new section is not changing the ground rules; it is making the process more robust to ensure that all the relevant information is available to make a proper and fair decision on the objection. The provision to require information will only apply to properties with an unimproved value of $2 million or more. So we are not talking about ordinary residential properties. The homes, investment properties and farms of mums and dads are not the ones that will be affected by this legislation.

If the chief executive reasonably believes that the objector has further information which is relevant to the objection the objector will be provided with a notice requesting the provision of this additional information. The objector will then have 28 days to provide this information and a further 14 days by agreement. Once again, it hardly seems like we are stopping people objecting. They will have 28 days and a possible further 14 days to provide the information.
