If this information is not received within the time frame the objector will receive a lapsing notice stating that if the information is not provided within a further 14 days--that is a total two months--then the objection will lapse. Once the objection has lapsed a decision cannot be made by the chief executive on the objection. Therefore, the appeal cannot be lodged with the Land Court.

This process provides the objector with ample opportunity to provide the information which is only being requested because it is considered relevant to the objection. I would also like to point out that if this information is not in the objector’s possession or cannot be provided because of legal professional privilege and the objector signs a statutory declaration to that effect then the objection will not lapse and the decision on the objection will be made based on the information before the chief executive. Whilst the objector cannot appeal the chief executive’s decision to require this information, the objector does have the right to request a review under the Judicial Review Act 1991.

Industry groups have raised concerns about this process saying that the department could use this to request information that is not relevant or that it is on a fishing expedition to justify the valuation that has been issued. This is simply not the case. The information would be requested because it is considered that it would be relevant to accurately decide the objection, provide for a fair decision to be made and take into account all of the relevant information. These provisions will encourage the provision of the appropriate information at the beginning and during the objection process. An improvement in the quality of the information considered in the objection process will provide landowners with more confidence in the robustness of the process and potentially reduce the number of objections that progress to appeal.

Reducing appeals lodged in the Land Court is a benefit to everyone, potentially saving landowners and the department a great deal of time and money--something I would have thought the LNP would have supported. Making a decision on an objection based on all available and relevant information ensures the right decision is reached. The department knows that it does not get every valuation right. If information is available to rectify an incorrect valuation it is better for everyone if this is resolved during the objection process.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (8.37 pm): In rising to participate in the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 I would like to address the need to validate valuations issued prior to the commencement of the new legislation. There has been considerable public discussion about the impact of the Court of Appeal decision on past valuations if not addressed.

The government has moved to address that court decision which overturned decades of past practice in commercial property valuation. If not addressed that decision would have changed the way in which commercial industrial property was valued, resulting in property values falling, valuations falling by up to 35 per cent and a consequential windfall reduction in the payment of rates and taxes.

However, of even greater concern is that under the current act the court’s decision would have to be applied to the last three annual valuations dating back, in some cases, to 2002. This would have resulted in an estimated repayment of rates of more than $600 million and $300 million in land tax. Who would have worn the cost of this? It would have been ordinary ratepayers. The government could not stand by and let that happen. Consequently, the bill provides for an amendment that valuations issued prior to the commencement of the new legislation will be validated to be correct as at their effective date.

The bill also provides that existing provisions that require the chief executive to apply the decision to all commercial and industrial valuations over the past three annual valuations be turned off. Existing appeals will not be captured by these validating provisions. On the basis of proceeding in good faith and without prejudice to negotiate settlements to these appeals, a new provision is being inserted in the bill to allow outstanding appeals existing at the time of the passage of the bill to be decided under the existing legislation up to and including 30 June 2010. These provisions protect the interests of the state by validating those valuations that are not the subject of appeal and have been accepted by landowners as being correct, thereby ensuring that significant refunds in rates and taxes do not accrue. They also protect the interests of appellants, preserving their appeal rights and providing an opportunity to settle these matters on reasonable terms within a reasonable time frame. Any outstanding appeals after 30 June 2010 will be decided on the amended legislation, if passed.

The Pacific Fair Court of Appeal decision has thrown into doubt the unimproved value methodology that has been used by State Valuation Services for many years. The court’s interpretation of the legislation has now created two methodologies as to how a valuation is to be determined--one methodology for commercial and industrial properties which delivers a huge reduction in the rates and taxes those property owners would have had to pay, and one methodology for residential property owners which would result in ordinary ratepayers having to pay extra in rates to subsidise the substantial loss of revenue to local governments. This uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue, and the procedures set out in this bill restore surety to the revenue base.

The property industry has stated publicly through media releases that the implications of the amendments will prove to be a windfall for government in relation to land tax. In effect the amendments equate to a ‘business tax’, as property owners who have developed their land to its highest and best use are now being penalised for this. I want to assure business owners throughout the state but particularly those in tropical North Queensland and my electorate of Barron River, particularly those involved with the tourism industry, that, contrary to the statements being made by the property industry in the media, this is not a new business tax which will penalise the people of Queensland. This is not even a tax; it is a land valuation. I recognise that the tourism industry in Far North Queensland in my electorate of Barron River should not be burdened with additional costs, particularly in the current economic climate. Land tax and rates will not increase because of these amendments.

The amendments to the definition of ‘unimproved value’ do not change the valuations that have been issued to every landowner in Queensland. Valuations will continue to be based on market sales. This legislation will validate all past valuations, with the exception of those currently under appeal. This will provide the certainty that landowners and the property industry are seeking. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr BLEIJIE: Like the member for Chatsworth, I would encourage all those opposite to listen carefully to what I have to say, including honourable ministers.

This bill clarifies the definition of ‘unimproved value’, which relates to the valuing of commercial properties for the purposes of rates and land tax. In a blatant tax grab by the Bligh government, it wants to redefine the rules in order to increase government revenue. It is ludicrous to value a property based on the actual use of the land rather than a system of comparable sales, which was far more equitable. The term ‘unimproved value’ is being redefined to include profit and risk, leases, goodwill and infrastructure charges.

The legal technicality that is intended to be corrected in this bill stems directly from a case in 2009 in which the Land Appeal Court rejected the government’s contention that unimproved value of the improved land for the purposes of levying land tax and rates included the added value of any leases, the goodwill associated with the business conducted on the land and any amount for any development premium or profit and risk associated with its previous development.

The Land Appeal Court determined that the definition of unimproved value of land in relation to improved land required that the land be treated as though it were vacant and unimproved. The benefit of leases, improvements and any development premium or profit associated with the property was all to be disregarded in arriving at the unimproved value of the property.

The definition of ‘unimproved value’ is being changed because this government has dollar signs in its eyes. It comes on the back of breaking two core election promises--(1) that it will not raise taxes and (2) that it will protect jobs. The introduction of this bill breaks those core promises. It increases land tax on mum-and-dad investors and property developers in this state, and the rate will be determined on the intention for the property. That is, the more the mums and dads and investors and developers make from the property, the more tax the government will make. It can be described as a half Robin Hood measure: the government is taking from the seemingly large pockets of developers and mum-and-dad investors and keeping it, all in a desperate attempt to raise government revenue and rescue Queensland’s bottom line. Whether you call it a levy, whether you call it a registration, whether you manipulate the definitions of ‘unimproved value’--call it what you like--it is a tax, and it is a tax that raises the cost of living expenses for Queenslanders which this government does at an alarming rate. I think all bets are off for who is the most unpopular member of this parliament. It is either the honourable minister or the honourable Treasurer. That is because this legislation will significantly increase the amount of overall land tax collected by this state government. This process is not being done transparently, either, by raising the base rate for the tax; rather it is being done by changing a definition that will ultimately increase the amount of tax that will be collected. As the value of properties rise, Queensland businesses and investors will pay more tax.

The state of the budget has caused the government to introduce a raft of measures to recover from 12 years of its mismanagement of the state’s coffers. Quite simply, Labor went bust in a boom. We have seen Queensland motorists slugged with increases in vehicle registration, the privatisation of some of Queensland’s main assets--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bill, if passed will massively increase the cost of doing business in Queensland. I have been contacted, as have other members of this House, by many constituents in relation to this land tax grab. The feedback that I have received has been unanimous. Their sentiments could not be better summed up by this statement by the Chairman of the Property Council of Australia, Mr Wayne Rex--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Commercial property owners are absolutely livid with the government for changing the rules without consultation and on the back of losing the court case.

These are the comments of stakeholders who are furious at the lack of consultation that was undertaken when this legislation was being formulated. In fact, let me talk about consultation on this bill. The Local Government Association of Queensland has made the claim that, unless this bill is passed, $600 million in local government rates, which has been collected over the past three years, will need to be repaid. Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (9.01 pm): I rise to speak on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The legislation we have before us today is yet another example of the mess this government makes in its haste and its arrogance. As others have iterated, in the original act a number of methods of valuing property for the purposes of rates and land tax existed. The most prevalent method for commercial properties was the use of comparable sales. However, in recent times the government has sought to value highly developed properties with reference to the use and businesses occurring on the land. The court decision the minister was seeking to correct came in the Pacific Fair case of last year. In that decision the court rejected the state’s assertion that the unimproved value of improved land, for the purpose of levying land tax and rates, included the added value of any leases, the goodwill associated with the business conducted on the land and an amount for any development premium or profit and risk associated with its previous development.

We have all seen the advertising about this bill from the Property Council of Australia. It is instructive to look at the explanatory notes at page 2, which state, ‘...a concept described as “ intangible improvements ” was enacted in 2003 with the encouragement of the Property Council of Australia’. For many years, in my practice with commercial law, there was always a struggle with valuation. The valuation of the unimproved value of land included the land as it was and excluded fences and buildings, but it also had to take into account any zoning or use to which the land was put. I do not think anyone in this House--if they had that sort of money--would say they did not get a bargain if they had offered $47.49 million for the Pacific Fair shopping centre, because that is what the valuation came to, having been reduced from $180 million. Anyone would reckon that they made a profit.
An honourable member interjected.

Mr HOOLIHAN: That is the rub, because the property owners were going to get that. That was the windfall. I hesitate to say it, but I will say it: I believe that the Property Council promised them that they would get all of this money back and that is why they took on the argument and tried to scare the people of Queensland. A number of people in my electorate have rural properties and they have been caught up in the fear campaign. This is what I would like to refer to in this debate. The minister will cover a lot of these areas in his summing-up. I refer to the impact of the amendments on land use for rural purposes by our farmers and graziers, the mums and dads. I have spoken to a couple of people who own big properties. Some of those are leasehold properties. This does not apply to leasehold properties. Rural landowners have nothing to fear from the proposed changes to the Valuation of Land Act. Rural properties have been value based on the unimproved value of the land since the inception of the Valuation of Land Act in 1944. This has not changed and will not change.

Traditionally, rural farming properties are valued using sales of other comparable rural properties taking place through normal market transactions. In analysing rural sales, State Valuation Services of the Department of Environment and Resource Management will continue to use the established practice of deducting the added value of physical improvements, such as houses, sheds, fencing, water facilities and timber treatment, from the sale price to arrive at an unimproved value. An allowance is also made for development interest. The new legislation will not affect this traditional approach to rural valuations.

Departmental valuers are very experienced in making these assessments and determining which sales are genuine and are truly reflective of the market. As Queensland has a large farming base--which I had believed the LNP claimed as its backers--properties are always selling, providing a good range of sales evidence, and the values are going up. The property market for rural properties is driven by supply and demand and often related to the seasonal conditions applying at that time. For example, it is difficult to sell grazing properties in dry times--I am not sure there would be too much trouble now--but after rain the volume of sales generally picks up. If there are no comparable rural sales in a locality, there are usually sales in another area that may be used to form a basis for valuation. Departmental valuers will continue to follow the market and apply market movement, including increases and decreases as they occur.

There is a myth going around that rural valuations will rise as a result of the new legislation. Mr Acting Speaker, I can assure you that this is not the case. Rural valuations will continue to reflect fluctuations in the property market only, as they always have. The valuations are generally issued by State Valuation Services to landowners before the end of March each year and are used by the local government to calculate rates in the financial year commencing on the next 30 June in the year the valuation is issued. That is the basis for requiring this legislation to be considered now. The councils--which I would hesitate to say did not really have much time for the Labor government at one stage--are realising that they are being looked after and they require those valuations.

The valuations determined under the Valuation of Land Act are only one of the considerations used by the relevant local government to calculate the rates which are levied for each property. Local governments have wide powers to moderate any substantial increase in the issued values which may be indicated by the real estate market. They may, for example, average the last two or three valuations issued for a property or adopt a cap above which a rate may not be increased. A minimum rate may also be applied. If a landowner is unhappy with the amount of the valuation issued, they may lodge an objection within 45 days of the date of issue of the valuation. A new, more robust and transparent objection process is also being proposed in this bill which will enable landowners to provide additional information upfront if they think their valuation is incorrect. In all the arguments about how much people have paid in land tax, every one of those people had a right, if they felt that their valuation was incorrect, to object to that valuation. It has always been open to them, but they have not done so. They have paid their land tax and that valuation is presently the basis for their argument.

The new objection form will require a landowner to provide details about their property. Information such as the lot and plan number, the valuation they think should apply, the reason or grounds that they are basing their objection on and any information to support those grounds will be required to inform the objection. Another change to be introduced is that, if an agent submits an objection on behalf of a landowner, the objection form must be accompanied by the landowner’s written consent. This will ensure that all objections are made with the full knowledge and authority of the landowner. State Valuation Services is producing a landowner’s guide to objections, with links to information and call centre advice, to assist all landowners in preparing objections. The proposed amendments in the bill are necessary to confirm and ensure that rural property will continue to be valued based on the existing valuation methodology and that there will be no impact on these properties.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (9.35 pm): I rise to support the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, introduced into this House earlier this year by the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade, the Hon. Stephen Robertson. The bill amends the Valuation of Land Act 1994 and the Water Act 2000. But I want to talk about the process used by State Valuation Services in the Department of Environment and Resource Management in determining the unimproved value of land when undertaking a statutory valuation.

Statutory valuations in Queensland are made on an unimproved basis under the Valuation of Land Act 1944. The previous speaker, the member for Keppel, defined valuation very well. I am sure that he has probably read the textbook which is recognised as the authority by the valuation profession--by Rost and Collins--which defines this in part by saying that when assessing the value of a parcel of land ‘it must be assumed that the land is notionally in its natural state but that it possesses whatever advantages that exist as a result of extrinsic circumstances, such as roads, railways, public services, amenities, land settlement in the neighbourhood and any other benefits which are not due to the operations on the land itself by past or its present occupiers’.

Therefore, in its simplest form, what a valuer has to consider is: here is a vacant piece of land--what would it sell for? In the case of residential properties, the highest and best use of this land is residential, so that is the basis for the valuation. It does not include the value of the house that is built on the property. When determining the valuation, the valuer will use comparable sales of vacant or slightly improved land to determine the current valuation. This can be done because there is an abundance of sales data for the valuer to use in the assessment. This is the case for most property types. However, this simplistic approach can be complicated when there are few sales of vacant land and there is a possibility that purchasers are prepared to pay an absolute premium above market price to obtain a scarce commodity.

In the case of complex properties such as shopping centres, there is very limited sales data available to the valuer to determine the value of the property this way. In these circumstances the legislation provides for an alternative method to determine the unimproved value of the land. Using shopping centres as the example, the land has been developed to its highest and best use as a shopping centre site, and the associated development approvals and leases, because its highest and best use has already been achieved, are not deducted from the value of that land. The only costs deducted are physical improvements, such as the cost for building the shopping centre, car parks and other site works.

In December 2009, the Court of Appeal affirmed a decision of the Land Appeal Court relating to the Pacific Fair shopping centre. The Land Appeal Court in 2007 determined that the definition of ‘unimproved value of land’ in relation to improved land required that the land be treated as though it were vacant and unimproved. Any development premium or profit and risk associated with its previous development was to be excluded from the unimproved value of the improved land. In the Pacific Fair decision, the Land Appeal Court also concluded that the benefit of leases of improvements entered into was to be disregarded in arriving at the unimproved value. The Pacific Fair decision of the Land Appeal Court found that any approvals which had been granted for the development of the shopping centre had to be assumed not to have been obtained and that the valuation had to be made against the assumption that there was a risk associated with obtaining the already existing approvals. The government appealed this decision, but the Court of Appeal rejected the government’s appeal in December 2009, confirming the 2007 Land Appeal Court decision.

The court’s interpretation of the legislation does not reflect the actual intent of the legislation, which is to value the land as developed at its highest and best use. If not addressed, this interpretation would fundamentally change the way that certain properties, primarily commercial and industrial properties, are valued in Queensland. This bill will confirm the valuation approach adopted to previously issued valuations and provide certainty for the future.

It has been stressed that the amendments do not affect landowners, as they simply reinforce the valuation approach that has always been used by the department. For example, the amendments do not impact on residential properties. Residential properties will continue to be valued in the way that they always have been, as a residential lot based on vacant or lightly improved sales. Similarly, agricultural properties will continue to be valued as they always have been, as a farm using other farm sales.

The amendments seek to strengthen the application of the Valuation of Land Act in valuing commercial properties to overcome the lack of equity between valuations of different types of properties created by the court decision. To ensure certainty for all landowners, the bill will clearly define the term ‘unimproved value’ in the act. The amendments will clarify that the benefit of a lease which enhances the value of the land must be included in its unimproved value. No amount will be deducted from the unimproved value of the land for goodwill, and no deduction for any profit or risk allowance or development premium will be made.

The benefit to the land of the payment of infrastructure charges must be included with the unimproved value. These infrastructure services, such as water and sewerage, are directly relevant to what the land would sell for, and hence its value. The bill, in amending the definition of ‘unimproved value’, confirms the approach used by departmental values in arriving at the statutory values of property in Queensland. I commend the bill to the House.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 3. Historically, has the added value of entrepreneurial profit or developer’s profit been included in the unimproved value?
XML.Hansard-Body: These are all issues that are dealt with by the legislation. These are issues that I doubt the best Treasurer in the world, in his own mind anyway, has actually thought about. He is probably too busy in front of the mirror practising his lines. Another constituent says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Ministers,

I moved to QLD from NSW when I was 3 in 1985. I love the QLD Reds with all my heart and have stuck by them in the last couple of years through thick and thin. I am a passionate Maroons supporter against the rest of my family who were born in NSW as well. In short I love QLD and what we stand for. Until now.
It absolutely pains me to say this but I am ashamed to be a Queenslander.
The proposals that the Bligh government is enforcing has lead me to be disenchanted with the way this State is being run.

I work in the Commercial Property industry and liaise regularly with National clients. We are the laughing stock of the country and these amendments will have an unmeasurable effect on real estate investment in this State and therefore my industry colleagues future employment. It astounds me that people (not just the Government) haven’t thought about the long term implications should these amendments go through.
You should vote against this bill and do what is right.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Another piece of correspondence says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am writing in relation to the amendments to the above Act to be argued before parliament. I have been a practising valuer in Queensland for over 20 years and never in that time have I seen a proposed amendment which would have a greater impact on the property market in this State.

This change will have a far greater negative effect on the market in Qld than the Vendor Tax had on the NSW market, which was introduced and then repealed in recent years due to the damage it caused. We have already witnessed buyers walking away from investment in Qld because of the legislation and that will cost the State hundreds of millions in stamp duty alone.

The proposed changes are a fundamental shift in valuation practice. I am aware that a small number of the department’s valuers have advised the Director General that it is not a change, however 90% of the department’s valuers and 100% of the valuers in private practice have been valuing Unimproved Values the same way and this legislation is a fundamental change.
I implore you to contact any number of the professional associations who have been trying to get these proposed amendments altered to establish the reality and flow on effect these changes will make.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Another constituents says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear All,

I write to you today to advise that every potential buyer of property in the Brisbane CBD from the southern states has now decided it is safer to invest in NSW & Victoria due to the crazy / lunatic antics of the current State Government in relation to changing the way the state values land. This is not just a local issue. How dare the elected government overturn decisions by no less than 4 Judges.
I am dumbfounded that this can happen in an educated society. We are supposed to be the Smart State--we are on a boat with no rudder.

The practicality of the legislation the way I see it is that we are going to have to start preparing our objections 6 months before the assessment notices issue otherwise the 42 days we are given to prepare the objections to the level proposed is a physical impossibility. So we are going to be preparing objections against something that hasn’t even happened.

There is no better example than industrial land. 4 years ago we all used to use $10 per meter as an estimate of outgoings. That figure is now closer to $30 and most of it is rates and land tax. To make matters worse deals are being done around $100 per meter gross meaning that 30% of rent goes out in outgoings. Therefore if the net yield on industrial is $70 per meter and the cap rate is 9 to 10% industrial is now worth $700 to $800 per meter of building area. What is the unimproved land value????? (Negative when I went to school) but the State will tell you it’s $500 per meter.

The point is we are all going to loose the question is who and how much. Theoretically industrial land will become worthless because there is no point in developing it. There will be no cut for the owner and the tenant can’t afford to rent it.
Total madness ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Another person said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Minister,
I am contacting you with my serious concerns about the introduction of the Valuation of Land Act and Other Amendments Bill 2010 due for debate on Tuesday.

My background is a Property Analyst and a Registered Valuer with retail and commercial valuation experience. I have read the proposed Bill and am alarmed at the implications this may have. I have estimated that these amendments will cause a circa 20% decline in value to a typical commercial office building with greater losses likely for retail properties. This has a direct impact on superannuation funds of mum and dad investors and other shareholders. I am more than willing to discuss with you my calculations if requested. Furthermore, this is likely to cause many owners to breach finance covenants and cause a significant increase in loan default, receivership appointment and job losses.

Valuation of income producing properties is quite technical and requires a high degree of skill. It would appear to me that this Bill has been drafted by parties which do not hold the required experience as the proposals are not only extremely detrimental to the values of income producing properties ... but illogical and unworkable from a practical sense. Contrary to the Government’s claims, these proposed changes represent a fundamental shift away from how valuations have been done in the past. What is even more concerning is the Queensland Government’s denial and rejection of the criticism it has received from most leading industry bodies regarding the issue.
XML.Hansard-Body: How would the people who have written in good faith feel if they were to look across the chamber, as I do, and see the dull, arrogant expressions of those opposite who are responsible for this madness? Those people would then get a little bit of a sense of what we are feeling now. The arrogance of members opposite is unbelievable. The dull, arrogant way they cross their arms, with their absolute contempt for the people of Queensland, is absolutely outstanding.

In closing, it is worth reminding this place of one of the leaders of the nascent Western world who was forced to give up absolute control of his country and was eventually forced to call the first parliament in 1264, Henry III. He was perceived by his constituents the barons as an inept king who taxed them to the hilt, ignored their counsel and wasted resources on unsuccessful campaigns. We are seeing history repeat itself once again here. Allowing such a dangerous and unfair bill to be presented to this place is just further proof that we have an inept Premier who has taxed the state to the hilt, ignored their counsel and wasted resources on unsuccessful campaigns but who will very soon pay the political price at the hands of those opposite, who may vote for this bill now but will vote against the Premier when it comes to the coming leadership spill in the Labor Party. My one piece of advice to the minister when he flies away is this: while the Left is away, the Right will play.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (10.00 pm): I rise to speak on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 which was introduced into this House on 11 February 2010. I firmly believe that business and personal investment in Queensland should be attracted by tax structures that enhance competitive positions. I think that the system should be simple to comprehend, equitable and provide incentives for long-term growth. But this bill as it stands before the House seeks to do none of that. In my opinion and in the opinion of many in the Aspley electorate, this legislation as it currently stands is purely and simply an attempt by Labor to gouge every cent it can from Queensland taxpayers to prop up its failing budget and pay for the massive $85 billion of Labor debt. Shamefully we are in a budgetary situation of debt and deficit, and now Queenslanders’ jobs and mum-and-dad investors’ financial security will be put at risk by the Bligh Labor government’s proposed changes to land valuation laws.

These laws are an unprecedented attack on Queenslanders’ jobs and investments, and industry groups estimate that if this bill is passed it will see increases in land tax of between 20 per cent and 40 per cent across-the-board. The Australian Bureau of Statistics data for January shows that Queensland had the equal highest unemployment rate in Australia with 137,500 people looking for work, and this sneaky new tax slug on business on top of the fuel tax and electricity and car registration hikes will put more Queenslanders on the unemployment line. While also slashing jobs, Labor’s tax increases will see massive cuts to the value of investments that Queenslanders have put aside to provide financial security for their future, the prime concern that the residents who are visiting and contacting my office have with this legislation currently before the House.

According to the explanatory notes, the objectives of the bill are to amend the Valuation of Land Act 1944 to, amongst other things, clarify the definition of unimproved value and the associated terminology; provide for a more focused process of objection designed to resolve disputes more efficiently at the objection stage; and to allow for the use of a schedule of valuations--the general valuation schedule--and an adjustment factor in the statutory valuation process. I want to focus on the first objective of the bill as it will have the most tangible consequences for anyone who owns property in Queensland.

In assessing the unimproved value of land for the purpose of levying land tax and rates, the Valuation of Land Act 1944 has long required that a valuer treat any improvements as if they did not exist. However, this government had sought to challenge the scope of the definition of ‘unimproved value’, especially with regard to highly improved commercial properties and, in doing so, has been struck down twice in the courts. In part, this was the motivation for the government to bring this rushed legislation before the House.

In the most recent case of the Pacific Fair centre, the Land Appeal Court stated that the government’s position on valuation amounted to a radical change to the state’s rating and land tax system, and so the government has retrospectively decided to change the law. Put simply, the proposed legislation places a tax on entrepreneurial effort. If we are going to include development approvals, leasing arrangements, tenancy arrangements, development profit and goodwill in the definition of unimproved value, we will simply be punishing business owners with a sneaky new way of taxing effort and enterprise. As a small business owner I understand the frustration of hardworking local businesspeople and investors who feel that this legislation is just another way to slug them in difficult economic times.

Members will be aware that the Aspley area of Brisbane’s north has been a commercial hub for decades. Long before the larger shopping centres of Chermside and Toombul existed, strip shopping on a large scale existed along Gympie Road in my electorate. This business corridor continues to operate, but its ongoing success and the jobs it provides to locals are placed in jeopardy by the legislation before the House. A quick search on the Sensis business counts data tells me that there are 1,366 business listings in the suburbs of Aspley, Carseldine, Bridgeman Downs and Bald Hills--suburbs that make up the bulk of my electorate of Aspley. That is thousands of business managers and owners who will have to find the extra money for increased rent and wages that will be the flow-on effect of these legislative changes. As one constituent in an email to me points out--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This legislation will burden my commercial properties. My properties cater for small businesses, which are the very backbone of the Queensland Economy. The increased costs will either be met by them or met by me. The tax will only cripple our economy when we need help for small business.
XML.Hansard-Body: But this current legislation is not merely about commercial property. I have seen in recent advertising that the government purports that there will be no changes to the way family homes, investment properties or farms will be valued, but nowhere in this current legislation does it make reference to big business, shopping centres or large commercial or industrial enterprises being the only categories of property affected. This is the most frightening aspect of the legislation because the principles contained in the bill can be easily applied to units, small businesses and residential property, and that is what the residents of my area are telling me they are most concerned about. They fear that as a landlord they will have to increase rents for their tenants to cover the costs of increased land tax. They fear that housing affordability will yet again be hit as the cost for homebuyers will rise to reflect the increase in land tax, particularly in greenfield sites, placing first home buyers at risk. Perhaps the biggest fear from the residents of Aspley is the concern for their superannuation investments for their retirement. The fact is many mums and dads, both directly and through superannuation funds, have interests in property. Under the bill before us, these mum-and-dad investors will have their investments slashed, and that is simply unfair.

I want to touch on an aspect of the legislation which I do feel is incredibly unjust--namely, the retrospective nature of the bill which I note from the explanatory notes means that the bill infringes on some fundamental legal principles. The Bar Association of Queensland has seen fit to write to the Premier to remind her of this principle and that citizens are entitled to organise their affairs, domestic and commercial, on the statute law as enacted from time to time. I find it abhorrent that existing outstanding appeals will now be assessed under new rules which differ from the rules that have governed objections and appeals in the past. Talk about changing the goalposts midplay!

Whilst talking about objections, I want to briefly turn to the new processes for making an objection to a valuation under the current bill. The minister said in his second reading speech that the reforms being introduced will update and modernise the objection process and will provide all landowners with a clear process to lodge an objection and will encourage the inclusion of the appropriate information at the beginning of the objection process. These amendments place an enormous burden on owners and, in my opinion, may be likely to be unworkable given that an owner has only 45 days to prepare and lodge any objection. As the Property Council says in its submission to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The proposed objection process in the Bill is burdensome, overly proscriptive, and unfairly constricts landowner’s appeal rights in a manner inconsistent with the principles of natural justice.
XML.Hansard-Body: I could not agree more. This morning the Premier announced that the government would be introducing major amendments to this bill which are in essence a face-saving attempt and an admission that the bill before the House is fundamentally flawed. Whilst the LNP will carefully consider the amendments, I cannot support the bill before the House as it stands--a cobbled-together, cash-grabbing piece of legislation about which the LNP and residents in Aspley have raised very real and grave concerns.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (10.08 pm): In speaking to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, to retain the present bill before any amendments are moved would be a catastrophe, and this is highlighted by the numerous concerns by businesses and citizens that will be affected by this bill. If the government had set about designing a course of action to inhibit development, hinder investment, destroy property values and increase the cost of living and entrepreneurial activities in Queensland, this would be the ultimate option.
Many investors acknowledge that there would be a disaster if this bill were passed without significant changes being made to it. On 7 March, Steve Greenwood wrote in the Courier-Mail --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Unless we can stop it, sometime soon (maybe this week) new laws will be passed in Queensland which are breathtaking in their scope and audacity.
They will massively increase the cost of living and doing business in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the 2004-05 period, land tax was $380 million. This year, land tax will escalate to $1 billion, making it one of the largest taxes in Queensland. The likelihood of astronomical increases in land tax, prepared in secrecy, has caused a tsunami of anxiety throughout the business sector. Constituents who have contacted me have expressed alarm over what will be a potential catastrophe because of this legislation’s unexpectedness, absurdity and injustice.

Far from delivering the loudly proclaimed 100,000 jobs for Queenslanders, this legislation will cost jobs as small businesses are hit yet again with another tax, resulting in some closing up shop. Increased rentals will reflect higher land tax on properties, future homebuyers will have to meet the flow-on cost of land tax imposed on developers and superannuation funds that include some form of land investments will see the financial security of retirement diminish or even disappear.

Over the past six years the government has lost several court cases and appeals. The courts found consistently that the government was not valuing land in accordance with its own legislation. The government’s remedy for an outrageous lack of legal acumen is to change the law retrospectively, making the radical changes to land tax legal. The definition of ‘unimproved value’ will be changed to include infrastructure charges, buildings, leases in place and business goodwill--items not previously included in the concept of ‘unimproved value’. Definition changes and retrospective legislation are the government’s solution to getting out of the hole that it has dug for itself.

Incentives for landowners to improve and value-add to their property will disappear as producers attempt to reduce the items to be calculated in the new unimproved value criteria. The process of appeal will also be made more difficult, reducing the eligibility criteria for the appeal and adding a complexity of detail required, ensuring that the government gets its way at the expense of others. These changes are alarming at best and blatantly dishonest at worst. It is very difficult to escape the conclusion that the government is in a desperate frenzy to grab every dollar.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (10.12 pm): I rise to speak to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. Every now and again legislation will come before this House that creates a great reaction in the community that it will affect, and this is one of those. I assume that each of us here has received quite a number of letters in relation to this valuation of land amendment bill. I do not think I have received one letter that has been in favour of the legislation. Each letter has expressed concerns and I believe all--if not all then the vast majority--have already been referred to. In recognition of the time, I will not reiterate the contents of those letters. Suffice it to say, the letters, whether they were from the Property Council, the valuers, residents or Chesterton--irrespective of whether the letter was from an individual or a company--expressed grave concerns about the impact of the proposed legislation on their business, whether they were big business, a medium sized business or a small business.

In a general sense it is vitally important for landowners, irrespective of the type of property they own, to be able to object to a valuation. I have said this to the valuers in my region, so I am not saying anything out of school. When the valuations are produced and released to local government, they are put on the public record for landowners to check their valuation and to decide whether the new unimproved capital value is something that they can accept or whether they believe that it is higher than is necessary. Overwhelmingly, my experience--and I have stated this to the valuers--in objecting to a valuation has been that you need a valium and a good lie down before having a conversation with valuers, because you are on a flogging to nothing to win anything.

It used to be that the unimproved capital value was assessed on the value of the land--its attributes. Then the valuation became a more sales based valuation, again based on unimproved capital value. If there were sales around the area then they were used to determine an increase or decrease in the unimproved capital value. As time went by, when there were no local sales valuers then imported sales. A lot of landowners used the argument that there were no local land sales. No properties had changed hands in years. Previously that was a reasonable argument, but then valuers started to import land sales and there was no way landowners could adequately prove their case.

I know that we are debating the legislation, and I acknowledge that the minister has significant amendments to be brought forward, but the fact is that, irrespective of what legislation is in place, landowners must be able to object or appeal to the valuation and that objection or appeal process must be accessible to whoever the landowner is. The objection process must not be complicated; it must be straightforward and it must be based on information that owner can easily provide so that landowners are not put in a position where their appeal can be dismissed by the department out of hand without a fair and transparent consideration.

I am not surprised that local government, through the LGAQ, has supported the legislation. My understanding is that that support is solely on the basis that local government was concerned that, on the basis of the court case on the Gold Coast, it could be faced with significant cost in terms of refunding dollars. However, I do not believe that local government would support generally, as members of the community, a new valuation act that disadvantaged landowners or, indeed, that based valuations on improved capital value that includes goodwill, which I find to be a most ethereal matter to be assessed by a valuer.

I am a little bit jaundiced by valuers--but not all of them. I have raised in this chamber before the instance where a valuer was acting for the government in my electorate valuing land for the purpose of government acquisition. I believe that the valuers were there to value what was on the property. They actually devalued a shed because they said that, in their estimation, the shed was too big for the property’s needs. That was completely out of order and completely unacceptable. My concern about introducing into the valuation process fewer objective matters to be considered is that landowners are going to be very much subject to an assessment by the valuer that is not based on objective fact.

The other matter that I would seek clarification on is that previously, in objecting to valuations, the landowner has been able to request a conference. It appears that, in this legislation, the meeting is going to be initiated only by the departmental people. If that is the case, I certainly would have to express grave concerns. Some people do not write well. Some people best articulate their view verbally. Those people who cannot put their thoughts on paper need to be able to request a face-to-face conference or a meeting so that they can put to the departmental officers the reasons for their concern about the valuation. Currently the request has to be in writing, but it can be just a letter requesting a meeting. I would certainly request a clarification on that point.

Based on all of the concerns that have been expressed to me--the disadvantage that the bill would establish, again on the basis of the information provided to me--means that I cannot support the bill as it stands. However, as already acknowledged, there are significant amendments foreshadowed. I will be listening to the consideration in detail and then I will determine my stance. The legislation must not disadvantage people in Queensland, particularly those who can ill afford to pay more in rates and charges. On that basis I will not be supporting the legislation, but I look forward to the consideration in detail.

Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP)
(10.20 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I must say firstly that I am embarrassed by the contributions of opposition members to this debate. Hansard will show that they have remained true to form. Through their partisan fearmongering contributions they continue to trash Queensland, they continue to scare businesses and communities and they continue to knock our state’s reputation. In respect of this debate Hansard will show that their contributions clearly misstate the real intent and effect of the amending bill.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr RYAN: I take the interjections as further proof of the opposition’s hatred for Queensland. They hate Queensland. They continually interject. They continually trash our state’s reputation. The amending bill is about preserving the status quo and providing certainty for landowners, governments and community members. It will come as no surprise to the House that the provision of public services and public infrastructure are funded through a budget process from public funds. The way in which those public funds are collected must be transparent, fair and accountable and must reflect taxation burden priorities.

It is important for taxation burden priorities to be clear and steps taken to preserve those priorities. There is only one bucket of money and the way that we fill that bucket of money depends on the relative priorities of government. This bill is about preserving those priorities. This bill is about preserving the status quo. This bill is about protecting the property owners, particularly residential property owners, from a change to the relative taxation burden priorities flowing from a recent case decided by the Queensland Court of Appeal. If the government did not act then the government would not be protecting Queenslanders from the potential for hundreds of millions of dollars in land tax and rate repayments which have emerged after a recent court decision. Make no mistake, to support the status quo, to protect property owners, particularly residential property owners and to provide certainty to government and the community for the future, members of this House must support this bill.

In speaking in support of this bill I would like to reassure property owners in the Morayfield state electorate and around Queensland that this bill will not affect their rates or land tax payable by them. The budget bucket is not getting larger as a consequence of this bill. This bill merely preserves the respective proportions contributed by different sectors of the Queensland community to the government budget.

In reassuring residential property owners in the Morayfield state electorate I would like to address the impact of the amendments on land used for residential purposes by the majority of Queenslanders. Valuations are made under the Valuation of Land Act 1944 and are one of the considerations used by relevant local governments to calculate the rate which is levied for each property. Local governments have wide powers to moderate any substantial increase in the issued values which may be indicated by the real estate market. They may, for example, average the last two or three valuations issued for a property or adopt a cap above which a rate may not be increased. A minimum rate may also be applied.

The valuations are generally issued by the Department of Environment and Resource Management to landowners before the end of March each year and are used by the local government to calculate rates in the financial year commencing on the next 30 June in the year the valuation is issued. The valuations reflect the price which an owner who is well acquainted with the real estate market would be expected to pay for the land as a vacant site but with the surrounding infrastructure in place. This figure would reflect the physical nature of the block before the current or former owners carried out any improvements on the land, such as a filling or levelling, and ignores the value of any structures erected on the land such as a house or shed. It does, however, reflect the services and advantages which would influence a purchaser in deciding which property they consider best meets their needs and budget. This could include existence or absence of road access to the property or the availability of services such as electricity, reticulated water, sewerage and access to rail and bus services. It could also include proximity to schools and shopping centres. This method has been adopted for residential lands in the past and will continue to be used. This is because the amendments have no effect and no impact on this historic valuation approach and residential values will continue to be based on sales of vacant or near vacant lands. There is generally no shortage of such sales to be used as a basis for valuing land. If there are no sales in one area there are usually sales in another area that may be used to form a basis of valuation for residential properties. Departmental valuers are very experienced in making these assessments.

A landowner who is unhappy with the amount of the valuation may lodge an objection within 45 days of the date of issue of the valuation. A new, more robust and transparent objection process is also being proposed in this bill which will enable a landowner to provide information upfront if they think their valuation is incorrect. The new objection form will require a landowner to provide details about their property. Information such as the lot on plan number, the valuation they think should apply, the reasons or grounds on which they are basing their objection and any other information to support these grounds will be required to inform the objection. The department will assist landowners to make a properly made objection where required.

There are claims circulating that all landowners in Queensland will be adversely impacted by the legislative changes. This is not the case. The government has made it quite clear that residential property owners, and to that end occupants of residential properties, will not be disadvantaged by this bill. As the minister said in his second reading speech, without intervention the commercial property owners would receive a massive discount in their rates at the expense of residential property owners. Without action by this Labor state government residential property owners would be put in a position of effectively subsidising the current relevant contributions made by major commercial property owners to the Queensland state budget. This is an unacceptable situation and I am proud that this Labor state government is acting to protect and give certainty to Queensland property owners. I commend the minister, his staff and the department on their hard work in respect of this bill and I also commend the bill to the House.

Mr SORENSEN (Hervey Bay--LNP)
(10.27 pm): I rise in the House today to speak against this badly drafted, draconian piece of legislation called the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. This is one of the most damning pieces of legislation that this Labor government has presented to the House that I can recall. Now we are told that there will be about 60 amendments.
Mr Robertson: All the years you have been here!

Mr SORENSEN: Yes, I know. This is just a money grab. When one looks at what will be used to decide the new valuation, it includes such things as goodwill. At the end of the day, goodwill depends on the businessperson who makes the business grow. Looking at the valuation of rent and development approvals, at the end of the day what are they worth if they cannot be sold onwards? Then there are the infrastructure charges. Some of the developers in my area are paying over $400,000 a year in land tax. The profit of potential development is one that really gets me.

If the government wants to know why people are worried about this legislation, I will give examples of what has happened to three small moteliers in Hervey Bay to show why. In 2007-08 the first motelier paid $4,044 in land tax. Three years later in 2009-10 they paid $12,300. That is a 304 per cent increase over three years. The second motelier in 2006-07 paid $6,124 in land tax and in 2009-10 they paid $21,000. This is an increase of 343 per cent over four years. Another owner of a small unit development in 2006-07 paid $2,487 in land tax and in 2009-10 they paid $10,630. That is an increase of 427 per cent in four years. People are worried about this legislation because there have been increases like this on small businesses that only have six or 10 units. They are worried about having around about a 100 per cent increase in land tax every year. It is a real problem. These people cannot pass this cost on to consumers in the economic climate that we have today. The government should think about that. These are only small businessmen. It might be all right for the government to go out there and try to catch the big fish, but it is going to kill a lot of little fellows along the way.

My short congress here has to show that this government has a record of not listening to its people or even its own members. This legislation does not consider many sides of this argument. I have seen many emails and letters from valuers, property institutions, small business owners and investors, large investors and institutions. Just about everyone I speak to about this bill pleads and says, ‘Do something about it.’ ‘This will cripple us,’ some of the smaller businesses say.

I refer to including goodwill, potential profit et cetera in a valuation using the same rate in the dollar for land tax. Small businesses, like the independent IGA supermarket, are already suffering from the huge increases. In the past few years they have faced even more and this will be added to the price of food. These small businesses are the backbone of Queensland. They employ hundreds and hundreds of people. Of course, even in the larger supermarkets and shopping centres that may be affected, once again the prices will go up and we will lose a lot of small businesses in some of those shopping centres. If the shopping centre loses those small businesses, will their valuation come down because the rents they are getting have dropped?

The badly indebted government cannot keep flogging the businesspeople of this state. It is hopeless that we are going down this track. In the last three to four years land tax has doubled. Today it has raised over $1 billion in taxes. That has to come from somewhere, and at the end of the day it usually comes out of the pockets of people who employ other people.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (10.32 pm): Today in the parliament we saw the collapse of the government’s ill-considered solar hot water rebate scheme and tonight we are going to witness the collapse of one of the most ill-prepared and ill-considered bills ever brought into this parliament. It is a bill that will collapse under the weight of 53 amendments. This government, with all the resources it has at its fingertips, has brought into this parliament something that is so flawed, that is so damaging to Queenslanders of all dimensions, that it has to have 53 amendments.

This just demonstrates the ignorance of this government. To bring in a bill that is so important to business, to development, to superannuants, to the grazing industry, to Queensland industry and to jobs in particular and to tack onto the end of it something that has nothing to do with all of this--to tack on issues to do with water management and land use plans--just demonstrates how incompetent this government is.

With the collapse of this ridiculous bill--an ill-considered bill--we see tonight another reason for Queenslanders to vote against a government that has been deceitful and dishonest and has been incompetent to the point where Queenslanders are drowning under $85 billion worth of debt. Not only that, they are also going to be drowning under the continual multibillion dollar deficits that are forecast for this state.

Queenslanders pay out of their own pockets for the incompetence and the financial mismanagement of their government. Queenslanders are paying now. Not only will they pay the extra cost that will emanate out of this particular bill; they are already paying and they cannot manage anymore. They cannot pay anymore for petrol with the 10c that has been added by the new petrol tax and the GST on top of that. They cannot pay anymore the 50 per cent increase over the past three years or so in electricity. They cannot pay anymore for the hundreds of per cent increase that some of them, particularly my constituents, have faced in the cost of gas and the cost of water in the case of the government withdrawing the normal state government subsidies being provided to local councils throughout Queensland. In the case of Toowoomba, some $6 billion is to be taken out. We are seeing massive increases in the price of water because these government grants are being taken out and councils have to find other ways to pay the interest on the infrastructure they have to borrow the funds for.

We are seeing a massive increase in rego costs for cars. We have gone from the cheapest in Australia to the dearest in Australia. On top of all of this, now we are going to have under this particular bill the proposed changes to the valuation system which will affect land tax in particular and will have indirect effects on the cost of shopping leases and on self-funded superannuation schemes where they have particular property. It will affect the prices that those shops or businesses have to charge to try to recoup some of this extra cost.

All of this is loaded on top of the petrol tax, on top of the sale of assets, on top of the loss of income from the sale of the airports that were sold a year or so ago and all the other assets that are about to be sold, on top of the rego, the gas, the electricity and the water costs. Ordinary average Queenslanders cannot pay anymore and here we see another money grab to try to cope with the $85 billion of debt and the $10 million to $14 million a day, seven days a week, that has to be found just to service the interest, let alone try to repay some of that debt so that future generations will not be saddled with tons and tons of debt that forever will saddle generation after generation in Queensland.

People have to pay. It is not the government’s debt; it is the people’s debt, but the people’s debt has been put in place by an incompetent government led by an incompetent Premier who was also the infrastructure minister and the Treasurer when much of this debt was accumulated. Now we have an incompetent Treasurer who continues to grow and grow the debt and continues to plunder the pockets of people. The ones who are really hurt are the low-income people--the people on pensions, the people on low incomes, the people on modest incomes. They cannot afford this anymore.

This bill will add to the burden on people. Not only that, this burden will result in a great loss of confidence in Queensland for a number of reasons. Investment, whether carried out singly or in groups through a superannuation fund or some form of trust that invests in development, is the lifeblood of the state so that there is work for builders, contractors and subcontractors. There are then opportunities for small businesses to operate. There are then shopping centres or little commercial areas where there might be mechanics, panelbeaters and so on. All of those are there to service the people of the state. All of those are going to have increased costs charged to them. All will be passing on the cost to the tenants. All of those tenants will have to pass on the costs to those who purchase their goods and services, and so on it will go.

People have had enough of the deceit. It is well known now in Queensland that people will never forgive the Labor Party for the deceit and dishonesty of the last election and the veil of secrecy that they tried to pull over the debt and pulled over issues like asset sales, the petrol tax and increases in the cost of other very important basic commodities.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Member for Toowoomba South, I have been reasonably patient, but let us get back to the valuation of land bill. Could you please refrain from the repetition?
Mr HORAN: Thank you.
Mr Fraser interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Treasurer, would you please regain your own seat if you wish to make comment.

Mr HORAN: People will not forget that deceit and dishonesty. They see it again in this particular bill. There has been almost negligible consultation with those who should have been consulted on this particular bill. As a result, we see the absolute mess and shambles of a bill that has been brought into this parliament which was to be debated during the last sitting week of parliament and which was withdrawn from the parliament. Now it is back in here and we are debating this bill. This bill will be shredded and will collapse later tonight with some 53 amendments.

On top of that, we will be asked to trust the government that it will stand by its word when it says that by September it will enact some of the changes that have been foreshadowed in the amendments. This has been a most embarrassing backflip by an incompetent government. It is another example that it has been in government for 12 years too long, that it has lost touch with the people and that it no longer cares. The government is swallowing debt at the rate of about $14 million a day in interest and the people are paying it.

Analysis has been undertaken of the mechanics of this bill and there are some fundamental flaws in it. The definition of ’unimproved value’ is fundamentally altered by including profit and risk, including leases, including agreements for lease and other instruments increasing the value of the land, including goodwill and including infrastructure charges. The items I just referred to were not previously included in the concept of unimproved value. The reference to infrastructure charges in the bill is probably incorrect and should be a reference to infrastructure credits. In recent years the courts have determined that those components do not form part of the unimproved value. The amendments proposed in the bill will change the law as determined by court decisions. It is considered the insertion of the above components into the concept of unimproved value will result in significant increases in unimproved values, leading to higher rates and land tax impositions.

In this debate some people have spoken about rates. Whilst the major effect will be upon land tax, there will be a flow-on effect to rates. When unimproved values or the valuations go up, councils do make adjustments. Regardless of that, when valuations go up, even with adjustments, rates still go up. AgForce supported the action against this bill. It is going to affect some of the massive areas of Queensland that are under leasehold arrangements where the annual rent depends upon a percentage of the valuation. The effects of this legislation will spread far and wide across the state.

It should be noted that the inclusion of infrastructure charges in the calculation of unimproved value will effectively see the calculation of land tax on previously levied infrastructure charges. People have come to see me about these issues. They are ordinary, average people who have worked hard all their lives and provided for themselves so they did not have to seek a pension from the federal government or the taxpayers of Australia. After years of hard work they have invested in commercial property and come to Toowoomba to retire. They are extremely concerned about what the changes to the valuation method will mean for the retirement funds that they have set up so that they can live independently and continue to make a contribution to society without being a burden on the taxpayer.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! There is too much audible conversation. Would those members standing around please take their seats. The member for Toowoomba South has the call.

Mr HORAN: I have received similar representations from quite elderly people who, many years ago when they retired, invested in property on the Gold Coast to be enjoyed by themselves and their families. After a lifetime of working and contributing to society, they purchased a unit within a family trust. They are now paying land tax because of the increase in valuations, even though they may only use the units for holidays and rent it out to try to cover some of the costs of rates and so forth. Such people will be caught by increased valuations that will put their properties into higher levels of land tax which, on top of body corporate fees, rates and everything else, could mean that in many cases they will have to sell up and will no longer be able to enjoy their holiday homes after a lifetime of contributing to our nation.

Another concern about the mechanics of this bill involves the introduction of the general valuation schedule and adjustment factor. There is no right of objection against the value following the application of the adjustment factor. The bill proposes to streamline the objection process by significantly increasing the level of detail required in an objection. The bill alters the appeal process. If dissatisfied with a decision of the department on the objection, the objector can appeal to the Land Court. However, the grounds of appeal are limited to the grounds included in the original objection.

The thing that sticks in everybody’s craw is the retrospective application. It is morally wrong to bring in legislation that is retrospective. If the government is dissatisfied with something and thinks there needs to be an improvement, the honest and moral thing to do is to make the change and say, ’From now on, from this day forward, that is what you will pay’, and that will be the process. However, when people have abided by the law and the decisions of the court, when their formal investigations are shown to be the correct application of the law and the courts have then proven they were correct, to change that retrospectively is immoral and dishonest. It is a sign of a desperate government.

It is important to put this bill into the context of what has happened in our state. We have a government in decay. This government is leading Queensland into devastating debt that will affect generations to come. That debt will mean that every single fee, levy, charge and cost will be at the absolute maximum because we have the highest debt of any state in Australia. Our debt is far above that of New South Wales. On top of the extra interest charges that homeowners have to find to meet their mortgage payments and all the other costs that they have to pay, now they will run into the situation that will result, directly and indirectly, from this bill.

What is going to happen to people who are trying to rent when investors in rental properties find that those properties are moving into higher land tax brackets? Somewhere along the line the investors will have to recoup that increase or they will simply stop buying rental properties because there will be no return on such an investment. People who need rental properties will not be able to find any, let alone one with a reasonable rent that they can afford to pay.

This bill mirrors all of the problems that beset the Queensland government. It reflects why the people of Queensland are fed up to the back teeth with the performance of this government. The introduction of this bill has been based upon incompetence, ignorance, deceit and an unwillingness to talk to people. Tonight we see the absolute farce of a major bill of this dimension the subject of 53 amendments because the government was so incompetent that it could not get it right at the start. This is as wrong as the mess it made of the solar hot-water system. The government pranced throughout the electorates, put pensioners on TV to talk about the solar hot-water systems that would cost next to nothing and that were to be introduced, but it could not deliver. We will be voting against this bill because everything about it is anti Queensland. It is a sign of the incompetence of the government to introduce a bill that is so flawed.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Toowoomba South, we have the message from your repetition. Thank you.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (10.48 pm): I rise to speak to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. This is the fifth term that I have served in this House. On quite a few occasions over the years, I have mentioned my incredulity with regard to the poorly formulated bills that come into this House. Some of the bills are so badly done that I can only assume that at the end of every term there must be a prize for the most number of bills that come through the House. Some of them are just not thought out properly.

When I was out there with Joe Public, I honestly used to think that the people who ran this state and the country of Australia were smart. In the 12 years I have been here, I have become convinced that they are not. They cannot even give themselves the time to concentrate on legislation and get it right. This is an abysmal piece of legislation. It is mind-boggling to think that the people who put this forward are running our state. It is embarrassing to stand here and be a part of this process. However, at least I can say what a lot of people cannot, which is that I oppose the nonsense that occurs in here. I am the next-to-last speaker on the list and I have listened to members of the government stand up and say what a wonderful bill this is. We all know that is not true, because if it were a great bill it would not need 53 amendments. For the government to blow its own trumpet in that way and then introduce so many amendments shows what a pack of idiots we in this House really are that we have to debate this legislation.

So this is a great bill! The government is bringing in 53 amendments. The reason it is going to bring in 53 amendments is so that it can get the legislation through the House without too much trouble from organisations. I note in the paper this morning that the minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Queensland Government has strong approval and public support for its proposed valuation amendments from key stakeholders ...
XML.Hansard-Body: Hello--where are those key stakeholders? Not one whom I have contacted and not one who has contacted me has been in support of this bill. In fact, there are so many people who are against it, whether they be big or small business, whether they be representing industry bodies. They were so totally opposed to this bill that I note this afternoon there had to be massive backflips for some of them to come forward and make a statement in the paper so that this bill might be passed. Again, we have a government that rapidly backtracks on its legislation because it is so poorly designed.

All I can see and all that most people outside are seeing is that this government is so intent on selling its assets and so short of cash, yet if it sells its assets it will not have the assets to bring in any money, and everybody knows that you do not sell the cow no matter how bad things get. I can only assume and most people outside are assuming that this land tax grab is to replace the income that those assets would have brought in to some extent. We have had so many increased taxes and so many increased levies and fees over the last 12 years. I do not know where people are going to find the money. I know they are doing it very, very tough now. They are quite frightened for their future because they know that as soon as this Labor government is voted out and the opposition is in government there will be a lot of belt tightening and people will really wear that. So they are going to do it really tough in the next few years through no fault of their own, rather through poor governance.

As I said, the government is going to bring in 53 amendments to make this an acceptable bill in some form or another. But what really surprises me is that the government thought it was acceptable to include goodwill in the unimproved valuation--I know very few businesses now that can ever sell goodwill; it just does not exist any more--to include rental value in the unimproved valuation and to include infrastructure and potential development in the unimproved valuation. It is a warped kind of logic. I must admit that I have difficulty with that sort of thing because to me when you say something is unimproved it is unimproved full stop.

I believe that this government hoped that with its numbers it could push this legislation through. I think it hoped that the people were as stupid as it thinks they are. But they are not.
