People are up in arms over this. People are getting to the point that they are so sick of legislation that hurts them that they are not afraid to speak up any more. People are not that silly. They are happy to have their say nowadays. They are quite vocal about it and I think it is about time. They have been walked over for long enough.

Just like everybody else in this House, I received so many emails that it was difficult to get through them. I know that most of us got a lot but I have an awful lot here that most people probably did not get. I received emails from the Queensland Rural Women’s Network and from CWAs. I received some from many other women’s networks who wanted me to stand and oppose this bill, which I had no intention of supporting. The arguments that some of them put forward and the effects that this bill might have on them, their families and their businesses I had not even thought of. So those who wrote to me should have no worry that I would have supported this bill. I am going to read a couple of the comments that I did receive.

I will read the letter sent to me by the Chamber of Commerce & Industry Queensland. I think most people would have received this, but I believe that it is well worth reading into Hansard . It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: On behalf of the Board and the 25,000 businesses that the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland (CCIQ) represents I write to express our organisation’s concern over the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010.

Every region in Australia is in competition with each other in the area of investment attraction through competitive taxation regimes. Whilst still competitive CCIQ is increasingly of the view that Queensland is unfortunately losing its low tax status.

The passage of this Bill will further lead to our State falling back into the pack. Indeed the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 will be creating a significant competitive disadvantage through the consideration expansion of the land tax base.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I would have thought that was something the government did not want. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In those areas that are within our control, our target must be the best in every aspect ... Indeed, recent trends in terms of Land tax receipts to the State Government are concerning. Land tax receipts since 2000-01 have increased by over $817 million or 355%--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is not exactly what I call in line with CPI--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The trend over the past two years has seen a 72% increase in receipts to the State.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It goes on further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 does little to bring Queensland into alignment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: as has been stated previously--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: with the other States in terms of the calculation of the land tax base. To the contrary it effectively moves us further away from this objective. The Queensland business community is right to expect policy consistency from your Government.
XML.Hansard-Body: That letter was addressed to the Premier. I am assuming everybody got that. With any luck, government members may have possibly read it and listened to some of that. I move on to an email from Ruth Bonnett to Grace Grace. She says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Hello Grace,
It is my will that the Queensland Government not pass this legislation.
This legislation will burden my commercial properties.
My commercial properties cater for small businesses, which are the very backbone of the Queensland economy.
These increased costs will either be met by them, or met by me.
This tax will only cripple our economy when we need to help small business.
This tax also removes incentives to improve or develop my properties.
Please vote against this legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: We know that Grace holds a lot of things close to her heart but we also know that the Labor Party will come first on this issue with her.
Government members interjected.
Mrs PRATT: I can keep going through these and go on and on.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Members, there is too much audible conversation in the chamber.

Mrs PRATT: As long as people keep yelling at me, I will keep going. I will use my full 20 minutes because this is a very important bill. Here is another email that most people should have got. It reads--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I write to express my concern to the proposed changes to the Land Tax regime in Queensland. Our company represents several hundred private investors, many of which are self funded retirees. We own and manage approx. $1.3b of real estate nationally. Recently, (26th February 2010) our first acquisition in Queensland was completed, being a $63,500,000 commercial office property. The stamp duty payable on this acquisition was $3,319,425.

I am in Brisbane again later this week to identify further property acquisitions, however I can confirm that whilst there remains a risk that the method of assessment of Land Values remains uncertain (ie, that the methodology is broadened to enable the value of leases, goodwill and profits to be captured), and/or the proposed legislation can be applied retrospectively, we will not complete any further acquisitions in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: Whether or not the government says this is the reality, perception in life, as we all know, is the reality for many people. It does affect business. If this bill were passed in the way that it is written, it would affect productivity and investment in Queensland. The emails just go on and on. We all received a huge number of emails.

I find it very hard to understand how it is that the government can disregard the general will of the people to a degree. I have understood why certain bills have gone through in the past, but why is the government constantly putting its hands in people’s pockets when there is virtually nothing there?

Retrospectivity is something that amazes me. I have often seen it occur in this House. When governments give themselves money, they often act retrospectively. When they take money, they want to do so retrospectively. When it benefits a government, it is happy to act retrospectively. When it concerns people outside this place, the government is happy to rob them blind. I think it is a very sad state of affairs.

I have to say that I am really pleased with two statements issued this afternoon. One is by the Premier, and the other by the Property Council is titled ‘QLD property owners breathe a sigh of relief’. I will not read it all because hopefully all honourable members have read it. The Property Council states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘Firstly we are pleased that the Government has taken our advice and will not be introducing this legislation retrospectively back to 2002. This will ensure the rights of those appellants with objections/appeals before the courts are protected and settlement negotiations can now continue without prejudice.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It further states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘This means that the Bill that will be passed by the Government today will only impact the 2010 round of valuations. We expect that these valuations will generally be lower, reflecting the impact of the global financial crisis on the property industry.
XML.Hansard-Body: I hope that is true. I hope that the 53 amendments that will be introduced in this House will indeed ensure that is true. The statement issued by the Premier and Minister for the Arts is as follows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Premier has today committed to moving to site valuation, consistent with other jurisdictions and in line with what the property industry and local government have been seeking for some time.
XML.Hansard-Body: So do not come in here and tell me that this bill, with its 53 amendments, was wholly and solely the government’s own idea. If there had not been such a backlash by the community, the government would not have brought in these 53 amendments. If it had thought properly about this bill, it would not have needed to bring in 53 amendments because it would have addressed the bill in an appropriate manner. There is no prize for rushing legislation into a House like this--and to continually rush legislation through. The prize at the end of the day for government members is to lose their seats.

I hope that the government will reflect a lot more on the bills which it introduces into the House in future, because I am totally disillusioned with this government. I understand the people’s disillusion. I would like to think we had a smarter mob in here than that which we have got.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (11.02 pm): I wish to speak briefly to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. Two weeks ago I started to receive a string of emails from pastoralists in my electorate. I will not talk about all the other emails, and particularly not about the ones from New South Wales. I would like to focus my attention first and foremost on the people in the electorate of Mount Isa.

The email to my constituents was in response to an e-newsletter being circulated throughout the state. I want to contain my comments to the impact of this campaign of misinformation and untruths which was circulated. We need to remember that the people to which all of this misinformation was directed have lived through the worst drought in history, have battled for years and have just in the last 12 months come through the worst floods in 30 years. These areas are now receiving exceptional circumstances funding for flood, which is unprecedented. These people have been genuinely doing it tough in my part of the world. They are battlers. I think they have enough to contend with and do not deserve the unscrupulous campaign that was waged--
Ms Struthers: Scaremongering.
Mrs KIERNAN: I take that interjection.
An opposition member: It’s the truth.

Mrs KIERNAN: It is not the truth at all. I have to say that I spent many nights and early mornings talking on the telephone to graziers. The fact is that rural landowners were never going to be, and will not be, affected by changes in respect to these laws.
Ms Struthers: They don’t pay land tax.

Mrs KIERNAN: No, well they wouldn’t. The e-newsletter circulated to rural producers was a campaign of fear being waged that had no foundation in relation to what was actually the case. Rural properties have been valued on the unimproved value of the land since the inception of the Valuation of Land Act in 1944. This has not changed and it will not change. Agricultural land is valued and will continue to be valued on its highest and best use as a farm, with the value of the physical improvements removed.

Valuers use evidence of sales of rural lands in the locality that is comparable to the land being valued. In analysing rural sales, valuers will continue to use the established practice of deducting the value of improvements such as fences, shearing sheds, water facilities and timber treatment to arrive at an unimproved value. There is not, and will not be, any consideration of written-down value of the fixed improvements on the property, as was being circulated.

These amendments will not lead to the extreme claims of an increase in valuation, and rates and rents going up as a result. The only movement rural landowners will see in their valuations will be as a result of normal market movement as evidenced by sales. Even with the amendments to the bill, the fact is that pastoralists and farmers will not be affected. I was summoned to one of my councils to explain to them what was happening with this bill on the very same day that the Local Government Association condemned the misinformation. I have to say that, of the 60 amendments that will be passed this evening, not one is relevant to rural or pastoral land.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (11.06 pm), in reply: In recognising all the contributions that have been made in this quite lengthy debate, I have to say with some exceptions, including one or two members of the opposition, that this has perhaps been the worst informed debate that I have ever had the displeasure of being part of in this place. The continuing parroting in this place of positions taken by industry without any understanding of how valuations operate in this state or how land tax operates in this state and the personal abuse meted out to members of the government on the way through were beyond the pale.

I appreciate the views expressed by the shadow minister. He is someone who does understand how valuations are conducted. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same for too many of the member for Callide’s colleagues, including the Independents. I sat here and listened to a former mayor of a midsized city in this state give the contribution that he did when the LGAQ--a body in which he would have been an active participant--has made it perfectly clear what impact this Court of Appeal decision would have had on the rate base of towns in which he lives. For him to carry on with the nonsense that he did I think reflects very poorly on his understanding of both local governments and how rates are calculated in this state.

I do not intend to speak long. This debate has gone on for too long. The important thing is that, as a result of exhaustive discussions with the Property Council, we have resolved a lot of issues that were in dispute. I will say this on the record: from day one we made it perfectly clear to the Shopping Centre Council and to the Property Council that it was never the intention of this government to use the outcome of the Court of Appeal decision as a revenue grab. That was made clear to them from day one.

The fact that they then went on a campaign and ignored the commitment that we gave from day one and repeated on every occasion that we had contact with them should be reflected upon. What we have endured in the campaign that was waged is people being misled about the impact of what we were trying to achieve. We were simply trying to achieve an outcome that ensured consistency--nothing new, no tax grab, no increase in rates. In fact, if members consider the report that I tabled earlier today they will see in terms of the commercial and industrial sectors, particularly here in the south-east, that valuations have actually gone down.

For members to stand up in this place and talk about some massive increase in land tax as a result of increasing valuations when the evidence that was actually put before them shows that this year’s valuations will actually go down in those sectors just indicates how political the debate has been tonight and how free of facts it has been as well. Most of the members of the opposition and Independents who participated in this debate frankly made fools out of themselves. Time will show exactly that.

The important thing for me--and I have been the minister for natural resources at various times for some years and have been a strong supporter of site value--is to have the announcement today that what we will be moving to by the middle of next year represents the single largest and most significant reform to valuation legislation in this state since 1944. Without wanting to be too antagonistic, when I heard my opposite number get up and say that we have finally agreed with him in moving to site value I asked my staff to search the Hansard record dating back to the day he came into this place for the name ‘Seeney’ and the words ‘site value’ and it returned no outcomes. When one googles ‘Seeney’ and ‘site value’, when one goes to the World Wide Web--that most exhaustive of resources--and looks for ‘Seeney’ and ‘site value’, no matches are returned.

I think it is important to state what the record actually does show and not The World According to Garp . That is, the member for Callide, whilst he may privately have supported site value, has never been bold enough to enunciate that support until it was clear that the Shopping Centre Council and the Property Council actually gave him permission to say so. My record is quite clear in this regard. I have been battling for site value for a number of years. I am very proud about the Premier’s announcement today that that is what we will be moving to in 2011 and this will stop the enrichment of lawyers going through the exhaustive appeal process brought about by a rickety old act that dates back to 1944. I commend the bill to the House.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the bill be read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 46--Attwood, Boyle, Choi, Croft, Darling, Dick, Farmer, Finn, Fraser, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Jarratt, Johnstone, Jones, Kilburn, Lawlor, Male, Moorhead, Mulherin, Nelson-Carr, Nolan, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Reeves, Roberts, Robertson, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Shine, Smith, Spence, Stone, Struthers, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Keech, Kiernan

NOES, 36--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Cunningham, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Flegg, Foley, Gibson, Hopper, Johnson, Knuth, Langbroek, McArdle, McLindon, Malone, Menkens, Messenger, Nicholls, Powell, Pratt, Rickuss, Robinson, Seeney, Simpson, Springborg, Stuckey, Wellington. Tellers: Horan, Sorensen
XML.Hansard-Body: Bill read a second time.
Mr ROBERTSON (11.21 pm): I move to following amendments--
I table the explanatory notes to my amendments.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes to Hon. Robertson’s amendments to the Valuation of Land and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SEENEY: As many members have made the point during their contributions to the second reading debate, the minister has tonight tabled some 52 amendments to this piece of legislation. Many members have made extensive comments about that during the second reading debate. I do not intend to repeat those comments. However, with the minister moving the first batch of amendments it is appropriate to note that I support the comments that were made by so many members on this side of the House and that were treated in such a derogatory manner by the minister when he summed-up the second reading debate.

It is quite extraordinary for a piece of legislation to have 52 amendments, but that reflects the extent to which the government has been forced to back down on this particular piece of legislation. What we have left after the passage of these 52 amendments--the first four of which the minister has moved en bloc--is a piece of legislation that has effectively been gutted, a piece of legislation that will have a sunset clause that will ensure that it will only be current for one valuation cycle, less than 12 months. But I do not intend to labour the point. It is worth putting on record that the comments that were made by so many members on this side of the House are accurate and reflect the lack of competency on behalf of the government. They reflect the situation that we have tried to illustrate since this bill was first introduced into the House. They reflect the truth in our claim that this bill should have been withdrawn, that the government should have gone back to the drawing board and started again. The government has chosen not to do that. In an attempt to save face, it has brought in 52 amendments which effectively gut the bill. But those 52 amendments have meant that it has been able to reach a compromise with the Property Council in the first instance and with other stakeholders that have been represented. It needs to be put on record that that is the effect of the amendments that the minister has moved and has chosen not to speak to.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause 5--

Mr SEENEY (11.24 pm): In addressing clause 5, I would make the point that there are a number of clauses that are consequential to clause 5. Clause 5 is the first of a number of clauses that deals with the definitions that relate to unimproved value and indeed improved value and, as I indicated in my contribution to the second reading debate, seeks to change the way that those essential elements of the valuation system are calculated by including a whole range of intangible improvements that were never considered to be part of the unimproved value of land. Because it has been a long debate and these issues have been well canvassed and because of the fact that a compromise has been reached and this bill effectively has been gutted and will be a very temporary piece of legislation, I do not intend to debate each of those clauses individually, nor do I intend to divide the House on each of those clauses. However, it is worth noting that, as I consider clause 5, there are consequential clauses such as 6 and 15 that in any normal circumstance could have been considered in some detail as well.

But all of those clauses go to the heart of this legislation. They go to the heart of the problem. They go to the heart of the issue which has been the instigation of this legislation--not just this legislation but the legislation that the government brought into this House in 2008--because they go to the issue of defining the unimproved value of a piece of land. That concept of establishing the unimproved value, as I indicated in the second reading debate, is at the heart of the land taxation system that uses that valuation for a whole range of taxes.

The government, as I indicated, set out on a course in 2002 which has brought us to this place tonight considering this bill. In 2002 it set out on a course to ensure that the unimproved value of land in Queensland was made as high as possible. It did that through a number of mechanisms, but the one that has been the instigator for this particular piece of legislation has been a change in the way that intangible improvements have been dealt with in the calculation of unimproved land, and it is there in the bill. You cannot deny that that has been the case and that the bill sets out to do that. If one looks at the bill that was introduced here originally, in proposed section 3 it sought to insert a new clause 5 that states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To remove any doubt, it is declared that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) the benefit of a lease, agreement for lease or any other instrument of any type relating to land, or improvements on land that enhances the value of the land, as unimproved or improved must be included in its unimproved value ...
XML.Hansard-Body: As the member for Clayfield quite rightly pointed out in his contribution to the second reading debate, this bill set out to make unimproved value mean improved value. It is quite clear from that section that the case being made by the member for Clayfield was certainly a valid one. That is what the bill set out to do. It set out to completely change the definition and the concept of unimproved land and make it improved land that was subject to land tax--the improved value was subject to land tax. And so that particular section goes on that sought to insert new clause 5 that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (A) the added value of improvements on the land including any allowance to be made under this section or section 5; and
(B) the added value of improvements involved in any comparable sale of improved land;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (ii) no amount can be deducted for goodwill whether in analysing the improvements on the land, or any comparable sale of improved land, or otherwise;

(iii) no deduction for any profit and risk allowance or development premium can be made for the realisation of the use of the land, or for continuing the use of the land, for any purpose for which it was being used on the date of valuation ...
XML.Hansard-Body: That reinforces the point that I made in my contribution to the second reading debate. The government set out to ensure that all of those intangible improvements were part of the unimproved value of the land, and that made it an absolute mockery of the definition of ‘unimproved value’. So it was necessary to put into the legislation that was introduced into this House that ridiculous clause that said that unimproved value had a special meaning that was unrelated to the ordinary dictionary definition of the words.

We will not support the continued inclusion of these particular clauses in the bill, because we think it sets a very dangerous precedent to allow such a sloppy piece of legislation, to allow such a horrendous definition to be included. We will not support these particular clauses, because we do not believe that the definition of unimproved land should be so corrupted and so changed as this series of clauses change it. I will not--
Mr Nicholls: Nor does the Queensland Law Society.

Mr SEENEY: Exactly. That point that the member for Clayfield made again was made over and over during the second reading debate. The Queensland Law Society does not support that change to the definition. None of the major stakeholders supports it. It is at the heart of the criticism that has been levelled at this legislation ever since it was introduced into this parliament. There is no need for this clause to be included in the compromise deal that has been reached. The bill will stand and serve its purpose in its short life, between now and when the new legislation is introduced in 2011, without this considerable change to the definition of unimproved land.

One thing I would note is the absurdity of the government’s continued defence that somehow or other the bill before the House does not set out to change the definition of unimproved land. We have heard it over and over again--from mindless backbenchers who stand up and read speeches that are written somewhere in the department, who understand nothing about what they are reading and who, even though there are extensive clauses in the bill that make it clear that a fundamental change is being made to the underlying principle of unimproved value upon which all land based taxation is based, stand up and parrot the line that somehow or other nothing is being changed.

Indeed, the government spent $25,000 of taxpayers’ money to run the ridiculous argument in the Courier-Mail that nothing had changed. Of course it has changed and it is self-evident to anyone who reads this legislation that a profound change has been made to the fundamental basis of land taxation in Queensland if this bill progresses in the form that it is, because the whole concept of unimproved value and what it means is changed and changed immeasurably. That is why we will oppose these clauses.

Mr ROBERTSON: In appreciation of the argument that has been put by the shadow minister, I think it is important that I respond and put on record the position that has been adopted by this government which is, in our view, a position that has been adopted for many years in this regard. The question is often raised: does unimproved value have a special meaning? That is at the heart of a lot of the argument that has been put by the opposition. The answer to that is absolutely. The meaning is not the dictionary meaning; it is the meaning as defined in the act. That is, it is the capital sum that the land might be expected to realise if offered for sale assuming that the improvements--that is, the physical improvements--did not exist. The capital sum that might be realised is based on the land as developed for its purpose--that is, for residential, rural or industrial purposes in consideration of its location, zoning et cetera.

Unfortunately, some people--and I think this is the heart of the opposition’s argument--interpret it to mean that land has not been developed for a purpose at all. For that reason, the bill makes it very clear that the meaning of unimproved value is as defined in the act and thus it has always been. That is why you have different categories for valuing residential land, commercial land and industrial land--because it is valued according to its purpose. That is all that is being sought to, if you like, buttress in terms of the definition in the legislation. To that extent, that is why we argue--and have consistently argued--that nothing has changed in this regard.

Mr SEENEY:
I will not labour the point because I think the difference between the government’s position and our position has been well illustrated. The minister cannot avoid the fact that this was an argument that was instigated by the government in adopting this position in 2002, and every time the government’s argument has been tested it has been found to be flawed. The government has lost every case it has taken to court. The government sought to use this parliament as the final court of appeal in 2008 and it seeks to do so again now. The government seeks to change the law to suit its interpretation. The government seeks to change the law to correct a situation in which it has been found by the courts of this land to be acting illegally. That is what is happening here tonight and that is why we will oppose the clause.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr ROBERTSON: I move the following amendment--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 9 Clause 7 (Amendment of s 5 (Meaning of value of improvements))

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘ ‘(3) In assessing the value of improvements the price payable for the construction of the physical’.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr SEENEY
(11.41 pm): In considering the amendment that the minister has moved to clause 7, I think members can see the reason why rural landholders were very concerned about the way that the original clause 7 was written. I was interested to hear some of the comments that were made by government members, in particular the member for Mount Isa, that somehow or other rural landholders had nothing to be concerned about in this legislation.

The way clause 7 was originally written certainly had every rural landholder in Queensland concerned, and so they should have been. There was a great deal of concern about how clause 7, proposed subsection (3), would impact on the unimproved value of properties all over Queensland and rural landholders’ properties in particular. Proposed subsection (3) dealt with the method of assessing the value of improvements. As I indicated a number of times in this debate, at the heart of the contention is how unimproved value is determined. In simple terms, unimproved value is determined by taking the market value of the property and subtracting the value of improvements.
This particular clause, clause 7, proposed subsection (3), limits the way in which the value of those improvements may be assessed. The bill as it was originally introduced into this House stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In assessing the value of improvements--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) the amount assessed can not be more than the total of the following--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (i) the depreciated value of the improvements, if any, recorded in books of account of the owner of the land current on the date of valuation;
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a frightening clause to every property owner because it means that without any shadow of a doubt the value of improvements that can be deducted from the market value to reach the unimproved value is limited to the depreciated value recorded in the books of account of the owner. Especially on rural properties, some of those improvements are depreciated for taxation purposes to a level that is understandably very low. To suggest that somehow or other that depreciation of those assets for taxation purposes could affect the unimproved value of the property sent a shiver of fear through landholding communities. The government has recognised that. In fact, the departmental officers recognised that when I raised it at the briefing. The amendment that the minister has just moved to clause 7 changes the proposed subsection (3) to read--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In assessing the value of improvements the price payable for the construction of the physical.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a lot closer to the situation that has long existed. In assessing the value of the improvements it was the price payable for the value of those physical improvements that was used in the calculation of the unimproved value. Let us put an end to this nonsense that somehow or other there was an unnecessary fear campaign which duped rural landholders. Rural landholders, like every other landholder in Queensland, had much to fear from clause 7, proposed subsection (3), because it severely limited the value that could be attributed to physical improvements and the value that could therefore be deducted from the market price to achieve the unimproved capital value. I am pleased that the minister has sought to amend it and I support the amendment, but let us have an end to the misinformation the like of which was peddled by the member for Mount Isa and recognise that the legislation that was originally introduced into this House was fatally flawed and the reaction from Queensland property owners was totally justified.
Amendment agreed to.

Mr SEENEY: Clause 26 is one of a number of clauses that deals with changing the processes relating to the objections and the appeals that are available to landholders. This issue, too, was dealt with in some detail in the second reading debate and I do not intend to repeat the arguments. I do, however, want to call members’ attention to the report of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee which expressed a deal of concern. If members read the report and understand the language that is used there I think it is obvious that the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee is expressing a deal of concern about the changes that are being implemented by this bill and the extent to which they restrict the concept of fairness and reasonableness and the opportunities that they deny landholders in regard to objections and appeals.

I fail to understand why those changes are necessary. I do not believe there is any reason for them to stand part of this bill. I think the government’s intention and the compromise that has been worked out with the industry stakeholders can be delivered and the purpose served without limiting the opportunities for objection and appeal in the way that these particular clauses--26 in this instance but also consequently 27, 32, 37 and 54. All are part of that limitation on the objection and appeal rights of property owners.

Because of that philosophy that I outlined in my second reading contribution which was reinforced by a number of members on this side of the House we will not support this particular clause in the bill. I will not divide the House on the other four clauses that follow, but I certainly believe that we need to support the comments that have been made by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee. There is no reason for this to be part of the bill. The comments made by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee reinforced the concern that I expressed and that other members on this side of the House have expressed. We will oppose this clause.

Mr SEENEY (12.00 am): At the conclusion of this debate I want to make a couple of comments about the sunset clause that is now inserted as part of clause 52. I was relieved to see a sunset clause in the list of the minister’s amendments because it does give a point of reinforcement to the promise that was given this morning by the Premier that the government would introduce legislation into the House by September--I think the assurance was--to ensure that we do have the complete revamp of the valuation system for which I have been calling for quite some years. I acknowledge the minister’s cleverness with his little Google search before. It was a tricky little stunt. I acknowledge it is clever, but it does not take away from the fact that I have long advocated that the basis of land taxation in Queensland needs a complete review.

I have said to the minister, both in this House and in other more informal forums, that the basis for land taxation in Queensland is long overdue for a major modernisation. When we look at the models that are available in other states in Australia especially, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that site values are the way to go. I welcome the commitment that was given in the parliament to move in that direction. I would be concerned about accepting that commitment at face value, except for the fact that the sunset clause in the legislation I believe will force the government’s hand. It will ensure that the legislation that will be passed in a few minutes time using the government’s numbers will have a very short lifespan. It will be enacted for one valuation cycle only. By the time the next valuation cycle comes around we will have a more modernised valuation system and hopefully it will be fairer for property owners in Queensland.

I look forward to seeing the government’s proposals for that. I will not enter into the elements of that debate now, as tempted as I might be. I look forward to seeing the government’s legislation and to judging just how genuine are the commitments that have been given as part of the compromise negotiations in dealing with this particular bill--just how genuine the commitments that have been given by the government actually turn out to be. I welcome the sunset provision that is inserted into clause 52 by the amendment that the minister moved. I look forward to another debate on land valuation and land taxation before this calendar year of parliament is completed.
Mr Robertson: So do we. Come September, I will buy you a drink. It is my shout.
